site_title: Apple lawyer, FBI director to face off before Congress
summary: Apple's general counsel Bruce Sewell and FBI director James Comey are set to testify before Congress on Tuesday about a court order to force Apple to unlock an iPhone belonging to one of the San Bernardino shooters. Apple maintains that creating a tool to unlock the phone would weaken security, while the FBI argues it could help solve the case and set a legal precedent. Manhattan district attorney Cyrus Vance will also testify in support of the FBI, arguing that default device encryption harms criminal prosecutions.

site_title: UN Security Council to vote on Tuesday on N Korea sanctions: diplomats
summary: The UN Security Council is set to vote on Tuesday on a US-drafted resolution imposing new sanctions on North Korea following its nuclear test and rocket launch. The 15-member council will meet to decide on the package of measures that the US claims will impose the toughest sanctions yet on North Korea.

site_title: Rare Thai labour win as tuna factory pays out US$1.3m
summary: A Thai tuna processing factory, Golden Prize Tuna Canning, has agreed to pay US$1.3 million in compensation to hundreds of migrant workers from Myanmar who were subjected to exploitative working conditions. The payment follows a 1,000-strong worker strike and negotiations with government officials and migrant worker leaders. The agreement is seen as a rare victory for migrant workers in Thailand's seafood industry, which has faced widespread criticism for rights abuses and trafficked labor.

site_title: South Korea Feb exports down for 14th month on depressed global demand
summary: South Korea reported its 14th consecutive month of declining exports in February, with shipments falling 12.2% to $36.42 billion, and imports plummeting 14.6% to $29.02 billion. The trade surplus narrowed to $7.39 billion. Despite a slight easing of the decline, the figures suggest depressed global demand continues to affect the domestic economy. The Bank of Korea is under pressure to cut interest rates further to stimulate the economy.

images.alt_text: South Korean exports in February fell for a 14th straight month, and although the decline was not as bad as in the previous month the overall downturn in overseas sales suggested depressed global demand continues to hobble the domestic economy.

site_title: Emerging nations to increase borrowing by 4% this year: S&P
summary: Developing nations plan to increase borrowing by 4% to $1.2 trillion in 2016, with total debt reaching $6.8 trillion. The 20 economies, led by China, Brazil, and India, aim to refinance maturing debt and cover a $562 billion net loan requirement. Rising debt burdens weigh on growth, with weak earnings and tightening lending conditions posing challenges for companies to repay debt. Central banks have raised borrowing costs to combat inflation, while capital outflows from China limit monetary policy flexibility.

site_title: Q & M Dental's FY2015 profit rises 33%
summary: Q & M Dental Group reported a 33% increase in net profit to S$11.4 million for FY2015, driven by revenue growth from new dental outlets in Singapore and increased contributions from dental equipment and supplies distribution. Revenue rose 16% to S$97.8 million. The group now operates 65 dental outlets, three medical outlets, and one aesthetic centre.

site_title: Gold extends advance as China growth concern fuels haven demand
summary: Gold prices rose 0.7% to $1,247.78 an ounce after China's manufacturing contracted for a record seventh month, boosting demand for a store of value. The metal climbed 11% in February, its biggest monthly gain in four years, and surged 18% this year amid economic growth concerns in China. Exchange-traded product holdings rose 12% last month, the most in seven years, and analysts predict gold may be this year's best-performing asset.

site_title: Singtel app down after software glitch shows details of other customers
summary: Singtel's mobile app experienced a software glitch on Monday night, allowing customers to view the personal information of other users. The issue was resolved on Tuesday morning, but not before raising concerns about account security and privacy. Customers were able to log in to another user's account and view details such as name and address. The incident has sparked discussions on social media, with some customers expressing concern over their own account security.

site_title: Indonesia's annual inflation rate rises to 4.42% in February
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation rate rose to 4.42% in February, surpassing the 4.35% predicted by a Reuters poll. This is slightly higher than the 4.14% recorded in January. Core inflation, which strips out volatile food prices, remained unchanged at 3.59%. Bank Indonesia, aiming for a 3-5% inflation target, has cut its benchmark reference rate twice this year. The central bank's next policy meeting is scheduled for March 16-17, following the US Federal Reserve's meeting.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's annual inflation rate increased slightly more than expected in February, the statistics bureau said on Tuesday.

site_title: China aims to lay off 5-6m state workers: sources
summary: China plans to lay off 5-6 million state workers from "zombie enterprises" over two to three years to curb industrial overcapacity and pollution. This would be the country's largest retrenchment program in nearly two decades, following a 1998-2003 program that resulted in 28 million redundancies. The move aims to address supply glut issues in industries such as coal and steel, with a target of 1.8 million layoffs in these sectors, according to the Ministry of Human Resources and Social Security.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, Sakae, EMS Energy, China Fibretech
summary: Olam International reported a net loss of S$221.3 million for the fourth quarter and full 2015 financial year, primarily due to one-off charges, including a writedown on its PureCircle investment. Despite the loss, the company remains optimistic about its recession-proof food business and diversified structure, which it believes will help it weather economic downturns.

site_title: ANZ poaches Google executive in new digital banking push
summary: ANZ Banking Group has appointed Maile Carnegie, Google's Australia MD, as digital banking chief, starting in July. The move is part of the bank's push into technology amid slowing revenues and increased competition. Carnegie will lead the bank's digital push, including strategic relationships with the fintech sector. Australian banks are investing heavily in fintech operations, with over a quarter of current banking industry revenue at risk from digital disruptors.

images.alt_text: ANZ Banking Group has poached Google's Australia MD Maile Carnegie to the newly created position of digital banking chief, as the country's No 4 lender pushes into technology amid slowing revenues and stifling competition.

site_title: Westjet talking with Boeing, Airbus on replacement for 767s
summary: WestJet Airlines Ltd has initiated talks with Boeing Co and Airbus Group to replace its fleet of Boeing 767-300 planes, expected to be delivered by the end of this decade. The airline currently operates three 767s and plans to expand its Europe-focused fleet. WestJet CEO Gregg Saretsky declined to comment on specific plans, but mentioned the 767's 11-hour range would allow for direct flights to cities in Asia, Eastern Europe, and South America. The airline's shares rose 5% on the Toronto Stock Exchange following the announcement.

site_title: Myanmar brings forward date for presidential nominations to March 10
summary: Myanmar has announced March 10 as the new date for presidential nominations, advancing the original date by a week. The country's upper house of parliament speaker, Mahn Win Khaing Than, made the announcement. The move follows three meetings between military chief Min Aung Hlaing and democracy leader Aung San Suu Kyi, who will dominate the incoming government after winning the November election. The NLD has no number two after Suu Kyi, sparking speculation about who might fill the top post. The presidential vote is expected to take place on the same day as nominations are announced.

images.alt_text: Myanmar democracy leader Aung San Suu Kyi. Myanmar will announce presidential nominations on March 10, the speaker of its upper house of parliament said on Tuesday, advancing the original date by a week, as a lengthy political transition in the Southeast Asian nation enters its last stages.

site_title: Barclays reveals restructuring plan, to exit Africa as profits fall
summary: Barclays reported a 2% fall in full-year adjusted pre-tax profit to £5.4 billion, citing weaker-than-expected results. The bank unveiled plans to simplify its UK & international operations, primarily by exiting its historic African business. Barclays Africa Group, created by combining Absa Group and Barclays' African operations, will be sold down to focus on stronger divisions, Barclays UK and Barclays Corporate and International. This restructuring aims to boost returns and cut costs.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares end higher, banks, resources lead
summary: Australian shares rose 0.9% on Tuesday, led by gains in banks and resources stocks following disappointing Chinese manufacturing data. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed 41.37 points to 4,922.3. New Zealand's benchmark index also inched higher, closing up 0.8%. The "Big Four" banks, including ANZ and Westpac, soared with 3% and 2.5% gains respectively.

site_title: Fitch rates Mapletree Industrial Trust's new notes 'BBB+'
summary: Fitch Ratings has assigned Mapletree Industrial Trust's new S$60 million 3.79% fixed-rate unsecured and unsubordinated notes a rating of "BBB+" and affirmed its "BBB+" long-term ratings on outstanding notes. The trust plans to use the new issue to refinance part of its debt due in 2017, which is expected to increase funding costs. Despite a granular portfolio with low industry concentration, Fitch notes that the trust has sufficient assets, strong financing flexibility, and positive rental rollover rates, but its rating is constrained by geographic concentration and limited operating scale.

site_title: EU, Canada make breakthrough on trade deal
summary: The European Union and Canada have made a breakthrough in completing their free trade deal, with hopes it will be in effect by 2017. The agreement, finalized in 2014, was delayed due to objections over an investment protection system that favored big business. The EU and Canada have modified the system to give more power to governments to regulate and created a full-fledged court to handle complaints. This deal is seen as a significant victory for the EU, which is also negotiating a similar agreement with the US.

site_title: Asia markets weighed by weak China data, oil price drop
summary: Asian stock markets declined on Tuesday, weighed down by weak Chinese manufacturing data and a drop in oil prices. China's central bank cut the reserve requirement ratio, aiming to boost growth, but manufacturing activity shrank at its fastest rate in four years. Oil prices fell 7 cents to $33.68 a barrel, and the dollar slipped to 112.41 yen. Despite the stimulus move, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index fell 0.69%, while Shanghai and Hong Kong edged up.

site_title: Australia deputy PM urges local investment in agriculture to meet strong Asia demand
summary: Australia's Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce urged the country's A$1.8 trillion pension fund industry to boost investment in agriculture, citing strong demand from Asia. Despite foreign interest, local pension funds have only 0.3% of their portfolio in the sector. Joyce called for a culture of investment in agriculture, emphasizing the need for investment in land, technology, and people to improve productivity. The Australian government is also tightening rules on foreign ownership of rural land amid public backlash over food security concerns.

site_title: Albedo narrows Q4 loss, sees healthcare revenue contribution from H2
summary: Albedo, a steel trader listed on the Catalist, narrowed its net loss for the fourth quarter to S$610,000, down from S$8.6 million a year ago. Revenue fell 42% to S$859,000, with S$253,000 coming from its new medical aesthetics business. The company expects weaker steel demand due to economic conditions and increased competition. Albedo is actively seeking new businesses and plans to expand its medical aesthetics presence in China, with revenue contributions expected in the second half of 2016.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Australia shares face cautious opening, NZ climbs
summary: Australian shares are expected to open lower on Tuesday, but mining stocks may limit losses due to China's growth boost and US rate hike expectations. New Zealand shares rose 0.4% in early trade, led by A2 Milk. In contrast, European stocks fell due to bank and healthcare sector declines, with US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Exxon said planning US$12b bond sale to build war chest
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp plans to raise $12 billion in its largest bond offering, seeking funds for future acquisitions and business opportunities amid a volatile energy market. The oil giant is offering debt in eight parts at above-average yields, with the longest portion being a 30-year bond yielding up to 150 basis points more than comparable government debt. Despite Moody's Investors Service warning of a negative outlook and Standard & Poor's placing the company on credit watch, Exxon is still considered a strong corporate credit, and the deal may be a sign of building a capital stockpile to take advantage of the market downturn.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei edges up as sentiment calmed by bounce in China stocks
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei share average rose 0.4% to 16,085.51 on Tuesday, reversing earlier losses, as risk appetite improved following China's Shanghai Composite Index rebound. The rebound came after Beijing's easing steps. However, sentiment remained fragile due to the yen's relative strength and weak manufacturing activity in China, which highlighted global concerns over the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Oscars draws eight-year low US TV audience
summary: The 2016 Oscars drew a record-low 34.3 million US TV audience, a 6% decline from last year's 36.6 million viewers. Despite controversy over the lack of ethnic minority nominees, the show received generally favorable reviews, with host Chris Rock's jokes praised as a unifying theme. Civil rights leader Al Sharpton's call to "tune out" appeared to be effective, contributing to the decline. The show still performed well with younger audiences, but the viewership marks the lowest in eight years.

site_title: Brooklyn judge denies government's request to unlock iPhone in drug case
summary: A federal judge in Brooklyn denied the US government's motion to compel Apple Inc to unlock an iPhone used in a drug case. The government sought access to the phone in October, but the judge's decision follows a similar ruling in California that ordered Apple to give the government access to an iPhone used in the San Bernardino attacks. The case is ongoing.

site_title: UK economic growth still in the doldrums in February: CBI
summary: The UK's private sector growth slowed in February, with a monthly growth indicator of +8, its slowest rate in nearly three years. The Confederation of British Industry (CBI) attributed this to a slowdown in the global economy and uncertainty over the UK's EU membership referendum. Despite this, businesses' investment intentions remained optimistic, with output expectations for the next three months rising to +19 in February. The UK economy's growth remains in the doldrums, adding to signs of a slowing economy.

site_title: Tigerair Australia makes priority landing in Australia
summary: A Tigerair Australia plane carrying 60 people made an emergency landing in Melbourne after an unusual odour was detected in the cabin. The plane landed safely, and four passengers were assessed by paramedics as a precaution. The airline reported that safety is its top priority and that robust procedures were in place to address the issue. The plane will be assessed by engineers. The incident occurred during a flight from Brisbane to Melbourne.

site_title: Japan prepares ground for more spending to bolster consumption
summary: Japan is preparing for potential additional government spending to bolster consumption, amid concerns about a weakening economy. Finance Minister Taro Aso hinted at a stimulus package for the 2016/17 fiscal year, citing rising tax revenue and falling bond yields. Economists expect the government to offset the impact of a planned sales tax hike by allocating at least 5-10 trillion yen in fiscal stimulus. This move could be an early example for the Group of 20 nations, which has called for more fiscal spending to support the global economy.

site_title: Pemex nearly doubles losses in 2015, production dips further
summary: Pemex, Mexico's state-run energy firm, reported a nearly doubling of losses in 2015, reaching US$30.3 billion, due to budget cuts and a 6.7% decline in crude production to 2.27 million barrels per day. The company cited a 521.6 billion pesos loss compared to 265.5 billion pesos in the previous year. Pemex's financial struggles continue amid declining production and increasing competition in the energy market.

images.alt_text: Mexico's embattled state-run energy firm Pemex posted on Monday US$30.3 billion in losses in 2015, nearly double from the previous year, and a further drop in crude production.

site_title: Japan PM Abe to form panel to debate extra stimulus budget: sources
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe plans to form an advisory panel to debate the need for an extra stimulus budget for the coming fiscal year to boost the flagging economy. The move aims to encourage other countries to adopt more fiscal spending, shifting away from austerity. Abe hopes to announce the plan on Tuesday, after the budget clears parliament, and convene the panel in mid-March to analyze the world economy. This could set an example for the Group of 20 nations, which called for more fiscal spending to support the ailing global economy.

images.alt_text: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will pull together a new advisory panel to debate the need for a supplementary budget for the coming fiscal year from April to stimulate the flagging economy, sources told Reuters on Tuesday.

site_title: Europe: Shares end higher as China move offsets G20 disappointment
summary: European shares ended higher, up 0.7% at 1,313.74 points, despite a third straight month of losses due to concerns over global growth. China's decision to resume easing its monetary policy helped offset disappointment over the G20 meeting's failure to agree on growth measures. Inflation unexpectedly turned negative in the euro zone, supporting expectations of further ECB stimulus measures. Miner and auto sector gains were led by metal price increases after China's rate cut, while Morrisons surged 5.9% after a distribution deal with Amazon.

site_title: China stimulus buoys Australian stocks as yen hits japan futures
summary: China's announcement of a cut in reserve-requirement ratios boosted economic stimulus, driving Australian stocks up 0.8% and New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 Index up 0.3%. Chinese index futures rose, while Japanese index futures declined 0.3% due to a resurgence in the yen. The move also lifted the yuan offshore and gold prices, while US crude remained near its highest level in seven weeks. The news followed a mixed February for financial markets, with global stocks capping a fourth consecutive monthly decline.

site_title: War of Kylies: Minogue hits back at Jenner trademark bid
summary: Kylie Minogue objects to Kylie Jenner's trademark bid for the name "KYLIE". Jenner, a member of the Kardashian clan, sought to register the name in capital letters for advertising purposes. Minogue, an Australian pop star, lodged objections, suggesting there's room for more than one famous Kylie in the world. The US Patent and Trademark Office will review Jenner's application.

site_title: Japan Q4 capital expenditure, profits signal weak business spending may hit growth
summary: Japan's capital expenditure rose at a slower pace in Q4, while corporate profits fell for the first time in four years, signaling weak business spending that may weigh on economic growth. The revised GDP may show Japan's economy contracted more than initially reported, adding to concerns about domestic demand. Japan's employment pattern remained robust, with seasonally adjusted unemployment falling to 3.2% and the jobs to applicants ratio reaching a 24-year high.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks close up on late afternoon rally
summary: China's stocks rose 1.9% and 1.7% on the CSI300 and Shanghai Composite Index, respectively, on Tuesday, driven by a late afternoon rally after the central bank cut reserve requirements for banks. Financials and industrials led the gains, with property shares outperforming. However, manufacturing and service sector surveys disappointed, highlighting the challenges faced by the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: South Korea Feb house prices up, but pace slows: lender
summary: South Korea's house prices rose 0.07% in February, marking the 30th consecutive month of gains, according to data from Kookmin Bank. This represents a 4.20% year-over-year increase. The pace of increase slowed from January's 0.08% month-over-month rise.

site_title: Airbus, Boeing jostle for China friendship and aircraft orders
summary: Airbus and Boeing are competing to secure aircraft orders in China, a key market for the two companies. China has identified aerospace as a priority industry and is encouraging foreign planemakers to invest in the country. Airbus is opening a finishing center for its A330 jets in Tianjin, while Boeing is seeking a location for a plane-completion facility. The companies are also collaborating with Chinese partners, including state-owned Aviation Industry Corp of China, to supply aircraft parts. Chinese airlines have ordered billions of dollars' worth of planes from Airbus and Boeing every year, and doing assembly locally is seen as a way to build goodwill and gain an advantage over competitors.

site_title: ICE said to explore rival bid for LSE to thwart Deutsche Boerse
summary: Intercontinental Exchange Inc (ICE) is exploring a counter bid for London Stock Exchange Group Plc (LSE) to thwart a planned merger with Deutsche Boerse AG, which would create the dominant European exchange operator. ICE, based in Atlanta and owner of the New York Stock Exchange, is working with Morgan Stanley to prepare a possible higher offer for LSE. The move aims to scuttle the merger and force Deutsche Boerse to increase its bid. No final decision has been made, and the March 22 UK takeover deadline for Deutsche Boerse's formal offer remains.

site_title: EMS Energy posts S$10.2m loss for FY2015
summary: EMS Energy reported a net loss of S$10.2 million for FY2015, reversing a net profit of S$15.4 million from the previous year. Revenue fell 36.9% to S$68.9 million, mainly due to reduced revenue from engineering and procurement segments. The company attributed the decline to low crude oil prices and a labor shortage in the industry. EMS Energy plans to streamline operations, cut costs, and secure recurring income through after-market sales and chartering contracts.

site_title: US mortgage-bond proposal to melt eight-year freeze advances
summary: The US Treasury Department's proposal for a "deal agent" to oversee mortgage securities without government backing may thaw the eight-year freeze in the market, limiting options for borrowers. Key principles call for an independent firm to ensure transparency in transactions, addressing concerns of conflicts of interest and inadequate investor protections. The move aims to strengthen the housing recovery, with some bond funds and influential mortgage companies lending their support to the proposal.

site_title: Dolby now about visual, not just sound, know-how
summary: Dolby Laboratories is expanding its capabilities beyond sound enhancement, focusing on visual technology with its Dolby Vision system. Since its launch in 2014, the technology has become an industry standard for image quality in movies, adopted by major Hollywood studios and television makers. Dolby Vision produces wider ranges of color and contrast, making images appear sharper, more vibrant, and 3D-like. The company's use of lasers in projectors results in intense, fluorescent colors, and its Atmos speaker systems create a real-life effect by assigning sounds to precise locations in a room.

images.alt_text: Major Hollywood studios have adopted Dolby Vision, such as The Revenant which won Best Picture at the 88th Academy Awards on Monday. The new Dolby technology offers a wider range of colour and contrast.

site_title: Chinese pitch big M&A break-up fees, small stakes to allay US regulatory fears
summary: Chinese companies are offering record-breaking break-up fees and minority stakes in US mergers and acquisitions to alleviate US regulatory concerns, amid a push for record M&As abroad to offset slowing economic growth. China has agreed to pay up to 8% of deal value in termination fees, a significant increase from the usual 1-1.5%. This move aims to secure deals and mitigate US scrutiny, with a focus on sectors less sensitive to national security concerns.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks open lower after central bank cuts reserve ratio
summary: China stocks opened lower on March 1, 2016, despite the People's Bank of China's decision to cut the reserve ratio ratio (RRR) by 50 basis points, injecting an estimated $100 billion into the economy. The CSI300 index fell 0.5% to 2,864.11 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.7% to 2,668.80 points. The Hang Seng index in Hong Kong rose 0.5% to 19,201.43 points.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.03% lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index down 0.84 points to 2,665.67, following a choppy session on Wall Street. US stocks fell, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 123.47 points (0.74%) to 16,516.50. Asian markets also declined, with Tokyo shares opening flat. Despite this, the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes reached fresh records, and Singapore's top counters traded with mixed results.

site_title: Opec watching Iran, Russia, unlikely to cut output in June
summary: Opec is unlikely to cut oil output in June, despite extremely low prices, as it will be too early to assess Iran's production levels. Saudi Arabia and Qatar want to test Russia's commitment to freezing output before considering further steps. Iran's output is rising after sanctions were lifted, and its February exports were lower than expected, fueling market skepticism. Analysts expect Iran's exports to rise to around 3.5 million barrels per day, but the picture will not be clear by June. A production freeze deal may be revisited by the end of the year if Iran's output matches its claims.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up tracking overseas markets, main index at 3-month high
summary: Taiwan's main stock index, the TAIEX, reached a 3-month high of 8,461.06 points, driven by overseas market gains. The index rose 0.6% on Tuesday, with the electronics subindex up 0.8% and the financials subindex down 0.1%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$0.287 to T$33.205 per US dollar. Shares in Hon Hai (Foxconn) were down 0.8% amid a delay in its takeover of Sharp.

site_title: Oil trades near US$34 as Chinese manufacturing slowdown deepens
summary: Oil prices traded near US$34 a barrel as Chinese manufacturing data showed a further decline, with the manufacturing purchasing managers index falling to 49 in February. US supplies are expected to have risen by 2.75 million barrels last week, and inventories remain high. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' output slid to 33.06 million barrels in February, with Saudi Arabian production remaining unchanged. Oil prices have slipped 8% this year, and analysts predict a soft seasonal demand and high inventories will keep prices steady.

site_title: Sydney home prices fall 4.6% to 10-month low in February
summary: Sydney's median home price dropped 4.6% to A$730,000 in February, reaching a 10-month low. The decline follows record values and a regulatory clampdown that tightened lending standards, reducing demand. This is the third consecutive month of decline, with outstanding mortgages growing at 7.3% in January, a decline from the previous month. The drop is double that of the national average and compares to a 2.7% decline in Melbourne.

site_title: Yen picks up amid gloomy market sentiment despite China stimulus
summary: The yen rose against the dollar on Tuesday despite gloomy market sentiment, following China's central bank announcement of a 0.50 percentage point reduction in the reserve requirement ratio. The move was seen as a stimulus to boost growth, but had little initial impact. The dollar slipped to 112.28 yen from 112.72 yen, while the euro fell to 122.19 yen. Emerging currencies also edged up against the dollar, while the euro weakened due to deflation in the eurozone.

site_title: Australia to shake-up media ownership laws, mergers tipped
summary: The Australian government plans to overhaul media ownership laws, allowing for mergers between metropolitan and regional broadcasters, as well as newspaper owners. The changes aim to help Australian media companies compete with foreign entrants, including Netflix and Facebook. Critics fear the move could lead to a loss of local voices and concentration of media power. Mergers are expected, including potential deals between Southern Cross Media Group, Nine Network, News Corp Australia, and Fairfax Media. The changes are seen as outdated and not equipped to handle digital media platforms.

site_title: 'Paywalls' become the norm at US newspapers: survey
summary: US newspapers have largely adopted digital subscriptions, with 77 of 98 newspapers with circulation above 50,000 implementing online subscription models. This marks a significant shift from 2010, when only six newspapers used digital subscriptions. The "paywall" models vary, with 62 using metered systems and 12 using freemium models, while three use hard paywalls. The potential revenue from digital subscriptions is uncertain, with some experts suggesting long-term growth rates may be unclear. The average weekly digital-only subscription charge is US$3.11, and digital subscriptions with a print newspaper add-on cost US$3.29.

site_title: VW chief vows to 'learn from past mistakes'
summary: Volkswagen CEO Matthias Mueller vowed to "learn from past mistakes" as the company seeks to recover from the emissions scandal. Mueller stated that 2016 would be the year to address diesel engine issues and realign the group for the future. The company's sales fell 5% in 2015, and overall group sales declined 2% in 2015, with 9.93 million vehicles sold. VW faces legal complaints and potentially huge damages in the US over pollution cheat devices on diesel-engine cars. Mueller expressed confidence in the company's ability to emerge stronger from the scandal.

site_title: Support for Merkel rises, but doubts over refugee policy remain
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel's popularity has risen to 54% after hitting a 4.5-year low, according to a poll. However, nearly 60% of voters remain unsatisfied with the government's refugee policy. Merkel is under pressure to reduce the refugee influx, which reached 1.1 million last year. She is pinning her hopes on European talks with Turkey and a migration summit, but a majority of voters doubt the effectiveness of these efforts. Merkel has defended her open-door policy, rejecting the idea of closing borders.

site_title: Airbus sees no serious impact on China plane market from slowing economy
summary: Airbus expects China's aviation market to remain relatively unaffected by the country's economic slowdown, with demand for 5,400 new airplanes over the next 20 years. Despite economic concerns, the number of Chinese leisure travelers going overseas continues to rise, and foreign travel is expected to grow another 10% this year. State-owned carriers and leasing firms have placed orders for hundreds of Airbus and Boeing aircraft worth tens of billions of dollars, supporting the company's optimism for the Chinese market. Airbus is considering boosting its bets on China and increasing production rates at its A320 assembly line.

site_title: Macau posts best gambling revenue result in 20 months
summary: Macau reported its best monthly gambling revenue in 20 months, with a 0.1% increase to 19.5 billion patacas ($3.37 billion) in February, surpassing analyst expectations. This marks the 21st consecutive monthly decline, but the smallest in 20 months. The growth is attributed to an increase in tourist numbers during the Lunar New Year holiday. Despite this, Macau's economy remains reliant on the casino industry, which has been impacted by a prolonged anti-corruption campaign and a decline in big-spending VIP gamblers.

site_title: Spectre of joblessness puts focus on Beijing as it sets new five-year plan
summary: China is finalizing its 13th Five-Year Plan, which will focus on addressing job destruction from a slowing economy and reforming bloated state enterprises. The country expects to lay off 1.8 million workers in the coal and steel industries, with Beijing allocating 100 billion yuan to relocate workers. The urban jobless rate remains stable at 4.05%, but many economists believe the real rate is higher. The government aims to reduce industrial overcapacity and high debt levels, but must balance this with the risk of massive layoffs triggering social unrest.

images.alt_text: Job seekers and recruiters attend a job fair in Yiwu, in China's eastern Zhejiang province on Feb 26, 2016. Job destruction from a slowing Chinese economy and reform of bloated state enterprises will put pressure on policymakers to come up with measures to create employment as Beijing finalises its plan for China's development over the next five years.

site_title: China super-regulator plan said to target 'fragmented' oversight
summary: China's government is expected to unveil a plan for a financial super-regulator this year, aiming to merge banking, securities, and insurance regulators into one entity. The proposal would give the People's Bank of China more power over the economy, addressing concerns about market stability and investor confidence. The move comes amid growing pressure from setbacks such as the US$5 trillion stock sell-off and financial scandals, which have led to calls for a more coordinated regulatory framework. The super-regulator would oversee the China Securities Regulatory Commission, CBRC, and China Insurance Regulatory Commission, with the State Council set to oversee its formation.

site_title: US questions Mercedes-Benz on diesel car emissions
summary: US environmental regulators have asked Mercedes-Benz for emissions data after a lawsuit accused the German carmaker of installing emissions-cheating technology on diesel models. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) requested test results for US diesel engines following a civil class-action lawsuit that claimed 14 Mercedes diesel models contained technology that concealed excess emissions of nitrogen oxide. Mercedes considers the suit unfounded and will defend itself by all legal means, citing its commitment to environmental protection.

site_title: Glencore profit collapses 69% as prices for metals and oil slide
summary: Glencore Plc reported a 69% slump in adjusted net income to $1.34 billion, down from $4.29 billion a year earlier, due to tumbling metal and oil prices. The company aims to reduce debt by 40% to $18 billion by scrapping its dividend, cutting costs, and selling assets. Profits from the world's biggest mining companies are evaporating due to gluts and slowing demand from China, the biggest customer.

site_title: China navy launches first self-propelled floating dock
summary: China's navy has launched its first self-propelled floating dock, the Huachuan No 1, enabling rapid repair of damaged warships at sea. The dock can handle cruisers, destroyers, and submarines, and can withstand waves up to 2 meters high. This move is part of China's efforts to modernize its navy and expand its maritime ambitions in the disputed South China Sea and other regions. The launch marks a significant breakthrough in the country's homegrown defense industry, with China's military budget increasing by 10% in 2015 to 886.9 billion yuan.

site_title: China's bold One Belt, One Road project eyes Australia detour
summary: China's sovereign wealth fund, China Investment Corp (CIC), is offering A$9 billion for Australian ports and rail operator Asciano Ltd as part of its One Belt, One Road initiative. The deal aims to secure global supply chains and expand transportation linkages across the region. CIC's bid is part of a larger effort to control logistics chains, with the company already owning stakes in London's Heathrow Airport and the US power company AES. The deal has been recommended by Asciano's board and is seen as a strategic move to boost exports and investment between China and Australia.

site_title: Refugees look to job fair for first step in German integration
summary: Refugees in Germany attended a job fair, seeking integration into their host country. Two Pakistani refugees, Muhammad Tahir and Muhammad Asjed, were recruited as security guards after brief interviews. The job opportunity could be a crucial step towards their integration, with the possibility of starting work in three months. The event was part of efforts to help refugees find employment and build a new life in Germany.

site_title: New Silkroutes to buy 51% stake in Stamford Management
summary: New Silkroutes Group (NSG) announced it will acquire a 51% stake in Stamford Management Pte Ltd, a Singapore-based investment manager overseeing about US$250 million. Stamford Management focuses on real estate, health sciences, and natural resources. NSG's wholly owned New Silkroutes Capital Pte Ltd will hold the controlling stake, and Stamford Management will be renamed New Silkroutes Capital Partners Pte Ltd subject to shareholder approval. This acquisition is part of NSG's efforts to expand its asset management business, following the formation of a joint venture with CG Capital Partners to offer fund management services in Asia.

site_title: S i2i swings into the black in Q4, plans 72.9 Singapore cents a share distribution
summary: S i2i, a telecom and IT service provider, has returned to profitability after a nearly half-year tenure under its founder's return in September 2015. The company reported a net profit of S$3.2 million in Q4 2015, compared to a net loss of S$47.1 million a year ago. S i2i plans to distribute about 72.9 Singapore cents a share to shareholders via a capital reduction exercise, using its cash balances. The company aims to create greater value for shareholders and exit the SGX-administered watch-list.

site_title: US: Stock rally stalls amid profit-taking
summary: US stocks fell Monday, with the Dow Jones dropping 123.47 points (0.74%) to 16,516.50, the S&P 500 falling 15.82 (0.81%) to 1,932.23, and the Nasdaq Composite Index shedding 32.52 (0.71%) to 4,557.95. The decline was attributed to profit-taking after a two-week gain. The US stock market stalled despite reaching record highs earlier in the session, amid ongoing US-EU trade tensions and tariff threats.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.980 points to 1658.420. The trading volume was 58.9 million lots worth RM14.4 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 108 to 88.

site_title: China stocks tumble as G20 meeting disappoints investors
summary: China's Shanghai Composite Index plummeted 4.4% as investors were disappointed by the lack of specific measures to boost growth during the G20 meeting in Shanghai. This decline brings the benchmark index to its lowest level since November 2014. The yuan is headed for its longest losing streak this year. The economic slowdown and concerns of accelerating capital outflows have contributed to the decline.

site_title: Petronas to cut capital, operational expenditure by up to RM20b in 2016
summary: Malaysia's national oil company Petronas plans to cut capital and operational expenditure by up to RM20 billion in 2016 due to a prolonged oil price slump. The company aims to re-phase its Floating LNG2 project and may scale down its US$16 billion Rapid refinery and petrochemical development. Petronas also reviews its business operating model, introducing a new organisation structure in April, and plans to cut capital and operational expenditure by RM50 billion over the next four years.

site_title: Oil surges on China stimulus, Saudi cooperation talk
summary: World oil prices surged 3.0% on Monday, with the US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rising to $33.75 a barrel. China's cut in reserve requirements for banks boosted oil prices, with analysts citing the potential for increased demand. Saudi Arabia also signaled openness to cooperative action to stabilize the market, but reiterated its plan to maintain spare capacity and meet global demand. Despite this, oil prices rose as traders welcomed the Chinese stimulus and Saudi cooperation, lifting Brent North Sea crude to $35.97 a barrel.

site_title: Nissan stock up the most since 2009 on share buyback news
summary: Nissan Motor Co. surged 12% on its largest-ever share buyback, with the company planning to acquire up to 400 billion yen ($5 billion) of stock. The move aims to counter a 24% decline in the company's shares this year and boost earnings. Nissan forecasts a record net income of 535 billion yen, driven by strong demand in the US for models like the Rogue crossover. The repurchase suggests the company doesn't foresee a global recession and is focused on generating significant free cash flow for shareholders.

site_title: BT's All-in-One package: get more at a special price
summary: The Business Times (BT) in Singapore will increase its prices starting March 1, with the All-in-One package now costing S$34.90 a month, up from S$28.65. However, subscribers who upgrade to the All-in-One package will receive a promotional rate of S$29.90 a month, equivalent to the new Print-only subscription price. The changes are part of a recent pricing review by Singapore Press Holdings, the media group behind BT.

site_title: Asia's tuk-tuks providing a wheel boost to African countries
summary: Asia's three-wheeled tuk-tuks have been introduced to Africa, particularly Liberia, as a cheaper and safer alternative to traditional motorcycle taxis. The ban on motorcycle taxis in 2013 led to the introduction of the kekeh, which has generated 5,000 jobs and reduced accidents by 90%. The kekeh is affordable, with a daily rate of around $25, and is seen as a more accessible means of transport for many Monrovians. The tuk-tuks are tightly regulated and offer more protection to passengers, making them a welcome addition to the continent's transport infrastructure.

site_title: Argentina, 'vulture' funds end 15-year debt battle
summary: Argentina has reached a deal with creditors, led by US billionaire Paul E. Singer, to settle a 15-year debt battle for $4.65 billion. The agreement, brokered by mediator Daniel Pollack, marks a significant step towards Argentina escaping financial pariah status. The funds must be paid in cash by April 14, and the deal includes a compromise on the amount owed, with Argentina paying 75% of what creditors sought. The breakthrough could lead to Argentina regaining access to international creditors and attracting foreign investors, but questions remain about the impact on future defaults and Argentina's foreign reserves.

site_title: Apple ready for encryption 'conversation': lawyer
summary: Apple is prepared to engage in a conversation with the US government to address the issue of accessing an encrypted iPhone used by one of the shooters in the San Bernardino attacks. Apple general counsel Bruce Sewell stated that encryption is a "good thing" and a "necessary thing" that should be decided by lawmakers, not through a warrant request. Apple has been increasing encryption in recent years, and the company's chief Tim Cook argued that the FBI's request to create a backdoor into the iPhone is "not possible" and would compromise user security.

images.alt_text: Apple wants a "conversation" to help settle a standoff with US law enforcement over accessing an encrypted iPhone, according to testimony prepared for a congressional hearing.

site_title: Technology could unwind decade-long trend in global trade
summary: A decade-long trend in global trade may be unwinding due to the increasing adoption of automation, according to Goldman Sachs analysts. As robots become a less-expensive input than labor, multinationals are shifting production closer to their customer bases, marking a shift away from the long-standing trade formula that relied on global supply chains. This trend is particularly concerning for emerging-market economies, which have seen export volumes decline despite continued growth among their major trading partners.

site_title: Protecting SMEs against risk
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) contribute significantly to the country's economy, but many remain underinsured against common business risks, including talent-related issues. Research by QBE Singapore found that one in seven SMEs lack business insurance, with 53% viewing insurance as low priority. Despite efforts by the government to address staff acquisition and retention issues, SMEs continue to operate uninsured, with 56% believing minimum coverage is sufficient. Experts urge SMEs to undertake a proper assessment of their businesses and consider customised protection to ensure long-term survival.

site_title: Unit sales help Wheelock to narrow Q4 loss
summary: Wheelock Properties narrowed its fourth-quarter loss to S$927,000, driven by a 302.7% year-over-year increase in revenue to S$108.31 million. The revenue growth was mainly due to unit sales in three projects: The Panorama condominium in Ang Mo Kio, Ardmore Three, and Scotts Square. The company sold 561 units in The Panorama and 277 units in Scotts Square, with current focus on leasing out unsold units. Net asset value dropped to S$2.54 from S$2.62, but the loss per share narrowed to 0.08 Singapore cents from 8.62 cents in the previous year.

site_title: Chris Rock scores and Spotlight takes centre stage at the Oscars
summary: The 88th Academy Awards honored Spotlight, a newspaper drama about the Catholic Church's cover-up of priestly abuse, as Best Picture. The film beat out The Revenant, which won three Oscars, including Best Actor for Leonardo DiCaprio and Best Director for Alejandro G. Iñárritu. Spotlight's win was seen as a surprise, as it was neck-and-neck with The Revenant in the Best Picture category. The ceremony also highlighted the issue of diversity in Hollywood, with host Chris Rock delivering a monologue on the topic, and winners like Alicia Vikander and Mark Rylance acknowledging the importance of representation.

images.alt_text: (From left) Nicole Rocklin, Michael Sugar, Blye Pagon Faust and Steve Golin accepting the Oscar for Best Motion Picture for 'Spotlight' during the live ABC Telecast of the 88th annual Academy Awards ceremony at the Dolby Theatre in Hollywood, California, USA, on Feb 28, 2016.

site_title: Rates of return reviewed regularly
summary: The Life Insurance Association, Singapore (LIA Singapore) reviews rates of return for participating (par) products annually to ensure their relevance. The association's review process considers macroeconomic factors, resulting in projected investment rates of 4.75% and 3.25%. Insurers use the lower rate to reflect realistic investment returns. The decline in interest rates over the past decade has affected bonus payouts, and LIA Singapore is working on enhanced disclosures, including projected yield to maturity or net return for par policies. Policyholders are updated annually on revisions to the long-term investment outlook.

site_title: Building a long-standing, wide-ranging relationship
summary: Singapore and China have commemorated 25 years of diplomatic relations, with a strong foundation laid by former leaders Lee Kuan Yew and Deng Xiaoping. The two countries have collaborated on numerous government-to-government projects, including the Chongqing Connectivity Initiative, to promote economic development and regional cooperation. Human resource development and trade are key pillars of their cooperation, with Singapore being China's largest foreign investor and China being Singapore's largest trading partner. The countries also work together to promote regional stability, including through the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank and the Belt and Road Initiative.

site_title: 3 ex-Tepco execs indicted over Fukushima disaster
summary: Three former executives of Tokyo Electric Power (Tepco) were formally charged with professional negligence over the 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster, the world's worst nuclear accident since Chernobyl. Ex-Tepco chairman Tsunehisa Katsumata, vice-president Sakae Muto, and vice-president Ichiro Takekuro were indicted for their roles in deaths and injuries resulting from the tsunami-sparked reactor meltdowns. They will plead not guilty, citing the impossibility of predicting the massive tsunami, and face the first criminal trial linked to the disaster.

images.alt_text: The indictment will lead to the first criminal trial over responsibility for the tsunami-sparked reactor meltdowns that forced tens of thousands from their homes.

site_title: UK mortgage approvals hit 2-year high
summary: British mortgage approvals surged to a 2-year high in January with 74,581 approvals, exceeding analyst forecasts of 74,000. Consumer credit expanded at the fastest pace in a decade, likely fueling concerns about lending requirements. The Bank of England may consider tightening lending standards in response to the strong demand.

site_title: Banking crisis? Singapore banks on sound footing
summary: Singapore banks face a challenging 2016 due to economic uncertainty, but a banking crisis is unlikely. Banks set aside reserves for bad loans through specific and general provisions, with Singaporean banks maintaining higher provisions than international peers. The central bank requires Singapore banks to maintain a general provision of at least 1% of loans and receivables. Despite this, Singapore banks have more capital than required, and their earnings will likely mirror the bumpy ride of the Singapore and Asian economies.

site_title: Small lift in S'pore business confidence for Q2
summary: Singapore's business confidence for Q2 2016 rose slightly to a marginally positive 0.89 percentage points, after hitting a historical low in Q1. The quarterly business optimism index (BOI) study showed a year-on-year decline from 15 percentage points in Q2 2015. Despite a slight rebound in Q1, selling prices fell, and the construction industry emerged as the most optimistic sector, while the manufacturing sector remains weak. Sentiment remains poor, and experts expect subdued optimism in the coming months.

site_title: Clinton and Trump shoot for inevitability on Super Tuesday
summary: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump are well-positioned to secure a significant lead on "Super Tuesday," with Clinton aiming to build an impregnable lead and Trump facing criticism for his comments on white supremacists and a quote attributed to Benito Mussolini. Republican rivals Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz have attacked Trump, but some members of the Republican inner circle have thrown their support behind him. Clinton is trying to assume a sheen of inevitability in her bid to become the Democratic nominee, while Trump's campaign is testing whether his unconventional tactics will affect voters.

images.alt_text: Mrs Clinton could come close to staking her claim to the nomination on March 1 when the race goes national, after a string of smaller but important single-state contests.
If Mr Trump sweeps the South, where many of the Super Tuesday races are taking place, it could be lights out for his Republican challengers.

site_title: Madonna proves she's still the Queen of Pop
summary: Madonna performed her first-ever concert in Singapore at the National Stadium, complying with the country's strict rules and regulations. The 57-year-old pop icon delivered a two-hour show with a theatrical set, despite removing three songs from her set list at the last minute. Her stage presence and star quality remained intact, impressing the crowd of 25,000 fans. The concert marked Madonna's return to Singapore after a 32-year hiatus, and she proved that she remains the "Queen of Pop," still filling stadiums and reinventing herself musically.

site_title: MAS flags some riskier practices in bank lending here
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has warned banks to maintain credit underwriting standards, particularly in trade finance, amid heightened competition in a low-interest-rate environment. Two emerging trends were noted: substituting trade-finance facilities with working capital loans and underpricing loans below the hurdle rate. This poses risks to banks, which may not adequately compensate for lending risks. The MAS review aims to address these practices and ensure the stability of the financial system.

site_title: Pending home sales in January take a hit from cold weather
summary: US pending home sales dropped 2.5% in January, the lowest since September 2014, due to winter weather in the Northeast. Despite this, sales were 1.4% higher than the previous year, with the Midwest experiencing a 4.9% decline and the South seeing a 0.3% increase. Experts attribute the slowdown to rising home prices and limited inventory, with potential buyers waiting for the spring season.

site_title: Sakae in the red with S$5.8m loss for FY2015
summary: Sakae Holdings reported a net loss of S$5.8 million for its FY2015, reversing a profit of S$2.1 million from the previous year. The loss was attributed to foreign-exchange losses, rising operating costs, and increased legal fees due to ongoing cases. Revenue dipped 1.8% to S$96 million due to weaker market sentiment and competition. The company expanded its business to food trading to boost revenue and profit. Two legal suits concluded, with the High Court setting timelines for closing submissions.

site_title: Startup lessons about artificial intelligence
summary: Artificial intelligence startups face increased odds of success due to advancements in the technology, but rely on basic business virtues like focus, flexibility, and resilience to thrive. Unlike big companies, startups must release products quickly, often within a year or two, to stay competitive. Investors and entrepreneurs agree that practical applications, such as those using data and machine-learning, are key to making AI investments worthwhile. Successful startups, like Narrative Science, have built their businesses around AI-powered software, generating reports and summaries for mainstream industries, and are growing rapidly.

site_title: With humility, Starbucks to enter Italian market, where standards are high
summary: Starbucks is set to enter the Italian market, marking a significant milestone for the company. CEO Howard Schultz has announced the opening of the first Starbucks store in Italy, in Milan, early next year. This move is seen as a personal and strategic effort by Schultz, who credits Italy's distinct coffee culture for inspiring the Starbucks experience. The company will partner with Percassi to operate the stores, and plans to tailor its offerings to local coffee habits, including a bar and competitive pricing. Schultz emphasized the need to earn respect from Italian customers and to not be perceived as a threat to local coffee bars.

site_title: At Milan Fashion Week, Cinderella goes to Dolce & Gabbana
summary: Dolce & Gabbana presented its latest womenswear line at Milan Fashion Week, featuring a fairytale-inspired collection with Cinderella and Snow White themes. The collection included richly-embellished dresses with sequined mice, carriages, and gold slippers. Models wore vibrant and colorful outfits with patterns and decorations referencing classic fairytales. In contrast, Philipp Plein's show at Milan Fashion Week featured a Superheroine Extravaganza theme, with a collection of black and shiny outfits inspired by Catwoman and The Avengers.

site_title: Templeton predicts 20% China stock rally as panic fades
summary: Franklin Templeton's Lirong Xu predicts a 20% rebound in China's $5.3 trillion stock market in the short term as economic growth picks up and yuan volatility decreases. The prediction comes after panicked investors caused the world's deepest selloff, with the Shanghai Composite Index dropping 24% this year. Xu believes the economy will bottom out in the first half and the yuan will stabilize, leading to a rally in commodity producers and new economy companies. The People's Bank of China announced a 0.5 percentage point drop in reserve requirements, adding to market easing efforts.

site_title: EU unveils details of data privacy pact with US
summary: The European Union unveiled details of a new data privacy pact with the US, replacing the invalidated Safe Harbor agreement. The "Privacy Shield" deal includes commitments from President Barack Obama to limit bulk-collected intelligence, a US ombudsman for EU citizen complaints, and fines for non-compliant firms. EU Justice Commissioner Vera Jourova calls it a "strong new framework" for easier redress, while Austrian activist Max Schrems criticizes it as insufficient, saying it allows too many bulk data collection areas. The deal will be subject to annual review and includes EU authority to fine firms up to 20 million euros for breaching EU rules.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here's a summary of the article in 100 words or less:

UOL Group is expected to deliver stable cash flows due to its diversified portfolio of commercial properties, including office and retail segments. DBS Group Research has set a target price of S$7.39 for UOL. Meanwhile, Samudera Shipping Line has reported higher core net profit, with positive free cash flows and a strengthening balance sheet. CIMB Research has added Thai Beverage Public Co to its "add" list, citing a strong showing by beer in Q4 FY15 despite weaker performance in non-alcoholic drinks. The research firm has set a target price of S$0.83 for ThaiBev.

site_title: Women's share of directorships improves to 9.5%
summary: Women's representation on Singapore-listed company boards increased to 9.5% in 2015, with media-related firms having the highest women representation at 21%. This marked the sixth consecutive annual increase, with women comprising 14% of new director appointments. The percentage of boards with women also improved to 47.6%, but Singapore lags behind global peers such as Norway, which had 35.5% women on its boards. Companies in the Straits Times Index and Catalist board demonstrated significant gains, with media-related firms showing the largest improvements.

site_title: China: Stocks flat despite boost measure
summary: Chinese stocks opened flat on March 1, 2016, despite a reserve requirement cut aimed at boosting the economy. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.40 points to 2,688.38, while the Shenzhen Composite Index increased 0.19 points to 1,643.55. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 0.81% to 19,267.33. The flat opening comes after February manufacturing activity shrank at its fastest rate in four years, according to official figures.

site_title: Brexit would open world digital gateway for Europe
summary: A Brexit would create a digital gateway for Europe, allowing the UK to tap into the global economy. Despite concerns about isolation, Britain's strong economy, language, and historical ties to Europe make it an attractive hub for international businesses. With a large population, a world-class university system, and a significant financial network, the UK would be well-positioned to serve as a gateway to the digital world, potentially even surpassing EU member states like Germany.

site_title: Planet on the ballot
summary: The 2016 US presidential election will determine the fate of the planet, with the winner's ability to steer the country towards saving the planet hanging in the balance. The partisan divide on environmental policy has grown wider, with Republicans opposing climate action and Democrats supporting it. However, executive action and existing laws can still achieve significant progress, and the election will decide whether the next president will be willing to take action. The ongoing revolution in renewable energy has made it possible to achieve carbon-neutral sources of energy, and moderate pro-environment policies can be implemented with minimal economic disruption.

site_title: Mahathir quits Umno over Najib scandal
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has quit the ruling party, Umno, citing its degeneration into a party dedicated to protecting scandal-plagued Prime Minister Najib Razak. Mahathir, who led Umno from 1981-2003, announced his departure after months of calling for Najib's ouster over allegations of corruption and accepting a mysterious $681 million donation. Mahathir will form a "core group" to work on removing Najib, but will not set up a new party or join another.

images.alt_text: Dr Mahathir is quitting Umno as it "is seen as supporting corruption" under the current Prime Minister.

site_title: Top performing gold miner looking to add to hedge book as price soars
summary: Gold prices have soared this year, reaching a 12-month high, prompting top gold miner St Barbara Ltd to consider hedging to secure profits. The company, which has seen its stock advance 740% in the past year, aims to hedge 25% of its production, while Evolution Mining Ltd and Harmony Gold Mining Co also have hedged forward sales. Analysts are divided on the direction of gold, with some predicting a rally to $1,400 an ounce and others expecting a slump to $1,000 an ounce.

site_title: AusNet Services sells long-tenure SGD hybrid bonds
summary: AusNet Services sold SGD 200 million hybrid bonds at 5.5% interest, with a tenure of 60.5 NC (non-call 5.5), allowing for early redemption by 2021 or maturity in 2076.

site_title: Japan tests biggest carbon capture at quake-prone area
summary: Japan is set to test its largest carbon capture project at a quake-prone area off the coast of Hokkaido, starting in April. The project, backed by the government, aims to inject 100,000-200,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide into deep saline aquifers annually to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Despite concerns over cost and safety, Japan CCS Co believes the technology can be proven in the country, and the project will demonstrate the three stages of carbon capture and storage. The project's success is seen as crucial for Japan to meet global emissions reduction goals.

site_title: Parliament passes updated Women's Charter Bill
summary: Singapore's Parliament passed an updated Women's Charter Bill allowing husbands to claim maintenance from women in divorce proceedings under certain conditions, such as incapacitation and a clear need for spousal maintenance. The bill also strengthens maintenance enforcement and introduces marriage preparation classes for couples under 21, and parenting programs for divorcing couples with minor children. The changes aim to protect families and women from the harm of social media and strengthen marriages. The bill takes effect on October 1.

images.alt_text: Singapore is still "not quite ready" to be gender neutral by letting men claim maintenance from women in divorce proceedings, Social and Family Development Minister Tan Chuan-Jin said in Parliament on Monday.

site_title: Money managers split over Brexit's effect on government bond market
summary: Investors in the UK's government bond market are divided over the potential effects of Brexit, with some seeing it as positive for UK sovereign debt due to lower interest rates and others anticipating a decline in economic activity and increased debt. Money managers such as Pimco and Pioneer Investments are weighing the risks of a "leave" vote, with Pimco predicting a 40% probability of Brexit and Pioneer considering selling gilts if the "out" vote wins. The Bank of England's monetary policy stance and sterling's volatility are key factors in the market's response to the Brexit referendum.

site_title: Apple case creates fervour for encryption bill in Congress
summary: A US court ruling has heightened the debate over encryption, prompting renewed calls for a legislative bill in Congress. The ruling, which ordered Apple to comply with FBI demands to access a San Bernardino shooter's iPhone, has sparked a heated discussion about when technology companies should assist government agencies. FBI Director James Comey has urged lawmakers to address the issue of encryption, which he believes is a pressing matter. The controversy has put a spotlight on the need for a clear policy on when companies should comply with government requests for access to secure information.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. European stocks fell, with banks and healthcare companies dragging down the market, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case related to 285 trillion rupiah. US stocks were lower amid fresh tariff threats from President Trump.

site_title: Government eases DC rates for key use groups
summary: The Singapore government has reduced development charge (DC) rates for most major use groups from March 1 to August 31, amid the overall price and rental weakness in the property market. Industrial use DC rates were trimmed by 3%, commercial use by 2-5%, and non-landed residential use by 2-4%. However, rates for landed residential use, place of worship/civic, and community institutions remain unchanged. The reductions are seen as a response to the weak occupier market and aim to support land values.

site_title: Space-tight SMEs tap solar power under new programme
summary: A new business model by Sun Electric allows small and medium enterprises (SMEs) to tap into solar power without rooftop space. The company separates solar power generation from consumption, enabling SMEs to benefit from solar energy. This follows Apple's similar deal to receive power from solar energy systems on other buildings. The move aims to increase adoption of solar power among SMEs in Singapore, promoting sustainable energy practices.

site_title: VietJet seeking IPO to become 'Emirates of Asia'
summary: VietJet Aviation Joint Stock Co, Vietnam's only privately owned airline, plans to hold an initial public offering (IPO) as early as the second quarter to build global routes and become a top budget airline in Asia. The airline's CEO, Nguyen Thi Phuong Thao, stated that the IPO's timing will depend on market developments, and the company may offer up to 30% of its stake to foreign investors. This move aims to increase the airline's presence globally and solidify its position as one of the region's top budget airlines.

images.alt_text: VietJet is seeking to expand in a market that has grown 20 per cent annually in the last three years.

site_title: Pipeline near nuclear power plant in NY reignites concerns
summary: A construction project to expand a natural gas pipeline across Indian Point property near a nuclear power plant in New York has reignited concerns about the facility's safety. The pipeline expansion has been criticized by officials and residents, who fear a rupture could unleash a nuclear catastrophe. The state is planning to conduct an independent safety analysis and has asked federal regulators to suspend approval of the project until the study is completed. This move comes amid ongoing safety issues at the plant since last May.

site_title: Petrobras gets US$10b Chinese loan in oil supply deal
summary: Petrobras secured a $10 billion loan from China Development Bank Corp as part of a deal to supply crude to China. The loan will help alleviate short-term liquidity pressure and is part of a larger agreement to supply oil to the Asian country. Despite providing temporary relief, analysts say the loan won't solve Petrobras' financial problems and will worsen leverage. The deal comes as Petrobras faces a severe financial crisis, with over double the loan amount in maturing debt over the next two years.

images.alt_text: Petroleo Brasileiro SA secured a US$10 billion loan from China Development Bank Corp as the beleaguered state-owned oil producer endures the worst crude market in a generation and faces more than double that amount in maturities over the next two years.

site_title: Saint Petersburg's new port aiming to become top Russian cargo hub
summary: Saint Petersburg's new deepwater port aims to become Russia's top cargo hub despite industry challenges. The port's development comes as Russia's economy faces a slump due to falling oil prices and Western sanctions. The rouble has also been battered. Officials are optimistic about the port's potential, aiming to increase cargo and container shipping.

site_title: Bank lending to businesses, consumers sees flat start
summary: Bank lending in Singapore remained flat in January, with loans to businesses and consumers growing only 1.5% year-on-year, according to BMI Research. Loans to financial institutions surged 5.4% to S$72.4 billion, while trade loans fell 5.1% to S$62.6 billion. Consumer lending, mainly driven by housing loans, rose 0.4% to S$185 billion. This marks a smaller contraction compared to the 1.3% year-on-year fall in December.

site_title: Green light for firms adopting sustainability
summary: Companies adopting sustainability initiatives can enhance brand equity and differentiate themselves in the market. Major brands, such as The Hershey Company, Mondelez International, and Unilever, are implementing new eco-initiatives, including deforestation prevention, palm oil supply tracing, and sustainable living plans. Effective sustainability requires holistic communication, phased implementation, and collaboration with external partners to mitigate initial costs and achieve long-term benefits. By embracing sustainability, organizations can unlock opportunities for new markets, launch sub-brands, and create innovative products, ultimately strengthening their brand equity.

site_title: Won hits 5 1/2-year low as dollar's rise dents Asian currencies
summary: The South Korean won hit a 5 1/2-year low against the dollar, falling to 1,245.3, amid a rise in the greenback due to upbeat US economic data. Other Asian currencies also eased against the dollar, with the Singapore dollar reaching a three-week low. Analysts attribute the dollar's firm tone to US data showing solid consumer spending and GDP growth, which may lead to interest rate hikes later this year.

site_title: America's passion for guns still intact as shooting toll rises
summary: US mass shootings continue to rise, with at least nine deaths in recent incidents. Despite President Barack Obama's efforts to tackle gun violence, a Republican-controlled Congress has been unable to pass meaningful reforms. Meanwhile, a bill in Iowa would allow children as young as one to use handguns with parental supervision, sparking debate over the Second Amendment and gun safety. The US has one of the highest rates of gun ownership in the world, with over 30,000 annual deaths attributed to firearms.

site_title: Japanese factory output rises for first time in three months
summary: Japan's factory output rose 3.7% in January, its first expansion in three months, offering some positive news for the country's economy. The growth comes as investors await clues about the state of the economy, which has been impacted by weak inflation numbers and a trade deficit. The positive industrial production figures are seen as a sign of improvement, but economists caution that the export trend is still weak and global growth risks remain.

site_title: Investors turn their backs on shipping amid bulk-carrier woes
summary: Private equity firms are reevaluating their investments in shipping due to the industry's overcapacity and low commodity shipping costs. The Baltic Dry Index, a measure of shipping costs, has hovered near all-time lows, causing fear among investors. As a result, private equity's contribution to the shipping market has shrunk 69% to $70 billion, down from $922 billion in the past year. Industry experts, including JPMorgan Asset Management's Andrian Dacy, are taking a wait-and-see approach, citing the volatility of the shipping industry.

site_title: Singapore signs bilateral investment treaty with Iran
summary: Singapore has signed a bilateral investment treaty with Iran, aimed at promoting trade and investment between the two countries. The agreement was signed by Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran and Iran's Minister of Economic Affairs and Finance Ali Tayyebnia. This marks a significant step in Singapore's efforts to re-enter the Iranian market, with bilateral trade valued at S$171.4 million in 2015. The treaty is expected to open up business and investment opportunities, particularly in the oil and gas, petrochemicals, and logistics sectors.

site_title: Risk-averse investors find safer harbour in Sing-dollar bonds
summary: Risk-averse investors in Singapore are favoring high-quality corporate bonds, driving sales of SGD-denominated bonds to S$2.8 billion in the first half of 2016, a 56% increase from last year. Longer tenures are also in demand, with issuers offering lower interest rates and longer maturities. This trend is driven by weak market sentiment and credit events, making high-quality issuers more attractive. Despite this, some analysts predict a lackluster performance for SGD bonds in the near term, citing tight valuations.

site_title: Golden Agri's Q4 dealt a double whammy
summary: Golden Agri-Resources, a palm oil plantation group, reported a Q4 net loss of US$88.4 million, quadrupling from the previous year, due to a higher fair-value loss and lower foreign-exchange gain. Core net profit rose 10.3% to US$50.9 million, while revenue fell 14.8% to US$1.6 billion. For the full year, the company recorded a net loss of US$16.7 million, reversing the previous year's profit of US$113.6 million.

site_title: China expects to lay off 1.8m workers in coal and steel sectors
summary: China plans to lay off 1.8 million workers in the coal and steel industries over the next two years as part of efforts to curb overcapacity and reduce industrial unemployment. The government will allocate 100 billion yuan (S$21.5 billion) to relocate workers, mainly focusing on the steel and coal sectors. The move aims to reduce downward pressures on the economy and support economic growth of 6.5-7% in 2016, while addressing job insecurity and potential unrest among workers.

site_title: Baring's Interplex offer could turn unconditional
summary: Baring Private Equity Asia has launched a S$450 million (US$320 million) offer to acquire Singapore-listed precision-engineering firm Interplex Holdings, conditional on two shareholders selling their shares. The offer price is S$0.82 per share, a 19.4% premium over Interplex's 12-month volume weighted average price. The offer will become unconditional once the two shareholders, controlled by CVC Capital Partners and Standard Chartered Private Equity, sell their shares. The offer values Interplex at S$450 million.

site_title: Brexit may trigger some fearful consequences
summary: The UK's Prime Minister David Cameron reached a "new settlement" with the European Union, agreeing on terms for a potential in-out referendum on Britain's membership. The settlement addresses UK concerns in economic governance, competitiveness, sovereignty, and social benefits, but does not reflect significant EU reform. The deal has sparked opposition from Conservative MPs and potentially could lead to another Scottish referendum on independence if the UK votes to leave the EU. Most polls suggest the "remain" option will win the referendum, which is scheduled for June 23.

images.alt_text: The Britain-EU negotiated settlement certainly does not reflect any significant reform of the EU. The only way substantial and fundamental change in the EU can occur is through negotiation of a new treaty or amendments to existing treaties.

site_title: Still too soon to lift property curbs: MND
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) in Singapore stated that it's too early to lift property curbs, including the buyer's stamp duty (ABSD), as they aim to maintain a stable and sustainable market. The MND's response comes amid calls from real estate developers for eased curbs, with billionaire Kwek Leng Beng speculating that ABSD may be abolished this year. However, the extent of a potential rebound in demand is unclear, and the MND emphasized that relaxing measures could result in a market rebound.

images.alt_text: Real estate players hoping for property market curbs in Singapore to be loosened sometime this year might do well to prepare themselves for a longer wait.

site_title: Vard plans diversification as Q4 sinks into the red
summary: Vard Holdings, a major shipbuilder, has unveiled diversification plans to overcome the industry downturn in its core offshore market. The company reported a red fiscal fourth quarter ending Dec 31, 2015, due to lower revenue, impairments, and reduced financial income. To mitigate the impact, Vard plans to expand into new markets and develop new products, aiming to improve its financial performance.

site_title: US abandons plan to swap obsolete buildings
summary: The US government has abandoned its plan to swap obsolete buildings along Independence Avenue for redevelopment, after failing to reach an agreement with developers. The General Services Administration had proposed trading the properties for proceeds to complete the construction of the GSA headquarters west of the White House.

site_title: M&As seen as main exit route for S-E Asia startups
summary: A Singapore-based venture capital firm, Golden Gate Ventures, predicts that mergers and acquisitions (M&As) will drive tech startup exits in South-east Asia over the next five years, with M&As expected to grow over 500% from 2015 to 2020. This is due to the growth of institutional funds and global players looking to expand their footprint in the region.
