summary: Baidu Inc. reported a 33% increase in sales to 18.7 billion yuan in the December quarter, beating analyst estimates. Mobile revenue rose 56% and accounted for 56% of total sales. The company's investments in mobile and services such as home delivery and online video are driving growth beyond advertising. Baidu's dominance in search is helping offset the impact of a slowing Chinese economy, and the company is investing heavily to compete with Alibaba and Tencent in the on-demand economy.

site_title: BOJ unveils price index that buoys governor's position
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) released a new price index showing Japanese consumer prices rose 1.1% in the year to January, excluding energy and fresh food costs, meeting more than halfway its 2% annual inflation target. The conventional index, including energy prices, remained flat. BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda defended the central bank's policies, stating they aim to achieve domestic price objectives, amid criticism and speculation about targeting the yen exchange rate. The move may help boost Kuroda's position, but the issue of negative interest rates remains contentious.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Noble Group recorded a loss for FY15 due to impairments against investments and supply chain assets. OCBC Investment Research sets a target price of S$0.39, citing a bearish outlook for commodities. City Developments' Q4 2015 results were in line, with Maybank Kim Eng Research setting a target price of S$9.33 due to a global financial crisis-level valuation. BreadTalk Group's FY16 profit growth is expected to be driven by bottom-line gains, despite weak revenue and same-store sales growth.

site_title: Q4 turnover for services sector comes in flat
summary: Singapore's services sector posted a flat turnover growth of 0.2% in Q4 2015, with all segments except education recording higher business receipts year-over-year. The health & social services sector experienced the highest growth of 6.6%, while recreation & personal services declined by 7%. The education segment saw a 5.4% drop in business receipts, and the financial & insurance sector grew by 3.5%. The mixed result reflects a decline in business receipts for the remaining three segments, excluding wholesale & retail trade, and accommodation & food services.

site_title: SGX bids for London's historic Baltic Exchange
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has made a non-binding bid to acquire The Baltic Exchange, a historic London institution providing benchmark maritime data. SGX competes with other suitors, including CME Group and ICE, and aims to strengthen its foothold in the shipping index and derivatives business. The Baltic Exchange's Baltic Dry Index is the industry standard, and a successful bid could complement SGX's growing freight derivatives business and boost Singapore's status as a maritime hub. However, some industry experts question the bid's strategic value and the exchange's financial viability.

site_title: Social enterprises - A new dimension
summary: Singapore's social enterprise ecosystem is rapidly growing, with almost 400 registered social enterprises as of May 2015, covering various industries such as education, healthcare, and IT. These enterprises aim to create positive social impact while being sustainable and profitable. The Singapore Centre for Social Enterprise (raiSE) provides support and funding to social enterprises, including the President's Challenge Social Enterprise Award and the Venture-for-Good grant. Impact investments are also becoming increasingly popular, with raiSE managing impact investments in high-potential social enterprises. This growth has the potential to create a new dimension of Singapore's future, with the public and private sectors working together to support social enterprises and drive positive change.

site_title: Japan's Aso tells G20 world economy growing, uncertainties rising
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso stated that the world economy is heading towards a gradual recovery, but volatility and uncertainty are increasing due to China's economic policies, oil prices, and divergent monetary policies. Aso proposed setting up a working group to investigate capital outflows from emerging markets and urged China to reform its currency and outline a mid-term structural reform plan. He also expressed concern about a currency devaluation race among G20 economies.

site_title: Alibaba in talks with several banks for up to US$4b loan: WSJ
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd is in talks with several banks to borrow up to $4 billion to fund expansion plans, including acquisitions and investments in new areas such as online video and local services. The loan is expected to be finalized next month. This comes as the company seeks to offset slowing volume growth in its core online shopping business. Alibaba's shares rose 2.2% in premarket trading after the news, despite a 18% decline in the stock this year.

site_title: Mid-luxury cars up to S$200k still selling well: dealers
summary: Singapore's mid-luxury car market remains strong despite an economic downturn, with sales of cars between S$150,000 and S$200,000 remaining steady. However, sales of higher-end luxury cars costing S$200,000 and up have slowed, with buyers becoming more cautious due to weak sentiment. Distributors attribute the trend to economic uncertainty affecting business owners and those with steady jobs, leading them to adopt a wait-and-see attitude. The sales director of a luxury dealership notes that the cut-off point for luxury car buyers is around S$250,000, and a recent drop in COE premium has sparked renewed interest in lower-end models.

images.alt_text: THE mid-luxury car market is still going strong despite the current gloomy economic outlook, but the higher-end luxury segment has slowed to a crawl as buyers' comfort levels slump in line with weak sentiment.

site_title: Apple rivals take cautious line on encryption issue
summary: Asian device makers, including Huawei, Lenovo, Samsung, and Xiaomi, are taking a cautious approach on the encryption issue, resisting demands from the US government to unlock encrypted iPhones. Unlike Huawei's CEO Richard Yu, who backed Apple CEO Tim Cook, other CEOs declined to comment or expressed concerns about complying with government requests. Many Asian countries lack privacy laws, and regulators are exploring ways to extract data from devices, citing national security concerns. This stance may prompt device makers to reassess their approach, potentially leading to more regulatory pressure.

site_title: Lazard, AMP latest firms to close Asia-focused hedge funds
summary: Lazard Asset Management and AMP Capital have closed their Asia-focused hedge funds. Lazard's US$9.8 million Lazard Asia ex-Japan Equity Strategy was shut down, while AMP Capital's AMP Capital Asia Quant Fund, which held US$104 million, was also closed due to the departure of its team. The trend of hedge funds closing globally continues, with over 800 funds shutting down last year, as market volatility and increasing costs make it challenging for money managers to raise funds and compete with larger firms.

site_title: Sapphire's rail acquisition puts turnaround on track
summary: Sapphire Corp has reported a significant turnaround in its financial performance, with net profit jumping to S$6.5 million in FY2015, up from S$138,000 the previous year. The company's acquisition of Ranken Infrastructure, a Chinese rail engineering specialist, has contributed to the improvement, with revenue doubling to S$116.4 million. Sapphire's CEO, Teh Wing Kwan, attributes the turnaround to strategic decisions, including the sale of its steel business and the acquisition of Ranken, which has given the company a strong platform for expansion in China's urban rail boom.

images.alt_text: TAKING UP THE CHALLENGE: Mr Teh took over the reins of Sapphire in October 2013 when the firm was en route to its third straight year of losses and on the brink of joining Singapore Exchange's dire 'watch list'.

site_title: Workshops for caregivers of autistic children
summary: The Autism Partnership will host two educational workshops in Singapore to guide caregivers on working with autistic children. The first workshop, "Navigating the Maze of ASD," will focus on causes, prognosis, and treatment of autism, while the second workshop, "Understanding and Facing the Challenges of Social-Sexual Development," will address strategies for dealing with social-sexual development and behavior. The workshops will be held on March 20 and 21, costing S$200 each, with a special price of S$300 for attending both sessions.

site_title: Setting the Pace
summary: Jaguar's F-Pace is set to launch in Singapore in June or July, with an all-wheel drive system and Intelligent Driveline Dynamics software for agile handling. The compact crossover boasts a lightweight aluminium architecture, reducing understeer and improving braking. Four engine variants will be available, including a 380 hp 3.0 V6 Supercharged First Edition. The vehicle will feature a class-leading boot space of 650 litres and an Activity key wrist-worn device with a waterproof design. Pricing has not been announced yet.

images.alt_text: Like the brand's sedan models, the compact crossover boasts lightweight aluminium architecture. Because it weighs less than a conventional steel body, the F-Pace's alloy structure benefits handling and braking.

Like the brand's sedan models, the compact crossover boasts lightweight aluminium architecture. Because it weighs less than a conventional steel body, the F-Pace's alloy structure benefits handling and braking.

site_title: Oil at seven-week high on supply issues, gasoline demand
summary: Brent crude oil reached a seven-week high at $36.63 a barrel, driven by strong US gasoline demand and supply disruptions in Iraq and Nigeria. The gains outweigh concerns about a fundamental glut in the market, with analysts noting that supply disruptions and rising demand are balancing each other out. Most expect oil prices to rise again in the long term, with investment bank Jefferies predicting a price recovery in the second half of the year due to production declines across non-OPEC producers.

site_title: US industry body sees no abuse in energy markets
summary: A US industry group, the Energy and Environmental Markets Advisory Committee, told the Commodity Futures Trading Commission that a plan to limit speculation in energy markets would only hurt investors. The committee concluded that excessive speculation is not evident in the energy markets, a finding that drew criticism from lawmakers. CFTC Chairman Timothy Massad defended his agency's oversight of energy trades, saying that restrictions would hinder markets. A dissenting member of the panel, Tyson Slocum, called for more regulations to prevent market manipulation. The CFTC is considering implementing controls to address potential hedging abuse.

site_title: S'pore trio to hit the fairways in S Africa
summary: A Singaporean trio is set to participate in the BMW Golf Cup International World Final in South Africa, following their successful qualification through the Performance Motors Golf Association tournament in January. The 2015 World Final will be held in George, South Africa, with over 100,000 amateur golfers from 46 countries competing. The event, which attracts top amateur players, offers a chance for the Singaporean trio to showcase their skills alongside international golfers.

site_title: African lives matter too
summary: A 1989 role-playing exercise by 800 tropical disease specialists revealed a lack of preparedness for an Ebola outbreak in poor African countries with existing Aids problems. 25 years later, the 2014-15 Ebola outbreak highlighted the world's failure to prepare, with the World Health Organization and international community slow to react. This pattern of deferring action until crisis proportions and disregarding the health of sub-Saharan Africa has repeated itself with diseases like HIV/Aids, Zika, and West Nile fever. The author argues that developed countries must prioritize research and resources for diseases affecting Africa to prevent global outbreaks and reduce human suffering.

site_title: Hedge funds winning in M&A arbitrage
summary: Hedge funds are benefiting from record mergers and acquisitions (M&A) deals, taking advantage of a lack of competition from banks. The funds returned 3.4% in the 13 months to January, compared to a 5% loss for other equities-focused hedge funds. Record US$4.3 trillion in acquisitions in 2015 has created opportunities for merger-arbitrage funds, which can profit from target companies rising towards the offer price and bidder's share price falling. The strategy is attractive due to its immunity from stock market fluctuations unless the deal falls apart.

site_title: Emerging market bulls should beware
summary: London-based strategist John-Paul Smith warns emerging market bulls that a turnaround is unlikely, citing a lack of progress in reducing state control and an increasing trend of authoritarianism in countries such as Russia, Turkey, and Poland. He also predicts a financial crisis in China as soon as this year, driven by rising non-performing loans and asset writedowns. This stance contrasts with predictions from BlackRock and Research Affiliates that emerging markets will become the next "trade of a decade."

images.alt_text: WORRYING: One of strategist John-Paul Smith's big concern is China, where he predicts a financial crisis will strike as soon as this year. Non-performing loans are poised to surge as borrowers pile on debt to repay their existing loans, he says.

site_title: Global commodity AUM at US$170b in January: Barclays
summary: Global commodity assets under management (AUM) rose to US$170 billion in January, with precious metals holding the largest share at US$81 billion. Energy assets followed with US$43 billion. Total investment flows into commodities were US$13.9 billion, driven by inflows of US$5.9 billion in energy and US$3.7 billion in precious metals. The positive trend is attributed to investors seeking cheapness in some commodities, particularly oil, and dollar weakness boosting interest in gold.

site_title: VW given a month to present diesel fix plan
summary: US District Judge Charles Breyer has given Volkswagen one month to present a plan to fix diesel engine cars with pollution cheat devices, with a March 24th court date set for the German auto giant and the US Environmental Protection Agency. The scandal affects over 500,000 US cars, with owners filing a class-action lawsuit seeking damages for environmental and health impacts. Volkswagen has admitted to using illegal cheat software, which limits emissions during testing but increases pollution in actual use, potentially leading to huge damages.

site_title: Voting for new Fifa president enters second round
summary: FIFA's presidential election enters its second round after none of the four candidates secured a two-thirds majority in the first round. Gianni Infantino leads with 88 votes, followed by Sheikh Salman bin Ebrahim Al Khalifa with 85 votes. The second-round vote will determine the winner, with a simple majority needed for victory. FIFA has also approved its deepest reforms in history, including a new 36-member council and an independent audit committee, aimed at ending corruption and scandal.

site_title: US consumer spending rises strongly; inflation stirring
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.5% in January, driven by increased purchases and warmer winter temperatures, and underlying inflation picked up by 1.3% in the 12 months through January, the largest increase since October 2014. This data, combined with manufacturing and employment growth, suggests the economy may have picked up at the start of the year. The Federal Reserve's interest rate increases remain on the table, despite financial markets eliminating bets for a March rate hike.

site_title: Apple encryption stand highlights mobile operators' dilemma
summary: Apple's stance on encrypting iPhone data has raised questions for mobile network operators, who must balance user privacy and government demands for security. Executives from Vodafone and Orange admit they struggle to take a clear stance, citing concerns over user data and security. The increasing use of end-to-end encryption is complicating matters, leaving operators blind to communications and posing commercial challenges. Industry experts say operators need to find ways to manage encrypted traffic without compromising quality of service or security.

site_title: Zero-per cent inflation in Germany turns up heat on ECB
summary: Germany's consumer price index fell to zero percent in February, matching the lowest level since September 2015. The Harmonized Index of Consumer Prices (HICP) also dropped to minus 0.2 percent, fueling speculation that the European Central Bank (ECB) will launch new stimulus measures. Analysts predict the ECB may trim its deposit rate by 10 basis points and increase its asset purchases. This move aims to avert possible deflation in the euro area and achieve inflation rates close to 2.0 percent, considered conducive to healthy economic growth.

site_title: Hedge-fund assets below US$3t for first time since 2014
summary: Hedge fund assets globally fell to below $3 trillion for the first time since 2014, with a net outflow of $21.5 billion in January, according to eVestment data. The decline was driven by losses and redemptions, with equity and fixed-income hedge funds experiencing net outflows. However, interest in commodity-focused hedge funds rose for the fifth consecutive month, with $1.2 billion in new investments. This marks a reversal of a trend since 2012, with investors seeking opportunities in the commodity space.

site_title: 'Brexit' would scupper London, Frankfurt stock exchange merger: Deutsche Boerse
summary: Deutsche Boerse, the Frankfurt stock exchange operator, has proposed a merger with the London Stock Exchange, with the combined group to be based in London and Frankfurt. The deal would give Deutsche Boerse 54.4% ownership and would be structured as an all-share merger of equals. However, a potential "Brexit" could jeopardize the plans, as both exchanges recognize that a British exit from the EU would put the project at risk. The merger is the third attempt to combine the two exchanges, and it faces regulatory and shareholder approval before March 22.

site_title: Electronics weightage in output index cut
summary: Singapore's monthly index of industrial production has been rebased to reflect the latest manufacturing sector structure. The electronics cluster, previously 33.4%, now accounts for 27.4% of the index. The biomedical manufacturing cluster has increased to 12.3%, while the general manufacturing cluster has risen to 12.3% from 10.3%. The Economic Development Board's index measures the real output of the manufacturing sector, covering 1,141 establishments that contribute 92% of output. The changes aim to better reflect the sector's current structure and composition.

site_title: China establishes direct trading pair between yuan and Korean won
summary: China has established a direct trading exchange market between the yuan and the Korean won, allowing for forex trading between the two currencies. The People's Bank of China announced the move in a statement, following a meeting between its governor Zhou Xiaochuan and South Korean finance minister Yoo Il-ho at the G20 meeting in Shanghai. The direct trading is set to begin in the first half of 2016.

site_title: Neo Group unit loses Halal certification, must re-apply after April
summary: Neo Group's subsidiary Deli Hub Catering has lost its Halal certification due to non-compliance with segregation and cross-contamination requirements. The suspension is set to expire on April 30, 2016, and the company will need to re-apply for certification. Neo Group is working with a consultant to resolve the matter and is not yet assessing the financial impact. The certification is administered by Majlis Ugama Islam Singapura, a key requirement for food businesses catering to Muslim customers.

site_title: Malaysia's ruling party suspends deputy chief over criticism of PM
summary: Malaysia's ruling party, UMNO, suspended its deputy president Muhyiddin Yassin over criticism of Prime Minister Najib Razak regarding a financial scandal involving state-owned firm 1MDB. The move strengthens Najib's grip on the party and weakens rival factions. Muhyiddin, a fierce critic of Najib, was sacked as deputy prime minister in August and had been suspended until the next party polls in 2018. Najib denies any wrongdoing, saying the funds were a political donation.

site_title: Nissan to buy back shares for US$3.5b
summary: Nissan announced plans to buy back US$3.5 billion worth of its own shares by the end of the year. The operation, starting on Monday, aims to return cash to shareholders, following a high cash flow position. Renault, Nissan's French partner, will also sell Nissan shares to maintain its 43.4% stake in the Japanese automaker. The move is seen as a strategic decision to allocate resources and support the alliance's cash flow position.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's Q4 profit plunges 93%
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's Q4 net profit plummeted 93% to 41.45 million yuan, mainly due to higher impairments and foreign exchange losses. Revenue fell 17% to 3.13 billion yuan, while gross profit rose 10% to 925.60 million yuan. The company delivered six vessels on schedule, but its full-year net profit fell 29% to 2.5 billion yuan. Despite this, the company's chairman remains optimistic, citing a healthy order book and strong financial position.

site_title: Gold funds post longest run of inflows since 2009: BAML
summary: Gold funds have seen their largest inflows since 2009, with a US$2.6 billion investment in the week to Feb 24, bringing the three-week total to $5.8 billion. Equity funds, however, have experienced their longest run of outflows since 2008, with a net US$2.7 billion withdrawal. Investors are cautious due to market turmoil and uncertainty, with the IMF likely to cut its global growth forecast and economists lowering their 2016 outlook. Monetary policy decisions and G20 meetings are also contributing to investor unease.

site_title: G20: Germany's Schaeuble says little room left for more monetary stimulus
summary: Germany's finance minister Wolfgang Schaeuble stated that there is little room left for additional monetary measures by central banks, as agreed upon by G20 policy makers. This consensus emphasizes the need for structural reforms to create better conditions for investment.

images.alt_text: Germany's finance minister, Wolfgang Schaeuble, said on Friday that many policy makers from the Group of 20 leading economies agreed that there was little room left for additional monetary measures by central banks.

site_title: STI ends volatile week 7 points lower at 2,649.38
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week 7 points lower at 2,649.38, despite a 45.98-point jump on Friday. The index's volatility was influenced by external factors such as oil prices, Dow futures, and China. Banks led the index's decline, with analysts predicting a tough year due to write-offs and provisioning. Commodities firm Noble Group reported a $1.67 billion loss for 2015, and its shares slipped 1 cent. The exchange also canceled trades in the shares of Dyna-Mac due to pricing errors, warning against exploiting such errors for commercial gain.

site_title: Hilton to spin off real estate, timeshare businesses
summary: Hilton Worldwide Holdings Inc plans to spin off its real estate assets and timeshare business into separate entities, a real estate investment trust and a publicly traded company, respectively. The REIT will own approximately 70 hotel properties with 35,000 rooms, valued at over $10 billion. The spinoffs aim to simplify the businesses and increase shareholder returns. The company expects to complete the spinoffs by the end of the year, following similar moves by MGM Resorts International and Darden Restaurant Inc.

site_title: UBS charged with money laundering in Belgian tax case
summary: Belgian authorities charged UBS Group AG with money laundering and fiscal fraud, alleging the bank helped clients evade taxes through its French operations. UBS is also accused of laundering proceeds from tax evasion in France. The bank will defend itself against the allegations. A pretrial court must decide whether UBS should stand trial on the charges, following a formal investigation in France that has been turned over to the national financial prosecutor.

site_title: US fourth-quarter growth revised up to 1.0%
summary: US economic growth slowed in the fourth quarter, revised up to 1.0% annual rate, as businesses reduced unwanted inventory, which could hurt output in the first quarter. The revision was higher than expected, despite a smaller trade deficit and less steep equipment spending contraction. The bigger inventory build is a concern, as it may reduce production and limit new orders. First-quarter GDP growth estimates remain high, but risks are tilted to the downside due to slowing world economies and a strong dollar.

site_title: ABR posts 4.6% drop in Q4 earnings
summary: ABR Holdings, the restaurant operator, posted a 4.6% drop in Q4 net profit to S$2.3 million due to outlet closures and a 7.1% decline in revenue to S$25.4 million. The company attributed the decline to weaker Malaysian ringgit against the Singapore dollar and a challenging food and beverage industry. Despite this, ABR expects to remain focused on driving revenue, managing costs, and improving operational efficiency. The company also declared a final cash dividend of 1.5 cents per share and plans to explore opportunities to expand its portfolio of brands and pursue property investment opportunities.

site_title: Family of Chinese MH370 victim sue Malaysia Airlines
summary: A Chinese family has filed a lawsuit against Malaysia Airlines for the death of a relative who disappeared on flight MH370 in 2014. The lawsuit, filed at a Beijing court, demands 4.7 million yuan (US$719,000) in compensation under the Montreal Convention. The victim, surnamed Wang, was one of 239 people on the flight that vanished after take-off, with over 150 passengers being Chinese nationals. The lawsuit is part of a larger wave of claims from relatives seeking damages under international agreements, which allow families to sue within two years of the incident.

site_title: UE's FY15 profit falls 17% without contribution from discontinued businesses
summary: United Engineers' (UE) FY15 net profit fell 17% to S$102.2 million due to earnings from discontinued operations. Excluding these, profit would have increased by 122%. Revenue fell 42% to S$1.9 billion, mainly due to the absence of divested businesses and the Austville Residences project. UE's property business faces challenging conditions in Singapore and China. The company declared an 8-cent payout per share, consisting of a final dividend and special dividend.

site_title: Euro zone economic sentiment drops more than expected in February
summary: Euro zone economic sentiment dropped to 103.8 in February, a decline of 1.3 points, more than expected. The business climate indicator fell to 0.07, and sentiment in industry, services, and retail trade all decreased. Consumer confidence dropped to -8.8, while the financial services sector reported a sharp decline in confidence to 7.5. Despite a slight improvement in manufacturers' confidence, the overall sentiment remained negative, indicating a pessimistic outlook for the Euro zone economy.

site_title: SMRT to transfer 175 buses to LTA at net book value
summary: SMRT Corp will transfer 175 buses to the Land Transport Authority (LTA) on May 31 at the net book value of S$66.3 million, with no impact on SMRT's net assets or earnings. The buses were purchased using loan facilities provided by the LTA under the Bus Service Enhancement Programme.

site_title: British Airways owner announces soaring annual profit
summary: British Airways owner International Airlines Group (IAG) reported a 52% surge in annual profit to 1.495 billion euros (S$2.32 billion) in 2015, driven by tumbling fuel prices and the purchase of Aer Lingus. CEO Willie Walsh attributed the strong results to lower fuel costs, despite the impact of a stronger US dollar. The company expects further strong operating profit gains in 2016.

site_title: India sees growth above 7% despite 'grim' global economy
summary: India forecasts economic growth exceeding 7% in the next financial year, despite a grim global economy, with a slowdown in China and recession in other emerging markets. The government's Economic Survey predicts a 7-7.75% GDP growth rate, down from an initial forecast of 8% last year. India's economy has outpaced China's growth in recent quarters, but faces challenges including high inflation, weak private investment, and a depreciating rupee. Investors await concrete reforms in Monday's budget to boost economic growth and create jobs for India's young population.

site_title: Pick-up in Malaysian traffic helps AirAsia return to Q4 profit
summary: AirAsia Bhd reported a net profit of RM554.2 million in Q4 2015, reversing a net loss of RM428.5 million in the same period in 2014. Revenue rose to RM2.17 billion, driven by a 10% increase in passengers on Malaysian routes. The airline attributed the boost to low fuel costs and the weaker Malaysian currency, which made the country a more attractive holiday destination. AirAsia has hedged 52% of its fuel requirement for 2016 and recently set up a US$1-billion financing plan.

site_title: Cogent's Q4 profit falls 33% in absence of one-off gain
summary: Cogent Holdings reported a Q4 net profit of S$7.3 million, down 33% from the previous year, due to the absence of a one-off gain from a property disposal. Revenue increased 9% to S$33.3 million, while full-year net profit rose 3% to S$25.5 million. The company has proposed a lower cash dividend of 1.88 Singapore cents per share for FY2015, citing expected financial commitments for a project.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore Exchange submits non-binding bid to buy The Baltic Exchange, marking a significant move in the maritime market. Meanwhile, Singapore's industrial production dropped 0.5% year-on-year in January, while median monthly household income rose 4.9% in 2015. The SGX also proposes increasing the public tranche of Mainboard IPOs to at least 10%, and business receipts for Singapore's services sector remained flat in Q4 2015.

site_title: China central bank chief seeks to reassure on yuan, growth
summary: China's central bank chief, Zhou Xiaochuan, has reassured markets that the yuan currency has no reason to keep falling and that the country has room to boost its economy. Zhou stated that fundamentals of China's economy remain strong and that short-term market volatility will give way to economic fundamentals. The central bank has taken steps to boost growth, including interest rate cuts and reserve reductions, and has a "prudent and slightly easing" monetary policy stance. Despite concerns over the yuan's value, the PBoC will not resort to competitive devaluations to boost exports.

site_title: New business forum launched to encourage inclusive hiring
summary: The Inclusive Business Forum, launched by SG Enable and the Singapore Workforce Development Agency, aims to encourage employers to hire persons with disabilities. The forum's inaugural event featured discussions on training, hiring, and integrating individuals with disabilities. The initiative includes online HR management guides, a disability employment portal, and grants for transition-to-employment programs, with a total of S$5 million allocated. The goal is to create a work culture that plays to the strengths of persons with disabilities, promoting inclusive hiring practices.

site_title: Indonesia's CT Corp chairman says Singapore's GIC to get 17.39% of retail arm
summary: Indonesia's CT Corp chairman, Chairul Tanjung, announced a 5.2 trillion rupiah (S$542 million) deal where Singapore's GIC will acquire a 17.39% stake in Trans Retail, CT Corp's retail arm. The company plans to launch an initial public offering in 2020 when it reaches 200 stores. The funds will mainly be used for expansion, and the conglomerate's debt is under control, according to Tanjung.

site_title: France's Total fined 750,000 euros over Iraq 'oil for food' graft
summary: French oil giant Total was ordered to pay 750,000 euros (US$827,000) for corruption linked to the UN's "oil-for-food" programme in Iraq during Saddam Hussein's rule. The fine, the maximum possible at the time, stems from allegations that Total siphoned cash from the US$64 billion programme, which allowed Iraq to sell limited quantities of oil to buy humanitarian supplies between 1996 and 2003. Total was among more than a dozen individuals and companies cleared of corruption in 2013 after an eight-year investigation.

site_title: Australia shares slip on banks; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares closed 1.18 points lower, falling 1.5% for the week, as big banks influenced the market. New Zealand shares remained flat. Woolworths rose 2% after a near 10-year low in earnings.

site_title: Mewah Q4 profit falls 79%; full-year earnings more than double
summary: Mewah Group, a palm oil producer, reported a 79% decline in fourth-quarter profit to US$1.8 million, citing lower sales and higher tax expenses. Revenue fell 35% to US$540.3 million. Despite a 22% decline in revenue for the full year, the company's net profit more than doubled to US$6.5 million. The firm expects the industry to remain under pressure due to a gap between production and demand. A dividend of 0.45 Singapore cent per share was proposed for the full year.

site_title: SGX proposes IPOs allot at least 10% to public, up from 5% plan
summary: SGX proposes increasing the minimum public allocation for Mainboard IPOs to 10%, up from 5%, to accommodate large deals with insufficient public appetite. For listings over S$1 billion, only S$100 million must be allocated to the public tranche. The move aims to increase retail participation and generate greater interest in the securities market. However, the proposal acknowledges that public demand may not be enough to take up 10% of large listings, and companies can reallocate shares to the placement tranche if necessary.

images.alt_text: SGX is consulting the public on plans to impose a 10 per cent minimum on the public tranche of Mainboard initial public offerings.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks, won pause as G20 meeting in focus
summary: South Korean stocks and the won held steady on Friday as investors awaited the outcome of the G20 meeting in Shanghai. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed at 1,920.16 points, up 0.1% from the previous day. The won remained flat at 1,238.2 won per dollar. The cautious trading was likely due to concerns over the meeting's outcome, which could impact global economic policies and market sentiment.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.28 points to close at 1,663.44, driven by gains of 335 stocks while 492 lost value. The index saw 1.69 billion lots valued at RM1.95 billion traded.

site_title: Spackman narrows FY15 loss to US$1.1m on lower costs
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group narrowed its net loss to US$1.1 million in FY15, down from a US$8.1 million loss in 2014, due to lower costs. Revenue fell 16% to US$13.6 million, but the company's cost of sales decreased 36% to US$9.9 million, resulting in a gross profit increase to US$3.6 million. The company released only one film, The Priests, which grossed US$10.56 million at the Korean box office. Spackman is considering restructuring its loss-making businesses in the coming year.

site_title: UOL FY15 profit dragged down by absence of one-time gain, lower fair-value gains
summary: UOL Group reported a 43% decline in net profit for FY15 to S$391.4 million, driven by lower fair-value gains and an absence of a one-time gain. Excluding the gain from the sale of Jalan Conlay land in Malaysia, revenue would have risen 12% to S$1.28 billion. The group's property development segment rose 27% to S$557.5 million, while its hotel business slipped 4% to S$419.4 million. UOL expects subdued conditions in Singapore's residential market and pressure on office and retail rentals in 2016.

site_title: As Modi euphoria cools, India faces test to keep foreigners invested
summary: India's business-friendly agenda, implemented by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, is facing a test as foreign investors show signs of dissatisfaction, dumping a net $2.4 billion in shares this year. The government's slow pace of reforms, including delays in a goods and services tax, has led to a slump in the NSE share index and a decline in the rupee's value. Foreign investors are now looking to exit, with net outflows in debt and equity investments exceeding $833.5 million, and analysts warn that Modi's failure to deliver on his promises may lead to a reevaluation of India's investment climate.

site_title: Passenger plane makes emergency landing in Nepal
summary: A passenger plane with 11 people on board made an emergency landing in western Nepal on Friday. The plane, carrying nine passengers and two crew, made a forced landing in Kalikot district after an unspecified incident. There were no immediate reports of fatalities, but rescue teams have been dispatched to the area. The incident comes two days after a Twin Otter turboprop plane crashed into a mountainside, killing all 23 people on board.

site_title: Thailand plans steps worth US$285m to help drought-hit rice farmers
summary: Thailand's government has announced measures worth around $285 million to help drought-hit rice farmers, who are struggling with low prices and debt. The measures include soft loans to farmers who store rice, aiming to stabilize prices and curb supply. Domestic and international demand for Thai paddy is expected to stand at around 25 million tonnes this year, with a projected output of 27.17 million tonnes. The government also advised farmers to grow less rice to manage limited water resources.

site_title: European stock markets rally at open
summary: European stock markets surged at the open on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 rising 0.85% to 6,064.32, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices jumping 1.3% and 1.2%, respectively. The rally followed a similar trend in Asian markets, driven by China's central bank chief's assurance of the country's economic stability. The gains come as G20 ministers gather in Shanghai, with US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares up 2% as China rebounds, G20 meeting eyed
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 2.5% to 19,364.15 points, their best day in nearly two weeks, as mainland China markets rebounded. Despite a 0.4% weekly gain, China's main benchmark indexes fell over 3%. Investors eyed policy messages from the G20 meeting in Shanghai, focusing on market turmoil and a global economic slowdown. Key gains included HSBC (3.8%), AIA (2.9%), and Cheung Kong Infrastructure (3.1%).

site_title: Sino Grandness narrows Q4 loss to 105m yuan
summary: Sino Grandness Food Industry Group narrowed its Q4 loss to 104.5 million yuan, a 47.8% decrease from the previous year. Revenue rose 70.2% to 857.3 million yuan, driven by higher sales in the domestic market. The company attributed the growth to expansion of its distribution network in China. Full-year revenue rose 17.5% to 3.3 billion yuan, despite a 17% decline in earnings due to higher expenses. The stock gained 2.4% to 43.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Germany against G-20 fiscal stimulus package: Schaeuble
summary: Germany's finance minister, Wolfgang Schaeuble, opposes a proposed G-20 fiscal stimulus package, citing concerns that government attempts to boost economies with monetary loosening could be counterproductive. He believes fiscal policies have reached their limits and that reforms are needed to stimulate growth. Schaeuble's comments contrast with US Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew, who sees fiscal and monetary policy as powerful tools when used together. The disagreement highlights differences in economic priorities between Germany and other major economies, particularly the US.

site_title: Royal Bank of Scotland posts narrowing annual losses
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland reported a 43% reduction in annual net losses to around £2.0 billion, down from £3.47 billion in 2014. The bank cited hefty costs linked to legal action and compensation for mis-selling an insurance product. Total litigation and conduct costs increased to £3.57 billion, with possible further financial hits anticipated. The bank warned of uncertainties surrounding the UK's EU membership referendum. As a state-rescued bank, RBS is around 73% owned by the British government.

site_title: South Korea Q4 household disposable income falls, first in 5 years
summary: South Korea's average disposable household income fell 0.4% in real terms in the fourth quarter of last year, marking its first decline in nearly five years. This follows a 0.2% gain in the third quarter and an annual loss since 2011. The decline is attributed to a slump in exports, which dropped nearly 20% in January, and high household debt, leading to a decrease in consumer sentiment. The Bank of Korea is under pressure to cut interest rates further to stimulate the economy.

site_title: China: Stocks rebound as G20 meeting kicks off, down over 3% for week
summary: China's stocks rebounded on Friday as the CSI300 index rose 1% to 2,948.03 points, ending a 3.4% weekly decline. The Shanghai Composite Index also rose 0.95% to 2,767.21, but still finished the week down 3.2%. The rebound came as investors awaited policy messages from the G20 meeting in Shanghai, where fears of tighter liquidity and economic slowdowns are expected to be discussed.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week with a 0.3% loss, despite a 45.98-point jump on Friday, due to volatility caused by external factors such as oil prices, Dow futures, and China. The majority of trading volume was in STI members, with 64% of Friday's trade coming from index components.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rise, Sharp dives on takeover questions
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.30% on Friday, driven by poor inflation data and potential central bank stimulus. However, Sharp fell 3.22% after the parent company of Taiwan's Foxconn delayed a $6.5 billion takeover. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 16,188.41.

site_title: Phonemakers bank on virtual reality, add-ons to ignite sales
summary: Smartphone manufacturers are launching new devices and services, including virtual reality headsets and accessories, to drive sales in a crowded market. Companies like LG, Samsung, and Sony are adding features like 360-degree cameras and earpieces to their phones. Analysts say these efforts are necessary to attract customers in a market where growth is slowing, with global revenue expected to grow only 1.1% this year. While some see potential in these new offerings, others believe they are niche products unlikely to deliver near-term growth.

site_title: Changi Airport's passenger traffic rises 10% year on year in January
summary: Changi Airport saw a 10% year-on-year increase in passenger traffic in January, with 4.86 million passengers handled. Aircraft take-offs and landings rose 4.7%, and cargo shipments improved 4% to 158,000 tonnes. The growth was driven by air travel demand to North East Asia and South East Asia, with six markets recording double-digit growth, including Indonesia, which saw a 7.3% increase.

site_title: Petronas set to reveal more cost, meagre profit amid oil price slump
summary: Malaysia's state-owned oil giant Petronas is expected to announce further spending cuts amid a slump in crude prices, which could see a RM50 billion reduction over four years. The company is forecast to reverse last year's loss and notch a net profit of less than RM1 billion in its fourth-quarter earnings report. Petronas is also expected to cut its 2016 dividend by almost 40% and review contract positions not critical to its core business, amid concerns of a downgrade by credit ratings agencies.

site_title: China Everbright to buy Hong Kong Tower for US$1.3 billion
summary: China Everbright Holdings Co. agreed to buy a commercial building in Hong Kong's Wan Chai district for HK$10 billion (S$1.8 billion), adding to the number of Chinese companies investing in the city's expensive office market. The 39-story Dah Sing Financial Centre will be used as office space for the group, with analysts noting that the price may be high on a yield basis. This deal follows previous transactions by Evergrande and China Life Insurance, which broke previous price records, and is seen as a sign of Chinese demand driving up rents in Hong Kong's high-quality offices.

site_title: CEL wins tender for residential site at New Upper Changi Rd/Bedok South Ave 3
summary: CEL Residential Development won the tender for a 24,394 square metre residential site at New Upper Changi Road/Bedok South Avenue 3 at S$419.38 million, translating to S$8,186.54 per square metre of gross floor area. The site has a 99-year lease term and a maximum gross floor area of 51,228 square metre. CEL submitted the highest bid, beating the closing date of Feb 23. The tender was launched on Jan 20.

site_title: Indonesia to cut spending after parliament delays tax amnesty debate
summary: Indonesia's government plans to cut spending due to a delayed tax amnesty bill, which was expected to bring in $6.27 billion in extra revenue. The bill, aimed at boosting revenue, was postponed until April after parliament delayed its discussion. This delay will force the government to revise its budget, particularly on spending on goods, amid a widened budget deficit in 2015. The delay will also put pressure on economic growth, which is expected to be implemented at the end of 2016.

site_title: Singapore's industrial production drops less-than-expected 0.5% in Jan
summary: Singapore's industrial production declined 0.5% year-on-year in January, beating a Reuters forecast of 4.8% contraction. The decline was offset by growth in the electronics and biomedical manufacturing clusters. Excluding the biomedical sector, output would have fallen 7%. The EDB attributed the decline to low oil prices and weaker demand for oilfield equipment.

site_title: China's home prices rise 2.5% in January
summary: China's home prices rose 2.5% in January, higher than the previous month's 1.6% gain, marking the fourth consecutive month of year-on-year increases. This follows government measures to stabilize the housing market. However, the recovery remains uneven, with small cities still facing large inventories of unsold homes.

site_title: BOJ's new index shows Jan consumer prices up 1.1% year-on-year
summary: The Bank of Japan's new consumer price index shows a 1.1% year-on-year increase in January, excluding energy and fresh food costs. This is less than the 1.3% annual increase in December. The BOJ has introduced the new index, which includes processed and imported food prices, to better measure inflation. The central bank is using this index to guide monetary policy amid stagnant core CPI due to slumping oil prices. The BOJ plans to release the new index monthly on the same day as the government's price data.

site_title: Indonesia central bank official says policy rate cannot be cut to 4% if inflation stays at 4%
summary: Indonesia's central bank official, Juda Agung, stated that the policy rate cannot be cut to 4% if inflation stays at 4% due to its "low" inflation rate. The central bank expects inflation to reach 4.38% in February and remain low in March. This contradicts the government's request for a 4-5% policy rate cut earlier in the week.

site_title: Former Tepco chairman, two others to be indicted for Fukushima
summary: Former Tokyo Electric Power Co chairman Tsunehisa Katsumata and two other executives will be indicted for their roles in the 2011 Fukushima Dai-Ichi nuclear disaster, with charges of professional negligence. The indictment follows an inquest that recommended the executives be tried. The disaster, caused by a magnitude 9 earthquake and tsunami, led to 160,000 evacuations and lasting radiation contamination. The indictment marks the first time a court will examine if the failure to prevent the disaster constituted a crime. The executives will face charges as early as Friday.

site_title: Spring helped over 20,000 enterprises, 300 startups with restructuring efforts in 2015
summary: SPRING Singapore reported that in 2015, it helped over 20,000 enterprises and 300 startups with restructuring efforts, creating 19,500 jobs and contributing S$6.9 billion to the economy. This represents a significant increase from 2014, with more SMEs and startups leveraging the organization's assistance. The success of these efforts is attributed to the simplified Capability Development Grant application process, which saw a 30% increase in applications. Spring's CEO, Poon Hong Yuen, emphasized the importance of innovation and internationalization for SME growth, with plans to continue supporting enterprises in restructuring and upgrading capabilities.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up on bargain-hunting, Hon Hai falls on Sharp takeover delay
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.2% on Friday ahead of a long weekend, with investors seeking bargains. However, Hon Hai Precision's shares fell 1.5% after putting a takeover of Sharp Corp on hold due to undisclosed liabilities. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$33.25 per US dollar. The TAIEX index closed up 1% the previous day.

site_title: Sharp, Foxconn CEOs plan to meet on Friday in China: source
summary: Sharp Corp CEO Kozo Takahashi and Foxconn CEO Terry Gou plan to meet on Friday in China. The meeting comes after Sharp put a deal to take over the ailing Japanese electronics maker on hold due to undisclosed liabilities. This delay was a day after the planned acquisition.

images.alt_text: Kozo Takahashi, president of Sharp Corp.

site_title: Cruz, Rubio team up against Trump in key debate
summary: Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio teamed up to attack Donald Trump in a Republican presidential primary debate, criticizing his hiring of foreigners and questioning his commitment to conservative principles. Rubio highlighted Trump's past support for a pathway to citizenship and accused him of hiring undocumented workers, while Cruz pointed to Trump's donations to Democrats. The debate marked a shift in the campaign trail narrative, with Trump lashing out at his challengers and warning of a "lights out" outcome if he wins "Super Tuesday" next week.

images.alt_text: Rivals Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio mounted a furious assault against Donald Trump in Thursday's Republican presidential primary debate, blasting the frontrunner for hiring foreigners and challenging his commitment to conservative principles.

site_title: US judge gives Volkswagen a month to present diesel fix plan
summary: A US judge has given Volkswagen one month to present a plan to fix diesel engine cars secretly outfitted with pollution cheat devices. District Judge Charles Breyer set a March 24th court date for Volkswagen and the US Environmental Protection Agency to present the plan. The judge urged the parties to achieve a resolution within the parameters set by the EPA, technologically feasible and acceptable to them.

site_title: Expansive policies may have laid foundation of next crisis: German finance minister
summary: Germany's Minister of Finance Wolfgang Schaeuble stated that expansive fiscal and monetary policies may have laid the foundation of the next economic crisis. These debt-financed policies were moderately successful in promoting growth but have led to high public and private debt levels. Schaeuble emphasized that there are no shortcuts to real economic growth and that reforms are necessary. He also expressed disagreement with a proposed G-20 fiscal stimulus package, citing concerns over raising debt, causing bubbles, and excessive risk-taking. The debt-financed growth model has reached its limits, according to Schaeuble.

images.alt_text: Germany's Minister of Finance Wolfgang Schaeuble said on Friday that the expansive fiscal and monetary policies implemented by governments to spur growth might have laid the foundation of the next economic crisis.

site_title: Oil falls on profit-taking after output cap hopes drive rally
summary: Oil prices dropped in Asia on Friday as traders took profits from a recent rally, driven by hopes of output cap agreements among major producers in March. A rally on Thursday was fueled by Venezuelan oil minister Eulogio Del Pino's statement and US durable goods orders data showing an improved economic outlook.

site_title: Median monthly household income from work in 2015 up 4.9% on year in Singapore
summary: Singapore's median monthly household income from work rose 4.9% in real terms to S$8,666 in 2015, driven by a tight labour market and increased employer CPF contributions. The lowest 20% households experienced the fastest real income growth, with 10.7% and 8.3% growth respectively. The Gini coefficient, a measure of income inequality, was 0.463 in 2015, similar to the previous year, and fell to 0.410 after adjusting for government transfers and taxes.

site_title: Asia: Shares inch ahead as G-20 talks, oil holds gains
summary: Asian shares rose on Friday as G-20 talks provided reassuring comments, but little policy stimulus. China's central bank chief said Beijing had room to support its economy, while German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble declared that global monetary and fiscal policy was exhausted. Oil prices held gains, with US crude rising 17 cents to $32.90 a barrel. Asian stocks added 0.7-1.2% and the S&P 500 rose 1.14% on data showing a 4.9% rebound in US durable goods orders. Despite the gains, analysts see little reason for a coordinated stimulus program to be agreed upon.

site_title: Business receipts of Singapore's services sector flat in Q4 2015
summary: Business receipts for Singapore's services sector were flat in Q4 2015, posting a 0.2% year-on-year increase. However, Q4 business receipts rose 3.2% from Q3. Growth was seen in health & social services (6.6%), financial & insurance (3.5%), information & communications (2.5%), and education (1.5%) segments. Declines were recorded in recreation & personal services (7%), business services (2.8%), and transport & storage (0.2%). The data excluded wholesale & retail trade, and accommodation & food services.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won tentative as focus turns to G-20 meeting
summary: South Korean stocks and the won remained steady early Friday as traders awaited the outcome of the G-20 meeting of finance and central bank chiefs. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rose 0.3% to 1,923.56 points, with smaller companies dominating activity. The won was also up 0.3% at 1,234.6 per dollar. The G-20 meeting aims to address a depressed global growth outlook, with policy makers seeking to boost markets despite caution.

site_title: Thai Nok Air posts 2015 net loss, hit by pilot shortage and loss at JV
summary: Thai budget carrier Nok Air reported a net loss of 726 million baht (S$28.5 million) in 2015, its second consecutive loss, due to fierce competition, pilot shortage, and losses at its joint venture NokScoot. The airline carried 7.95 million passengers in 2015, but its market share fell to 26.26% due to intense pricing competition. Nok Air's revenue per passenger decreased 6.64% to 2.11 baht per seat per kilometre. The airline's shares have fallen nearly half over the past year.

site_title: China central bank chief seeks to reassure on yuan, growth
summary: China's central bank chief, Zhou Xiaochuan, reassured the public that the yuan's depreciation is not justified, citing the country's strong economic fundamentals. The yuan fell 1.4% in January and nearly 5% in mid-August, prompting concerns of a currency war. However, Zhou stated that the market volatility will give way to economic fundamentals, and Beijing has room to boost the economy. China's economy grew 6.9% last year, and the central bank has taken steps to boost growth, including interest rate cuts and targeted spending increases.

site_title: Gold rises despite equity gains on bullish technicals, fund flows
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,236.60 an ounce, driven by bullish technicals and fund flows into exchange-traded funds. Despite a rebound in stocks, gold maintained support from investors seeking safe-haven assets amid economic concerns. The 16.5% rally this year has been fueled by safe-haven bids, and the recent "golden cross" technical formation suggests a bullish buy signal for technical traders. Meanwhile, platinum and palladium declined, with platinum near a two-week low due to its industrial usage.

images.alt_text: Gold edged higher on Friday despite a rebound in stocks, underscoring support for the safe-haven metal from bullish technicals and money flows into exchange traded funds.

site_title: China central bank head says China has more room to support economy
summary: China's central bank governor Zhou Xiaochuan stated that the country has more room to support its economy, which is facing downward pressure. He also emphasized that fiscal policy will be more proactive and that the yuan's depreciation is not justified. The direction of China's reforms will not change, but the pace might accelerate. Zhou attributed no basis for persistent yuan depreciation.

images.alt_text: China still has more room and tools in its monetary policy to tackle downward pressure in the economy, and its fiscal policy will be more proactive, central bank governor Zhou Xiaochuan said on Friday.

site_title: Japan inflation falls back to zero in January: govt
summary: Japan's inflation rate fell to zero in January, according to government data, marking another challenge for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" policies. The 0.1% growth in core consumer prices was unchanged from the previous month, and further price weakness is expected due to falling oil prices and a strong yen. The Bank of Japan has introduced a negative interest rate to boost lending, but its impact is uncertain, and the target inflation rate of 2.0% may not be reached until next year.

site_title: Australia to hike tax on backpacker workers, may hit Asian exports
summary: Australia plans to increase taxes on foreign workers on working holiday visas from 0% to 32.5% on earnings above A$18,000, potentially affecting the country's supply of labor for fruit harvests and impacting its goal of becoming Asia's delicatessen. The move is estimated to net A$540 million between 2016 and 2020 and may deter backpackers from working, as one traveler plans to leave due to the higher tax. The decision could also affect the country's A$34.8 billion international tourism industry.

images.alt_text: Australia is set to increase taxes on foreign travellers who work in the country, raising concerns from farmers that their supply of "backpacker labour"at harvest times may dry up and undermine Australia's ambitions of being Asia's delicatessen.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares steady as banks rebound
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares remained steady by midday Friday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising half a point to 4,881.70. Banks rebounded, with top four banks up 0.3-0.9% and Woolworths recouping early losses to shore up the market. Mining stocks fell after iron ore and copper prices dropped, with BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto down 2.5% and 3%, respectively.

site_title: Germans talk tough, fete Facebook's Zuckerberg
summary: Prominent Germans expressed mixed views on Facebook during a visit by CEO Mark Zuckerberg, despite criticizing the company's data protection and hate speech record. Zuckerberg met with Chancellor Angela Merkel's chief of staff and received an award, but avoided discussing sensitive topics. Critics, such as Austrian law student Max Schrems, contrasted the US approach to European governments' "negotiations" on data protection. Zuckerberg's charm offensive aims to address concerns, but he may face tougher questions at a town hall meeting on Friday.

site_title: JC Penney's quarterly sales rise due to higher Home, Sephora sales
summary: JC Penney Co Inc reported a 2.5% increase in quarterly revenue to US$4 billion, driven by strong sales in its Home and Sephora divisions. Same-store sales rose 4.1%, beating analyst expectations. The company expects 2016 comparable sales to increase 3-4% and adjusted earnings to be positive. Despite a loss of US$131 million, shares rose 25.5% to US$8.36, driven by the company's positive outlook.

site_title: UK consumers least confident in over a year on economic uncertainties
summary: British consumer morale reached its lowest level in over a year in February, falling to 0 from +4 in January, according to a survey by market research firm GfK. Concerns over economic uncertainties, including a potential Brexit, and a darkening global economic outlook contributed to the decline. The survey also found that households are downbeat about the economy's prospects for the next 12 months, with a measure of economic optimism declining to -12 from -5. Economists warn that a British exit from the EU could have negative implications for the economy.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday before G-20 meeting
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened at 2,625.13 points, up 21.73 points or 0.83% on Friday ahead of the G-20 meeting in Shanghai. The index saw 75 million shares worth S$90.6 million change hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 102 to 37. Top stocks included Jardine Matheson, Singtel, and DBS.

site_title: SGX submits non-binding bid to buy Baltic Exchange
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has submitted a non-binding bid to acquire The Baltic Exchange, a maritime market information provider. The bid aims to boost Singapore's role as a maritime hub and strengthen SGX's freight derivatives business. Discussions are preliminary, and no certainty exists that the transaction will materialize. Other parties, including CME Group, ICE, and Platts, have also held talks on a potential deal. SGX's shares last traded at S$7.01.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, SGX, ST Engineering, Jardine C&C
summary: Noble Group recorded its first annual loss in nearly two decades with a US$1.67 billion loss in 2015 due to an impairment charge. Singapore Exchange (SGX) submitted a non-binding bid to buy The Baltic Exchange. ST Engineering's net profit decreased 0.5% to S$529.0 million, while Jardine Cycle & Carriage's net profit dropped 16% to US$688 million.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, rising 6.87 points to 1664.84. The market saw 50.1 million lots traded worth RM20.6 million, with 132 gainers outnumbering 54 losers.

site_title: China: Stocks gain as central bank head reassures on economy
summary: Chinese stocks rose on Friday, with the Shanghai Composite Index gaining 0.69% and the Shenzhen Composite Index adding 0.68% after the head of the central bank reassured investors about the economy. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 1.87% in opening deals. The gains came after the previous day's heavy losses, which saw the Shanghai Composite Index fall over six percent. The central bank head's comments aimed to boost confidence in the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Fifa to pick post-Blatter leader in bid to end to crisis
summary: Fifa members have elected a new president in a bid to end the crisis following the downfall of Sepp Blatter, with Sheikh Salman bin Ebrahim Al Khalifa and Gianni Infantino competing in the Asia v Europe battle. The new president will aim to implement reforms, including a 12-year-term limit and increased funding for national associations, in a bid to restore credibility to the organization. However, experts say that corruption investigations will continue regardless of the outcome, and the result of the vote is uncertain, with Prince Ali bin al Hussein also in the running.

site_title: OECD calls for reforms to wake up growth
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has called for governments to implement reforms to boost economic growth, citing "clouded" global growth prospects. The recommended reforms include promoting entrepreneurship, labor mobility, and higher productivity, as well as easing access to services and improving health and pension benefits. The OECD notes that some reforms can be implemented quickly and with minimal upfront investment, but many require significant upfront investment, which may be challenging for governments with tight budgets.

site_title: Keppel Land sells two property companies in Sri Lanka, Vietnam
summary: Keppel Land, a subsidiary of Keppel Corp, has sold its stakes in two property companies in Sri Lanka and Vietnam. It sold a 60% interest in Keppel CT Developments Pte Ltd for S$5.5 million and its shares in Fernland Investment Pte Ltd for US$10.86 million. The transactions are expected to have no material impact on Keppel Corp's earnings per share and net tangible asset per share for the current financial year, as part of efforts to strengthen its presence in core markets and recycle assets for higher returns.

site_title: Pfizer seen avoiding US$35b in tax via Allergan merger
summary: Pfizer Inc is set to permanently avoid paying $35 billion in US taxes after merging with Allergan Plc, according to a report by Americans for Tax Fairness. The merger, valued at $160 billion, will move the company's tax address to Ireland and allow it to access $140 billion in foreign earnings tax-free. However, a tax consultant has described the figure as "a little misleading," as Pfizer may still owe some US taxes, and the main benefit of the deal is Pfizer's access to foreign earnings for loans among affiliated companies.

site_title: Revenue chasm widens between Singapore's large corporates and SMEs
summary: Singapore's top 1,000 companies have reached a combined revenue of S$3 trillion, a 50% increase from S$2 trillion three years ago, driven by strong performance in the commerce-wholesale, transport/storage, and information and communications sectors. In contrast, the top 1,000 small and medium enterprises (SMEs) saw a 2.9% year-on-year rise in revenue to S$29.2 billion, but combined profits fell 1.6% to S$3.3 billion. The SME sector faces challenges with high business costs and growing competition, with finance and property firms experiencing significant declines in average profits.

site_title: US dollar little changed in steady forex market
summary: The US dollar remained largely unchanged in a steady foreign exchange market, despite a slight decline against the euro. A pair of solid US economic reports, including a 4.9% jump in durable goods orders, contributed to the improved sentiment. However, a potential downward revision to the US GDP growth rate for the 2015 fourth quarter could pose headwinds for the dollar and the Federal Reserve's interest rate plans. Analysts expect the central bank to adopt a wait-and-see approach in 2016.

site_title: ST Engineering's FY2015 net profit slips 0.5%, expects comparable 2016 pre-tax profit
summary: ST Engineering reported a 0.5% decrease in FY2015 net profit to S$529.0 million, with revenue falling 3.1% to S$6.3 billion. The electronics sector contributed to the growth, while the marine sector faced weaker results. The company expects comparable 2016 pre-tax profit despite higher revenue. ST Engineering's order book stood at S$11.7 billion, and its cash reserves were S$1.4 billion. A final dividend of 10.0 Singapore cents a share was recommended for FY2015.

site_title: China securities regulator says no change to ChiNext listings
summary: China's securities regulator clarified that there will be no change to the ChiNext listing process, contrary to speculation that a new registration system would be introduced. The ChiNext board, a Nasdaq-style market, will continue to use a regulator-approved listing process. The move came after the main Shanghai Composite Index slid 6.4% on Thursday due to rumors about the ChiNext market and investors booking profits after the market's recent rebound. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) strongly condemned the rumors as irresponsible and false.

site_title: New Zealand, Australia dollars near 8-week peaks on data, better sentiment
summary: The New Zealand and Australian dollars surged to near eight-week highs on Friday, driven by upbeat data and improving risk sentiment. The New Zealand dollar jumped 0.6% to an eight-week peak of US$0.6775, while the Australian dollar rose to US$0.7248, near its peak. The gains were fueled by a surprise monthly trade surplus in New Zealand and a rebound in oil prices, sparking a risk rally. The Aussie is on track for a weekly increase of 1.3%, its third week of gains, with economists predicting no rate change from the Reserve Bank of Australia on March 1.

site_title: Goldcorp posts bigger quarterly loss on US$3.9b charge
summary: Goldcorp Inc reported a quarterly loss of US$4.27 billion, or US$5.14 per share, due to a US$3.9 billion charge. The company's adjusted loss more than doubled to US$128 million, or 15 cents per share. Gold production increased to 909,400 ounces in the quarter. This is the second consecutive quarter the company has cut its annual dividend.

site_title: Sapphire posts 2015 profit of S$6.5m, boosted by Ranken acquisition
summary: Sapphire Corporation reported a 2015 net profit of S$6.5 million, up from S$138,000 the previous year, driven by the acquisition of China's Ranken Infrastructure. Revenue doubled to S$116.4 million. The company sold its steel business and plans to scale up Ranken's production capacity for civil engineering projects. No dividend was declared, and the company's share price is S$0.099.

site_title: Industry group sees no abuse in energy markets; US lawmakers howl
summary: US industry group says speculation in energy markets is not abusive, contradicting lawmakers' concerns. The Energy and Environmental Markets Advisory Committee, created under the Dodd-Frank reform legislation, told the Commodity Futures Trading Commission that limiting speculation would harm investors. However, some lawmakers, including Senator Elizabeth Warren, argue that the committee's findings are biased and that the CFTC should implement regulations to control market abuse. CFTC Chairman Timothy Massad remains skeptical, saying the plan is a solution to a non-existent problem.

site_title: Japan January core CPI flat, keeps BOJ under pressure
summary: Japan's core consumer prices remained unchanged in January from a year earlier, indicating persistent falls in energy costs will keep inflation below the central bank's 2% target. This challenges the Bank of Japan's efforts to generate a positive cycle of rising corporate profits driving up wages and consumption. Despite adopting negative interest rates last month, the central bank expects inflation to hit 2% around mid-2017, a projection deemed too optimistic by many analysts.

site_title: Google, Facebook, others plan briefs supporting Apple in iPhone case
summary: Google, Facebook, Microsoft, and Twitter plan to file or sign on to amicus briefs supporting Apple's fight against a magistrate's order requiring it to help the US Federal Bureau of Investigation break into a San Bernardino shooter's iPhone. The briefs aim to protect Apple's right to refuse government requests to access encrypted data. The filings are expected to argue that forcing Apple to assist in the iPhone hack would set a dangerous precedent for user data security. The move is seen as a significant development in the ongoing debate over encryption and government access to digital data.

site_title: US: Wall Street rallies as battered investors eye support
summary: US stocks rallied on Thursday, driven by higher oil prices and a 3% jump in the S&P 500, which surpassed its 50-day moving average for the first time this year. The financial sector led gains, up 1.38%, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.87%. Orders for US durable goods rose more than expected, offering hope for the manufacturing sector. Shares of Salesforce.com and Sturm Ruger & Co surged, while Microsoft and Kraft Heinz Co also gained. Despite the rally, the S&P 500 remains down 5% in 2016.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 1.06% higher on weaker yen, Wall St gains
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.06% on Friday, driven by a weaker yen, boosting exporters. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index reached 16,311.52, while the Topix index climbed 0.96%. The gains followed a Wall Street rally on stronger oil prices, lifting investor sentiment.

site_title: China to secure 'de facto' control of South China Sea: US admiral
summary: US Admiral Harry Harris warns that China is securing "de facto" control of the South China Sea through military build-up, including air bases, hardened bunkers, and radar systems on reclaimed islands. China's claims to the South China Sea are disputed, and the region is a potential flashpoint. The US plans to increase "freedom of navigation" operations to rebut China's assertions of sovereignty, with defense secretary Ashton Carter noting that regional neighbors are responding by strengthening their maritime defenses and aligning themselves with the US.

site_title: Europe: Shares end higher helped by strong earning updates
summary: European shares rebounded 2% on Thursday, lifting the FTSEurofirst 300 index to 1,284.58 points, after strong corporate results from banks Lloyds and AXA, and refinancing plans from Seadrill and Deutsche Telekom. This rebound comes despite concerns about a slowing global economy and Europe's banking sector. The FTSEurofirst remains 10% weaker since the start of 2016. The G-20 meeting in Shanghai this weekend is expected to have little impact on markets.

site_title: Apple asks to block court order to help decrypt iPhone
summary: The US government has requested a federal court to force Apple to help unlock an iPhone used by one of the San Bernardino attackers. Apple has responded by asking the court to dismiss the order, citing its constitutional rights to free speech and the potential vulnerability of user data. The company argues that creating a backdoor to access the device would weaken its security and undermine its values. Apple's lawyers claim that no court has authorized such an action and that the government's request exceeds its legal authority.

site_title: Herbalife says it is in talks with FTC; outcome uncertain
summary: Herbalife Ltd is in talks with the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) regarding a probe into its business practices, sparked by allegations of a fraudulent model compared to a pyramid scheme by hedge fund manager William Ackman. The company has denied the allegations and said the outcome of the talks is uncertain, with possible outcomes including a contested civil complaint, settlement, or closure without action. Herbalife exclusively sells products through independent distributors, who also earn commissions. The outcome of the talks has not been estimated, and the company is unable to estimate potential losses.

images.alt_text: Herbalife Ltd is in talks with government regulators regarding a probe of the company's business practices and said that the outcome of the talks was uncertain, the company said in a filing on Thursday.

site_title: Japan builds US$124 billion cash hoard even as it cuts treasuries
summary: Japan has built a record $124.1 billion cash hoard at overseas institutions, as part of its foreign-exchange reserves, after selling US Treasuries. This shift aims to protect Japan's reserves from potential losses due to rising US interest rates and declining bond-market liquidity. The move coincides with a surge in dollar holdings by global central banks, including the US Federal Reserve. By holding more cash, Japan is positioning itself for a stronger currency and benefiting from higher US interest rates. This change in reserve composition is a response to declining liquidity in the Treasury market.

images.alt_text: Japan has stockpiled a record amount of cash at central banks as part of its currency reserves, after selling Treasuries, as policy makers around the world adjust to rising US interest rates and falling bond-market liquidity.

site_title: Brazil unemployment reaches 7.6% in January
summary: Brazil's unemployment rate reached 7.6% in January, the highest since 2009, according to government figures. This marks a significant increase from the previous month, with 1.9 million people without a job. The country's economy is struggling with a double-digit inflation rate and a growing fiscal deficit, and has been crippled by gridlock in Congress and a protracted battle to impeach President Dilma Rousseff. Moody's cut Brazil's credit rating to junk, citing low growth, worsening debt, and challenging politics.

site_title: Google delivers 'blazingly fast' news to smartphones
summary: Google has launched its Accelerated Mobile Pages (AMP) project, delivering "blazingly fast" articles to smartphones and tablets, challenging Facebook's Instant Articles and Apple News. AMP loads mobile Web pages an average of four times faster than the current norm, using 10 times less data. The technology, launched with hundreds of partners, aims to improve the mobile Web experience and protect publishers from DDoS attacks with "Project Shield", offering the service for free. This move follows Facebook's expansion of its Instant Articles program and Apple's launch of its Apple News application.

site_title: Aztech sinks into the red in Q4
summary: Aztech Group, a diversified electronics-based company, reported a net loss of S$12.4 million in Q4 2015, down from a net profit of S$280,000 in the same period last year. The full-year loss was S$20 million, driven by an impairment provision charge and unrealised mark-to-market losses. Revenue fell 4.8% to S$73.6 million in Q4 and 3.2% to S$318.9 million for the year. The company expects a "challenging business environment" in 2016.

images.alt_text: Diversified electronics-based Aztech Group has sunk into the red, with a net loss of S$12.4 million for the quarter ended Dec 31, 2015, compared to a net profit of S$280,000 a year ago.

site_title: Indofood Agri Q4 net profit down 22.5% to 174.6b rupiah
summary: Indofood Agri Resources reported a net profit of 174.6 billion rupiah, down 22.5% from the previous year, due to lower sales from its plantations and edible oils and fats divisions. Revenue fell 10% to 3.78 trillion rupiah. The company also recorded a 19.9 billion rupiah loss from changes in fair value of biological assets. For the full year, net profit was down 92.4% to 57.9 billion rupiah. A first and final dividend was declared but details will be announced in March.

site_title: First cargo of US shale gas makes its way to Brazil
summary: The US has shipped its first cargo of shale gas to Brazil, with the liquefied natural gas tanker Asia Vision departing Cheniere Energy Inc's Sabine Pass export terminal in Louisiana.
