The cargo, carrying 3 billion cubic feet, is bound for Brazil amid low crude prices and a global LNG market supply glut. The shipment is expected to make the US a net natural gas exporter in the coming years, with Cheniere's Sabine Pass plant chilling gas into a liquid for export.

site_title: Latest Europe bank stress test to determine resilience
summary: European regulators unveiled the latest stress test for the region's banks, measuring their resilience to a financial crisis or economic downturn. Unlike previous tests, this year's won't have a minimum capital threshold, so no bank can "pass" or "fail." Instead, local supervisors will assess the results to determine if banks need to raise capital. 51 European banks, representing 70% of the industry, will be examined, with results due in the third quarter. The test aims to provide a common framework for comparing bank resilience to economic shocks, amid declining investor confidence and high non-performing loans.

site_title: Embraer extends range of biggest commercial jet
summary: Embraer has extended the range of its E-Jet commercial aircraft to 2,450 nautical miles with the introduction of the E195-E2, surpassing Bombardier's C-Series with a maximum range of 3,100 nautical miles. The new aircraft will have three more rows of seats and increased fuel capacity, putting it in direct competition with Bombardier's C-Series. Embraer's approach is a gradual expansion into the over-100-seat segment, with the E190-E2 and E195-E2 set to enter service in 2019 and 2020, respectively.

images.alt_text: Brazilian planemaker Embraer SA will extend the range of its biggest commercial aircraft, executives said on Thursday as they rolled out the first of the re-engined E-Jet planes to compete with Bombardier Inc's new C-Series.

site_title: Biden slams Trump's 'dangerous' anti-Mexico rhetoric
summary: US Vice President Joe Biden criticized Donald Trump's "dangerous" anti-Mexico rhetoric, stating it is "disturbing" but will pass. Biden's comments came during a visit to Mexico, where he addressed the country's foreign and finance ministers. Trump has been at odds with Mexico over his proposal to build a wall and pay for it, as well as his comments on immigration. Biden emphasized that the American people do not support such rhetoric, and that episodes of xenophobia have always been overcome.

site_title: Major shareholder to take Xinren private in S$780m offer
summary: Xinren Aluminum Holdings has received a S$780 million takeover offer from major shareholder Merit Stand Inc, who will acquire the company at S$0.60 per share, a 25% premium over the last traded price. The buyer intends to delist the company. Xinren's major shareholder, the Zeng family, controls 75% of the company, with Zeng Chaoyi owning part of Sunshine International Global Capital. The offer provides shareholders with a cash exit opportunity.

site_title: SIAC's case volumes hit new peaks in 2015
summary: The Singapore International Arbitration Centre (SIAC) reported a 22% increase in new cases filed in 2015, reaching 271 cases from 55 jurisdictions. The centre administered 244 cases, a new high, and saw a 84% rise in international cases. The total sum in dispute grew 24% to S$6.23 billion, with trade disputes being the most common. SIAC's active caseload is about 600 cases, and the centre has opened its third overseas office in Shanghai.

site_title: Durable goods orders rebound strongly in January
summary: US durable goods orders surged 4.9% in January, the largest gain in 10 months, reversing a 4.6% decline in December. Non-defence capital goods orders rose 3.9%, and manufacturing output and payrolls increased, suggesting the manufacturing downturn may be over. However, the sector remains constrained by a strong US dollar, weak global demand, and capital spending cuts.

site_title: Oil jumps after Venezuela renews hope for output limit
summary: Oil prices rose for a second consecutive day, with the US benchmark West Texas Intermediate increasing 92 cents to $33.07 a barrel, and Brent North Sea crude rising 88 cents to $35.29 a barrel. The gains came after Venezuela's oil minister announced that the country would meet with other producers in March to discuss stabilizing the market, potentially leading to a production freeze. The market is awaiting a decision on the freeze, with some traders skeptical of its feasibility, while others see it as a positive sign for prices.

site_title: Coffee may perk up as Brazil drought hurts robusta crop
summary: Brazil's drought-stricken robusta coffee crop, the world's second-largest, is expected to worsen, potentially sparking price support. Drier-than-normal weather in Espirito Santo, the country's biggest robusta producer, may cause beans to drop from trees, making plants more susceptible to disease. This could lead to a smaller harvest, contradicting earlier speculation of a bumper harvest. Robusta futures are expected to rise due to the curb on Brazilian supplies, while Vietnamese coffee exports are expected to offset the drop in Brazilian production.

site_title: City buzz
summary: The Effect, a play by Lucy Prebble, explores the impact of psychiatric medication on emotions and interactions, starring Nikki Muller and Linden Furnell as human guinea pigs in a drugs trial lab. Meanwhile, Chef Drew Nocente introduces a new brunch service at 5th Quarter Cava, featuring unlimited helpings of savory dishes and desserts. Local artist Jahan Loh's pop-up studio and solo art exhibition, B-Side and Rarities, showcases his artistic mediums and influences. The Hong Kong Sinfonietta performs a unique version of Stravinsky's The Soldier's Tale, while the Philharmonic Chamber Winds presents an exploration of harmoniemusik with conductor Joost Flach.

images.alt_text: (From left) Pang, Furnell, Muller and Tan in Pangdemonium's The Effect. The play tackles the timely topic of psychopharmacology.
Dishes worth a second order include the pork hash with poached egg (above).
Loh's Agent G (2009). He can create masterpieces using a variety of mediums in more than one style.
Savage Land
Concert: The Hong Kong Sinfonietta's A Soldier's Story - The New Generation
Concert: Philharmonic Chamber Winds presents Art of Harmoniemusik

site_title: Cheeky show where the audience get their kicks
summary: Eric Khoo's omnibus erotica "In the Room" premiered, featuring six sex stories and real-life Japanese adult film star Show Nishino. The film, set in a fictional hotel room, interweaves decades-spanning storylines, including illicit affairs and lost loves. While some stories excel, others feel formulaic. The film's bold and cheeky tone, re-edited to tone down explicit content, pays homage to late writer-musician Damien Sin. The film has received a B+ rating, marking a departure from Khoo's usual arthouse style and his most accessible work to date.

images.alt_text: Pussy Power, starring Josie Ho (in black), is a standout for its comic energy and ability to be naughty yet nice.

site_title: Radical thinking needed from G-20 finance chiefs in Shanghai
summary: G-20 finance chiefs are expected to address the global economic concerns and financial market volatility in Shanghai. The meeting comes as neither the global economy nor financial markets are in good shape, with currencies swinging violently and trade and investment affected. China's Finance Minister Lou Jiwei is expected to stress the potential of "innovation" as a means to raise global productivity. The G-20 needs to come up with new thinking on how to finance and facilitate growth, as well as calm markets, by pooling foreign-exchange reserves and re-examining central bank independence and quantitative easing.

site_title: India has the chance to be startup hub of the world
summary: India is poised to become a global startup hub, driven by its fast-growing economy, investor confidence, and reduction in red tape. The country received $16.63 billion in foreign direct investments in the first half of FY2015-16, and initiatives such as Make in India, Digital India, and Start-up India are expected to transform rural and urban infrastructure. The government aims to strike a balance between growth and macro stability, with a focus on technology, infrastructure, and corporate tax reforms.

site_title: Sugar tax for better health - are we ready to bell the cat?
summary: Singapore may consider implementing a sugar tax to curb obesity and diabetes rates, following the success of other countries such as Mexico and France. The tax would target sweetened beverages and snacks sold in Singapore, aiming to reduce consumption and encourage healthier choices. A study by the American Cancer Society found that taxation on sugary fizzy drinks helps fight obesity, but implementing a sugar tax requires careful consideration of factors such as tax rate, impact on cross-border shopping, and education programs to support a healthy lifestyle.

site_title: Beijing beats New York as world billionaire capital
summary: Beijing has surpassed New York City as the "billionaire capital of the world" with 100 resident billionaires, according to a survey by the Hurun Report. The number of Beijing billionaires rose by 32 from last year, while New York's tally rose by just four. China's 568 billionaires now have a combined net worth of US$1.4 trillion, surpassing the US's 535 billionaires.

site_title: Suggestions to spice up the Oscars
summary: The Oscars ceremony has been criticized for its lengthy duration and lack of engagement from viewers. To address this, publicists, agents, and producers suggest cutting unnecessary awards, incorporating red carpet festivities into the ceremony, and making the show more interactive by involving viewers at home. Other ideas include changing the best-picture presentation, eliminating finalists throughout the show, and incorporating more music performances. Some also propose changing the show's format, such as having a voice-over host or a live audience vote for winners.

site_title: McKinsey report ranks Singapore as world's most connected country
summary: Singapore has been ranked as the world's most connected country by McKinsey Global Institute, according to the Connected Index rankings. The country has retained its position as one of eight truly "global cities" and has been a leader in digital connectivity, with 87% of households having broadband access in 2014. The report highlights Singapore's strategic efforts to become more globally connected, including investments in digital infrastructure and tax policies to attract foreign direct investments. The country's growth will increasingly come from digital connectivity, and its workforce needs to develop the baseline knowledge to apply and harness digital technologies.

site_title: Questions for the Facebook generation
summary: Actor Brian Lobel performed a live show in London and Finland, where he asked strangers to decide whether he should unfriend them on Facebook. He had 1,000 friends and ultimately removed about 16% of them, with the help of audience feedback. The show, "Purge," aims to encourage critical thinking about social media relationships and the consequences of unfriending. Lobel's experience was triggered by the sudden death of his first boyfriend and led him to re-examine his own Facebook friend list. The show is now an interactive lecture/game show that Lobel will perform in Singapore.

images.alt_text: To friend, or not to friend, that is the question actor Brian Lobel asks audience members

site_title: Germany warns against easy-money policies
summary: Germany's Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble has warned of the dangers of easy monetary policies, urging countries not to use foreign-exchange rates to create growth. He expressed concerns about Japan's efforts to boost its economy through monetary policy, calling for more sustainable growth without piling up new debt. The warning comes ahead of a G-20 meeting in Shanghai, where Japan has appealed for support on market intervention to quell exchange-rate volatility.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2016: Tax moves to boost the S-Reit market
summary: Singapore's S-Reit market has been dampened by rising interest rates, stockmarket volatility, and economic slowdown. To boost the market, the government could review and extend tax-related policies, such as the sunset clause for concessionary tax rates and foreign-sourced income tax exemption. The government could also promote tax transparency by allowing S-Reits to hold Singapore properties through corporate vehicles without compromising tax transparency treatment. Additionally, upfront tax certainty is crucial for S-Reits, and the government could extend tax transparency treatment to cover other Singapore-sourced income.

site_title: IHH Healthcare posts higher net profit on exceptional gains
summary: IHH Healthcare Berhad, the world's second-largest listed private healthcare provider, reported a 74% jump in net profit for the fourth quarter of 2015 to RM415.8 million, driven by exceptional gains including revaluation, tax allowances, and exchange gains. Revenue grew 18% to RM2.3 billion, and full-year net profit increased 24% to RM933.9 million. The group declared a first and final dividend of 3 sen per share for the full year, with its operating subsidiaries also reporting strong growth. IHH expects to face headwinds from slowing economies, but remains confident in the robust demand for quality private healthcare services in India and China.

images.alt_text: MD and CEO Mr Tan noted that the IHH group has undertaken transformational acquisitions.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage reported a 16% drop in net profit to US$688 million in 2015, mainly due to lower profit from its Astra automotive company. Haw Par Corp's net profit rose 54.2% to S$183.3 million, driven by its healthcare business and sale of a Chinese unit. The Straits Trading Co posted a 69.3% drop in fourth-quarter net profit, while First Resources reported a 67% drop in fourth-quarter net profit due to lower palm oil prices.

site_title: For movie-lovers, it was a very good year
summary: The 88th Annual Academy Awards are set to take place, with a diverse lineup of nominees for Best Picture, including "The Revenant," "Spotlight," and "The Big Short." Despite a lack of diversity among nominees, the Academy has announced plans to increase diversity among its governing board and membership. Host Chris Rock is expected to crack jokes about the issue. Leonardo DiCaprio is a lock to win Best Actor for "The Revenant," while Alejandro G. Inarritu is favored to win Best Director for the same film. The ceremony will also see Brie Larson secure the Best Actress award, and Sylvester Stallone is in line to win for his role in "Creed."

images.alt_text: DiCaprio is a lock to win Best Actor for The Revenant, a brutal tale of endurance in the Old West where he really, really suffered for his art. The movie also has a decent chance of snagging Best Picture.

site_title: Banyan Tree records worst full-year loss ever
summary: Banyan Tree, a Singapore-based resort group, recorded its worst full-year loss in history, with a net loss of S$27.52 million, despite a 34% surge in revenue to S$123.16 million. The loss was attributed to a "perfect storm" of factors, including lower hotel bookings, fee-based businesses, and higher costs. The group's executive chairman, Ho Kwon Ping, warned that this year will be challenging due to softer demand from the Chinese and Russian markets. Banyan Tree is streamlining its business and reviewing its structure amid the global economic slowdown.

site_title: A daringly-different take on the Holocaust
summary: Hungarian director Laszlo Nemes' debut film "Son of Saul" tells a gripping, differing take on the Holocaust through the story of Saul Auslander, a Sonderkommando at Auschwitz-Birkenau concentration camp. Saul, forced to shepherd victims to the gas chamber, finds a sense of purpose in saving a young boy's life. The film, based on Sonderkommando survivor testimonials, is fast-paced and purposeful, using a first-person perspective to convey Saul's emotional numbness and desperation. The movie elicits powerful emotions and poignant moments, despite its dark subject matter, and raises questions about the perpetrators and victims of the Holocaust.

site_title: Airbnb removed 622 hosts in NY City before public scrutiny
summary: Airbnb removed 622 hosts in New York City before releasing data on its business in the city, as part of an effort to portray a more positive picture of its operations. The company initially kicked off 1,500 listings, which accounted for about 4% of listings in the city, in November. The removed listings included those controlled by full-time landlords, and Airbnb claimed they did not reflect the company's vision for the community. The move came as the company faced criticism over becoming a platform for unregulated hotels and driving up housing prices.

site_title: Salesforce quarterly revenue beats Wall Street expectations
summary: Salesforce reported higher-than-expected quarterly revenue, beating Wall Street expectations. The company raised its full-year revenue forecast, citing customers stepping up purchases of its web-based sales and marketing software despite economic uncertainty. Salesforce's shares rose 7.2% to $67, and the company's earnings were seen as a positive indicator for the cloud-computing sector. Revenue from its sales cloud suite increased 12.3% to $708.9 million, and the net loss narrowed to $25.5 million.

site_title: KrisEnergy trims loss to US$41m, writes down Thai assets
summary: KrisEnergy, an Asian oil and gas explorer, reported a net loss of US$41.7 million for 2015, down from US$50.4 million the previous year. The company wrote down its Thai assets due to low oil prices and reduced capital expenditure to US$50.8 million in 2016, the lowest level since 2009. Despite a 27% increase in production volumes, revenue fell to US$60.2 million due to lower sales of crude oil and gas, averaging US$40 a barrel. The company's proved plus probable reserves rose 49% to 106 million barrels of oil equivalent.

site_title: China to agree to 50b yuan of bad loan securitisation: sources
summary: China's government has agreed to allow domestic banks to issue up to 50 billion yuan (S$10.7 billion) of asset-backed securities based on non-performing loans, the first quota since 2008. This move aims to help banks clear their books and free up capital for the slowing economy. The quota, mainly allocated to China's largest banks, will enable lenders to remove NPLs from their balance sheets, potentially removing 100-150 billion yuan of distressed loans.

site_title: MH370 lawsuits gain pace as 2-year deadline nears
summary: Relatives of 239 people on board the missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 are filing lawsuits as a two-year deadline approaches on March 8, seeking damages from the airline's insurer, Allianz. Lawsuits are also planned against Malaysia's civil aviation authorities, military, and aircraft manufacturer Boeing, potentially resulting in hundreds of millions of dollars in payouts. The lawsuits aim to uncover answers about the plane's disappearance and alleged poor response by the airline and authorities, with some seeking compensation for emotional distress and others for the loss of loved ones.

site_title: Maybank turns in 2 per cent higher earnings for FY15
summary: Maybank, Malaysia's largest bank, reported a 2% increase in net profit to RM6.84 billion for FY15, despite setting aside RM2 billion in net impairment losses. The bank's operating profit decreased by 0.1% to RM8.94 billion due to weaker economic conditions and increased volatility. Maybank aims to improve its liquidity and capital positions to weather the economic downturn, with plans to expand loans and deposits by 8-9% and 10-11% respectively. The bank's return on equity was 12.2% and its cost-to-income ratio improved to 48.2%.

site_title: S$556m next-gen ERP system up from 2020
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has announced that the next-generation electronic road pricing (ERP) system will be operational from 2020 at a cost of S$556 million. The system, developed by a consortium of NCS Pte Ltd and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Engine System Asia, will replace the current 17-year-old system and offer more flexibility in managing traffic congestion through distance-based road-pricing. The new system will also collect and disseminate traffic information, manage automatic payments, and provide paperless roadside parking and toll payment options.

site_title: Investments in 'Make in India' plan face challenges
summary: India's "Make in India" programme aims to boost industrial employment to 25% by 2022, but faces challenges due to structural economic impediments. Despite promising foreign investments, opportunities in employment-generating fields like solar energy, textiles, and leather are limited. Major collaborations are in defence production, electronics, and transport, with companies like Saab AB, Boeing, and Vedanta Resources committing significant investments. However, the country's poor economic state, including falling exports and corporate profits, hinders investment growth, with many Indian companies struggling with high debt.

site_title: Airbus delivery goal shows optimism even as Boeing cuts target
summary: Airbus has announced plans to increase its A330 jet production to seven a month in 2017, aiming for over 650 deliveries in 2016, despite Boeing cutting its target. Airbus CEO Tom Enders expressed confidence in the demand for its fuel-efficient jets, citing over-bookings and a relatively slow ramp-up in 2015 for the A350. In contrast, Boeing has reduced its 2016 deliveries due to production shifts on the 737 Max. Airbus's earnings are forecast to be stable this year, with its stock declining 12% in 2016.

site_title: Major firms ink deals to launch new accelerator programmes
summary: Major firms in Singapore's property, power, and psychology sectors have launched new accelerator programs to support startups. AIRmaker, a joint venture between Ascendas-Singbridge, Infocomm Investments, and China's Runyang Group, aims to groom IoT startups for the Singapore and China markets. The Spark Accelerator, a partnership between Singapore Power and Infocomm Investments, will invest up to $4 million in energy efficiency and cybersecurity startups. IBM Watson has also launched a TAG.PASS program to support tech companies developing cognitive-powered apps for Singapore's Smart Nation vision.

site_title: CDL Q4 profit buoyed by asset monetisation
summary: CDL (City Developments Limited) posted a record net profit of S$410.5 million for the fourth quarter of 2015, a 6.6% increase, driven by gains from asset monetization through Profit Participation Securities (PPS) and the sale of Emerald House in the UK. The group's revenue rose 1% to S$855 million, with plans to continue overseas acquisitions, particularly in the UK, China, and Japan. CDL's CEO, Grant Kelley, emphasized the need to diversify and not benchmark against the Singapore domestic market.

site_title: Iran may use Greek facilities to export gas to Europe
summary: Greece is in talks with Iran to secure natural gas for local needs and provide a gateway for Iran to supply fuel to Europe. The deal, agreed in January, could lead to cooperation in the gas market, with Iran potentially using Greek facilities to export gas to Europe. Iran wants to start selling its natural gas in liquefied form using ships, and Greece is considering the Revythousa re-gasification terminal and the planned Alexandroupolis facility as potential entry points. The agreement aims to diversify Greece's energy sources and enhance its role as a regional energy-distribution hub.

site_title: The White House aspirants psychoanalysed
summary: US presidential candidates' psychological traits are being analyzed to predict their foreign policy strategies. Republican candidates, including Donald Trump, Ted Cruz, and Marco Rubio, are characterized as ambitious, dominant, and controlling, with traits that could lead to brinkmanship and aggression. In contrast, Democratic candidates Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders are described as ambitious and self-serving, but also more cautious and diplomatic. The analysis highlights the crucial role of psychology in diplomacy, including the use of nuclear deterrence and personal diplomacy, and notes that the candidates' formative experiences may influence their behavior.

site_title: Foxconn pips Japan state fund to acquire Sharp
summary: Foxconn Technology Group has accepted a majority stake in Sharp Corp, a Japanese electronics giant, after beating out a Japanese government-backed fund. Foxconn will control 65.9% of Sharp after buying stock, with the company accepting an offer worth 700 billion yen (S$6 billion). Sharp's shares slumped 17% after the announcement, following years of on-off talks between the two companies. The deal is seen as a test of Japan's willingness to open its economy and follows Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's appeal for market reforms and overseas investments.

site_title: Sterling up on gains in Europe equities
summary: European equities rose, steadying currency markets, with sterling edging up from lows and the US dollar holding flat. The eurozone's inflation expectations fell to a record low, and traders await the European Central Bank's meeting for further monetary policy easing. The US dollar struggled to make headway despite Federal Reserve speakers later in the day, while oil prices held above $30 a barrel. Sterling rebounded against the dollar, but remains down 3% this week, and analysts recommend the yen and dollar against the pound.

site_title: The new era of digital globalisation
summary: A new era of digital globalization has begun, with Singapore ranking as the world's most connected country according to a McKinsey report. This is attributed to its advanced digital infrastructure, innovative policies, and strong business environment. The report highlights the country's ability to attract top talent, invest in digital technologies, and foster a culture of innovation. Meanwhile, other notable tech developments include startups like GoTo and Manus accelerating their presence in Singapore, and OpenAI releasing a web browser to challenge Google Chrome. These trends indicate a shift towards increased digital connectivity and innovation globally.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2016: NTUC joins call for one-stop application process for productivity-linked schemes
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) has recommended to the Ministry of Finance that the government introduce a one-stop application process for productivity-linked schemes, aiming to reduce confusion and under-utilization of these schemes. The NTUC suggested harmonizing and strengthening the various productivity incentives to achieve long-term sustained wage growth for workers. The organization also proposed reviewing the criteria for the Employment Pass and Workfare Income Supplement to better support industries and workers.

site_title: Mining a dark past for a new play
summary: Theatre practitioners Alvin Tan and Haresh Sharma, co-founders of The Necessary Stage, are set to release a new play called Manifesto, which explores the era of suspicion towards artists in Singapore during the 1990s. The play, which opens next month, depicts four stories involving the artist and the state, including a young painter forced to leave his family and art due to 1960s upheavals. Inspired by historical events, Manifesto examines the role of artists in society and their right to change the world. The play features a cast of talented young actors and creative team members, including sound designer Bani Haykal and actress Siti Khalijah Zainal.

site_title: UK economy at risk from high property prices, EU referendum: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund has warned that the UK economy is at risk due to high property prices and the looming EU referendum, which could undermine business investment. The pound fell for a third day amid concerns about a potential Brexit. The IMF advises the Bank of England to keep borrowing costs low and be prepared to support the economy in case of sluggish demand. Chancellor George Osborne should also be ready to use flexibility in his fiscal framework to address potential economic challenges. A UK exit from the EU would be "negative on all fronts," according to IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde.

site_title: Nam Cheong posts Q4 loss of RM21.47m
summary: Malaysia's offshore support vessel builder Nam Cheong posted a Q4 loss of RM21.47 million, mainly due to a share of loss of RM22.33 million from an Indonesian associate. The company's quarterly revenue more than halved to RM241.84 million, and its shipbuilding revenue fell by 50% to RM233.61 million. Despite a lower gross profit margin, Nam Cheong projects its shipbuilding margin will trend towards "low teens" in the coming quarters. The company has deferred its BTO shipbuilding programme and remains asset-light, with a shipbuilding order book of RM1.2 billion for 17 vessels.

site_title: Mansion sales and discount dining: oil rout hits Houston's rich
summary: Houston's rich are feeling the pinch of the oil price crash, with mansion sales plummeting and luxury car sales slowing. The city's economy, while diversified, remains heavily reliant on the energy sector, with oil executives' compensation tied to energy market fluctuations. As a result, luxury businesses are offering discounts, including free opera tickets and cut-price dinners. Despite the downturn, the city's overall job market has shown resilience, adding 20,000 jobs to its 3 million-strong workforce.

site_title: Giving a leg-up to youths with disabilities
summary: A 2-year pilot project, Project IN, launched by SG Enable and the Singapore Business Federation Foundation (SBFF), aims to provide young adults with intellectual disabilities and autism with employment opportunities. The program, which began with 19 interns at three employers, offers internships, on-the-job learning, and job search support. The initiative aims to build an inclusive workforce and help employers tap into a previously underutilized talent pool, ultimately empowering individuals with disabilities to integrate into the workforce and contribute to a more inclusive society.

images.alt_text: Participants in the Project IN initiative are given a chance to develop their soft and life skills. This photo shows them piecing a jigsaw puzzle together to build teamwork and learn problem solving skills.

site_title: AIA Singapore posts strong showing in 2015
summary: AIA Singapore reported a 24% increase in its value of new business (VONB) to US$341 million in 2015, driven by its 4,200-strong agency force. The insurer's annualized new premiums grew 5% to US$471 million, while total weighted premium income rose 6% to US$2.28 billion. Operating profit after tax increased 9% to US$430 million. AIA Singapore attributed its strong performance to increased productivity among financial services consultants, expanded partnerships, and leadership in its group insurance business.

site_title: Raffles Med's steady growth, share split may spur the stock's next climb
summary: Raffles Medical Group (RMG) has announced a 3:1 stock split, increasing the number of shares from 575.25 million to 1.73 billion, making the stock more accessible to investors. The stock split is expected to enhance liquidity and widen the shareholder base. Despite global market volatility, RMG's steady growth trajectory and consistent revenue increase in its healthcare and hospital services divisions are seen as positives. Analysts express confidence in the stock, citing the company's growth story and potential synergies from its expansion projects, although some note limited price upside due to high price-to-earnings ratios.

site_title: Apple working on an iPhone even it can't hack
summary: Apple is developing security measures that would make it impossible for the government to hack into an iPhone using traditional methods, potentially leading to a new cycle of court battles and technical fixes. The company's engineers have begun working on a solution, following the FBI's request to access data stored on an iPhone used by a San Bernardino killer. Experts say the move could set a precedent for tech companies to resist government requests for data, and that Congress may need to intervene to clarify obligations.

site_title: CM Pacific not ruling out purchases outside China
summary: China Merchants Holdings (Pacific), a toll road operator, remains open to acquisitions outside of China despite increased gearing. The company's chief operating officer, Jiang Yan Fei, stated that it has the capacity to acquire new toll roads using bank borrowings, subject to market conditions. CM Pacific plans to balance its US dollar-denominated loans by borrowing more renminbi in the future. The company reported a 19% year-on-year decline in net profit to HK$597.22 million for FY2015, despite a 9% increase in revenue.

site_title: Post-Valentine, love's a mess
summary: A new production at Alliance Francaise Theatre, "The Savage/Love Of Danny And The Deep Blue Sea," combines three American theatre pieces by Sam Shepard, Joseph Chaikin, and John Patrick Shanley. The double bill, directed by Kamil Haque, features a 25-minute film of Shepard and Chaikin's "Savage/Love" followed by Shanley's "Danny And The Deep Blue Sea." The production has received praise for its performances but criticism for its disjointed format, which blends film and live acting. The play explores themes of love, loneliness, and hope, running until February 27.

site_title: Rio Tinto's dividend cut plan fails to stop Moody's downgrade
summary: Rio Tinto's credit rating was cut to Baa1 by Moody's Investors Service due to a decline in energy and metals prices, putting pressure on producers worldwide. The miner had previously announced plans to slash its dividend by as much as half to shore up its balance sheet. The downgrade follows a slide in commodity prices, with iron ore prices falling 19% over the past year. Moody's cited a fundamental downward shift in the mining sector and a protracted challenging operating environment as reasons for the downgrade, which has a negative outlook.

site_title: Robots making way for humans on car assembly lines
summary: Mercedes-Benz is shifting away from automation in car assembly, opting for human workers instead due to the increasing need for customization and individualization. The company's robots lack the flexibility and dexterity needed for complex tasks, forcing Mercedes to reduce its reliance on machines. The German carmaker is instead investing in skilled workers, enabling it to quickly adapt to changing production requirements. This approach is part of a broader trend in the automotive industry, with other manufacturers such as BMW and Volkswagen also exploring the benefits of human-centered production.

site_title: Consultants see good interest in 'palatable' Sembawang site
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority launched a public tender for a 0.7-hectare residential site in Sembawang, Singapore, with a maximum permissible gross floor area of 9,864 sq m. Consultants expect good interest from small to mid-cap developers, with bids likely below S$50 million. The site is expected to yield 110 residential units, and consultants predict a top bid price between S$400 and S$470 per square foot per plot ratio, translating to a land price of less than S$50 million. The tender closes on April 7, 2016.

site_title: Air NZ profit more than doubles to record NZ$338m in H1
summary: Air New Zealand reported a record first-half profit of NZ$338 million, more than doubling its previous year's profit. The airline attributed the surge to growing tourism numbers and a 44% drop in jet fuel prices, despite other global carriers reaping similar benefits from low oil prices. CEO Christopher Luxon expects the airline to achieve its best-ever annual earnings of over NZ$800 million, driven by revenue growth and increased tourist arrivals, which reached a record 3.17 million in the past year.

site_title: China stocks slump 6% in biggest one-day loss in a month
summary: China's stock market plummeted 6% on Thursday, its largest one-day loss in a month, amid profit-taking and concerns over a tightening financial system, cooling economy, and looming liberalization of initial public offerings. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 6.4% to 2,741.25, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng index also falling 1.6%. The decline follows a recent rebound and comes ahead of a G20 meeting in Shanghai, where investors are awaiting policy cues. The market's fragility and gloomy economic prospects have led some to sell before the annual legislature meeting in March.

site_title: Mad for Madonna and more
summary: Madonna's Rebel Heart World Tour is set to make its Singapore debut, becoming a landmark concert with a record-breaking ticket price of up to S$1,288 for the highest-tiered VIP package. The show, which will be held at the National Stadium, has generated significant buzz in Singapore's live music calendar despite initial concerns over its viability. Despite the high ticket prices, the event is expected to attract a large crowd, with fans from Asia having to travel long distances to attend. The concert's success is seen as a boost to Singapore's live music scene, with promoters citing the need for fans to support shows to ensure acts continue to tour the city-state.

site_title: Ho Bee's profit drop masks strong rental income growth
summary: Singapore-based property developer Ho Bee Land posted lower net earnings for the fourth quarter and full year due to lower fair-value gains on investment properties and an impairment loss on its stake in Cape Royale condo. However, the company's rental revenue grew significantly, driven by occupancy at its Singapore property, The Metropolis, and office blocks in London. Despite the decline in net earnings, Ho Bee proposed a special dividend of two Singapore cents per share, citing a strong recurring income stream and upcoming development projects in Australia, China, and the UK.

site_title: Fighting for the right to use his own name
summary: Dalton Trumbo, a Hollywood screenwriter, was blacklisted in the 1950s for his alleged Communist sympathies. He used pseudonyms to continue working, despite being jailed and barred from the industry. Trumbo's story is told in the biopic "Trumbo," which follows his struggles to win the right to use his real name. The film highlights his unwavering commitment to his First Amendment rights and his eventual redemption with two Academy Awards for his scripts. Trumbo's perseverance ultimately led to his name being cleared, and he was able to regain his place in the industry.

site_title: Takeover Code to incorporate lessons from F&N saga
summary: Singapore's Takeover Code will be updated to incorporate lessons learned from the Fraser and Neave (F&N) saga, a three-year battle that raised precedents and issues. The changes, effective March 25, will clarify resolution of competing offers, offeree boards' roles, and timeliness of disclosures. The updated Code will include an outline for an auction if a stalemate arises near the end of a competitive bidding period and will also extend the deadline for competing offers to increase competition. The changes aim to create greater certainty in takeover processes and prevent deadlocks.

site_title: Striving for a more inclusive workplace
summary: Singapore's inaugural Inclusive Business Forum aims to increase awareness of employing persons with disabilities, amid a labor crunch. The event, organized by SG Enable, brings together employers to share best practices and resources for hiring and integrating PWDs. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam will attend, and 200 participating employers are expected to make a commitment towards inclusive hiring. SG Enable's efforts have seen over 650 PWDs placed in jobs, and its Enabling Employers Network (EEN) aims to encourage industry peers to employ PWDs. The forum is held at the Enabling Village, a community space providing career services and training for PWDs.

site_title: CDL to launch third PPS this year
summary: CDL plans to launch its third profit participation securities (PPS) structure this year, aiming to tap into its local assets and achieve a target of S$5 billion in assets under management (AUM) by 2018. The group has successfully launched two PPS vehicles, unlocking S$2.6 billion of AUM and bolstering earnings. CDL's CEO Grant Kelley signaled that the third PPS will likely be launched in the next two years, focusing on sectors poised for medium-term growth.

images.alt_text: CDL group CEO Mr Kelley has signalled that the assets to be monetised under the third PPS are likely to be local ones.

site_title: Airlines concerned that Zika virus may be impacting travel: IATA CEO
summary: Airlines are expressing concern that the rapidly spreading Zika virus may impact travel, with the International Air Transport Association's Director General and CEO Tony Tyler stating that the industry is aware of the potential effects. While Tyler couldn't comment on specific impacts, the acknowledgment marks one of the first times the industry has acknowledged the virus's potential to affect revenue. This is not a direct article about the Zika virus, but rather airlines' concern about its impact on travel.

site_title: What art looks like in the future
summary: teamLab, a Japanese artist-technologist collective, is set to unveil a 15-piece exhibition at the Marina Bay Sands ArtScience Museum in Singapore, starting March 12. The interactive installations, designed by 450 artists and experts, blend art and science, offering immersive experiences that respond to viewer interactions. The works, including "Flowers & People" and "Crystal Universe," are rendered in real-time, continuously changing with each unique visitor, creating a dynamic and ever-changing environment.

images.alt_text: In Crystal Universe (above), you feel like you're creating your own night sky.
Inoko (above) says that people become part of the artwork when they cause the space to change.
In Flowers & People, Cannot Be Controlled But Live Together (above), if you stand still and observe, the flowers will bloom.

site_title: Stylish tech
summary: The Mobile World Congress in Barcelona showcased various mobile gadgets, including Huawei's Matebook, Samsung's Galaxy S7 and S7 edge, and LG's G5. Huawei's Matebook is a 12-inch, Windows 10 tablet that features an aluminium unibody, stylus, and powerful Intel Core processor. Samsung's Galaxy S7 and S7 edge boast a sleek design, glass and metal construction, and improved camera capabilities. LG's G5 has a modular design, allowing users to transform it into a digital camera or music player. The Xperia X series, announced by Sony, features a visually appealing design and impressive camera capabilities.

site_title: German beer purity in question after environment group finds weed-killer traces
summary: A German environmental group has found traces of glyphosate, a widely used weed-killer, in 14 of Germany's top-selling beers, raising concerns about the country's "pure" brewing tradition. The group tested samples from major brands and found levels above the allowed limit in drinking water. Industry and government have played down the report, with the Federal Institute for Risk assessment stating that high levels would require drinking 1,000 liters of beer daily to pose a health risk. The controversy comes as Germany's Reinhheitsgebot, a 500-year-old food safety law, is under scrutiny.

site_title: Negative yield plus: Japan got paid 52b yen to borrow
summary: Japan received a record 52 billion yen (S$648 million) from investors to borrow money, a windfall that will help Prime Minister Shinzo Abe tackle the country's massive debt burden. Since October 2014, Japan has been able to borrow at negative yields, with prices on securities selling for more than the cost of paying interest on the debt. This trend is expected to continue, with the Bank of Japan's negative-rate policy pushing the yield curve down and generating a 500 billion yen to 600 billion yen windfall for the government.

site_title: CAO chalks up strong profit for Q4FY15
summary: China Aviation Oil Corp reported a net profit of US$11.41 million for Q4FY15, more than doubling from US$4.43 million a year ago, driven by higher gross profit and associate contributions. Revenue slumped 54.4% year-over-year to US$1.97 billion due to low oil prices. Gross profit from jet fuel supply and trading increased nearly 75% year-over-year. The company expects a challenging oil trading environment in the coming year and plans to expand its global jet fuel supply and trading network.

site_title: Emergency workers find bodies of Nepal crash victims
summary: Emergency workers in western Nepal have found the bodies of 19 people killed in a plane crash, bringing the total death toll to 23. The Twin Otter turboprop aircraft crashed into a mountainside in the remote Myagdi district, where it can only be reached on foot or by helicopter. A makeshift helipad has been built to transport the bodies to the nearest airport, but strong winds have prevented helicopters from reaching the site. An investigation into the cause of the tragedy has been launched, with the European Union blacklisting all Nepal's airlines in 2013 due to safety concerns.

images.alt_text: Wreckage of the Twin Otter plane is seen on Tuesday at Myagdi, Nepal. The Tara Air flight from Pokhara to Jomsom was carrying three crew and 20 passengers, including a Chinese national and a Kuwaiti.

site_title: US home prices rose 5.8% in fourth quarter from prior year
summary: US home prices rose 5.8% in the fourth quarter from the prior year, driven by a tight supply of listings and improving employment. The median existing single-family home price reached $222,700, up 6.9% from a year earlier. Prices climbed 1.4% seasonally adjusted from the previous quarter, with Nevada experiencing the largest gain at 12.7%. The rise in home prices is attributed to a competitive market with fewer choices, despite instability in financial markets.

site_title: STI weakens for second straight day
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 16.56 points to 2,603.4 on Thursday, its second consecutive decline, amid a 6.4% drop in the Shanghai Composite and weak Dow futures. Banks, led by OCBC, declined, with Moody's warning of deteriorating asset quality due to slowing economic growth and oil-related recession fears. Volume increased, with 1.1 billion units traded, and shares of Riverstone Holdings rose after the company reported a 78.4% increase in after-tax profit.

site_title: Appetite for Buddhist art on the rise globally
summary: Chinese collectors are increasingly seeking Tibetan, Nepalese, and Northern Indian Buddhist art, driven by a growing interest in modern works. The appetite for Buddhist art has risen globally, with prices varying from one season to the next due to economic and market fluctuations. Notable sales include a 15th-century gilt copper alloy deity for $893,000 and a 16th-century Guhyasamaja Mandala for $929,000. Experts attribute the surge to the growing interest in quality and rarity among collectors, with South-east Asian collectors also showing a new interest in the market.

site_title: Fed's Bullard says largest banks may still be too big: CNBC
summary: St. Louis Fed President James Bullard stated that the largest banks may still be too big to fail, despite new regulations making the financial system safer. Bullard expressed concerns that these regulations have strengthened the market position of the largest banks, potentially discouraging innovation. He praised his colleague, Minneapolis Fed President Neel Kashkari, for suggesting the need to revisit the issue of breaking up the largest banks.

site_title: Hugo Boss CEO steps down after weak China, US sales
summary: Hugo Boss CEO Claus-Dietrich Lahrs is stepping down after eight years, following weak sales in China and the US, which led to a 5-year low in the company's share price. Lahrs will remain on the board until a successor is found, with Bernd Hake taking on sales and retail responsibilities starting March 1. The move comes amid a slowdown in sales growth and adjusted operating profit forecasts.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Stock analysts from OCBC, Maybank Kim Eng, and Jefferies Research have upgraded their ratings for Sheng Siong, Super Group, and Citic Envirotech, citing strong financial performances. Sheng Siong's net profit grew 19.3% to S$56.8 million, while Super Group's gross margin increased 40% year-on-year. Citic Envirotech expects more PPP projects in China, despite a 20% cut in earnings forecasts. The analysts attribute the upgrades to improved operational efficiency and growth potential in the respective sectors.

site_title: Venture returns to Q4 profit in absence of year-ago impairment
summary: Venture Corp reported a net profit of S$44.8 million in Q4 2015, driven by a one-time impairment loss in 2014. Full-year net profit doubled to S$154.0 million, with revenue increasing 7.7% to S$2.7 billion. The company maintained its dividend payout and described the economic outlook as "challenging." It plans to focus on new business and product development, talent recruitment, and core competency enhancement to drive superior performance and stay ahead of competition.

site_title: Noble plunges to US$1.67b loss
summary: Noble Group, a commodity trader, reported its first annual loss in nearly two decades, totaling US$1.67 billion for 2015. The loss was primarily due to a US$1.9 billion impairment charge on coal contracts, which was not caused by overly optimistic price estimates. The company's revenue dropped 22% to US$66.7 billion, and its operating cash flow was still negative at US$235.5 million. Despite the loss, Noble's CEO said the company is making progress on its priorities, including reducing debt and raising capital.

site_title: Facebook donates servers to speed up research into AI
summary: Facebook is donating 25 computer servers to European research institutions to accelerate AI and machine learning research. The servers, each with 8 graphics processing units, will be used in image analysis and chemical modeling. The donation is aimed at addressing bottlenecks in research due to limited compute resources, and Facebook will work with institutions to provide software and collaborate on projects. This move is part of Facebook's investment in AI research, which is expected to have a significant economic impact over the next decade.

site_title: Brazilian miner Vale posts US$12.1b loss in 2015
summary: Brazilian mining giant Vale reported a loss of $12.13 billion in 2015 due to lower iron ore prices, a sharp depreciation of the real, and a mining accident that killed 19 people. The accident occurred in November and was described as the worst environmental disaster in Brazilian history. Revenue declined and the price of iron ore dropped 43% in 2015. The government is negotiating compensation and cleanup payments with the mine owners.

site_title: US: Wall St higher as manufacturing activity rebounds
summary: US stocks rose slightly on Thursday as manufacturing activity rebounded, with durable goods orders increasing 4.9% in January. However, gains were limited by a drop in oil prices, which offset strong US gasoline demand. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.42%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite indexes also increased. Investors are watching the US Federal Reserve's next move on interest rates, with some policymakers calling for a pause on rate hikes.

site_title: Zurich Insurance says it is not exiting Singapore, HK markets
summary: Zurich Insurance has denied reports it is exiting the Hong Kong and Singapore markets, stating it remains committed to its general insurance and global life businesses in the region. The insurer, which has faced significant pressure due to setbacks in its general insurance division, has been reviewing its strategy to deliver annual cost savings of $300 million by the end of 2016. Despite this, Zurich retains its top two general insurer position in Hong Kong and one of the top five in Singapore, and plans to continue serving customers in these key markets.

site_title: US jobless claims up, but trend points to firming labour market
summary: US jobless claims rose 10,000 to 272,000 for the week ended Feb 20, surpassing economists' forecasts. Despite the increase, the trend indicates a firming labor market, with the 51st week of claims below the 300,000 threshold. The four-week moving average of claims fell to 272,000, suggesting a strong labor market. The labor market remains resilient despite global economic concerns, and further monetary policy tightening later in the year remains a possibility due to the jobs market's resilience.

site_title: Lian Beng to buy Broadway Plaza in Ang Mo Kio for S$51.5m
summary: Construction group Lian Beng has purchased Broadway Plaza in Ang Mo Kio for S$51.5 million. The 5-storey commercial property has a gross floor area of approximately 55,351 sq ft and about 61 years left on its lease. The acquisition is considered a strategic investment for rental returns, and the purchase was made through a wholly owned subsidiary.

site_title: Apple unlocking case will not be 'trailblazer' for legal precedent: FBI chief
summary: The FBI's case against Apple to unlock an iPhone belonging to one of the San Bernardino shooters is unlikely to set a broad legal precedent, according to FBI Director James Comey. Comey stated that the complex nature of mobile phone software will limit the case's applicability. Instead, broader policy questions about law enforcement access to encrypted data will need to be resolved by Congress and others, making the case "instructive but not trailblazing."

site_title: Hong Kong to price land sales to market, official says
summary: Hong Kong's government is preparing to sell land into a falling market to meet its commitment to supply 19,200 flats. The government will set base prices for tenders, but not guarantee high land premiums. The land sale program for 2016-2017 includes 29 residential sites and eight commercial sites, with tenders closing on Friday. If no tender reaches the base price, the land will not be sold to ensure public resources are safeguarded. The program aims to provide 18,000 flats this year.

site_title: Earnings slip for China Merchants Holdings despite higher revenue
summary: China Merchants Holdings (Pacific) reported a 19% decline in net profit to HK$597.22 million for its 2015 full financial year, despite a 9% increase in revenue to HK$2.21 billion. Lower profit contributions from toll road operations and the absence of a gain on disposal of a discontinued business contributed to the decline. Earnings per share fell to 45.43 HK cents, down from 85.26 HK cents in the previous year, and the net asset value per share decreased to HK$5.32. The company declared a final dividend of 3.5 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: China can achieve 6.5-7% GDP growth in 2016: state adviser
summary: China may achieve 6.5-7% GDP growth in 2016 if it drives ahead with "supply side reform", according to Li Wei, president of the State Council's Development Research Centre. The goal is to balance supply and demand, tackling property inventories and overcapacity in heavy industries. China reported 6.9% growth in 2015, but the economy has been slowing. To achieve stable growth, China must implement "supply side reform" and address its economic challenges.

site_title: Consumer comfort in US holds in narrow range for eighth week
summary: US consumer sentiment remains stable, holding at 44.2 for the eighth consecutive week, the narrowest range in eight weeks. Cheaper gasoline and job security contribute to upbeat views on buying conditions. However, turmoil in financial markets and concerns about the global economy's impact on the US economy weigh on consumer confidence. The Bloomberg Consumer Comfort Index is at odds with the Conference Board's report, which showed confidence declined to a seven-month low in February.

site_title: CEFC's Q4, full-year revenue and earnings jump on arbitrage opportunities
summary: CEFC International reported a 16-fold jump in its net profit to US$7.6 million in Q4, and a 25-fold increase in full-year net profit to US$17.9 million. Revenue rose eight times to US$286 million, and earnings per share increased to 0.18 US cents. The company attributed the growth to "active exploitation of arbitrage opportunities" and an agreement with CEFC Shanghai International Group.

site_title: US durable goods orders rebound strongly in January
summary: US durable goods orders rebounded 4.9% in January, the largest increase in 10 months, reversing a 4.6% decline in December. This surge offers hope for the manufacturing sector, which has been constrained by a strong dollar, weak global demand, and capital spending cuts. Non-defense capital goods orders excluding aircraft jumped 3.9%, while shipments of core capital goods fell 0.4%. The rebound may lead to revised GDP growth estimates, currently running above a 2% annual rate.

site_title: Oil hit by oversupply and economic growth concerns
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday due to concerns over oversupply and a slowing global economy. Brent crude futures dropped 37 cents to $34.04 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 48 cents to $31.67 per barrel. The lack of action by major exporters to freeze production has weighed on prices, with US crude stockpiles reaching an all-time peak of 507 million barrels. Economists warn that a slowing global economy risks hurting demand for oil and keeping prices low, with some predicting a temporary rise to the $50 level over the next four months.

site_title: SIAC sets record in new cases filed, total sum in dispute in 2015
summary: The Singapore International Arbitration Centre (SIAC) set a new record in 2015 with 271 new cases filed, a 22% increase from 2014, and administered 244 cases. The total sum in dispute grew 24% to S$6.23 billion, with the highest claim amount being S$2.03 billion. This marks a 5% increase from the previous record set in 2013. The top three foreign users were India, China, and South Korea, with trade, commercial, and corporate/maritime disputes being the most common types of disputes filed.

site_title: Foxconn puts Sharp takeover on hold over undisclosed liabilities: sources
summary: Foxconn has put its proposed takeover of Japanese electronics maker Sharp Corp on hold due to undisclosed liabilities. Sharp disclosed contingent liabilities amounting to "hundreds of billions of yen" that must be resolved before a deal can be finalized. The issue was brought to Foxconn's attention after reviewing previously unknown details from Sharp. Both companies declined to comment on the matter, and Foxconn stated it would not sign the agreement until clarification is reached in a new key document.

site_title: UBS expects 250-300 bln euro of distressed credit in current cycle
summary: UBS analysts predict 250-300 billion euro of distressed credit in the current credit cycle due to energy, metal, and mining companies' struggles with rock-bottom commodity prices and slowing global demand. European banks' exposure to distressed debt is lower than US counterparts. US$1 trillion in speculative-grade debt faces a high risk of default, with a 12.2% default rate in the natural resource sector. Defaults are expected to be significant even if commodity prices improve, according to UBS strategists Matthew Mish and Stephen Caprio.

site_title: Visa signs MoU with China UnionPay
summary: Visa Inc signed a memorandum of understanding with China UnionPay to collaborate on payments security, as the company awaits regulations to access the Chinese market for clearing bank card transactions. The market, valued at US$6.84 trillion in 2014, was set to open to foreign payment networks from June 2016. Visa continues to work towards a formal application while waiting for final regulations, following China's announcement last year to open up the market.

site_title: Interplex board appoints CIMB as adviser in S$450m takeover by Baring Private Equity
summary: Interplex Holdings, a precision engineering firm, has appointed CIMB Bank as its independent financial adviser following a S$450 million takeover offer by Baring Private Equity Asia. The takeover is supported by majority owners Metcomp Group Holdings and Standard Chartered's private equity arm. Both parties have stated their acceptance of the offer, paving the way for the deal to proceed.

site_title: Major shareholder plans to take Xinren Aluminum private in S$780m offer
summary: Xinren Aluminum Holdings has received a S$780 million takeover offer from major shareholder Merit Stand Inc, which will acquire the company at S$0.60 per share, a 25% premium over the last traded price. Merit, owned by Zeng Chaoyi, intends to delist the company and control 100% of Xinren Aluminum. The move comes after Zeng's family controls 75% of the company, with Sunshine International Global Capital holding 33%.

site_title: Jardine C&C FY15 net profit falls 16%
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage (JCC) reported a 16% drop in net profit to US$688 million for FY15, from US$820 million the previous year. Revenue declined 16% to US$15.7 billion. Astra, JCC's Indonesian automotive company, saw earnings fall due to challenging trading conditions. Despite this, Astra's strong cash generation and balance sheet enabled it to invest for the future. The company proposed a final dividend of 51 US cents, down from 67 US cents in 2014, citing uncertainty in the external macro-economic environment.

site_title: SBI Offshore announces termination of US$24m contract
summary: SBI Offshore announced the termination of a US$24 million design and engineering contract due to the downturn in the offshore and marine industry, primarily caused by a sharp fall in oil prices. The contract was originally announced in 2014 for a jack-up drilling rig. The company also reported a 50% dip in full-year revenue to US$7.1 million and swung to a net loss of US$4 million for FY2015.

site_title: CIMB Bank Q4 net profit jumps on higher income, low provisions
summary: CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, Malaysia's second-largest bank by assets, reported a net profit for the fourth quarter that more than tripled to 850 million ringgit, driven by higher operating income and lower provisions. The bank attributed the improvement to lower provisions from Indonesia and Thailand. CEO Zafrul Aziz stated that the bank aims to start operations in Vietnam by the end of 2016 and expects performance to improve this year with slower growth in loans and assets.

site_title: Haw Par FY15 profit grows 54.2% to S$183m on healthcare, investment sale gains
summary: Haw Par Corp's net profit rose 54.2% to S$183.3 million in 2015, driven by its healthcare business and a 32.3% increase in investment profits. The company reported a 42% increase in healthcare operating profit and a 16% rise in revenue. However, the leisure business and property segment suffered losses, while the company took an impairment charge on fixed assets. Haw Par described the operating environment as "challenging" and warned of further setbacks in these areas. The company proposes a dividend of 29 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Household spending sustains UK growth in Q4 2015
summary: The UK economy sustained growth in Q4 2015 with a 0.5% increase in gross domestic product, unchanged from initial estimates. Household spending, despite slowing to 0.7% in the quarter, remained strong at 3.1% annually. Business investment fell 2.1% in the fourth quarter, its sharpest decline in nearly two years. The economy grew 2.2% in 2015, with policymakers expecting a similar pace this year, but cautioning about the global economy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Thursday, closing at 1,658.16 after 1.65 billion lots valued at RM1.86 billion were traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 271-565. This marks the end of a two-day rally, as investors reacted to various market news, including US-EU trade talks and the US stock market's edge towards fresh records despite tariff concerns.

site_title: G20 likely to declare readiness to take action if growth outlook worsens: official
summary: The G20 is likely to declare readiness to take action if economic conditions worsen further, according to an official with a European delegation. The International Monetary Fund forecasts global growth in 2015 was 3.1%, with a predicted pick-up to 3.4% in 2016. The G20 will discuss policy responses to the weaker outlook and coordinate efforts if needed. A working group will prepare additional measures, which would be implemented quickly if finance ministers decide. To meet their 2% growth pledge by 2018, the G20 must intensify reform efforts this year, with only 0.8% of the agreed reforms completed so far.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance FY15 profit up 16%
summary: Hong Leong Finance reported a 16% increase in full-year net profit to S$72.9 million, driven by stronger income and higher loan yields. The company also settled a US legal action, writing back S$3.64 million in provisions. Net interest income rose 8.8% and fee and commission income gained 1.6%. Hong Leong Finance declared a final dividend of 7 Singapore cents per share, up from 4 cents last year. The company attributed its results to a restructuring domestic economy and challenging business conditions for SMEs.

site_title: CAO's Q4 profit bolstered by lower cost of sales, higher contributions from associates
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a net profit of US$11.41 million for Q4 2015, more than doubling from US$4.43 million a year ago, driven by lower cost of sales and higher associate contributions. Revenue slumped 54% to US$1.97 billion due to lower oil prices and trading volume. Full-year net profit rose 25% to US$61.28 million, with a proposed dividend of 3 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: IHH Healthcare posts 74% jump in Q4 net profit on exceptional gains
summary: IHH Healthcare Berhad, a Malaysian private healthcare provider, reported a 74% jump in Q4 net profit to RM415.8 million, driven by exceptional gains from revaluation, tax allowances, and exchange gains. Excluding these items, profit after tax and minority interests decreased 11% year-over-year to RM214.6 million.

site_title: Flash: Noble Group records US$1.7 billion loss for 2015
summary: Noble Group reported a significant loss of US$1.7 billion for 2015. The loss is attributed to various factors including declining commodity prices and increased costs. This marks a substantial decline from the company's previous year's profit. The loss is a major setback for the Singapore-based multinational conglomerate.

site_title: Thai exports suffer worst drop in four years
summary: Thai exports fell by nearly 9% in January, the worst drop in over four years, due to economic woes fueled by political instability and slowing export demand. The kingdom's economy grew 2.8% last year, one of Southeast Asia's slowest rates, disappointing the junta government's efforts to boost trading. This decline further highlights Thailand's struggles with a lacklustre growth rate and its impact on the military rulers.

images.alt_text: Thai exports fell by nearly nine per cent in January, their worst drop in more than four year as economic woes continue to pile up on the kingdom's military rulers, government figures released Thursday showed.

site_title: Japan fair trade watchdog plans guidelines for state-backed bailouts
summary: Japan's Fair Trade Commission is developing guidelines to prevent damage to competition when state-backed funds invest in troubled firms, following the criticism of Japan Airlines' 2010 bailout. The guidelines won't be legally enforceable, but aim to prevent unfairness. Japan Airlines has since rebounded, prompting criticism from rival ANA Holdings Inc. This move contrasts with the European Commission's power to block government support if it gives a company an unfair advantage. The guidelines are open for public opinion and aim to prevent future similar bailouts.

site_title: Kingsmen's net profit up 11.2% for FY2015
summary: Kingsmen Creatives posted a net profit of S$19.1 million for FY2015, up 11.2% from the previous year. Revenue dipped 2.5% to S$327.9 million, with the exhibitions and museums division seeing a 26.3% increase in revenue. The company declared a dividend of 2.0 Singapore cents per share and expressed "cautious optimism" about the outlook for FY2016, citing expansion plans and enhanced fulfillment capabilities.

site_title: China seeks to reassure trading partners on FX, markets ahead of G20
summary: Chinese policymakers have ruled out an imminent devaluation of the yuan, citing a need to maintain market stability while driving structural reforms. Finance Minister Lou Jiwei stated a proposal to devalue the yuan is not on the G20 agenda, and Vice Finance Minister Zhu Guangyao said China will keep the exchange rate stable under its "managed float" regime. The comments come ahead of the G20 summit, where market turmoil and a global economic slowdown are expected to be key topics of discussion.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore labour movement submitted a 7-page list of recommendations to the Ministry of Finance, including a review of employment pass and workfare income supplement criteria. Noble Group recorded a US$1.7 billion loss for 2015 due to a US$1.9 billion impairment. The Monetary Authority of Singapore introduced changes to the takeover code to address competitive bids and offeree boards. China stocks plummeted 6% due to investors booking profits after a recent market rebound. The Straits Times Index fell 16.56 points due to a 6.4% decline in the Shanghai Composite.

site_title: Changes to takeover code address competitive bids, boards' roles, timings
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will introduce changes to the Code on Take-overs and Mergers on March 25 to address competitive bids, boards' roles, and disclosure timeliness. The revised code will align offer-period timetables with the latest competing offer, extend the deadline for competing offers, and introduce an auction process for non-declared final bids. Boards of target companies will be allowed to share management projections and forecasts with independent financial advisers, and material changes to information must be disclosed earlier. The changes are in line with proposals outlined in a 2015 public consultation.

site_title: Growth in eurozone private sector picks up slightly: ECB
summary: The European Central Bank reported a slight increase in eurozone private sector growth, with loans to households and companies rising 0.6% in January, up from 0.4% in December. The ECB's key indicator of economic health, borrowing growth, increased 0.8% year-over-year, fractionally faster than the previous month. The central bank's policy measures, including a public sector bond-buying program, aim to boost the eurozone's weak economy and drive inflation higher. ECB chief Mario Draghi hinted at potential additional stimulus measures in March if inflation doesn't pick up soon.

site_title: CMT issues S$100m in 10-year debt at 3.5%
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) issued S$100 million in 10-year fixed rate notes at 3.5% per annum to institutional and accredited investors. The funds will be used to refinance existing borrowings. The notes will be listed and quoted on the Singapore Exchange on Feb 26, 2016, with a maturity date of Feb 25, 2026. This is the second debt issue under CMT's S$2.5 billion multi-currency medium-term note programme established in 2007.

site_title: G20 nations face slowing global growth in China meeting
summary: G20 finance ministers gather in Shanghai amid growing concerns over slowing global growth, fueled by China's faltering economy, falling oil and commodities prices, and financial market turbulence. The IMF warns of a "derailed recovery" and urges strong policy responses to contain risks and propel the global economy to a more prosperous path. The G20 meeting comes as the world grapples with multiple challenges, including the looming "Brexit" and weak commodity prices.

images.alt_text: G20 finance ministers gather in Shanghai from Friday with the global economy assailed on multiple fronts, from China's slowing growth to weak commodity prices, amid simmering disagreements over how best to face the challenges.

site_title: Beijing beats New York as world billionaire capital: survey
summary: Beijing has surpassed New York City as the "billionaire capital of the world" with 100 resident billionaires, according to a survey by the Hurun Report. The number of Beijing billionaires rose by 32 from last year, while New York's tally rose by just four. China minted more new billionaires than any other country last year, mainly due to new listings, and is now home to 568 billionaires with a combined net worth of $1.4 trillion.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares up, Sharp tumbles after Foxconn bailout
summary: Tokyo shares rose 1.41% on Thursday, driven by higher oil prices, after a three-day losing streak. Sharp tumbled 14.9% after accepting a multi-billion-dollar bailout from Foxconn's parent company. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 16,140.34, while the Topix index rose 1.79%.

site_title: ICBC plans to issue green bonds as China eyes clean environment
summary: ICBC plans to issue green bonds as part of China's efforts to promote clean environment. The move comes after China authorized the first sales of green bonds in December. ICBC's 702.8 billion yuan of outstanding green loans have a low non-performing loan ratio, indicating a promising green lending market. The National Association of Financial Market Institutional Investors is studying guidelines for green bonds, and the market is expected to exceed $50 billion this year, driven by the Paris Agreement to tackle climate change.

site_title: Foxconn to delay signing of Sharp takeover deal, says to clarify terms
summary: Taiwan's Foxconn has delayed signing a deal to take over Japanese firm Sharp Corp due to new terms that need clarification. The acquisition, if finalized, would be the largest of a Japanese tech firm by a foreign company, bolstering Foxconn's position as Apple's biggest supplier. Foxconn received a new key document from Sharp on Wednesday morning, which it responded to, stating it needs clarification before a deal can be signed. A resolution is expected as soon as possible.

images.alt_text: Taiwan's Foxconn on Thursday said it would delay the signing of a deal to take over Sharp Corp as the Japanese firm had included new terms that needed to be clarified.

site_title: Samsung Group's Lee to buy US$186m worth of shares in group firms
summary: Samsung Group's de facto leader Jay Y Lee is acquiring 230.2 billion won (S$261 million) worth of shares in two group companies, including 200 billion won in Samsung C&T Corp and 30.2 billion won in Samsung Engineering Co Ltd. The acquisitions are part of an ongoing succession process and boost Lee's stake in the conglomerate's de facto holding company. The deals are aimed at increasing Lee's control over the group's operations and ensuring a smooth transition.

site_title: Next-generation ERP in action from 2020
summary: Singapore's next-generation Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) system will be operational by 2020 at a cost of S$556 million. The new system, based on Global Navigation Satellite System technology, will replace the 17-year-old current system and allow for distance-based road pricing without physical gantries. The system will be more flexible, fairer to users, and will also enable traffic information collection, automatic payment, and paperless roadside parking. An 18-month switchover period will be implemented to ensure a seamless transition, with the government covering the cost of IU replacement for Singapore-registered vehicles.

site_title: XinRen Aluminum's FY2015 net profit drops 90.7% to 26.43m yuan
summary: XinRen Aluminum Holdings reported a 90.7% drop in FY2015 net profit to 26.43 million yuan, despite a 77.9% increase in revenue to 25.76 billion yuan. The decline was attributed to swelling expenses. Earnings per share dropped to 2.03 yuan cents from 2014's 21.78 yuan cents. The company plans to raise Xinjiang Plant's output and capacity by the end of 2016, citing its integrated value chain as a key factor in its resilience during the downturn. No dividend was recommended.

site_title: Noble records US$1.7b loss for 2015
summary: NOBLE Group reported a significant loss of US$1.7 billion in the 2015 financial year, primarily due to a US$1.9 billion impairment. This marks a substantial decline from the net profit of US$132 million in 2014. Revenue dropped 22% to US$66.7 billion, despite increased trading volumes. The loss is attributed to the firm's struggling operations amidst a challenging market environment.

site_title: Lloyds bank profits slump on mis-selling scandal
summary: Lloyds Banking Group reported a 59% slump in annual net profits to £466 million due to huge costs linked to the mis-selling of payment protection insurance (PPI). The bank set aside £4.0 billion in 2015 and now has a total bill of £16.0 billion to compensate customers, far higher than other British banks. The mis-selling of PPI, which provides insurance for consumers who fail to meet loan repayments, became controversial after it was revealed that many customers were sold it without understanding the cost was added to their loan repayments.

site_title: Transnational crime booming across Southeast Asia: UN
summary: The UN has warned of a booming transnational crime scene in Southeast Asia, with estimated illegal trade worth over $100 billion, surpassing the combined GDP of Myanmar, Laos, and Cambodia. The problem is fueled by rapid regional economic integration and weak policing. The region's sophisticated criminal networks exploit corruption and lack of governance to trade drugs, wildlife, natural resources, and counterfeit goods. The UN urges Southeast Asian nations to balance economic growth with better policing and controls, citing the need for serious measures to address the issue, particularly in the poorest countries.

site_title: Bring in new management to regain credibility, Iceberg tells Noble Group
summary: Noble Group's credibility is at risk due to its accounting practices, prompting Iceberg Research to recommend bringing in external management. The commodity trading group has employed public relations strategies to address criticism, but failed to provide stakeholders with meaningful financial information, particularly on commodity contracts fair values. Iceberg believes external management is the only way to regain credibility, as internal efforts have been insufficient.

site_title: Indonesia parliament commission drops request to audit central bank
summary: Indonesia's parliament commission has dropped a request to audit the central bank, Bank Indonesia, after closed-door hearings with the governor.
