The commission had called for the audit in January amid concerns over the rupiah's decline, but decided not to pursue it after the governor's explanations and improving financial conditions. The rupiah has strengthened in 2016, and the central bank has managed to prop up reserves. However, the government still pressures the central bank to cut interest rates further to aid economic growth.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's parliament has dropped a request for an investigative audit of the central bank, a lawmaker said, after several closed-door hearings with Bank Indonesia's (BI) governor.

site_title: S Korea: Won at nearly 6-yr closing low, despite firmer stocks
summary: The South Korean won dropped to its lowest close in almost six years, ending at 1,238.8 per dollar, due to traders' anxiety over Chinese and global market prospects. Despite a 0.3% gain in the Korea Composite Stock Price Index, the won's decline was not supported by firmer stocks, which remained shaky.

site_title: Swee Hong to raise up to S$8m from placement of new shares, warrants
summary: Swee Hong, an engineering group, has entered into a term sheet to place 300 million new shares and 500 million warrants at S$0.01 each to Readymade Steel Singapore. The deal is expected to raise up to S$8 million. The funds will help Swee Hong, which is facing financial issues, to restructure its debt. The company is currently suspended from trading.

images.alt_text: ENGINEERING group Swee Hong said it has entered into a term sheet to place 300 million new shares at S$0.01 a share, and 500 million free unlisted detachable new warrants to subscribe for one new share at S$0.01 per warrant share, to Readymade Steel Singapore.

site_title: Rich not richer in Malaysia as billionaire numbers shrink
summary: Malaysia's billionaire numbers shrank by a quarter last year, with only six people growing their fortunes, according to Forbes. The country's richest saw their fortunes slump by up to half due to weak oil prices and a financial scandal. The number of billionaires dropped from 16 to 12, with energy-dependent Malaysia's economic outlook continuing to be a concern. The country's currency, ringgit, also fell 12.6% against the dollar, further affecting the fortunes of Malaysian tycoons.

site_title: European shares rebound as Lloyds and Seadrill rally
summary: European shares rebounded on Thursday, lifting the pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index 1.3% after solid corporate results from Lloyds and Seadrill. Lloyds surged 9.1% on a special dividend payment and higher profits, while Seadrill advanced 6.7% on a refinancing plan. However, Zodiac Aerospace slumped 24% on a profit warning. The rebound was driven by a 53% of European STOXX 600 companies meeting or beating market expectations with their fourth quarter results.

site_title: Yen beats 'Brexit'-plagued pound in currency volatility face-off
summary: The yen has surpassed the pound in terms of currency volatility, with a 4.5 percentage point increase in three-month implied volatility in the dollar-yen pair, compared to 3.3 percentage points for the pound-dollar pair. The yen has surged 7% against the dollar this year, driven by the Bank of Japan's stimulus expansion and investor concerns about a global slowdown. The pound has dropped 5.4% against the dollar, amid uncertainty over the UK's potential "Brexit" vote on June 23.

site_title: China: Stocks close down over 6%, worst loss in a month
summary: China's stocks plummeted over 6% on Thursday, marking their largest one-day loss in a month, as investors booked profits after a recent market rebound. The CSI300 index fell 6.1% and the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 6.4%. Traders cited profit-taking, liquidity fears, and concerns over a cooling economy and potential cash crunch from looming liberalisation of initial public offerings. The sell-off was attributed to a confluence of factors, including tighter liquidity in the financial system and worries about the economy.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish weaker after 6.4% plunge in Shanghai index
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 16.56 points to 2,603.4, its second consecutive loss, with a 2.6% decline over two days. The decline was attributed to a 6.4% drop in the Shanghai Composite and weakness in Dow futures. Traders may have been selling on weak sentiment and recession fears, while also capitalizing on a short-covering bounce that had run its course. The STI's loss was offset by higher trading volume, with 1.1 billion units traded on Thursday.

site_title: UK watchdog tells banks to open up payment system to competition
summary: Britain's Payment Systems Regulator (PSR) proposed that banks cut their stakes in the VocaLink payment system, a key infrastructure provider, to increase competition. The PSR found that the system's common ownership by a small number of lenders stifles innovation and competition. VocaLink processes over 11 billion transactions worth £6 trillion annually. The regulator will consult on the proposals until April 21. This move aims to open up the market and allow for more effective competition and innovation in the industry.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall, dragged lower by slumping China stocks
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 1.6% on Thursday, dragged down by a 6% slump in China stocks, their largest one-day loss in a month. The Hang Seng index dropped to 18,888.75 points, while the China Enterprises Index fell 2.4% to 7,871.94 points. All main sectors in Hong Kong fell, as investors booked profits after the market's recent rebound.

site_title: Indonesia central bank says current rupiah rate competitive, sees it strengthening
summary: Indonesia's central bank says the current rupiah exchange rate is competitive for exports and is expected to strengthen due to capital inflows. The rupiah traded at 13,418 per dollar, up over 2% this year. The bank's executive director, Juda Agung, stated that the rate is slightly undervalued against the dollar. This move is seen as a positive development for the country's economy, which relies heavily on exports.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks plunge 5.06% in afternoon trading
summary: Shanghai stocks plummeted 5.06% in afternoon trading on February 25, 2016, due to concerns over China's slowing economy and tight liquidity. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 148.24 points to 2,780.66, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 6.46% to 1,755.18.

images.alt_text: Shanghai stocks plunged more than five per cent in afternoon trading on Thursday, weighed down by worries over China's slowing economy and tight liquidity, dealers said.

site_title: Australia: Shares end a touch higher, NZ dips
summary: Australian stocks rose 0.1% to 4,881.20, rebounding from a 2.5% drop in the past two sessions. Major banks such as Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, National Australia Bank, and Westpac Banking Corp gained, while Commonwealth Bank eased. Breville, a kitchen appliance maker, surged 12.1% after posting higher profits and increasing its dividend. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.1% to 6,225.28.

site_title: Maybank Q4 profit drops 14.5% as impairment losses rise
summary: Malayan Banking Bhd (Maybank), Malaysia's largest lender, reported a 14.5% drop in Q4 net profit to 1.65 billion ringgit due to higher impairment losses amid a challenging economic environment. Net interest income rose to 2.9 billion ringgit, while revenue increased 14% to 11.05 billion ringgit. The bank attributed the decline to increased allowances for impaired loans and lower recoveries. Maybank also expects Malaysia's overnight policy interest rate to be lowered by 25 basis points to support growth.

site_title: US says to present draft UN sanctions resolution on North Korea
summary: The US is set to submit a draft UN sanctions resolution to the Security Council on Thursday, targeting North Korea over its latest nuclear test and ballistic missile launch. The resolution aims to expand existing sanctions, with the US working with the council to develop a strong and comprehensive response to North Korea's nuclear program.

site_title: Singapore Power in tie-up for accelerator programme in energy sector
summary: Singapore Power has established the Spark Accelerator Pte Ltd, a joint venture with Infocomm Investments Pte Ltd, to discover and accelerate startups in the energy sector. The program will invest up to S$4 million in 30 startups, providing complimentary working space and a 6% equity stake. The accelerator aims to develop innovative solutions for energy efficiency, mobility, cybersecurity, and on-demand customer services, opening for applications in Q2 2016.

site_title: BOJ Kiuchi warns negative rates could destabilise banking system
summary: Bank of Japan board member Takahide Kiuchi warned that negative interest rates could destabilize Japan's financial system, citing potential harm to financial institutions' revenues. Kiuchi, who voted against the BOJ's decision to adopt negative rates, said economic conditions had not deteriorated enough to justify easing and that the move could backfire by tightening monetary conditions. He advocated for a more targeted approach to monetary policy, rather than relying solely on quantitative easing.

site_title: The dark side of world's lucrative mobile industry
summary: Activists criticize the mobile industry for ignoring rights abuses in Chinese factories and Congolese mines, where workers are exploited and exposed to carcinogens. The industry, worth $3.1 trillion, contributes to armed conflict in the Democratic Republic of Congo, where children as young as 7 work in makeshift mines. Companies like Fairphone are trying to address these issues by promoting transparency and fair trade practices, but the complex supply chain makes it difficult to ensure ethics. The Fairphone 2, launched at the Mobile Social Congress, is an example of a smartphone manufactured with ethical considerations.

site_title: Gold rises on safe-haven demand, fund purchases
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,232.90 an ounce due to safe-haven demand amid market volatility and "Brexit" fears. The metal rebounded after earlier losses, driven by investor buying from bullion funds. Sterling fell to a 7-year low against the dollar and 2.5-year low against the yen, fueling gold's rally. The metal has gained 16% this year, supported by safe-haven bids and inflows into gold ETFs, which have surpassed outflows for the whole of 2015.

site_title: IMF warns G-20 that world economy 'highly vulnerable'
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that the world economy is "highly vulnerable" due to slowing growth, market turbulence, and geopolitical conflicts. The IMF expects to lower its forecast for world growth in 2016, citing a weakened global recovery. To mitigate risks, the IMF calls for strong policy responses, boosting fiscal stimulus and pushing through reforms to increase demand. Central banks should maintain accommodative monetary policies, while near-term fiscal policy should support the recovery where possible. New financing mechanisms to help countries in financial turmoil are also recommended.

site_title: Noble says sale of interest in Noble Agri unconditional, to get US$750m on March 3
summary: NOBLE Group has confirmed the sale of its remaining 49% stake in Noble Agri to Chinese state-backed grain trader Cofco International for US$750 million. The disposal will be completed on March 3, 2016, with proceeds used to repay debt. The transaction will result in a non-cash loss of US$546 million. This marks a significant sale for Noble Group, following the 2014 sale of its 51% interest in Noble Agri for US$1.5 billion.

site_title: China commissions homegrown missile frigate amid naval buildup
summary: China has commissioned a domestically produced missile frigate with a displacement of over 4,000 tonnes, featuring long-range surveillance and anti-aircraft capabilities. This move comes amid China's naval buildup and US concerns over Beijing's military expansion in the South China Sea. The commissioning of the frigate marks a significant milestone in China's efforts to modernize its navy and assert its dominance in the region.

site_title: Banyan Tree hit by 'perfect storm', posts worst loss in its history in 2015
summary: Banyan Tree Holdings reported a net loss of S$18.4 million in Q4 2015, its worst loss in history, due to a "perfect storm" of factors including devaluation of the Russian rouble and economic slowdowns in China and Europe. Revenue rose 34% to S$123.2 million, but net loss for the full year 2015 was S$27.5 million. The company's cash reserves were S$165.5 million by end 2015, and no dividend was declared for 2015.

site_title: Australia warns of 'advanced' Indonesia terror threat
summary: Australia has warned of a potential "advanced" terrorist threat in Indonesia, advising travelers to exercise caution due to the high risk of attacks in Jakarta, Bali, and Lombok. The warning comes after similar threats were issued for Malaysia, and Indonesian police recently arrested dozens of suspected Islamic extremists. The threat level remains at "exercise a high degree of caution," with the government urging travelers to be vigilant in areas with low security and potential terrorist targets, such as nightclubs and places of worship.

site_title: Australia: Shares burdened by banks and miners, NZ soft
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.25% to 4,862.80, weighed down by banks and miners, with BHP Billiton falling 1.1% and Commonwealth Bank dropping 1%. Crown Resorts fell 5% after reporting a sharp drop in profits, while Seek jumped 7.7% after beating earnings expectations. In New Zealand, the benchmark index fell 0.24% to 6,215.52, with Air New Zealand rising 1.05% after posting a record half-year profit.

site_title: Brazil Senate passes bill to relax Petrobras hold on rich oil region
summary: Brazil's Senate has passed a bill reducing Petrobras' control over the Subsalt Poligon, a promising offshore oil region, in an effort to revive Brazil's oil industry. The bill, which passed 40-26, relaxes a 2010 law requiring Petrobras to operate and invest in the area. The move aims to increase foreign investment and boost oil development, which has been hindered by low oil prices and a corruption scandal at Petrobras. If passed, the bill could help kickstart the country's oil industry.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise; Hon Hai up 4% as Sharp accepts takeover offer
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose on Thursday, led by Hon Hai Precision's 4% gain after Japan's Sharp Corp accepted a takeover offer. The largest acquisition by a foreign company in Japan's technology sector, it would be a significant move for Hon Hai. The main TAIEX index rose 0.9% to 8,353.93, while the electronics subindex gained 1.1%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to TW$0.242 to TW$33.248 per US dollar.

site_title: Oil prices fall as oversupply worries return
summary: Oil prices fell in Asia on Thursday, reversing a brief rally, as concerns about oversupply returned. The decline came after Saudi Arabia's decision to shoot down hopes for an Opec output cut. Oil prices rose the previous day on a record high in US commercial crude inventories but fell as traders reassessed the market. The decline was attributed to worries about brimming supplies, following the swift dismissal of hopes for an output cut.

site_title: India gears up for 'make or break' budget
summary: India's government is set to present its budget on Monday, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi aiming to deliver on promises to overhaul the tax regime and boost public spending. The budget is seen as a "make or break" moment for Modi's government, which faces challenges including a weak economy, a stagnant main stocks index, and a lack of progress on the Goods and Services Tax. Experts expect announcements on reducing corporate tax and a clear roadmap for the GST, as well as increased spending on infrastructure and public sector banks.

images.alt_text: India's government is expected to deliver on promises to overhaul the tax regime and ramp up public spending in its budget Monday, as Prime Minister Narendra Modi bids to shore up his sagging reputation as a reformer.

site_title: South Korea central bank raises ceiling for low-rate lending for firms
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, raised the ceiling for low-rate lending programs for smaller firms by 5 trillion won (S$5.7 billion) to support the faltering economic recovery. The increased ceiling will be allocated to three programs supporting foreign trading firms, capital investment, and business start-ups, providing funds at low interest rates (0.50-0.75%) to banks to support lending to eligible companies. The existing ceiling was 20 trillion won, and an additional 4 trillion won will be allocated to the programs.

site_title: Japan's Sharp decides to accept Foxconn takeover offer: source
summary: Japan's Sharp Corp has agreed to a takeover by Taiwan's Foxconn, a deal worth 659 billion yen (S$8.3 billion), making it the largest acquisition by a foreign company in Japan's insular technology sector. Sharp's board accepted the offer after a two-day meeting, citing Foxconn's investment and global sales channels as key benefits. The deal aims to stabilize Sharp's finances and consolidate Foxconn's position as the world's biggest assembler of Apple's iPhones and iPads.

site_title: Australia business investment up in Q4, outlook still dim
summary: Australian business investment rose 0.8% in Q4, the first increase in a year, driven by spending outside the mining sector. However, investment intentions for 2017-2018 dropped to A$82.6 billion, below expectations. The outlook remains dim, with annual growth seen stuck below potential at 2.6%. Investors expect a possible interest rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia to stimulate growth, but the RBA has argued that rates are already low.

site_title: South Korea's short-term external debt burden declines at end-Q4 vs end-Q3
summary: South Korea's short-term external debt fell to 29.6% of foreign reserves by the end of December, the lowest level in over a decade. The debt decreased to $108.7 billion from $119.6 billion at the end of September. This is a decline from 32.5% of foreign reserves three months prior. The ratio of short-term external debt to foreign reserves was the lowest since 2004, indicating a decrease in South Korea's external debt burden.

site_title: MH370 lawsuits gain pace as two-year deadline nears
summary: Malaysia Airlines flight MH370's next-of-kin are filing lawsuits over the plane's disappearance, with a two-year deadline approaching on March 8. Dozens of relatives are seeking damages from Allianz, the airline's insurer, which would not impact the airline's finances. Lawsuits also target Malaysia's civil aviation authorities and aircraft manufacturer Boeing, with potential payouts reaching "hundreds of millions" of dollars. Despite international agreements providing $160,000 per passenger in compensation, families seek more, citing a slow, bungled response and withholding information from authorities.

images.alt_text: Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 next-of-kin have begun filing a slew of lawsuits over the plane's disappearance as a two-year deadline approaches on March 8, with some hopeful that court scrutiny will help reveal answers about what befell the ill-fated plane.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2016: Review employment pass, workfare income supplement criteria: NTUC
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) submitted a seven-page list of recommendations to the Singapore Ministry of Finance ahead of Budget 2016, focusing on reviewing employment pass and workfare income supplement criteria. The NTUC aims to incentivize industries to build a strong Singaporean core while differentiating between companies that develop Singaporeans and those that don't. The suggestions also cover four key areas: strengthening the Singaporean core, improving productivity, enhancing training, and improving retirement adequacy.

site_title: AIA Singapore posts 24% rise in expected profits to US$341m
summary: AIA Singapore reported a 24% rise in expected profits to US$341 million in 2015, driven by a 11.1% increase in value of new business margin to 72.4% and 5% year-on-year growth in annualised new premiums. Operating profit after tax climbed 9% to US$430 million. The insurer attributed its strong performance to increased productivity, expanded partnerships, and leadership in group insurance. AIA Group, the parent company, posted a 26% rise in value of new business to US$2.2 billion, with a proposed total dividend of 69.72 Hong Kong cents per share, up 39%.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise on oil, Wall St but gains capped; won trapped
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.5% in early trading on Thursday, driven by gains in US stocks and oil, but gains were capped by market participants' wariness of oil price volatility. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rose to 1,922.03 points, with shares in Korea Electric Power Corp and Samsung Electronics Co Ltd up 3.7% and 0.3% respectively. The South Korean won was effectively steady against the dollar, and March futures on three-year treasury bonds were flat.

site_title: China: Stocks fall on growth fears ahead of G-20 meeting
summary: Chinese stocks fell on Thursday, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index dropping 0.58% and the Shanghai Composite Index easing 0.23%, ahead of a G-20 meeting where growth concerns are expected to be addressed. The Shenzhen Composite Index also slipped 0.22%. The declines come as investors weigh the impact of US-China trade tensions and economic slowdowns. The G-20 meeting in Shanghai is set to begin on Friday, with leaders expected to discuss global economic growth and trade.

site_title: China's largest bank says no basis for continued yuan depreciation
summary: China's largest bank, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, says there is no basis for continued yuan depreciation. Chairman Jiang Jianqing stated that financial institutions face pressure from slowing economic growth, but the risks are under control. China's finance minister Lou Jiwei also confirmed that devaluing the yuan is not on the agenda for the upcoming G20 meeting.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday as oil rebounds
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index opened at 2,641.78 points, up 21.82 points or 0.83%, following a rebound in Brent oil prices. The top stocks by value traded were DBS, UOB, Jardine C&C, Jardine Matheson, and Keppel Corp. Gainers outnumbered losers 114 to 24, with 67.8 million shares worth S$151.7 million changing hands.

site_title: Japan got paid US$464m to borrow thanks to negative yields
summary: Japan's government has received at least $651.5 million in interest from investors since the country's debt yield fell below zero in 2014, resulting in negative yields on some bonds. This is a result of the Bank of Japan's asset purchases and charges on lenders' reserves, which have reduced bond-market activity. The money earned is used to repay notes reaching maturity, and the government plans to sell more bonds to finance its massive national debt, which stands at almost $1.045 trillion.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on gains on Wall Street
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Thursday, driven by a weaker yen and gains on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.43% to 15,983.47, while the Topix index gained 0.40%. The positive lead from Wall Street and rebounding oil prices also contributed to the gains.

site_title: Oil finds footing after US gasoline stockpiles drop
summary: Oil prices stabilized on Wednesday, rising 28 cents to $32.15 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate, after a 2.2 million barrel drop in US gasoline inventories, the largest in 15 weeks. US commercial crude supplies rose to a record 507.6 million barrels, but oil production fell for a fifth straight week. Despite Saudi Oil Minister Ali al-Naimi's comments on an Opec output freeze, analysts downplayed expectations of a reduction, citing a supply-demand imbalance. Oil prices are expected to remain under pressure as supply continues to outpace demand.

site_title: AIA Group posts 26% rise in new business growth for 2015
summary: AIA Group Ltd, the world's second-largest life insurer, reported a 26% rise in new business value to US$2.20 billion in 2015, driven by demand for insurance in Hong Kong and China. Annual operating profits after tax rose 16% to US$3.21 billion. The company also proposed a 39% increase in dividend to 0.6972 Hong Kong dollars per share.

site_title: First Resources' Q4 profit down 67% on lower crude palm oil prices
summary: First Resources, an Indonesian palm oil producer, reported a 67% decrease in Q4 net profit to US$19.8 million, down from US$59.2 million a year ago, due to lower crude palm oil prices. Revenue fell 26% to US$130.9 million, mainly due to lower selling prices. The company declared a final dividend of 1.25 Singapore cents, down from 2.3 cents a year ago. Despite lower prices, the company believes the fundamentals of the palm oil industry remain favorable, driven by demand from the Indonesian biodiesel mandate and emerging markets.

images.alt_text: INDONESIAN palm oil producer First Resources reported a net profit of US$19.8 million for its fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2015, down 67 per cent from US$59.2 million a year ago.

site_title: China could raise budget deficit to top 4% of GDP
summary: China may increase its budget deficit to over 4% of GDP to support economic growth, according to a central bank researcher. The move comes as the country's leaders aim to stimulate the economy after disappointing monetary policy easing. The potential increase in the fiscal deficit rate was written by Sheng Songcheng, director of the Survey and Statistics Department at the People's Bank of China. China's economy is expected to slow down, putting pressure on policymakers to take action.

site_title: Asia: Shares tentative as growth concerns cloud G-20 meet
summary: Asian shares were mixed on Thursday as growth concerns weighed on markets ahead of a G20 meeting. Tokyo's shares rebounded on rising oil prices, while energy and materials companies led US stocks higher. In Europe, stocks fell with bank and healthcare stocks dragging down the market. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, despite the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: Fed's Bullard sticks to script, says unwise to keep hiking rates
summary: Federal Reserve President James Bullard expressed opposition to further interest rate hikes, citing declining market-based inflation expectations. The break-even expected inflation rate in five years' time has dropped to less than 1.5%, eroding central bank credibility. Bullard stated that continuing to hike rates in this environment would be unwise, highlighting the need for a cautious approach to monetary policy. His remarks come as the US central bank considers future rate adjustments.

site_title: Nam Cheong slides to RM21.5m Q4 loss, stops dividend
summary: Nam Cheong, an offshore support vessel builder, reported a Q4 net loss of RM21.5 million, down from a year-ago profit of RM41.1 million, due to lower oil prices and weak demand. Revenue fell 54% to RM241.8 million. The company has deferred vessel deliveries and will not declare a final dividend. Its gross order book stood at RM1.2 billion at end-2015, with deliveries until 2018. The company cited a weak outlook for the offshore and marine sector.

site_title: Citi downgrades 2016 global growth forecast to 2.5%
summary: Citi economists downgraded their 2016 global growth forecast to 2.5% from 2.7% due to slowing activity in developed economies and weakening emerging markets. They also warned of a risk the world economy may grow below 2% due to "mismeasurement" of Chinese growth data and a potential deterioration in emerging economies. This marks a further deterioration in global growth prospects, with advanced economies experiencing weakness alongside previous struggles in emerging markets.

images.alt_text: Citi economists on Wednesday marked down their forecast on 2016 global economic expansion to 2.5 per cent from 2.7 per cent due to slowing activity in developed economies in addition to weakening emerging markets.

site_title: Stocks to watch: City Developments, oil and gas counters
summary: City Developments reported a 6.6% increase in net profit to S$410 million for its fourth quarter. In contrast, oil and gas-linked counters like Nam Cheong and Pacific Radiance fell into the red, while KrisEnergy defered exploration expenditure due to the oil price situation.

site_title: City Developments posts higher Q4 profit, driven by asset monetisation
summary: City Developments (CDL), a real estate developer and hotel owner, reported a 6.6% increase in Q4 profit to S$410 million, driven by the monetization of prime office assets through a second Profit Participation Securities investment platform. The company's full-year net profit rose 0.5% to S$773 million, while revenue fell 12.2% to S$3.3 billion. CDL's hotel business was affected by global uncertainty, but the company remains focused on expanding overseas and growing its funds management platform. A final dividend of eight cents per share was declared.

site_title: Pacific Radiance posts Q4 net loss of US$2.6m, cuts dividend
summary: Pacific Radiance reported a Q4 net loss of US$2.6 million, down from a net profit of US$5.1 million a year ago, due to lower vessel utilisation and weaker market conditions. Revenue fell 42% to US$21.7 million. For the full year, net profit fell 94% to US$3.8 million and revenue fell 29% to US$121.8 million. The company cut its final dividend from three cents to one Singapore cent a share.

site_title: Australia to boost defence spending by US$21 billion, buy 12 new submarines
summary: Australia plans to increase defence spending by nearly A$30 billion over 10 years, aiming to protect its interests in the Asia-Pacific region amid China's rise. The country will build 9 new frigates, 12 offshore patrol vessels, and acquire 12 new submarines, with the supplier to be determined later this year. This move follows a competition between Japan and France to supply Australia's next submarine fleet, valued at A$50 billion.

site_title: At 83, Yoko Ono says she didn't break Beatles
summary: At 83, Yoko Ono has defended herself against allegations that she broke up The Beatles, stating in a Us Weekly interview that she "had nothing to do" with the 1970 split. Ono cited Paul McCartney as a "pretty cool dude" and suggested that tensions among the band were already present. The reasons for the breakup remain disputed among fans and historians, with Ono's constant presence in the studio previously cited as a contributing factor. Ono's comments aim to set the record straight on her legacy and reputation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.89 points to 1664.97. Volume was 51.7 million lots worth RM50.4 million, with 95 gainers and 79 losers. No specific events or news were mentioned in the article.

site_title: Ackman's fund off 17.3% for year, erases banner gains from 2014
summary: Billionaire investor William Ackman's Pershing Square Holdings portfolio has lost 17.3% so far in 2016, erasing his 40% return from 2014. The fund's decline is attributed to Valeant Pharmaceuticals, which has been a major loser for Ackman's fund. Ackman's flagship fund still earns an average 12% a year over the last decade, but investors who added money after 2014 may have lost their investments. Despite the losses, investors continue to put money into hedge funds, citing their relatively better performance compared to stocks.

site_title: Apple chief calls FBI iPhone case 'bad for America'
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook stated that the US government's request to unlock an iPhone in the name of fighting terrorism would be "bad for America." Cook emphasized the importance of public safety and data protection, arguing that creating a master key to crack iPhone encryption would expose people to vulnerabilities. Apple is battling the government in at least 10 cases, including the high-profile San Bernardino dispute. Cook believes the risks outweigh the potential benefits, and that creating a master key would set a precedent that many Americans would be opposed to.

site_title: Adele steals the show at 2016 BRIT Awards
summary: Adele made a triumphant return to the 2016 BRIT Awards, winning four trophies including album of the year for her third studio album, "25". The British singer received widespread acclaim for her performances and awards, including best British female and best British single. Adele also paid tribute to Kesha, who was a victim of emotional manipulation by her former producer. The ceremony honored the late David Bowie with a tribute by Annie Lennox, and included performances by international stars Rihanna and Justin Bieber.

site_title: France demands 1.6b euros in tax from Google
summary: French authorities have demanded Google pay 1.6 billion euros (S$2.5 billion) in back taxes, amid controversy over multinational corporations' tax arrangements. The demand comes as Google CEO Sundar Pichai defended the company's tax practices in Paris, where he met with France's economy minister. The figure emerged after Google declined to comment on the tax demand, which may be subject to "fiscal confidentiality." This follows similar disputes with other companies, including Apple, Starbucks, and Amazon, and raises concerns over Google's tax practices and potential fines.

site_title: Changtian Plastic sinks into the red in Q4 and FY2015, hit by impairment loss
summary: Changtian Plastic & Chemical reported a net loss of 17.5 million yuan in Q4 2015, and a full-year net loss of 7.1 million yuan, due to a significant decrease in gross profit and an impairment loss of 15.1 million yuan on property, plant, and equipment. This weakened performance pulled the company into the red for FY2015.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit one-week low as commodities stocks slump
summary: European stocks fell to a one-week low on Wednesday, with the FTSEurofirst 300 index down 2.3% due to further selling pressure on commodities-related shares. Copper and crude oil prices slipped, affecting mining stocks and oil majors. The index has fallen 12% in 2016, driven by concerns over China's economy. Despite this, shares in Wolters Kluwer rose 5.2% after reporting better-than-expected results.

site_title: Moody's cuts Brazil credit rating to junk
summary: Moody's cut Brazil's credit rating to junk, citing low growth, worsening debt, and political instability. This move, combined with previous cuts by Fitch and S&P, makes Brazil the seventh biggest economy in the world to receive a negative outlook. The downgrade follows a challenging economic environment and may lead to further downgrades.

site_title: Airbus delivery goal shows optimism after Boeing target cut
summary: Airbus has announced plans to lift production of the aging A330 jet and increase annual deliveries, showing optimism after Boeing's target cut. Airbus aims to deliver over 650 jets in 2016, up from 635 in 2015, with output of the A350 wide-body more than tripling to 50 jets. The company's CEO, Tom Enders, stated that demand is present and that they are handling the ramp-up, despite Boeing's lower deliveries.

site_title: KrisEnergy narrows full-year loss to US$41.7m, to defer exploration expenditure
summary: KrisEnergy, an upstream oil and gas explorer, reported a net loss of US$41.7 million for the full year of 2015, narrowing from US$50.4 million a year ago. Revenue fell to US$60.2 million due to lower sales of crude oil and gas. The company completed its targets by developing two new oil projects in the Gulf of Thailand and secured its production licence for the Rossukon oil development.

site_title: Petrobras to receive first shale gas cargo to be exported from US
summary: Brazil's state-owned energy company Petrobras is set to receive the first shipment of shale gas from the US, scheduled to arrive in early March via Cheniere Energy Inc's Sabine Pass terminal in Louisiana. The shipment is expected to meet increased demand in South America due to a drought, with Brazil relying on liquefied natural gas for power-plant fuel. This milestone comes amid a global glut of fuel and shifting demand, potentially affecting financing and contracts for other gas-export projects.

site_title: Pound suffers again on Brexit worries; yen slips
summary: The British pound dropped 0.7% to a 7-year low of $1.3923 due to persistent worries about a potential Brexit, affecting its value and impacting global growth. The International Monetary Fund warned that the world economy is "highly vulnerable" and needs to boost global demand. Meanwhile, the yen remained steady despite early gains, as investors sought safe-haven assets amid broader economic concerns.

images.alt_text: The British pound took another hit Wednesday as worries that the country will vote to exit the European Union persisted.

site_title: S$1,030-1,050 psf average price for The Wisteria
summary: The Wisteria, a 12-storey mixed development in Singapore, is set to launch with an average price of S$1,030-1,050 per square foot. 108 out of 216 units will be available in the initial launch, with 80 apartments priced below S$1 million each. The development will include 83,361 sq ft of retail space, Wisteria Mall, which will be held for rental income by the developers. The project is expected to be completed in 2018 and will feature smart home features and prefabricated prefinished volumetric construction.

site_title: One-third of US tech 'innovators' are immigrants: study
summary: A US study found that one-third of technology innovators are foreign-born individuals, making up 35.5% of the sector. Immigrants with advanced degrees have made significant contributions, debunking stereotypes about the industry. However, women and US-born minorities, including African Americans and Asian Americans, are underrepresented in the tech innovation space, accounting for only 8% of US-born innovators. The study emphasizes the need for flexible immigration policies and increased education in STEM fields to address these disparities.

site_title: Canadian island invites Trump haters to move north
summary: Cape Breton Island in Canada is offering a humorous escape to Americans who dislike Donald Trump, with a website promoting the island as a welcoming destination for political refugees if Trump wins the presidency. The island, located off Nova Scotia's Atlantic coast, boasts affordable housing, universal healthcare, and natural beauty, with over 300,000 website visits and 5,000 Americans seeking information about the island in the past week.

images.alt_text: The rise of Donald Trump has given an unlikely boost to a Canadian island offering to take in Americans as political refugees if the Republican real estate mogul wins the White House.

site_title: Ho Bee's Q4 earnings fall on lower fair value gain, takes impairment loss for Cape Royale
summary: Ho Bee Land reported a 32.1% decline in Q4 net profit to S$193.7 million, due to a lower gain in fair value of investment properties and an impairment loss for its 35% interest in Cape Royale. Full-year net profit fell 23.1% to S$242.2 million. Despite a 30.5% rise in rental income, revenue declined 28.5% to S$222.6 million. The group expects a challenging year ahead but anticipates profit contributions from development projects in Australia and China.

site_title: Amid transition, Myanmar's Senior General emerges from the shadows
summary: Myanmar's Senior General Min Aung Hlaing has emerged from the shadows, transforming from a secretive military leader to a politician and public figure. He has cemented his position as de facto No. 2 in the country's post-election political scene, meeting with Nobel laureate Aung San Suu Kyi to discuss how they will work together. Despite the military's reluctance to step back from politics, Min Aung Hlaing aims to improve the military's image, saying it wants to be seen as "the sons and daughters of the people." His term will be extended by five years, making him the second most powerful figure in government.

site_title: Shanghai to raise supply of small flats to cool market
summary: Shanghai authorities have introduced new rules to increase the supply of medium and small-sized apartments, aiming to cool the city's overheating housing market. The rules require at least 70% of land supply for homes smaller than 100 sq m in downtown areas and 60% in suburb areas. This move is expected to make Shanghai the first Chinese city to implement such measures. The surge in home prices in Shanghai reached 15.5% in December 2015, prompting the authorities to take action.

site_title: Fifa reduces Blatter, Platini bans to six years
summary: FIFA's appeal committee reduced Sepp Blatter and Michel Platini's bans from eight years to six years for ethics breaches, including a $2 million payment to Platini in 2011. The bans will still be enforced, but both will attempt to have them overturned at the Court of Arbitration for Sport. The FIFA election, which will determine the next president, is still uncertain, with Gianni Infantino and Sheikh Salman bin Ebrahim al Khalifa vying for the position. The election has been overshadowed by scandals and corruption allegations.

site_title: Jackpot! Remote South Korea casino cleans up as China gamblers fold
summary: Kangwon Land Co Ltd, a South Korean casino, has seen a significant surge in revenue as Chinese gamblers have been deterred by Beijing's crackdown on graft and excessive spending. The casino, located three hours east of Seoul, has become the top-performing casino stock in Asia, with a 21% increase over the past year. Its valuation now stands at US$7.2 billion, trailing only two other major casino operators in the region.

images.alt_text: Asia's best performing casino won't be found on Macau's Cotai Strip, Singapore's waterfront or even the shores of Manila Bay, but tucked away at the end of a winding mountain road, three hours east of Seoul.

site_title: Pound seen diving to 30-year lows if Brexit comes to pass
summary: The pound is predicted to plummet to 30-year lows if the UK votes to leave the European Union, with 29 economists forecasting a rate of US$1.35 or lower within a week of the referendum. Twenty-three economists believe sterling won't recover from this rate within three months, while seven predict it will fall below US$1.20 immediately. The pound has already dropped 2% versus its peers in 2016, and experts expect it to continue falling if the UK votes to leave the EU.

site_title: Manufacturing still has important role: MTI
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector contracted 6.7% year-on-year in the fourth quarter, surpassing the official estimate of 6%. Despite this decline, manufacturing remains important to the Singapore economy, with greater spillover effects on the economy than services. The sector's productivity growth is ahead of others, indicating its continued significance. This is in line with the Ministry of Trade and Industry's (MTI) assessment that manufacturing still has an important role in the economy.

site_title: Air New Zealand posts record interim profit
summary: Air New Zealand has posted a record interim net profit of NZ$338 million, up 154% from the same period last year. The airline attributed the surge to falling fuel prices and rising passenger demand, with operating revenue rising 12% to NZ$2.7 billion. The carrier expects to exceed NZ$800 million in earnings before taxation for the full year 2016. Fuel prices fell 44% over the reporting period, while demand increased 17%. Air New Zealand also increased its interim dividend by 54% to 10.0 cents a share.

site_title: Zika crisis to 'get worse before it gets better': WHO chief
summary: WHO chief Margaret Chan warns the Zika virus crisis will worsen before it improves, citing the virus's "mysterious" nature and the lack of a proven link to microcephaly. Brazil, the epicenter of the outbreak, has reported 583 confirmed cases of microcephaly, a 14.7% increase from the previous week, with an estimated 120 babies dead due to the birth defect. Chan praises the Brazilian government's efforts to combat the mosquito-borne virus, but acknowledges the challenges ahead.

site_title: Trump's third straight win has rivals looking for answers
summary: Donald Trump won the Nevada caucuses, his third consecutive victory, outdistancing rivals Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz. Trump's decisive win solidifies his position as the front-runner in the US Republican presidential nomination. His campaign credits strong support from various demographics, including Hispanics, evangelicals, and poorly educated voters. Trump's rivals, including Rubio and Cruz, are under pressure to develop counter-strategies to challenge him ahead of Super Tuesday on March 1, where several southern states will hold primaries.

site_title: US: Stocks swing higher as oil rallies
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday as oil prices rebounded, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 53.21 points (0.32%) to 16,484.99. The S&P 500 advanced 8.53 points (0.44%) to 1,929.80, while the Nasdaq Composite climbed 39.02 points (0.87%) to 4,542.61. Speculation about China's potential economic stimulus boosted markets, with energy-related stocks turning higher.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Temasek Holdings priced 600 million euro of 0.5% bonds due 2022 and 500 million euro of 1.5% bonds due 2028 at spreads of 48 and 80 basis points, respectively. POSH secured long-term charters for five vessels valued at US$85 million. Soilbuild Construction Group's net profit fell 28% in Q4 to S$5.6 million, while Yongnam Holdings clinched four contracts worth S$69.8 million. NERA Telecommunications' net profit slipped 5% in Q4 to S$4.4 million, and Soilbuild Construction Group is declaring a cash payout of 1.5 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Nasa innovations could cut carbon emissions and save airlines billions
summary: NASA's Environmentally Responsible Aviation (ERA) project has developed green technologies that could save the US airline industry over $250 billion by reducing fuel consumption, pollution, and noise. The project, conducted from 2009 to 2015, aimed to develop integrated solutions to improve noise, pollution, and carbon output. The technologies, including more efficient engines and lighter-weight materials, are expected to be commercialized and integrated into commercial and military aircraft over the next 10 years, resulting in significant fuel savings and reduced carbon emissions.

site_title: Overwhelming demand for larger flats in Bidadari estate
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) launched 4,170 new flats in three projects in Bukit Batok, Sengkang, and Bidadari, but saw an overwhelming response for the larger flats in Bidadari, with 408 applicants chasing 236 five-room and 3-generation flats. The application rate for these flats was 1.7, and demand from second-timers was particularly strong, with an application rate of 13.8. The demand is attributed to the popularity of Bidadari as a desirable and highly sought-after HDB estate.

site_title: Oil extends decline as Saudi Arabia, Iran resist production cuts
summary: Oil prices extended their decline after Saudi Arabia and Iran signaled resistance to production cuts. The American Petroleum Institute reported a 7.1 million-barrel rise in crude inventories, further pressuring prices. Saudi Arabia's Oil Minister Ali al-Naimi said high-cost producers should bear the burden of rebalancing markets, while Iran's Oil Minister Bijan Namdar Zanganeh deemed a Saudi-Russia proposal to freeze output "ridiculous". As a result, oil futures slid 3.7% in New York, with WTI falling to $30.68 a barrel.

site_title: Genting Malaysia doubles Resorts World investment to RM10.4b
summary: Genting Malaysia Bhd has doubled its investment in Resorts World Genting to RM10.38 billion, aiming to elevate itself from regional competition and become a destination of choice. The company's shares fell 3.7% after the announcement, despite a 20% increase in full-year net profit to RM1.2 billion. The new investment will be used to expand the 20th Century Fox World theme park and set up a new casino, with costs rising to over RM2 billion. The company remains cautious on the near-term outlook of the leisure and hospitality industry but is positive in the longer term.

site_title: DBS clinches US$750m Khazanah bond deal
summary: DBS Bank clinched a US$750 million unsecured Islamic bond deal from Khazanah Nasional Berhad, priced at 3.035%, marking 2016's largest sukuk sale. This is Khazanah's first standalone sukuk bond, showcasing Malaysia's investment grade status. DBS was chosen over other banks after a failed attempt by Barclays, UBS, CIMB, and Morgan Stanley in January. The bond will be used to refinance Penerbangan Malaysia Berhad's US$1 billion guaranteed notes, saving the Malaysian government 2.59% in interest.

site_title: Morgan Stanley sees flat US commercial property price growth
summary: Morgan Stanley analysts predict flat US commercial property price growth in 2016, reversing a previous forecast of 5% growth. The decision is attributed to a dynamic between lenders and property values, where lower leverage requires higher income to offset falling property prices. Higher financing costs and slowing corporate earnings also contribute to the forecast. The analysts note a possible bifurcation between high and low-quality properties, with CMBS funding segment declining.

site_title: Design, chemistry, weather behind Takata ruptures
summary: US researchers found moisture entering the Takata airbag inflator, not dried by a chemical, is the cause of ruptures, which spray metal and plastic shards. This finding will aid regulators in determining how many vehicles need to be recalled. The discovery also resolves a dispute over how recall costs should be shared among carmakers and the supplier.

site_title: Singapore Flyer helps bolster Straco's Q4 performance
summary: Straco Corporation, the operator of tourist attractions including the Singapore Flyer, reported a 42% leap in net profit to S$6.26 million for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2015, driven by revenue from the Singapore Flyer. Revenue rose 23% to S$23.83 million, despite lower profits from other subsidiaries. The Singapore Flyer's acquisition in November 2014 contributed to the company's improved performance.

images.alt_text: Singapore Flyer contributed about 19% of the profit for FY2015, said Straco's executive chairman Wu Hsioh Kwang.

site_title: Rowsley falls into S$36.1m FY15 loss amid heavy impairments
summary: Rowsley, a Singaporean property developer, reported a net loss of S$36.1 million in 2015 due to heavy impairments, including S$24.4 million on investment properties and a S$10.1 million loss on goodwill. Revenue declined 5% to S$83 million, and the company expects a "challenging" outlook but plans to carry out growth activities in the next 12 months.

site_title: France chases economic opportunities in Macri's Argentina
summary: French President Francois Hollande visited Argentina, seeking investment opportunities under President Mauricio Macri's new economic measures. This visit follows Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's and US President Barack Obama's upcoming visits. The turnaround in Argentina's global profile since Macri's takeover two months ago has improved diplomatic ties and credit profile. The French delegation, consisting of 30 business leaders, aims to capitalize on these opportunities, reflecting a shift in Argentina's global profile.

images.alt_text: Argentina's President Mauricio Macri received fresh endorsement of his new-broom economic measures on Wednesday when French President Francois Hollande flew in to Buenos Aires with 30 business leaders to sniff out investment opportunities.

site_title: Norway's oil industry woes likely to deepen with further spending cuts
summary: Norway's oil industry is expected to face further spending cuts this year due to low crude prices, adding pressure to the country's economy. The Norwegian Confederation of Trade Unions warns of a crisis on the west coast, while analysts predict a 9-12.5% decline in oil and gas investments, down from the 171 billion kroner (S$27.6 billion) estimated in November. The mainland economy is forecast to grow only a few tenths of a percentage point, and the central bank may cut interest rates in March to support the economy.

site_title: India government bonds take a beating over Budget fears
summary: India's sovereign bonds have become Asia's worst performers in 2016, dropping from the best performers in the previous two years, amid concerns that Prime Minister Narendra Modi's budget will show fiscal discipline slipping away. The government is expected to borrow 6.8 trillion rupees, a 13% increase from this year's estimate, and may raise its deficit target to 3.7% from 3.5%. This could lead to higher borrowing costs and a loss of credibility for the government, negatively impacting the bond market.

site_title: Weak demand, new supply weigh on Far East H-Trust
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust reported a 8.6% decline in distribution per stapled security to 1.17 Singapore cents for its fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2015, due to weak corporate travel demand and new hotel supply. Revenue fell 4.7% to S$28.9 million, with net property income decreasing 4.9%. The trust has implemented asset enhancement programs to improve property quality and competitiveness, and expects refurbishments to be completed by the second quarter.

site_title: Singtel's Innov8 teams up with telco counterparts to help startups
summary: Singtel's Innov8 has launched Go Ignite, a global startup alliance with Deutsche Telekom, Orange, and Telefónica, to connect ecosystems across Asia, Africa, Europe, Latin America, and the Middle East. The alliance offers a program to help top startups find business development opportunities, accelerate commercialization, and scale globally. Up to five startups will be selected, benefiting from resources such as market insights, introductions to partners, and access to collective customer bases. The program ends on April 30, with OptiWi-fi and Idomoo already benefiting from the arrangement.

site_title: Virtual Reality, innovation take centre stage at mobile show
summary: Mobile World Congress in Barcelona saw a shift away from traditional handset launches, with brands like Huawei, LG, and Sony focusing on innovation and virtual reality (VR). Huawei unveiled its Matebook, a laptop-tablet hybrid, while LG introduced the modular Android smartphone G5 and the LG Rolling Bot, a remote control device. Sony revealed four concept gadgets, including the Xperia Projector, which projects an interactive interface on any surface. Analysts note that VR is over-hyped, with limited consumer demand expected in 2016, but companies will need to develop self-created content to drive growth.

site_title: Chinese New Year is becoming many bankers' Xmas
summary: Chinese companies have announced plans to spend over $75 billion on foreign acquisitions in 2016, a ten-fold increase from last year, making China the hot spot for global M&A. This trend has upended traditional holiday schedules for European bankers, who are now working on Chinese time. Despite regulatory hurdles, Chinese buyers continue to expand, with the largest purchase being China National Chemical Corp's $43 billion acquisition of Swiss pesticide maker Syngenta AG. This shift has significant implications for Western bankers, who risk losing out if they fail to adapt to China's growing influence in global M&A.

site_title: MAS dismisses talk of Singapore banking crisis
summary: MAS has dismissed talk of a Singapore banking crisis, citing the banking system's well-capitalized and diversified nature. Deputy MD Jacqueline Loh noted that local banks' capital adequacy positions and liquidity are strong, and asset quality remains healthy despite a rise in non-performing loans. MAS conducts regular industrywide stress tests, which showed the system remains resilient to adverse outcomes.

site_title: S&P downgrades SingPost's credit rating to A- with stable outlook
summary: S&P has downgraded SingPost's long-term credit rating from "A" to "A-" with a stable outlook, citing increased earnings volatility due to the company's transformation into a logistics and e-commerce provider. The downgrade follows a previous CreditWatch placement with negative implications. S&P expects SingPost to strengthen its balance sheet, with a debt-to-Ebitda ratio below 2.0 times by end-March 2017. An upgrade is considered unlikely over the next two years due to declining mail volumes and competitive pressures in the logistics industry.

site_title: Samsung Pay, Netflix HDR to hit Singapore shores by late this year
summary: Samsung Pay, a mobile payment service, will be available in Singapore by late this year, following its global rollout in China, Australia, Brazil, Spain, and the UK. This move aims to provide consumers with a convenient payment option. Meanwhile, Singapore's SUTD has launched an office of AI and Digital Innovation to foster design AI skills in students, and the country is also home to various AI-focused innovation hubs, including those from mining giant BHP and tech companies like Oracle and Grab.

site_title: Are ECs a better long-term investment than condos?
summary: A study by OrangeTee suggests that executive condominiums (ECs) are a better long-term investment than private condos in Singapore. ECs initially have a 20% price gap with private condos due to sales restrictions and lower costs. However, this gap narrows to 0% after 10 years when ECs are fully privatised. The study concludes that ECs can be a more stable and affordable investment option, especially after the initial 5-year minimum occupation period (MOP).

site_title: Major Japanese bank in advanced talks for space in Marina One
summary: A Japanese bank, The Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ, is in advanced talks to lease 140,000 sq ft of office space at Marina One in Singapore. The bank is moving from Republic Plaza, where it occupied 150,000 sq ft. Meanwhile, Johnson & Johnson is finalizing a lease for 170,000 sq ft at Ascent in Science Park 1. These transactions indicate a growing interest in Singapore's office space despite a generally quiet leasing market.

site_title: HK office rents most expensive in the world: JLL
summary: Hong Kong has the world's costliest office space, with average rents of US$262 per square foot per year, according to JLL's Global Premium Office Rent Tracker. London ranks second at US$240 psf per year, while Beijing ranks third at US$199 psf per year. In contrast, Singapore's office space is becoming more affordable due to new supply, with no specific rent mentioned in the article.

site_title: BOJ chief says Tokyo ready to ease further, despite controversy
summary: Bank of Japan (BOJ) Governor Haruhiko Kuroda has assured that the central bank will not hesitate to ease monetary policy further if needed, despite already imposing negative interest rates. The BOJ aims to achieve 2% real annual growth, while Prime Minister Shinzo Abe targets a 20% increase in GDP. Analysts say Tokyo is pulling out all stops to meet targets ahead of a key Upper House election. Kuroda has sparked criticism for his handling of interest rates, but claims to be watching market developments closely.

site_title: Jittery markets send safe-haven yen soaring
summary: Worries over falling oil prices and a possible British exit from the EU drove the euro to a three-year low against the yen and sterling to a seven-year low against the US dollar on February 24, 2016. Oil fell below $33 a barrel after Saudi Arabia ruled out production cuts and a report showed record US crude stockpiles. This led to a surge in demand for safe-haven currencies like the yen and Swiss franc. The decline in oil prices and EU uncertainty sparked market volatility, causing investors to seek refuge in more stable assets.

site_title: QAF's FY profit up 17%; sales hit by exchange rate
summary: QAF Ltd, a Singapore-listed bakery company, reported a 17% increase in net profit to S$52.5 million for FY2015, driven by higher earnings per share. Revenue was 2% lower due to exchange rate fluctuations. The company's bakery operations in Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Australia saw higher sales, while its meat producer in Australia and Malaysian bakery operations experienced lower sales. A final dividend of 4 Singapore cents per share was declared.

site_title: Singaporeans target 8.4% annual returns: BlackRock survey
summary: Singaporeans aim for an 8.4% annual return on investments, but hold nearly half of their savings in cash. Millennials are the most ambitious, with the highest expectations for investment returns, but also the most conservative, holding the most cash. To overcome this, Singaporeans need to be more confident in investments and willing to take steps out of cash. Only 30% of SMART investors (those who save, make retirement a priority, actively invest for income and growth, recognize the need to take steps out of cash, and take financial planning seriously) earn above S$100,000 annually, highlighting the need for more financial education and planning.

site_title: Slightly more upbeat year for trade in 2016
summary: Singapore's trade performance for 2015 was dismal, with total trade falling 9.5% to S$884.1 billion and non-oil domestic exports (NODX) dipping 0.1%. However, forecasts for 2016 indicate a slight improvement, with total trade expected to grow 0.0 to 1.0% and NODX growth forecasted at 0.0 to 2.0%. The decline in total trade was attributed to depressed commodity prices, particularly oil prices, but IE Singapore noted that the actual decline was less severe than expected.

site_title: Oil sector sees a new league of two: the ultramajors
summary: US oil giants Exxon and Shell are shifting their focus from massive projects to more efficient and cost-effective operations amid the low oil price era. The two companies, known as the ultramajors, have been forced to cut spending, including high-risk projects, as oil prices barely exceed $30 a barrel. Exxon is slashing investment by 25% this year, while Shell is reducing spending by 6.5% compared to 2015, with executives citing the need for nimbler and lower-cost operations to remain competitive.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2016: Boosting value creation through Budget 2016
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat has emphasized the need for the country to transition from a value-adding to a value-creating economy. The Committee on the Future Economy will focus on finding ways to boost value creation, including innovation, branding, and internationalization. The current Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) scheme has been criticized for being ineffective, and a hybrid framework is proposed to offer targeted incentives for different activities at various stages of business development. Additionally, the government is considering introducing a tax scheme to support brand building and acquiring Singaporean brands.

images.alt_text: The only way for businesses to survive and thrive is to continually create new value through new products and services, new markets or new business models. Revamping the PIC scheme will provide a good base of support for businesses to start on their value-creation journey.

site_title: Home prices in 20 US cities increase at steady pace
summary: Home prices in 20 US cities increased at a steady pace of 5.7% from December 2014, matching projections of a 5.8% advance. Nationally, prices rose 5.4% year over year, indicating a healthier residential real estate market contributing to economic expansion. Gains in payrolls and low jobless claims are making home purchases more attractive.

site_title: No off-cycle monetary policy move seen
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), has ruled out an off-cycle monetary policy adjustment, stating its next review will be as scheduled in April 2016. MAS deputy managing director Jacqueline Loh said the monetary policy stance remains "appropriate and unchanged" despite a decline in oil prices and lower-than-expected Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums. The MAS lowered its 2016 headline inflation forecast to -1 to 0% and maintained its core inflation forecast at 0.5 to 1.5%.

site_title: Seoul's loud and chaotic fish market resists futuristic move
summary: Seoul's Noryangjin Wholesale Fisheries Market, a 45-year-old city landmark and tourist hotspot, is resisting a move to a futuristic, $500 million facility. Vendors, who have called the current site home for 45 years, prefer the sprawling, run-down location due to concerns over small and overpriced stalls in the new building. The market, which attracts 30,000 customers daily, has become a cultural icon and is feared to lose its identity if relocated. The management insists the current site is outdated, inefficient, and structurally dangerous, but negotiations have stalled, with a final draw for stalls set to take place by March 15.

site_title: Review panel asks anti-graft agency to continue Najib probe
summary: Malaysia's anti-graft agency, MACC, has been instructed by an external review panel to continue investigating a $681 million donation to Prime Minister Najib Razak's personal bank account, despite an earlier order to close the case. The review panel found the investigation into the donation was "still incomplete" and recommended MACC continue its probe. The agency will seek the attorney-general's help in obtaining further evidence and documents from banks overseas. Najib has denied any wrongdoing, claiming the funds were a political donation.

site_title: Brent's slump cuts short STI's brief ascent
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 1.95% on Wednesday, its sharpest single-day fall since January 20, as Brent crude prices dropped 2% to $32.60 per barrel. The decline was driven by rigbuilders Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Marine, which fell 4.2% and 4.3% respectively. Commodity trader Noble Group also tumbled 9.3% amid earnings concerns. The STI lost 52.11 points to 2,619.96, wiping out hopes of a return above the 2,700-point mark.

site_title: GIC to invest 5.2t rupiah in Indonesia's Trans Retail
summary: GIC invests 5.2 trillion Indonesian rupiah (S$544 million) in PT Trans Retail, Indonesia's largest retailer. The investment aims to capture the country's modern retail market, as stated in a joint release by GIC and Trans Retail. This move is expected to allow Trans Retail to expand its operations and capitalize on Indonesia's growing retail market. The investment is seen as a strategic move to boost Trans Retail's growth and competitiveness in the market.

site_title: Investors take heed of the tale of two Chinas
summary: China's stock market experienced a 21% decline in January 2016 due to a quadruple-whammy of events, but the underlying reality is that New China sectors such as services are growing faster, while Old China sectors like steel manufacturing are losing momentum. The sell-down was largely driven by hedge funds' short-selling of the yuan and capital outflows, but these are not indicative of a weakening economy. In fact, China's GDP growth slowed from 6.9% in Q3 to 6.8% in Q4, but this was largely due to the decline in the financial sector. The country's forex reserves have declined by $500 billion, but this is largely due to the repatriation of foreign-currency debt and the "emigration" of ill-gotten gains from corrupt officials. The yuan may still depreciate moderately, but this is not expected to be a sharp decline.

site_title: Mars recalls Dutch-made chocolates from 55 countries
summary: Mars, a US chocolate giant, has recalled millions of Mars and Snickers bars made at its Dutch factory due to a piece of plastic found in a Snickers bar in Germany. The plastic was traced back to the Netherlands factory, prompting the recall in 55 countries. The company has ordered a massive international recall to ensure consumer safety.

site_title: New home sales in January tumble from 10-month high
summary: US new home sales declined 9.2% in January to a 494,000 annualized pace, the weakest in three months. This drop brings sales more in line with the steady pace of progress since the end of the recession. Despite the decline, the labor market remains strong, and household spending is expected to continue, according to economists. The median sales price of a new house fell 4.5% to $278,800, while the supply of homes increased to 5.8 months.

site_title: Online investment firms pose greatest threat: survey
summary: A survey by recruitment firm Robert Half found that online investment firms and challenger banks pose the greatest threat to the financial services sector in the next 12 months. Three in 10 global financial services leaders believe online investment firms will cause the most disruption, followed by challenger banks and peer-to-peer lenders. In Singapore, four in 10 respondents said online investment firms would be the greatest threat, leading banks to increase investments in their own technologies to counter the threat, with an average increase of 13.6% among Singapore banks.

site_title: Who will be left standing at the end of the oil cold war?
summary: The "oil cold war" continues, with various oil-producing countries struggling to stay afloat due to low oil prices. Saudi Arabia, with its low production costs, is weathering the storm better than others, but its breakeven point is difficult to pin down due to its extensive government spending. US shale producers, on the other hand, are hedging their bets to stay profitable, despite low oil prices. Venezuela, with its high production costs and economic crisis, is facing disaster. The breakeven point varies greatly among countries, with some, like Iraq, able to fund their military efforts at low prices, while others, like Venezuela, are on the brink of collapse.

site_title: United Technologies-Honeywell merger still up in the air
summary: A potential merger between United Technologies and Honeywell remains uncertain due to anti-trust reservations from United Technologies. The two industrial conglomerates have previously discussed the possibility, but a deal has yet to materialize. The outcome depends on addressing these concerns.

site_title: Apple-FBI row spurs Senate bill on encrypted data access
summary: US Senators Richard Burr and Dianne Feinstein are drafting a bill that would require Apple and other companies to provide government access to encrypted data, amid the FBI's dispute with Apple over the San Bernardino shooting case. The bill aims to eliminate any legal argument that companies can refuse government orders for access to data, creating a federal pre-emption standard. The measure is part of a larger debate on law enforcement and intelligence agencies accessing encrypted communications, with the bill potentially applying to all US companies, not just technology firms.

site_title: Audi tops US Consumer Reports rankings despite emission scandal
summary: Audi has topped US Consumer Reports' rankings as the best luxury car brand, despite the emissions scandal affecting its parent company, Volkswagen AG. Audi's models were not included in the emissions investigation, and the brand's focus on incremental improvements over dramatic changes contributed to its top ranking. Subaru and Lexus followed closely, with BMW and Porsche scoring high in Consumer Reports tests but being rated slightly lower due to average predicted reliability. The magazine's rankings are based solely on road tests and predicted reliability, and do not account for corporate practices or brand perceptions.

site_title: Unsustainable for productivity gains to lag wage growth: MTI study
summary: A new study published in the Economic Survey of Singapore found that average wage growth in Singapore outpaced productivity gains over the last decade and in the 2010-2015 period. However, the trend is unsustainable in the long run. The study suggests that Singapore's economy may face challenges in maintaining productivity growth, which could impact its competitiveness. The study's findings highlight the need for Singapore to adapt to changing economic conditions and ensure that its workforce remains productive and competitive.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Three Singapore-listed companies - Neptune Orient Lines, Petra Foods, and Bumitama Agri - received updates on their stock performance. Neptune Orient Lines' Q4 2015 core earnings remained in the red, but net loss narrowed. The brokerage OCBC Investment Research recommended investors to accept the offer at S$1.30, citing a stronger balance sheet. Petra Foods was downgraded to "Sell" by RHB Research due to high valuations and ongoing restructuring. Bumitama Agri was upgraded to "Buy" by Maybank Kim Eng Research, citing a 17% earnings per share recovery and undervaluation at 11.5 times price-to-earnings ratio.

site_title: JPMorgan paints rosy picture even as its stock takes a pounding
summary: JPMorgan Chase executives presented a positive outlook for the US economy and the bank's business at their annual investor day, despite its stock price falling 4.2% after disclosing additional reserves to cover potential losses from falling oil prices. The bank's CEO, Jamie Dimon, expressed optimism about nearly all business lines and predicted record profits this year. However, concerns over the global economy and declining oil prices continue to impact the stock market, with JPMorgan's stock down 17% since late November and many banks trading near 2011 levels.

site_title: China Yongsheng to be privatised at S$0.032 a share
summary: China Yongsheng, a CATALIST-listed concrete supplier, is being taken private at S$0.032 a share in a buyout by management and related parties. The buyout values the company at S$53.2 million, a 52% premium to its last traded price. The offeror, Torrington Place Pte Ltd, aims to streamline management and cost structure, allowing shareholders to exit at a premium. The company has been struggling due to weakness in the building and housing industries, resulting in a loss of S$5.1 million in 2015. The buyout is the culmination of negotiations to delist the company since 2014.

site_title: The worst is yet to come for rig-builders
summary: Rig-builders face uncertain times, with oil prices unlikely to recover soon. Despite hopes for a bottom in oil prices late this year, offshore drilling activity is expected to take two years to recover. Listed yard groups in Singapore are exposing themselves to further deferments in deliveries or cancellations of rig projects due to financial distress among clients. Sembcorp Marine and Keppel Offshore & Marine have provisioned for risks tied to ongoing rig-building contracts, with SembMarine setting aside S$609 million. Experts warn that rig builders may have to take ownership of deferred new-builds or recognize impairment charges to survive a protracted downturn.

site_title: EDHEC spearheads infrastructure investment research in Singapore
summary: EDHEC Business School has launched the EDHEC Infrastructure Institute-Singapore, a research unit focused on infrastructure investment research in Singapore. Funded by a grant from the Monetary Authority of Singapore, the unit aims to create the world's largest database on infrastructure investments, with an estimated cost of S$14 million over five years. The research will provide debt and equity investment benchmarks, helping asset owners and investors better understand infrastructure investments. The unit expects to issue its first set of benchmarks by the end of the year and will eventually include 4000 debt and equity projects globally, with Asia's share expected to be around 10%.

site_title: Nike chief to give US$400m for Stanford scholars to address world problems
summary: Nike co-founder Philip Knight is donating $400 million to Stanford University to establish the Knight-Hennessy Scholars Program, a global graduate scholarship initiative addressing world problems such as poverty and climate change. The program aims to recruit 100 students annually, with a focus on producing leaders who can drive positive change. This is one of the largest individual donations to a university, and it matches John Paulson's $400 million gift to Harvard last year. The program is the brainchild of Stanford President John Hennessy, who plans to step down this summer.

site_title: Saudi Arabia to US oilmen: cut costs or get out
summary: Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Ali al-Naimi, warned US oilmen to cut costs or leave the industry, as the country faces financial pain from low oil prices. The message, delivered at a Houston conference, aims to reduce debt and layoffs among high-cost producers, including those in the US. The industry faces significant challenges, with 74 North American producers struggling to sustain debt, and the International Energy Agency predicting another two years of low prices. The warning is part of Saudi Arabia's efforts to balance the market, which may involve a production freeze and further restructuring.

site_title: US crude stocks rise; gasoline stocks fall for first time since November: EIA
summary: US crude stocks rose 3.5 million barrels last week, exceeding analyst expectations. Gasoline inventories fell 2.2 million barrels, marking the first decline since November, while distillate stockpiles dropped 1.7 million barrels. Crude imports fell 117,000 barrels per day. The rise in crude stocks followed refinery cuts and high utilization rates, while gasoline stocks rose on the East Coast to a record.

site_title: Sugar tax needed to combat increase in child obesity and diabetes
summary: Singapore's rising child obesity and diabetes rates, with over a third expected to be diabetic by age 65, highlight the need for action. A sugar tax is proposed to discourage sugared drink consumption, a practice already in place in several countries, including Mexico and Britain. The World Health Organization supports taxation measures to influence purchasing behaviors, citing strong evidence and calling for tighter regulations on sugar-rich foods and drinks, especially for children. A sugar tax could be part of a multi-pronged effort to combat obesity and diabetes, but its effectiveness would depend on its size and implementation.

site_title: London developers finding most expensive apartments hard to sell
summary: London developers are struggling to sell the most expensive apartments due to a sales tax increase for landlords and second-home buyers set to take effect in April. Sales at projects like Lillie Square and Battersea Power Station have slowed, with some developers reporting a 19% decline in demand for London homes under construction. The tax increase will add 15% to the cost of luxury homes, with buyers from Russia and China also purchasing fewer apartments.

site_title: With BG deal completed, Shell is going full speed ahead
