summary: China's new securities chief, Liu Shiyu, vows to take a tough stance on market misconduct, including checking for manipulation and guiding funds into equities. He aims to rebuild investor morale and support the stock market, which has been struggling since last summer's price collapse. Liu replaces Xiao Gang, who was removed after near-unchecked leverage drove the boom. The regulator has increased fines and illicit gains confiscation to a record 5.4 billion yuan, and plans to overhaul initial public offerings and expand trading links with Hong Kong.

site_title: US: Wall St stumbles as oil slumps again
summary: US stocks declined over 1% on Tuesday, hurt by a 4% drop in oil prices, which undercut the market's recent rebound. Energy shares fell 3.2%, leading declines across sectors. The decline is linked to the volatile oil market, with Saudi Oil Minister Ali Al-Naimi ruling out production cuts. This marks the third time oil prices have dropped by over 4% in recent weeks, contributing to the market's downturn.

site_title: Audi tops consumer reports rankings, emission scandal aside
summary: Audi tops Consumer Reports' US rankings as the best brand, despite an emissions scandal affecting its parent company, Volkswagen AG. Audi's consistent excellent road tests, owners' low maintenance reports, and reliability made it stand out. The magazine excludes models under investigation for emissions violations and focuses on current models. Brands with mature lineups, like Audi, and those with improved reliability, such as Lexus and Toyota, performed well. Subaru and Mazda also received high praise, while Fiat Chrysler Automobiles' Jeep brand ranked last due to below-average reliability.

site_title: Fitbit bets on marketing drive for latest devices to stay ahead
summary: Fitbit Inc forecasted revenue and profit in the current quarter that fell short of analysts' estimates, causing its shares to decline 20% in extended trading. The company attributes the shortfall to marketing efforts for its new devices, including a smartwatch, which may slow sales and increase costs. Despite this, Fitbit remains confident in its market share and addressable market, citing a growing demand for wearable health-tracking devices. The company expects sales in the first quarter to be between $420 million and $440 million.

site_title: Apple-FBI row spurs Senate bill on encrypted data access
summary: The US Senate is drafting a bill that would allow government agencies to access encrypted data from US companies, including Apple, without their cooperation. The measure, backed by Republican Senator Richard Burr and Democrat Dianne Feinstein, aims to resolve the ongoing standoff between Apple and the FBI over the San Bernardino shooting investigation. Under the proposed bill, companies would not be able to refuse government orders for encrypted data access, potentially changing the rules of law enforcement. The bill's introduction comes as Apple faces criticism for resisting the FBI's request to unlock an iPhone used by the terrorist gunman.

site_title: Just a few crumbs of comfort
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) warns shipping firms and ports may face tough conditions this year due to uncertainty in global trade, low oil prices, and a slowing Chinese economy. Despite this, most shipping companies are expected to weather the storm, with S&P indicating a negative outlook on 25% of its rated shipping portfolio, potentially leading to rating downgrades. The agency notes that weak global demand and chronic oversupply in the industry will continue to pose challenges.

site_title: Teho unit terminates JV agreement with Sok Bun
summary: TEHO International's unit, Teho Development (Cambodia), has terminated its joint-venture agreement with real estate magnate Sok Bun. Sok Bun will transfer 51% stake in Teho-SBG Development Co to Yim Chhay Line, who has replaced him as director since August. The termination follows allegations of a brutal attack on a former TV presenter and Sok Bun's resignation from other roles. A new joint-venture agreement has been entered into with Yim Chhay Line, with no changes to terms and obligations.

site_title: Jakarta sees no reason to join underperforming Asean stock trading platform
summary: Indonesia's capital market regulator has expressed no intention to join the underperforming Asean Trading Link, citing anaemic trading volumes, jurisdictional concerns, and a lack of post-trade linkage. The platform, launched four years ago, aims to facilitate cross-border trading among Singapore, Malaysia, and Thailand exchanges. Indonesia will only consider joining if the benefits are clear, with at least half of total trading volume carried out on the system. The regulator is also seeking to address issues such as post-trade linkages and jurisdictional disputes before making a decision.

site_title: Oil slumps 4% as Saudi Arabia reaffirms no output cut
summary: Oil prices slumped 4% on Tuesday as Saudi Arabia's oil minister reaffirmed opposition to a production cut, citing a lack of cooperation from other producers. The US benchmark West Texas Intermediate fell to $31.87 a barrel, while Brent North Sea crude dropped to $33.27 a barrel. Saudi Oil Minister Ali Al-Naimi expressed hope for a potential output freeze in March, but Opec member Iran criticized the idea. Analysts expect US crude stockpiles to rise further, with commercial supplies expected to increase by three million barrels.

site_title: CEO of embattled Mexican builder ICA quits - sources
summary: Mexican construction company ICA's CEO, Alonso Quintana Kawage, is leaving his post amid a debt restructuring effort. The company, which has defaulted on interest payments and seen its net debt rise to $51.147 billion, has appointed Luis Zarate as new CEO. Current co-CEO Alfonso Gonzalez Migoya will remain in his post. The move aims to regain investor confidence after a steep slump into debt under Quintana's leadership. ICA is expected to present a restructuring plan in March.

site_title: Qantas posts record H1 profit, announces buyback
summary: Qantas Airways Ltd posted a record first-half profit of A$921 million, more than double its previous year's result. The profit was driven by a 4,500 job cut, cost reductions, and a lower oil price, which reduced its biggest single overhead. The airline also announced a second consecutive A$500 million share buyback. CEO Alan Joyce attributed the turnaround to "good management, not good luck," and the company plans to offer in-flight wireless internet and hire 170 pilots by 2019.

site_title: SICC to give awards for collaborations between large companies and SMEs
summary: The Singapore International Chamber of Commerce (SICC) will give two awards for collaborations between large companies and small and medium enterprises (SMEs) on Feb 26. The awards, part of SICC's "Innovations in Productivity" series, recognize collaborations that enhance SME capabilities, productivity, and growth. The winners will be chosen from a diverse field of nominations and include companies such as Deloitte, HP Indigo, and Rolls-Royce. The awards aim to support Spring Singapore's "Partnerships for Capability Transformation" programme, which matches large and small organizations in collaborative ventures.

site_title: Tech millionaires keep China's wealth machine humming
summary: Chinese tech entrepreneur Wang Feng, chairman of Linekong Interactive Group, has successfully navigated the country's fintech industry, raising $300 million in financing and investing in over 60 companies. Feng, 46, also co-founded Geek Founders Capital, which has raised $60 million for a home console game company. His success is attributed to "fast technological innovations" and smart business decisions, with investors expecting continued growth in China's wealth machine. Global banks are monitoring emerging fintech business models in the country.

site_title: Party ending for India's beer king
summary: Vijay Mallya, India's "beer king," is facing a party-ending end as lenders will auction his Kingfisher Airlines' Mumbai office on March 17. The move comes after banks reported their largest ever losses due to rising bad debts, with 8 trillion rupees (S$164 billion) of stressed assets identified. Mallya's Kingfisher Airlines owes 70 billion rupees to lenders and has been declared a "wilful defaulter" by Punjab National Bank. The auction may trigger the beginning of the end for Mallya, who is also under pressure to repay his debts and revive stalled projects.

site_title: French banks deviate from European rivals; pursue universal banking model
summary: French banks are deviating from European rivals by maintaining a universal banking model, which includes a broad array of businesses and activities. This approach is backed by long-term investors but penalized by the market. French banks, such as BNP Paribas, Societe Generale, and Credit Agricole, are prioritizing growth in market share and supporting French companies' overseas business. Despite lower capital ratios and lower stock market approval, the French government and banks argue that their strategy is necessary to support the French economy and punch above its weight in global financial services.

site_title: Fund managers set up global Islamic stock funds in Indonesia
summary: Fund managers BNP Paribas, Manulife, and Schroder have set up global Islamic stock funds in Indonesia, a move expected to boost the country's Syariah finance industry. The funds will invest in Islamic stocks worldwide, targeting dollar-denominated investments and capitalizing on Indonesia's large Muslim population. This development aims to address Indonesia's stagnated Islamic banking growth and underdeveloped corporate sukuk market, with the country's net asset value of Islamic mutual funds currently 7% of Malaysia's.

site_title: UK staying in an EU stuck in limbo is preferable to leaving
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron may gain support in the June 23 referendum on EU membership as Mayor of London Boris Johnson's decision to join the "out" campaign appears counterproductive. Johnson's move may ultimately help Britain and the EU, while damaging his own political career. Cameron can appeal to his lack of strong beliefs and the UK's "special status" within the EU, as well as the international tide backing the "in" campaign. A "Yes" vote may lead to an EU stuck in limbo, but this is preferable to leaving, which could precipitate partial dismemberment of the EU and disrupt Britain's international trade.

site_title: Emotion, spin clouding UK-EU economic facts
summary: The UK referendum on EU membership is clouded by emotional and spin-driven debate, critics claim. Despite this, economic facts suggest that both sides will seek mutually beneficial trade and investment deals if the UK leaves or stays in the EU. The UK's trade with the EU accounts for 42-53% of its exports and imports, with the EU also being a major source of inward investment. A Brexit would likely have initial uncertainty, but a two-year transition period would allow for the best possible trade and investment deals to be negotiated.

images.alt_text: Mr Cameron's negotiations and limited deals have been widely criticised.

site_title: WHO chief 'confident' Olympics will be safe despite Zika
summary: WHO chief Margaret Chan expressed confidence that Brazil can host the Rio Olympics safely despite the Zika threat, citing the government's efforts to control mosquitoes and coordination with international bodies. Chan praised Brazil's preparation and said she is confident that visitors will receive maximum protection. However, she acknowledged that a long battle against the mosquito-borne virus is ahead. The Olympics are set to begin on August 5.

images.alt_text: The head of the World Health Organization (WHO) said Tuesday she is confident Brazil can host the Rio Olympics safely despite the Zika threat, though she warned of a long battle against the mosquito-borne virus.

site_title: Kuroda hints at shift in thinking on monetary policy's power
summary: Japan's central bank governor Haruhiko Kuroda hinted at a shift in thinking on the power of monetary policy, stating that a monetary base expansion alone cannot achieve the 2% inflation target. Despite nearly tripling the country's monetary base, consumer prices have remained stagnant, and the bank has bolstered its stimulus program twice. The BOJ is considering easing monetary policy again if market turmoil discourages firms from increasing capital spending and wages, with its next policy meeting scheduled for March 14-15.

site_title: Asian Pay Television Trust Q4 profit flat at S$16.3m
summary: Asian Pay Television Trust (APTT) reported a Q4 net profit of S$16.2 million, flat compared to the same period last year. The trust's distribution for the quarter was in line with management guidance and forecasts. The results were announced before the market opened on Tuesday.

site_title: BHP Billiton cuts dividend, posts US$5.67b interim loss
summary: BHP Billiton, the world's largest diversified miner, cut its interim dividend by 75% to 16 US cents per share, its first loss in over 16 years. The company posted a net loss of US$5.67 billion for the six months to Dec 31, 2015, due to a prolonged commodities downturn. BHP pledged a minimum 50% payout of underlying profit going forward and announced a corporate structure revamp to simplify operations. The company's shares ended 2.62% higher despite the dividend cut.

images.alt_text: Mr Mackenzie: "The financial flexibility we will gain as a company from this move . . . will allow us to invest counter cyclically. It will allow us to look at tier one assets in distress."

site_title: Keppel stresses zero tolerance towards illegal acts
summary: Keppel Corp reiterated its zero-tolerance policy towards illegal activities amid Brazil's ongoing corruption probe involving Petrobras and rigbuilder Sete Brasil. Brazilian police are investigating possible bribes paid in contracts signed by Keppel Fels, with over S$6 billion in contracts at stake. Keppel has put its agency relationship with Zwi Skornicki on hold pending investigation outcomes, while SembCorp Marine's parent also denied making illegal payments. The companies' shares have taken a hit, with Keppel closing at S$5.27 and SembCorp Marine at S$1.635.

site_title: Fixing this global malaise is a trip in uncharted waters
summary: The global economy is facing prolonged stagnation, with the World Bank, OECD, and IIF revising down growth forecasts to around 3% this year and next. A global recession is a possibility, but unlike the 2008 Great Recession, there is no "China rabbit" to save the world. Central banks' efforts through quantitative easing have shown diminishing returns, and some argue that inflation could be a more effective stimulus. A financial crisis, such as a massive corporate debt crisis in emerging markets, could tip the world back into recession. The global economy is navigating uncharted waters, and conventional solutions may not be enough to prevent another downturn.

site_title: UK referendum raises Europe-wide currency-market risks
summary: The UK's potential exit from the European Union is raising currency-market risks across Europe, with the pound and euro experiencing significant declines. The UK's exit could damage trade, encourage renegotiations among EU members, and signal further losses in the euro. European leaders are warning of the potential fallout, with some economists suggesting that the UK's departure could call into question the entire European project. The European Central Bank may welcome a weaker euro to revive the region's economy, but systemic risk would be more troubling.

site_title: Facebook not an enemy, telecom carriers told
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg stated that the relationship between telecommunications carriers and messaging apps like Facebook's WhatsApp and Messenger is "symbiotic" and not hostile. He believes that increased use of messaging services generates more traffic and revenue for telecom networks. This is due to the growing trend of sending photos and videos through messaging services.

site_title: Myanmar stops tourists scaling Bagan pagodas
summary: Myanmar's government has banned tourists from climbing the ancient pagodas at Bagan, a UNESCO World Heritage site, due to "disgraceful" tourist behavior. The ban, starting March 1, aims to protect the buildings and prevent potential danger. Locals consider the pagodas holy sites, and the government cited issues with tourists wearing inappropriate clothing, dancing, and sleeping on the monuments. The decision is expected to continue despite the site's popularity, with nearly half a million foreign tourists visiting Bagan last year.

site_title: Yen broadly higher as risk sentiment takes hit
summary: The yen surged over 1% against the euro and US dollar, as risk sentiment declined amid a weaker Chinese yuan and a sharp drop in the German business climate index. The euro fell to its lowest since 2013 against the yen, while the Swiss franc rose to a one-month high against the euro. The US dollar fell 0.8% against the yen, and the pound plummeted 2% on Monday, with sterling expected to remain volatile ahead of the UK's EU referendum on June 23.

site_title: Singapore aims high as Asia's LNG trading hub
summary: Singapore aims to become Asia's leading liquefied natural gas (LNG) trading hub, connecting East and West by linking African gas producers to Asian buyers. The city-state has existing infrastructure and plans to expand its storage capacity to 11 million tonnes per annum. Singapore's Energy Market Authority has shortlisted four companies to supply LNG, and the Singapore Exchange has launched a price index for LNG contracts. The region's growing demand for small-scale LNG solutions, particularly in South-east Asia, is expected to drive the growth of LNG trade in the area.

site_title: Noble warns of Q4 loss from US$1.2 billion of impairments
summary: Noble Group announced a net loss for its fourth quarter and a full-year loss for 2015 due to US$1.2 billion of impairments and adjustments, primarily related to coal prices. The write-downs, which include a conservative coal price of US$55 per tonne, will push 2015 results into the red and NAV from S$1 to over S$0.70 a share. The firm's cash realised from long-term contracts was in line with expectations, and its balance sheet remains strong.

site_title: When will we see the turning point in EMs?
summary: Emerging markets (EMs) face significant challenges in 2016, driven by negative investor sentiment, low commodity prices, and economic slowdowns in key regions. Despite this, Asia is preferred over Latin America and EEMEA due to its strong tech, consumer discretionary, and financial sectors. China's economic growth is expected to slow, but domestic equity markets remain volatile. Selective and tactical allocation to EMs is recommended, with a focus on Asia's tech names, India's structural story, and the Philippines' domestic story. DMs are expected to outperform EMs, driven by improving domestic demand and liquidity from central banks.

site_title: Aspiring entrants to mobile market will need deep pockets
summary: The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) has confirmed plans for a fourth mobile phone operator in the country, despite industry doubts. The IDA has reserved 60 MHz of spectrum, including the 900 MHz band, for the new operator. The reserve price has been reduced from S$40 million to S$35 million. Aspiring entrants to the mobile market will need significant funds to pay for spectrum, survive a possible bid war, and compete aggressively on price in their first two years.

site_title: Parcel delivery firm Yamato eyes Asean market with GDex stake
summary: Japan's largest parcel delivery company, Yamato Group, has acquired nearly a fourth of Malaysia's GD Express Carrier Bhd (GDex) for RM217.3 million. The acquisition gives Yamato a 22.8% stake in GDex, making it the second-largest shareholder. The companies have signed a memorandum of business collaboration to explore growth opportunities in Malaysia, Singapore, and other Asean countries, with a focus on e-commerce and last-mile delivery. Yamato aims to leverage GDex's strengths and competitiveness to deliver on its Asean aspirations.

site_title: No evidence of petrol price fixing, S'pore competition watchdog finds
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) has found no evidence of petrol price fixing among the four major oil companies in Singapore. Despite a 59-cent drop in crude oil prices over two years, consumers paid 45 cents less for 95-octane fuel. The CCS attributed the relatively high pass-through of wholesale price changes to non-fuel components such as taxes, duties, and operating costs. The study, which covered a six-year period, also found that the listed retail petrol price moved in tandem with the wholesale MOPS price, but with a delay.

site_title: Trump vs Hillary on the cards
summary: Donald Trump's presidential campaign has defied expectations, despite numerous predictions of his demise. Trump won a significant victory in South Carolina, with 33% of the Republican vote, and his campaign momentum appears strong. Jeb Bush dropped out of the race, and Ted Cruz finished third. Trump's performance has raised questions about the viability of Trump sceptics' narratives, with many predicting his downfall. His ability to win in South Carolina, a traditionally Republican state, and his dominance among military retirees, suggests he may be a strong contender for the Republican nomination.

images.alt_text: It was the Trump conventional wisdom that peaked once again in South Carolina on Saturday. Winning close to 33 per cent of the Republican vote, the Donald won big in the Palmetto State.

site_title: CapitaLand prices Cairnhill project 'to fit market conditions'
summary: CapitaLand has priced its 268-unit Cairnhill condominium project at S$2,500 per square foot, targeting affordable prices in the Orchard Road area amid loan curbs. The project, which includes a 220-unit Ascott serviced residence, is designed to fit current market conditions, with units ranging from 591 to 3,864 square feet and starting prices from S$1.35 million to S$6.67 million. The developer believes the pricing is competitive, with a VIP preview scheduled for Feb 27 and official launch in mid-March.

site_title: US economy continued to rebound in 2015, says White House report
summary: The US economy continued its strong rebound in 2015, with unemployment falling to 4.9% and average nominal hourly wages growing 2.7%, the highest since the recession began. However, the report acknowledges that rapid technological change is weighing on workers, sharpening income disparities and fuelling disaffection. The White House attributes the economic growth to President Obama's policies, but notes that Congress has not passed all of his requested measures, including a minimum-wage increase and infrastructure plan.

site_title: Billionaires face up to life's changes
summary: A UBS Billionaires Insights 2015 report found that the total wealth of the world's billionaires increased eight-fold from $0.7 trillion to $5.4 trillion over the last two decades, despite global GDP doubling from $30 trillion to $77 trillion. The average billionaire's wealth rose from $2.9 billion to $11 billion in the same period. The 14 largest billionaire markets accounted for three-quarters of the world's total billionaire wealth, with the wealth of the average billionaire also increasing in these markets.

site_title: Why is Asian private banking still attractive when everyone else is selling?
summary: The Asian private banking industry is expected to continue growing briskly over the next decade, driven by the region's large and growing high-net-worth individual (HNWI) population. Despite current global economic dislocation, Asia's HNWI segment is fundamentally sound, with China and India expected to lead the region's wealth growth. However, Asian wealth is distinct from Western wealth, requiring tailored solutions and a focus on liquidity, hedging, and foreign exchange overlays. As wealth is passed to the next generation, clients are becoming more sophisticated, seeking diversified and professionally managed portfolios. Despite low revenue margins and high costs, the industry is expected to remain attractive, with those that invest in digitalization and talent standing a better chance to succeed.

site_title: Investing in a diversified fund-of-funds portfolio amid volatility
summary: Investors are advised to diversify their portfolios amid market volatility, particularly in 2016, due to Chinese policy uncertainty, oil price collapse, and weakening economies. A diversified fund-of-funds portfolio, including institutional share classes, liquid alternatives, and ETFs, can provide a disciplined and structured approach to managing risk and seeking long-term returns. By allocating to hedge funds and ETFs, investors can enhance their portfolios' risk-return profiles and access targeted investment opportunities. A long-term, unemotional approach to investing is recommended to benefit from market trends.

site_title: Chance for SingPost board to further cement confidence
summary: SingPost's board is considering further steps to restore confidence with investors after the company's shares recovered from a sell-down in January. A joint special audit with law firm Drew & Napier (D&N) and PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) may help alleviate concerns about independence. However, minority shareholders may feel they are not getting the optimal cost-benefit equation, as they will indirectly pay for the fees. The board could strengthen its relationship with investors by releasing the full special audit findings or offering to foot the costs of the audit.

images.alt_text: Now that Singapore Post shares have recovered from their sell-down in January, what the group does next with its special audit findings could be a good opportunity to further restore confidence and cement its relationship with investors.

site_title: IMF chief sees 'tepid' growth for world economy
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde stated that the world economy is experiencing a "tepid" recovery, with global growth at 3.1% last year and expected to grow 3-4% this year and 4-5% in 2017. However, advanced economies, such as the US, Europe, and Japan, are not reaching their potential growth. Emerging economies, except India, are slowing down, with China, Russia, Brazil, and South Africa expected to be in negative territory this year. Commodity producers face a new reality due to declining prices, which is changing their business models.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng unit puts in top bid for site near Tanah Merah MRT
summary: Chip Eng Seng's unit, CEL Residential Development, has submitted the highest bid of S$419.38 million (S$761 per square foot per plot ratio) for a residential site at New Upper Changi Road/Bedok South Avenue 3. The site, originally on the reserve list, was launched for tender after a developer submitted a minimum price. The proposed 720-unit condo with full facilities and a childcare centre is expected to be financed by internal funds and bank borrowings. The top bid exceeded most consultants' expectations, with analysts attributing it to favourable market conditions and the absence of a strong competing project in the area.

site_title: BHP admits that dividend pledges and mining do not mix
summary: BHP Billiton, the world's largest miner, has slashed its interim dividend by 74% to $0.16 a share, citing a cyclical sector where consistency matters less than safeguarding the balance sheet. The company will now distribute at least half of net profit before one-offs, rather than following a "progressive" policy. This move is seen as a response to market pressure, with the stock's double-digit yield previously indicating an excessive payout. BHP also reduced capital expenditure plans by $3.5 billion to $12 billion over the next two years.

images.alt_text: BHP Billiton has slashed cash returns to shareholders and followed rival Rio Tinto in scrapping a progressive policy.

site_title: Gas only a stopgap for UK without carbon capture: report
summary: A UK Energy Research Centre report states that natural gas will only serve as a stopgap until 2020 before being limited without carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology, which is necessary to meet the UK's goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 80% by 2050. Gas currently accounts for 47% of UK primary energy consumption and will decrease to 10% by 2050. Without CCS, gas will need to be phased out over 35 years, with nearly all emissions removed by 2050.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: OUE Limited has agreed to raise its stake in OUE Commercial Reit to 64.98% by purchasing 203.15 million units from Gordon Tang for S$165.97 million, a 14% discount to the net tangible asset value per unit. The purchase price works out to S$0.817 per unit, above the closing price of S$0.645.

site_title: Yes, tax sugar but ease up on alcohol
summary: A sugar tax in Singapore is worth exploring due to the high incidence of diabetes (12.9% of adults) and childhood obesity. Implementing a sugar tax, like in Mexico, could reduce sugar content and consumption by 12%. Countries like Indonesia, the Philippines, and India are studying similar measures. The government could also consider reducing taxes on alcohol to balance the issue, as cheaper drinks are available in neighboring cities. A sugar tax would help redraw lifestyle choices and promote healthier habits.

site_title: Markets look to G20 meeting for solutions
summary: The G20 meeting in Shanghai aims to address market fluctuations and restore stability to currencies and stock markets. Finance ministers and central bank governors will discuss ways to respond to the global economic situation. Japan's finance minister Taro Aso expressed a desire to consider firm responses to the economic situation. The meeting seeks to build certainty in governance and global economic policy.

site_title: The iPhone saga: Apple hindering a criminal probe only it can assist
summary: Apple has refused to unlock an iPhone 5c used in the San Bernardino massacre, citing concerns over building a backdoor to the device and compromising customer privacy. The US government, led by the FBI, had requested access to the data, citing national security concerns. Apple claims compliance would set a dangerous precedent, but industry peers and civil liberty groups support the tech giant's stance. Microsoft's Bill Gates, however, views the FBI request as a limited demand. The case highlights the tension between data protection, customer privacy, and public protection.

site_title: What lies ahead for Asean markets?
summary: Asean markets are expected to remain cautious in 2016 due to emerging currency risks, slow growth, and the impact of US Federal Reserve's monetary tightening on local currencies. Commodity exporters, such as Malaysia and Indonesia, may see a drop in export revenues, while elevated household debt in countries like Malaysia and Thailand may hold back consumer spending. However, Asean still offers opportunities in infrastructure development, medical tourism, and trade agreements like the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), which could boost trade growth and create new economic avenues.

site_title: Navigating changing expectations with agility
summary: ABN Amro predicts that investors will need to navigate changing market expectations in 2016, as the global economy and financial markets have shown resilience despite past risks. The firm expects a moderate recovery in the US and Europe, but with fluctuations in market confidence. To adapt, investors should focus on international diversification, fundamentals, and agility, particularly in equities, corporate bonds, and hedge funds. Key areas of interest include European equities, travel sector, and emerging markets, where the rise of the middle class is driving growth.

images.alt_text: Changing expectations in 2016 will see moments when risk reprices, paving the way for new investment opportunities, according to Mr Duret.

site_title: Boeing studying novel design for mid-market plane
summary: Boeing is developing a novel mid-market plane design with 240-250 seats, aiming to replace its 757 model and rewrite airplane economics. The plane's unique oval-shaped cross-section and potential use of carbon-composite materials could reshape the engine industry for the next two decades. Engine makers Pratt & Whitney and Rolls-Royce are studying the project, with Pratt's new president expressing interest in collaborating with Boeing. The development could influence the outcome of the next fleet renewal in 15 years and impact the engine industry's future dynamics.

site_title: Sheng Siong Q4 earnings up on better revenue, margins
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singaporean supermarket group, reported a 23.6% year-on-year jump in net profit to S$14.61 million in its fourth quarter, driven by higher revenue and improved gross margins. Revenue rose 4.9% to S$187.1 million, with new store openings contributing 6.6% to the top line. The group expects competition to remain keen and warned that consumers may become more cost-conscious, affecting its ability to pass on input cost increases to customers.

site_title: F1 bosses meet to agree on regulations for 2017 season
summary: Formula One bosses met in Geneva to agree on 2017 season regulations amid declining TV audiences and concerns over the sport's entertainment value. Outspoken CEO Bernie Ecclestone described the sport as "the worst it has ever been." The meeting comes as the sport seeks to revamp its image and attract new fans. No specific regulatory changes were announced, but the meeting aimed to address the sport's stagnant performance and explore ways to improve its appeal.

site_title: China banks' January net forex sales fall to US$54.4b
summary: China's commercial banks saw a 39% decline in net foreign exchange sales in January, falling to US$54.4 billion from US$89.4 billion in December. The central bank also sold a record US$644.5 billion in foreign exchange, amid concerns about China's economic slowdown and potential interest rate hikes. China's foreign exchange reserves fell US$99.5 billion to US$3.23 trillion, the lowest level since May 2012. Despite this, Chinese officials attribute the capital outflows to companies repaying foreign debt, rising outbound investment, and increased tourism spending.

site_title: Investor overtakes CEO in Glencore shareholding
summary: Glencore's CEO Ivan Glasenberg has been overtaken by investor David Herro as the largest shareholder of the Swiss commodity trader-cum-miner. Herro's firm, Harris Associates LP, now owns over 8.5% of Glencore, surpassing Glasenberg's 8.4%. Herro attributed the shift to a "bear story" being overblown, and expressed optimism about the company's future. Glencore's shares have rebounded 46% this year as the company implements a debt reduction plan. Herro believes Glencore remains significantly undervalued.

site_title: China's Moon Lake Investment gets nod to buy oldest Australian dairy farm
summary: China's Moon Lake Investment has received approval to purchase Australia's oldest dairy farm, Van Diemen's Land Co, for A$280 million. The deal comes under new tax rules for foreign firms, requiring compliance with Australian tax laws and information sharing. Treasurer Scott Morrison stated the deal would ensure employment and investment in Tasmania while enforcing tax payment. Failure to comply could result in prosecution and divestment of the asset, aiming to prevent multinational companies from shifting profits to low-tax havens.

site_title: Pasta-maker finds bugs are recipe for success
summary: An artisanal pasta-maker in northeastern France, Atelier a Pates, is struggling to meet demand after adding insect flour to its recipes. The insect flour, made from crickets and grasshoppers, is high in protein and has been successfully marketed as a high-protein pasta for athletes. The company's products, priced at around 6 euros per 250g package, are more expensive than standard pasta but can replace meat for vegetarians and offer health benefits, particularly for those with iron or magnesium deficiencies.

images.alt_text: An artisanal pasta-maker in north-eastern France is struggling to meet demand after adding a crunchy, protein-rich ingredient to the noodles: insects.

site_title: Concerns over SingPost still linger for fund managers
summary: Concerns over SingPost's corporate governance issues persist among major fund managers, with over 10 institutions contacting the company's board and management to discuss the issues. The shares have recovered somewhat since a selldown last month, but unanswered questions remain a worry for institutions.

site_title: Banks largest contributors to STI's rise
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 11.42 points to 2,672.07, mirroring gains in other markets, including Dow futures, Hong Kong, and China. The largest contributors to the index's gain were the three banks, which rose alongside other stocks. Turnover was 1.4 billion units worth S$1.3 billion, with 212 rises and 165 falls. The index's performance is part of a broader market trend, but no specific conclusion can be drawn from this single day's data.

site_title: Thai government approves 93b baht in soft loans to help farmers
summary: Thailand's military-led government approved 93 billion baht in soft loans to help farmers affected by falling commodity prices and drought. The loans include 72 billion for small agricultural businesses, 15 billion for crop changes, and 6 billion for emergency lending. The move aims to support rural Thailand, which accounts for half of the population and has been in recession for over a year. The loans are part of the junta's efforts to revive the country's economy, which has been struggling with weak exports and domestic demand.

site_title: Super Group's Q4 profit falls 39%
summary: Super Group's Q4 profit fell 39% to S$15.7 million due to higher tax expenses and lower food ingredient sales. Revenue slipped 8% to S$141.1 million, with a 6% dip in full-year revenue to S$509.2 million. The company attributed the decline to increased operating costs from rebranding efforts. A second and final dividend of 1.2 cents a share was proposed, bringing the total dividend for 2015 to 2.2 cents a share.

site_title: Buckle up for a rocky ride
summary: The article discusses the challenges investors face in 2016 due to heightened market volatility. To navigate this environment, diversification across asset classes is key, with a focus on rebalancing and staying invested. Three factors that may influence the outlook for risk assets are the weakening Chinese yuan, the longevity of the US business cycle, and low oil prices. The US Federal Reserve is expected to slow the pace of rate hikes, and low oil prices are likely to benefit the global economy, offsetting losses in the energy sector. A diversified portfolio of equities, income-generating assets, and alternative strategies can help investors navigate the market volatility.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: DBS Group Holdings' net profit margin stabilised at 0.9% in 2015, with management aiming to keep it below 1.3% in 2016. Despite valuations being relatively low, global banks are trading at less than 0.5-0.6 times price-to-book. Raffles Medical Group's FY2015 results met expectations, with management focusing on staff costs to improve margins. Meanwhile, Singapore rigbuilders Sete Brasil and SMM are uncertain due to Petrobras' lease contract proposal delay, with potential implications for their working capital and yard facilities.

site_title: The investment outlook for 2016
summary: In 2016, markets will be driven by ongoing trends including China's economic slowdown, sharp commodity price declines, and US monetary policy normalisation. China's economy grew 6.9% in 2015, the slowest in 25 years, while the US Federal Reserve is expected to hike interest rates 100 basis points, with a 25 basis point increase in December. This may lead to higher volatility in global markets, with the eurozone and Japan appearing undervalued but lacking catalysts for a rerating. A neutral stance on risk assets is recommended, with a focus on maintaining a cash buffer and adopting a tactical approach.

images.alt_text: The US dollar should remain strong given monetary policy divergence with most other major economies, notes Mr Neo

site_title: Seas rising faster than they have in 2,800 years, say scientists
summary: Scientists have reconstructed sea level history over 3,000 years, concluding that the 20th century rise was "extremely likely" faster than any previous 27 centuries. The study, published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, found that sea levels rose about 14 centimeters from 1900 to 2000, with a rate of 1.4 millimeters per year. The current rate is 3.4 millimeters per year, suggesting acceleration. The study blames global warming for the anomalous 20th century rise, with no chance of a 14-centimeter rise if humans hadn't warmed the planet.

site_title: NOL's Q4 loss narrows to US$75m
summary: NEPTUNE Orient Lines (NOL) reported a net attributable loss of US$75.45 million for Q4, down from US$85.07 million a year ago. The carrier turned a full-year profit of US$707.2 million, excluding a loss of US$259.84 million previously. Despite a 28% decline in revenue, NOL narrowed its Q4 net loss by US$8 million and its full-year loss from continuing operations fell by 5% to US$72 million. NOL's acquisition by CMA CGM is expected to be completed by mid-2016.

images.alt_text: Freight rates hit historical lows in Q4 on supply pressure from a large number of newbuild vessels joining the global fleet and weakness in demand across many trade lanes from a lacklustre global economy, China's softening growth and ultra-low bunker prices.

site_title: In art we trust
summary: A single art collection can significantly impact a person's net worth, but it also poses significant security risks, particularly upon the collector's death. Disputes over art ownership and value have led to numerous cases of missing works, with some valued at over $60 million. To safeguard art investments, collectors can consider wealth planning, which involves holding art in a trust to ensure proper stewardship, security, and insurance. This approach can also help avoid probate and publicity, allowing collectors to pass on their passion while achieving their legacy goals.

site_title: 3D printers may soon be making spare parts for flawed hearts
summary: Researchers are working on 3D printing customized spare parts for flawed hearts, bypassing donor lists and immune-suppressing drugs. The technology, already used in various medical applications, has shown promise in printing models of organs and tissues. Scientists envision printing custom patches or full-fledged beating hearts, exact fits for patients' bodies. Experimental studies have created knee cartilage, bones, and artificial ears, and costs are decreasing as discoveries accelerate. Multiple teams are working on bioprinting heart tissue, which could help 100,000 people a year facing long waiting lists for transplants.

site_title: Mars recalling products in 55 countries: AP
summary: US chocolate company Mars Inc is recalling candy bars and other products in 55 countries after finding plastic in one of its products. The recall, initially announced in Germany, was later expanded to include other countries. The company has not commented on the matter. This move is a response to the discovery of plastic in one of its products, highlighting potential quality control issues.

site_title: Cushman & Wakefield appoints new Singapore MD
summary: Cushman & Wakefield has appointed Stephen Saul as its new managing director for Singapore, effective March 1. Saul, a 30-year industry veteran, replaces Toby Dodd and will lead the Singapore business, focusing on corporate real estate growth. Saul previously held senior executive positions at JLL and Glenborough Realty Trust, driving growth for businesses in the Asia-Pacific region. He will report to Stuart Roberts, Cushman & Wakefield's chief executive for the Asia-Pacific.

site_title: Existing home sales in Jan is second-strongest since Feb 2007
summary: Existing US home sales rose 0.4% to a 5.47 million annual rate in January, the second-highest pace since February 2007, according to the National Association of Realtors. This indicates the housing industry will continue to prosper. Prices increased, while the number of dwellings on the market decreased, contributing to the growth.

site_title: A tweak to the inflation forecast, a debate over MAS's Sing dollar policy
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) lowered its 2016 headline inflation forecast to -1 to 0 per cent, down from -0.5 to 0.5 per cent, due to the significant step-down in global oil prices and the decline in Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums. However, the core inflation forecast remains unchanged at 0.5 to 1.5 per cent. Economists interpret the decision as a possible sign of a weaker Singapore dollar policy, but others see it as a wait-and-see story, with MAS likely to ease monetary policy in April.

site_title: Yuan use for trade deals growing despite volatility, interventions
summary: Despite concerns over China's cooling economy and potential currency weakness, the yuan's attractiveness for trade deals is expected to grow this year. Arbitrage activities, particularly interest rate and foreign exchange rate differences, are driving the increase in transactions settled in the currency. Companies are benefiting from these differences through various means, including fake trade invoices and interest rate arbitrage. Analysts predict that yuan cross-border trade settlement may reach 30% of China's total trade by the end of 2016, despite volatility and market concerns.

site_title: London Stock Exchange says in merger talks with German rival
summary: The London Stock Exchange Group is in merger talks with Deutsche Boerse, a German rival, in a potential deal of equals. The talks follow a sharp jump in LSE Group's share price, with both boards confirming detailed discussions. The merger would bring together the London and Milan exchanges, owned by LSE Group. No further details have been announced, but the move aims to strengthen the European exchange market.

site_title: A tale of two halves - alpha vs beta strategies for 2016
summary: Global capital markets started 2016 on a negative note due to concerns over falling oil prices and China's economic slowdown. However, market experts emphasize that fundamentals, not initial sentiment, determine long-term direction. Despite dire predictions from doomsayers, the past five years have seen significant market growth. The article concludes that investors should focus on fundamentals rather than being swayed by fear or doomsday scenarios, and that past predictions of market crashes and hyperinflation did not come to pass. Market bears and experts alike agree that the year's tone and trend are ultimately determined by underlying fundamentals.

images.alt_text: It's important to have an appropriate investment time horizon as time in the market matters, advises Mr Yeo.

site_title: Revisiting an Asian marathon
summary: Credit Suisse's private banking business in Asia has seen significant developments since 2012, including major mergers and acquisitions (M&A) involving the private banking industry. Despite bouts of market volatility and regulatory demands, Asia's wealth pools continue to grow, with the Asia-Pacific region projected to generate 50% of global wealth growth in the next five years. The region's middle-class wealth has expanded by 70% to $27.2 trillion, creating opportunities for businesses targeting young consumers. To succeed, private banks must adopt complex operating models that combine offshore and onshore platforms, taking into account diverse client needs in a rapidly evolving regulatory environment.

images.alt_text: Managing the expanding wealth pools of Asian economies continues to be a rewarding business with secular growth potential, says Mr de Ferrari.

site_title: Tokyo candy shop offers a sweet taste of the past
summary: A Tokyo candy shop, Umebachiya, founded in 1915, offers traditional crystallized vegetables using techniques from the Edo period. Owner Soichi Maruyama preserves his family's techniques, which involve simmering vegetables in sugared water over several days. The shop's products, including sugared cherry tomatoes and goya bitter gourd, have gained attention for their unique flavors and textures. With only one remaining craftsman, Umebachiya aims to balance tradition with innovation, offering 20 types of sugared products and collaborating with hotels to promote their unique offerings.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% due to market uncertainty and tariffs. US stocks edged down from records amid Trump's tariff threats on Canada. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, with similar operating loss as H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Chinese yuan - Where do we go from here?
summary: China's yuan has faced pressure due to the trilemma challenge of flexible exchange rates, open capital accounts, and controlled interest rates. The country's nominal GDP growth has slipped to 6.0% in 4Q15, impacted by weak productivity, slowing wage growth, and weaker export growth. To address the issue, China's policy makers initially chose monetary easing, but later shifted to a more balanced approach, with the yuan appreciating on a trade-weighted basis. Capital outflows and declining FX reserves have been a result of the trilemma pressures, which have been building since mid-2014.

site_title: US existing home sales rise to six-month high
summary: US existing home sales rose 0.4% to a six-month high of 5.47 million units in January, exceeding forecasted declines. This marks the highest sales pace since July 2020, with the median price increasing 8.2% to $213,800 from a year ago. The surge in sales is attributed to a tightening labor market, boosting wage growth, and more first-time buyers entering the market. The housing report suggests the economy regained momentum after slowing in the fourth quarter, with sales up 11% from the previous year.

site_title: Centurion stays upbeat on demand; profit down on lack of one-off gains
summary: Centurion Corp reported a 90% drop in net profit to $7.5 million for the fourth quarter, despite revenue rising 8% to $28.3 million. The company attributed the decline to fair-value gains on investment properties and share of results of associated companies and joint ventures. However, its core business operations saw a 9% increase in net profit to $9.2 million. Centurion remains confident in the demand for purpose-built worker accommodation in Singapore and Malaysia, with occupancy rates of over 90% in Singapore and 70% in Malaysia.

site_title: Indonesia calls for central bank to cut policy rate
summary: Indonesia's chief economic minister, Darmin Nasution, has urged the central bank to cut its policy rate to 4-5% to reflect liquidity conditions and drive down banks' lending rates. The current benchmark interest rate is 7.00%, and the government aims for the lending rate to be as low as 9% by year-end. The move aims to stimulate economic growth, which slowed more than expected in 2015, and to make Indonesia's interest rates more competitive with neighboring countries.

site_title: US banking profit rose 7.5% in 2015 as legal costs fell
summary: US banking profit rose 7.5% in 2015, driven by modest revenue gains and lower litigation costs. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp reported $163.7 billion in industry earnings, with fourth-quarter earnings increasing 12% to $40.8 billion. Large banks experienced year-over-year margin growth of 3.13% and saw a 2.3% increase in lending, with commercial and industrial lending remaining strong. The improvement in asset quality and reduced legal expenses contributed to the increase in net income.

site_title: JPMorgan sees 'massive uncertainty' if Britain votes to exit EU
summary: JPMorgan Chase's CEO predicts "massive uncertainty" if Britain votes to exit the European Union, citing potential economic and infrastructure costs. The bank may relocate hundreds of salespeople or duplicate its infrastructure, resulting in significant expenses. Pinto notes that the outcome's short-term impact will be negative for everyone involved, while its long-term effects are uncertain.

site_title: What's a billion here there?
summary: Asian private banks continue to find opportunities in the region despite the tough financial market conditions in 2015. Major players in the industry reported significant growth in assets under management (AUM) and revenue. DBS Bank, Bank of Singapore, UOB Private Bank, UBS Wealth Management, Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank Wealth Management, Maybank Private Wealth, and ABN Amro Private Banking Asia and Middle East reported AUM growth ranging from 14% to 77% and revenue growth of 14% to 50%. Industry experts believe Asia remains an attractive market for private banking, with wealth creation continuing and the region expected to add significant economic value over the next 25 years.

site_title: Iran dismisses oil production freeze as 'joke': minister
summary: Iran's oil minister, Bijan Zanganeh, has dismissed a proposed output freeze deal between top oil producers Saudi Arabia, Russia, and OPEC members as "a joke." The deal aims to stabilize the oversupplied market, but Iran, which has increased production since sanctions were lifted, will not relinquish its market share. The freeze would freeze production at 10 million barrels per day, while Iran would freeze at 1 million barrels per day. Iran's dismissal of the deal has sparked disappointment among those hoping for an output cut, and oil prices have risen over 2% in response.

site_title: Share of past-due US commercial and industrial loans rises
summary: US businesses fell behind on commercial and industrial loans in the fourth quarter, with the share of loans 90 days or more past due rising to 0.78% from 0.69% a quarter earlier. This marks the fourth straight quarterly increase. The global economic slowdown, which has affected the US energy and manufacturing sectors, is being closely watched by the Federal Reserve. Despite this, US households appear to be on a better footing, with the noncurrent loan rate for nonfarm residential properties at 0.86% and credit card loans at 1.15%.

site_title: US consumer confidence falls in February
summary: US consumer confidence fell in February to 92.2, down from 97.8 in January, amid high market turbulence. Assessments of the present situation and expected situation in six months declined. While half of respondents viewed current business conditions as "normal", those viewing them as "bad" increased, and job prospects improved slightly. The decline in consumer confidence suggests greater economic apprehension.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as oil rally falters
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones down 47.46 points, the S&P 500 losing 6.57 points, and the Nasdaq Composite index dropping 21.08 points. The decline came after oil prices resumed their declines, thwarting a rally. The market struggles to sustain gains despite records set earlier in the week, amid ongoing US-EU trade tensions and concerns over tariffs.

site_title: Does China really support the US-Asean partnership?
summary: US President Barack Obama hosted a special US-Asean summit meeting in California, marking the first such meeting held in the US. The summit discussed the South China Sea issue, with leaders expressing collective concern over militarization in the region. Despite China's anxieties, the Sunnylands Declaration issued after the summit refrained from criticizing China and instead reaffirmed key principles, including the peaceful resolution of disputes and freedom of navigation. The US aims to deepen its relationship with Asean countries, with Obama urging them to join the Trans-Pacific Partnership. The summit's outcome is seen as a positive step in strengthening US-Asean ties, which will be crucial for the new president to inherit.

site_title: German business sentiment hits 14-month low in February
summary: German business confidence hit a 14-month low in February, according to the Ifo economic institute's closely-watched business climate index. The decline marks the lowest level since December 2014, reflecting gloomy economic prospects. This news comes as the global economy faces various challenges, including rising US tariffs and slowing GDP growth in China. The negative sentiment may impact Germany's economic performance and overall European economy.

site_title: US home prices up in December, but short of expectations
summary: US single-family home prices rose 5.7% in December on a year-over-year basis, matching the previous month's increase but falling short of economists' expectations of 5.8%. Prices rose 0.8% from November on a seasonally adjusted basis, with three cities - San Francisco, Denver, and Portland - reporting the highest year-over-year gains. The pace of home price growth is slowing, according to S&P Dow Jones Indices' managing director David Blitzer.

site_title: Lippo Malls Indo Retail Trust raises Q4 DPU by 14% to 0.81 Singapore cent
summary: Lippo Malls Indo Retail Trust raised its Q4 distribution per unit by 14% to 0.81 Singapore cent, driven by a 22.3% increase in net property income to S$40.2 million. The full-year net property income rose 25.8% to S$158.6 million.

site_title: Volkswagen chief predicts 'renaissance' in US business
summary: Volkswagen CEO Matthias Mueller predicts a "renaissance" in the US business, despite the company's involvement in the massive emissions-cheating scandal. Mueller acknowledges the need to face fines but believes the US sympathizes with the underdog, giving Volkswagen a second chance. The company admitted to installing defeat devices in 11 million vehicles worldwide, sparking a global crisis. Mueller, who traveled to the US in January to resolve the scandal, is confident in the company's ability to survive and thrive, stating "Certainly. And very well."

site_title: First Ship Lease Trust Q4 profit falls 98.9% to US$83,000; no distribution for quarter
summary: FIRST Ship Lease Trust reported a 98.9% decline in Q4 net profit to US$83,000, and no distribution for the quarter or the year. The trust's full-year net profit more than tripled to US$14.1 million. Rentals from vessels increased by 5.8% to US$14.2 million, but depreciation expenses rose 33.4% to US$15.3 million. The company expects a US$4.2 million loss on disposal of two Panamax container ships due to falling steel prices.

site_title: IMF chief sees 'tepid' growth for world economy
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde said the world economy is experiencing a "tepid" recovery, with global growth at 3.1% last year and expected to grow by 3.2% this year. Growth in advanced economies should be higher, but is currently lower than potential output. Emerging economies, except for India, are slowing down, with countries like China, Russia, Brazil, and South Africa facing challenges. Commodity producers, particularly oil exporters, are dealing with a new reality due to declining prices.

site_title: JPMorgan to increase oil and gas loan loss reserves by over 60%
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co plans to increase its reserves to cover potential oil and gas loan losses by over 60% in the first quarter, setting aside an additional $500 million. This follows a stressed scenario where oil prices are at $25 a barrel for 18 months, requiring an additional $1.5 billion in reserves. The bank also expects to increase reserves for metals and mining loan exposure by $100 million to $350 million.

site_title: Morgan Stanley says US commercial real estate price growth will be flat this year
summary: Morgan Stanley analysts predict US commercial real estate prices will remain flat in 2016, reversing a previous forecast of 5% growth. The decision is attributed to a worrying dynamic between lenders and property values, where lenders are hesitant to lend due to the rapid appreciation of prices. This has led to a decrease in investment demand, resulting in flat price growth. The analysts' prediction contrasts with the recent rapid appreciation of commercial real estate prices in the US.

site_title: Thailand examines airline finances due to safety concerns
summary: Thailand's civil aviation authority ordered Thai-registered airlines to submit financial reports by March 31 to avoid license revocation. This move follows the US Federal Aviation Administration's downgrade of Thailand's safety ratings in December. The Civil Aviation Authority of Thailand (CAAT) found four small airlines with high debt levels affecting safety standards. The military government aims to improve aviation standards and address safety concerns.

site_title: Chocolate giant Mars orders recall of Mars, Snickers bars in Germany
summary: Mars, a German chocolate factory, has ordered a massive recall of Mars, Snickers, Milky Way Minis, and Celebrations bars due to the discovery of plastic in a product. The recall affects products with a best before date from June 19, 2016 to January 8, 2017. The company is voluntarily recalling the products to prevent consumers from consuming them. A full list of affected products can be found on the company's website. The recall is the company's largest in history.

images.alt_text: Chocolate giant Mars Tuesday ordered a massive recall of Mars and Snickers bars as well as Milky Way Minis in Germany after plastic was found in a product.

site_title: EU to start 2016 stress tests of banks on Feb 24
summary: The European Banking Authority (EBA) will begin conducting stress tests on European banks on February 24, 2016, to assess their financial resilience to potential economic and other threats. The tests, held every second year, will evaluate banks' business models and profitability. This year's test, which will involve 53 lenders, including 39 in the eurozone, will also test banks' foreign exchange exposure and address misconduct risks. The results will not include a pass/fail minimum capital hurdle, marking a shift in the test's focus from capital gaps to sustainable business models.

site_title: Burberry sparks "see now, buy now" debate at London Fashion Week
summary: Burberry sparked debate at London Fashion Week by skipping the usual six-month gap between runway and retail, sparking concern among smaller designers. The brand showcased its "see now, buy now" collection, which includes snakeskin trench coats and metallic dresses, and will deliver it quickly if customers want it. Luxury labels are adopting the trend to meet demand from customers in different climates, with fashion director Ken Downing praising the move as the future of the industry. However, smaller designers expressed concerns about the impact on their operations and ability to compete.

images.alt_text: British designer Burberry sparked a debate at this year's London Fashion Week by skipping the usual six-month gap between putting its designs on the catwalk and into shops, prompting concern among smaller designers that they would be unable to compete.

site_title: OUE lifts stake in OUE C-Reit to 65%
summary: OUE Limited has acquired 203.15 million units in OUE C-Reit from Gordon Tang, increasing its stake to 64.98%. The purchase price of S$165.97 million is a 14% discount to the net tangible asset value per unit. However, the actual price paid is S$0.817 per unit, which is above the market price of S$0.645. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move by OUE to strengthen its position in the Reit.

site_title: Asia-Pacific crude: Demand firm even as refining margins weaken
summary: The Asia-Pacific crude market experienced pressure from weakening refining margins, despite oil prices near their lowest in a decade maintaining demand. Spot differentials for Russia's Sakhalin Blend remained steady, while light grades were supported by tighter supply. Crude flows from Iraqi Kurdistan to Turkey are expected to resume on February 29 due to security issues. Meanwhile, China's Dongming Petrochemical will reduce crude throughput by half for maintenance, and Kazakhstan plans to produce 74 million tonnes of oil in 2016.

site_title: Shell Signs offshore oil, gas exploration accord with Bulgaria
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has signed a five-year contract to explore oil and gas deposits in the Silistar block of the Black Sea off Bulgaria's coast. The deal, worth 18.6 million euros, aims to reduce Bulgaria's reliance on Russian energy imports. Shell plans to invest US$20.5 million and has an option for two two-year extensions. This contract follows another exploration block in the region, where Total, OMV, and Repsol are also investing, despite low oil prices and pressure to cut exploration budgets.

site_title: Lamborghini picks ex-Ferrari F1 team boss as CEO
summary: Lamborghini has named Stefano Domenicali, former Ferrari F1 team boss, as its new CEO, replacing Stephan Winkelmann on March 15. Domenicali, who was vice president for new business initiatives at Audi, will oversee deliveries and revenues at the Italian supercar brand, which have more than doubled to a record 3,245 cars last year. Winkelmann, who has led Lamborghini since 2005, will take over as head of Audi's high-performance car division quattro GmbH. This move comes as Volkswagen continues to restructure its corporate culture following the emissions scandal.

site_title: Super Group Q4 profit falls 39%
summary: Super Group reported a 39% drop in Q4 net profit to S$15.7 million due to higher tax expenses and absent income. Revenue slipped 8% to S$141.1 million, driven by lower sales to Indonesia and China. The company's full-year net profit fell 31% to S$47.3 million, and a proposed final dividend of 1.2 cents per share brings the total dividend for the year to 2.2 cents per share, down from 3.1 cents in 2014.

site_title: S&P says Noble Group's losses could complicate loan refinancing
summary: Standard & Poor's has downgraded Noble Group to CreditWatch, citing its potential to breach financial covenants due to a large loss and uncertainty over covenant definitions. Noble, a commodity trader, warned of its first full-year loss in nearly two decades, blaming US$1.2 billion in writedowns on a slide in coal prices. This could complicate refinancing of its revolving credit facility due in May.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Noble Group reported net losses for its Q4 and FY2015 due to weak commodity prices. Keppel Corp reiterated its zero-tolerance stance against bribery amid Petrobras investigations. Consumer prices in Singapore fell 0.6% in January, and the Competition Commission of Singapore found no collusion in petrol pricing. Standard Chartered's annual profit slumped 84%, while Singapore shares closed higher, led by banks.

site_title: Kuroda hints at shift in thinking on monetary policy's power
summary: Japan's central bank Governor Haruhiko Kuroda hinted that his view on monetary policy's power has shifted, after an unprecedented stimulus program failed to achieve his inflation target of 2%. Kuroda acknowledged that expanding the monetary base alone cannot achieve the price target, and instead emphasized the importance of increasing inflation expectations and a tighter gap in supply and demand. This marks a shift from his previous optimism about the power of monetary policy, and suggests that the BOJ may target interest rates instead of continuing bond purchases.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysian shares rose on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 2.69 points to close at 1,677.28. Over 1.91 billion lots worth RM1.80 billion were traded, with 438 gainers and 417 losers.

site_title: Temasek launches dual tranche offering of 6-year, 12-year EUR Temasek Bonds
summary: Temasek Holdings is launching a dual-tranche offering of EUR Temasek Bonds, comprising a 6-year and 12-year bond. The bonds will be issued through its subsidiary, Temasek Financial (I), and will be fully guaranteed by Temasek. The net proceeds will be used to fund Temasek and its investment holding companies. This move aims to provide liquidity and support the company's ordinary course of business.

site_title: TEHO unit terminates JV arrangement with Sok Bun
summary: TEHO International's unit, TEHO Cambodia, has terminated its joint venture arrangement with Okhna Sok Bun, who agreed to transfer 51% stake in TEHO-SBG Development Co to Yim Chhay Line, daughter of Cambodia's Deputy Prime Minister, in exchange for 510 ordinary shares. This move comes after Sok Bun's resignation following allegations of a violent attack and his removal as director of ECG Cambodia.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher, led by banks
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 11.42 points to 2,672.07, driven by gains in banks. The three major banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, led the gain, with CIMB citing concerns over asset quality issues, particularly in the oil & gas sector. CIMB maintained an "overweight" on banks, recommending OCBC, DBS, and UOB, citing present prices as discounting a more bearish view.

site_title: Hotelier IHG posts higher full-year profit, to return US$1.5b
summary: InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG) reported a 4% rise in yearly profit to US$680 million, boosted by strong demand across its regions. The company will return US$1.5 billion to shareholders via a special dividend after selling two properties, Le Grand InterContinental in Paris and InterContinental Hong Kong, for 330 million euros and US$938 million, respectively.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets fall at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell at the start of trading on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 dropping 0.6% to 6,000.3 points, and the eurozone's Frankfurt and Paris indices falling 0.7% and 0.6% respectively. The decline followed a global rally on Monday driven by strengthening oil prices, with worries about a potential British exit from the EU also affecting the pound.

site_title: NOL narrows Q4 loss to US$75m amid ongoing industry weakness
summary: NOL narrows its Q4 loss to US$75.45 million, down from a year-ago loss of US$259.8 million, amid industry weakness. The shipping company cut costs by 28% and reduced operating expenses by 29%. Revenue fell 28% to US$1.3 billion due to weak container trade demand and low freight rates. The outlook remains subdued, with freight rates expected to remain under pressure. NOL's full-year profit swung to US$707.2 million, or 27.27 US cents per share.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng unit puts in highest bid for Upper Changi Road residential tender
summary: A Chip Eng Seng unit has submitted the highest bid of S$419.38 million (S$760.56 per square foot per plot ratio) for a 24,394 sqm residential site at New Upper Changi Road. The site, which has an allowable gross plot ratio of 2.1 and a maximum gross floor area of 51,228 sq m, will feature about 720 residential units and 500 sq m for a child care centre. The proposed development will be financed by internal funds and bank borrowings, and is expected to have no impact on the group's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: StanChart annual profit slumps 84%
summary: Standard Chartered's annual profit plummeted 84% to US$800 million, down from US$5.2 billion last year, due to weaker global financial markets, tumbling commodity prices, and rising loan impairments. This was lower than analysts' average estimate of US$899 million. The bank's emerging markets focus has been impacted by these factors.

site_title: Chinese buyer for Australia's largest dairy farm business
summary: A Chinese investor, Lu Xianfeng, has been given the green light to buy Australia's largest dairy farm company, Van Diemen's Land Company, for Aus$280 million. The sale was approved by Australian Treasurer Scott Morrison, who stated that the investment is not contrary to national interests. Lu has committed to expanding the business and increasing its workforce. The sale has been welcomed by New Zealand's New Plymouth District Council, but some independent politicians have expressed opposition, citing the importance of Australian ownership of strategic assets.

site_title: Bill Gates sides with government in Apple clash, FT says
summary: Bill Gates has sided with the US government in a dispute over Apple's refusal to unlock an iPhone belonging to a terrorist involved in a December attack. Gates stated that accessing the phone's information is no different from accessing bank records, differing from his own company's stance. He emphasized that the request was a one-time case and not a precedent for building backdoors into mobile software. Gates' opinion appears to break ranks with the industry and Apple CEO Tim Cook, who has warned about the dangers of such a precedent.

images.alt_text: Microsoft Corp co-founder Bill Gates has sided with the US government in a dispute over Apple Inc's refusal to break into a terrorist's iPhone, breaking ranks with the industry in a face-off with law enforcement, the Financial Times reported.

site_title: Use of yuan for trade deals seen growing despite volatility, interventions
summary: China's yuan is expected to be used for more trade deals this year despite economic concerns and volatility, with analysts predicting a 30% rise in yuan cross-border trade settlement by the end of 2016. This growth is driven by arbitrage activities, where companies benefit from differences in interest rates and foreign exchange rates between mainland China and Hong Kong. Heavy central bank interventions have steadied the currency, but some market players remain cautious about using the yuan due to volatility.

site_title: Oil prices fall as global glut offsets prospect of lower US output
summary: Oil prices fell due to a global glut, offsetting expectations of lower US output. Saudi Arabia and Russia proposed an oil production freeze, but Iran's rising exports cast doubt on the plan. Global oversupply is estimated at 1-2 million barrels per day, and US production is expected to recover in the long term, potentially reaching 14.2 million barrels per day by 2021. Oil prices are currently trading at $32.72 per barrel for US West Texas Intermediate crude and $34.08 per barrel for international benchmark Brent.

site_title: Seoul: Shares give up gains on profit-taking; won up
summary: Seoul shares closed down 0.1% at 1,914.22 on Tuesday, after foreign investors snapped a three-session buying streak and sold a net 4.9 billion won worth of KOSPI shares. The decline was attributed to profit-taking and the impact of retreating oil prices and stock losses in China.

site_title: AP Oil International posts lower full-year profit on loss incurred by new business
summary: AP Oil International Limited reported a 15% fall in 2015 full-year net profit to S$4.2 million, due to a loss incurred by its newly acquired petrochemicals business. Revenue grew 9% to S$85.7 million, while cost of sales rose 11% and distribution costs increased 85% year-over-year. The company expects a challenging business environment in 2016 due to the plummet of crude oil prices. Despite this, it plans to develop the China market as part of its long-term growth strategy.

site_title: OKP Q4 profit doubles to S$1.9m; to pay S$0.01 per share dividend
summary: OKP Holdings' net profit surged 127.8% to S$1.9 million in Q4, with a 175.7% increase in full-year profit to S$7 million. The company is declaring a final dividend of 0.7 Singapore cents and a special dividend of 0.3 Singapore cents, totaling one Singapore cent per share. This marks a significant turnaround from the company's previous costs tightening.

site_title: Sheng Siong posts stronger profits for Q4FY15 on better margins
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singaporean supermarket group, reported a 24% year-on-year increase in Q4FY15 profit to S$14.61 million, driven by improved gross margins. Revenue rose 5% to S$187.1 million, with new stores contributing to the increase. The company's full-year net profit rose 19.3% to S$56.78 million, with earnings per share increasing to 0.97 cents. A final dividend of 1.75 cents was proposed, up from 1.5 cents last year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares track China markets lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.3% to 19,414.78 points, tracking mainland China shares lower, despite gains in energy and resources sectors. Most sectors declined, with the blue-chip CSI300 index falling 1.0% to 3,089.36 points. Investors took profits from the previous session's 2% gain, but analysts expect buyers to return ahead of China's annual legislature meeting, where key economic goals will be set.

site_title: Swiss tourism reports fewest European overnights since 1958
summary: Switzerland reported the fewest European overnight stays since 1958 in 2015, with a 0.8% decline, mainly due to the strong Swiss franc. Demand from Europeans outside Switzerland dropped 9.8% and foreign visitors declined 1.7%. Swiss Tourism Director Juerg Schmid expects further declines in 2016 before stabilization by the end of the year.

site_title: British bosses say exit from EU would hit economy and jobs
summary: British business leaders, including CEOs of major companies such as BT, Marks & Spencer, and BP, have warned that an exit from the EU would harm the economy and threaten jobs. A letter signed by 36 FTSE 100 companies, urging the UK to remain in the EU, was published in response to concerns that Britain may vote to leave the bloc in a June referendum. The move is seen as a significant boost to Prime Minister David Cameron's efforts to persuade Britons to stay in the EU.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall from three-week high
summary: Australian shares fell 0.43% on Tuesday, dropping 21.62 points to 4,979.6 points, after reaching a three-week high. This followed a 1% gain on Monday. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.59% to 6,175.67 points. The decline was attributed to profit taking, while other markets, such as Singapore and the US, saw gains.

site_title: Indonesian govt says Bank Indonesia to review steps to lower policy rate to 4-5%
summary: Indonesia's chief economic minister Darmin Nasution has asked Bank Indonesia to review steps to lower the monetary policy rate to 4-5% as part of measures to drive down banks' lending rates. The current benchmark interest rate stands at 7%, and the government aims for lending rates to companies to be as low as 9% by year-end.

site_title: Honda shakes up management as recalls persist after CEO switch
summary: Honda Motor Co. is revamping its top management under President Takahiro Hachigo, one year after recalling multiple models due to quality and safety issues. Chairman Fumihiko Ike and Executive Vice President Tetsuo Iwamura will retire, with Seiji Kuraishi replacing Iwamura. The overhaul comes after the company struggled with quality issues and a safety crisis with supplier Takata Corp.
