The facility was conceptualized by Cogent's executive chairman, Tan Yeow Khoon, with a charity donation of S$168,888.88 to local funds.

images.alt_text: (From left) Cogent CEO Benson Tan, managing director Edwin Tan, executive chairman Tan Yeow Khoon, Business Times editor Alvin Tay and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund general manager Tan Bee Heong with a cheque for S$168,888.88 donated by Cogent to The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund and The Business Times Budding Artists Fund at the opening of the Cogent 1.Logistics Hub on Monday.

site_title: 1MDB bonds trading at widest spread versus regional SOEs
summary: Societe Generale's Asia Credit research report found that investors, despite market concerns, are "highly involved" in 1Malaysia Development Berhad's bonds. The bonds, issued by 1MDB Global and 1MDB Energy, are trading at the widest spreads compared to regional sovereigns and state-owned enterprises, reflecting market apprehension over political uncertainties in Malaysia. The report noted that a letter of support from the Malaysian government is "at best largely an implicit guarantee," but previous cases show the government has fulfilled its obligations when tested.

site_title: India's Tata Motors renames hatchback Zica as Tiago
summary: Tata Motors has renamed its hatchback Zica to Tiago, following the outbreak of the Zika virus. The car, showcased at the New Delhi motor show, will now be sold under the new name. The company made the decision to distance itself from the virus.

site_title: Hedge funds sceptical about copper rally
summary: Copper prices have rallied in four of the past five weeks, driven by improved industrial demand in China. However, hedge funds and other large speculators remain skeptical about a sustained recovery, with many betting on declines since October. Goldman Sachs predicts a 10% drop in copper prices by the end of 2016, citing a global surplus of 665,000 tonnes. Despite Chinese policymakers loosening restrictions, weak demand and a supply glut are expected to keep copper in a bear market through 2018.

site_title: Roxy profit down, expects more lumpy earnings from FY2017
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings reported a 73% drop in fourth-quarter net earnings to S$12.34 million, due to the absence of profit recognition from the sale of strata retail floors in Hong Kong. For the full year, net profit slipped 12% to S$85.10 million. The group expects lumpy earnings from FY2017 due to the recognition of revenue and profit on overseas development projects only upon completion. Despite this, Roxy-Pacific has proposed a final dividend of 1.297 Singapore cents, unchanged from the previous year.

site_title: Why the buyout interest in Ascendas H-Trust?
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust (A-HTrust) is facing a buyout bid from several interested parties, including Blackstone, Gaw Capital, and Starwood Capital. The interest is driven by the trust's strong hotel portfolio in inbound tourism markets, such as Australia and Japan, where tourism is booming. A-HTrust's small size and high yield make it an attractive proposition for buyers. The trust's sponsor, Ascendas, may be looking to divest its hospitality unit, which is not its core strength. The buyout is structured differently, with the parent firm selling both its manager and Reit vehicle, which may be cheaper and less time-consuming.

site_title: Vaccine reduces cervical-cancer virus' prevalence in teenage girls by almost 65%
summary: A US study found that the HPV vaccine, introduced a decade ago, has reduced the prevalence of the virus in teenage girls by almost 65% and in women aged 20-24 by over 34%. The vaccine's effectiveness has been a welcome boost to the country's efforts to encourage vaccination, with rates currently at around 40% for girls and 20% for boys between 13-17. Researchers attribute the vaccine's success to its ability to prevent the spread of the virus among vaccinated individuals, and efforts are underway to improve vaccination rates, including mandatory administration in some countries and free school vaccination programs.

site_title: Mild winter a boon for NY maple-syrup makers
summary: A mild winter in northern New York state has kicked off the maple syrup production season early, with producers starting to tap trees in early February. This is one of the earliest starts on record, setting the stage for a potentially record-breaking season. Improved technology and increased demand for local food are driving the growth of the industry, with New York state becoming the second-largest domestic producer of maple syrup, surpassing previous records.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Swee Hong Limited's managing director and CEO Ong Hock Leong stepped down after his lawyers informed of a bankruptcy order against him. He will remain as an adviser to the board and management team. Vard Holdings secured a 325 million Norwegian kroner contract for a stern trawler, while Otto Marine secured three shipbuilding contracts worth US$23 million. Frasers Commercial Trust signed a deal to manage three properties via a subsidiary, securing a 3% annual fee.

site_title: Oil prices rise on lower US rig count, but glut weighs on sentiment
summary: Oil prices rose 4.9% on Monday, reaching $34.62 a barrel, due to a decline in the US rig count and a fall in global oil stocks. Analysts expect little relief from a proposed oil production freeze by Russia and Opec, citing the ongoing oversupply in the market. The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts world oil prices won't rise before 2017, and even then, their recovery will be slow. Demand growth is slowing, and record crude stocks in the US are weighing on markets.

site_title: Nokia's 5G pickup could begin as early as 2017, says chief executive
summary: Nokia's CEO, Rajeev Suri, predicts the shift to 5G wireless networks could begin as early as 2017, contrary to the widely-held expectation of 2020. The company plans to invest in 5G technology in 2016 and sales of 5G-ready equipment could start in 2017. This marks a faster-than-expected transition, driven by the need for equipment upgrades and the expansion of 5G's applications beyond mobile devices to the "Internet of Things."

site_title: Sterling plunges to near 7-year low against dollar on Brexit fears
summary: The pound sterling plummeted to a near seven-year low against the dollar, falling to $1.4058, after London Mayor Boris Johnson backed the Brexit campaign in a June referendum. The drop was attributed to uncertainty and investor concerns, with Johnson's endorsement shifting the odds slightly in favor of a "Leave" vote. The pound also weakened against the euro, falling to 77.98 pence. Analysts believe the uncertainty will weigh on the currency rather than a specific outcome.

site_title: Britain's bankers step up opposition to 'Brexit'
summary: Britain's financial industry has intensified its opposition to the country leaving the European Union, citing potential job losses and regulatory uncertainty. London's banking sector, in particular, is concerned about its ability to operate in the single European market and has warned of thousands of jobs being shifted to the euro zone. The industry's campaign against Brexit gained momentum after London Mayor Boris Johnson announced his support for leaving the EU, causing sterling and bond prices to fall. Industry leaders, including HSBC, have expressed concerns about the impact of a Brexit on their business models and have urged businesses to speak out against the move.

site_title: Everything dies from old age - even expansions
summary: Federal Reserve Board Chair Janet Yellen was mistaken when she said expansions don't die of old age. Despite her confidence, economists recognize that longer expansions can lead to changes in attitudes, behavior, and spending patterns that ultimately doom the expansion. This can be caused by factors such as exhausted demand, overinvestment, and inflation, which can take about a year to work through the system. The two longest expansions in US history, in the 1960s and 1990s, ended in devastating busts, highlighting the risks of prolonged economic growth.

site_title: Why do people spend so much to buy celebrities' hair?
summary: Celebrities' hair has become a collectible item, with locks from famous individuals selling for thousands of dollars. A 50-year-old lock of John Lennon's hair sold for $35,000, while a strand from Elvis Presley sold for $115,000 in 2002. Professional hair collectors, like Paul Fraser, buy and sell these items, citing their "immutable quality" and rarity. The pursuit of famous hairs combines human psychology's love of collection and celebrity obsession, with fans seeking tangible objects from widely recognized cultural figures.

site_title: Formula One: F1 bosses seek deal to turnaround "worst ever" state
summary: Formula One bosses will meet in Geneva to discuss potential regulations for the 2017 season, amid declining television audiences and concerns the sport has become boring. CEO Bernie Ecclestone claims F1 is "the worst it has ever been" and Russian President Vladimir Putin is the "guy who should run Europe." The goal is to reduce the dominance of engine performance and increase excitement, with a March 1 deadline to agree on changes. Failure to reach an agreement may delay changes until 2018.

site_title: Police say probing Petrobras contracts with Singapore's Keppel
summary: Brazilian police are investigating possible bribes paid in contracts with Singapore's Keppel Fels by state-run oil company Petrobras and shipbuilder Sete Brasil. The probe is part of the "Operations Car Wash" corruption investigation, which started nearly two years ago. Federal police carried out searches and arrests at Odebrecht's offices in Sao Paulo, Rio de Janeiro, and Bahia. The investigation is the latest in a series of actions against companies involved in the scandal.

site_title: Bringing Chinese New Year cheer to elderly residents of Bedok South
summary: About 20 journalists and volunteers from The Business Times, Raffles Institution, and Engaging Hearts brought Chinese New Year cheer to 200 elderly residents in Bedok South, Singapore. The event, organized by Thye Hua Kwan (THK) Crest @ Bedok, included performances, quizzes, and activities to raise awareness of mental health. The event raised S$1,600 for the cause and collected 600 household items. The collaboration aimed to promote community engagement and bring festive cheer to the senior citizens.

images.alt_text: After the morning's programme, BT journalists, together with the RI students and representatives from Thye Hua Kwan Crest @ Bedok, have a photo taken as a memento of the day.
Business Times journalists (in blue) preparing the goodie bags, each of which contained a toothbrush, toothpaste, a face towel and two mandarin oranges.
The goodie bags and hongbao being distributed.

site_title: IBM inks deal with VMWare, tries to bolster cloud credentials
summary: IBM has expanded its partnership with VMWare to make it easier for companies to deploy and run virtualization products on IBM's cloud data centers. The agreement aims to attract VMWare's customers to IBM's cloud services. IBM also plans to upgrade its developer tools, including WebSphere and Bluemix, to work more seamlessly with cloud-oriented settings. As the company seeks to bolster its cloud credentials, IBM is also exploring acquisitions, such as its recent $2.6 billion purchase of medical-data company Truven Health.

site_title: 'Brexit' could leave Britain vulnerable: Europol
summary: Europol warns that a potential Brexit could leave Britain more vulnerable to terror attacks and organized crime, citing a loss of access to intelligence projects and database. Director Rob Wainwright stated that Britain's security would be "no longer have the benefits" of being in the EU. This comes as British Prime Minister David Cameron and some cabinet members, including Boris Johnson, support the "Leave" campaign, citing the potential for increased security and stability outside the EU.

site_title: Ascott forms alliance to deepen China presence
summary: CapitaLand's serviced residence business unit, The Ascott, has formed a strategic alliance with Dongfu Investment Development Corporation to deepen its presence in China. The partnership will grant Ascott the first right to manage apartments under development and future projects by Dongfu Investment, a subsidiary of China State Construction Engineering Company. This move aims to expand Ascott's China operations and capitalize on the growing demand for serviced residences in the country.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% due to market uncertainty, tariffs, and sanctions. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while Europe's stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector concerns. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potentially lower-than-expected H2 revenue and similar operating losses. London's Heathrow airport is considering increasing fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained an employee of Trafigura in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Petra Q4 profit falls 93.5%; to distribute US$0.0982 per share from excess cash
summary: PETRA Foods reported a 93.5% drop in Q4 profit to US$800,000, amid a weaker Indonesian economy. The company will distribute US$0.0982 per share from excess cash, after a full-year net loss of US$4.7 million. Revenue declined 23.8% to US$100 million, mainly due to a slowdown in the Indonesian economy and increased advertising spending. Petra will retain US$51.65 million for operations and distribute US$60 million to shareholders. The distribution is subject to shareholder approval.

site_title: Venezuela says freeze deal could boost oil prices by US$10-US$15
summary: Venezuela's Oil Minister Eulogio Del Pino says a potential oil production freeze could boost crude prices by $10-$15 a barrel, helping to counter depressed prices. Leading producers including Saudi Arabia, Russia, Qatar, and Venezuela agreed to freeze output at January levels if others join, with Venezuela calling on Opec and non-Opec countries to participate. The deal aims to reach an equilibrium price and prevent a price collapse, but its success is uncertain, with a senior US energy official expressing skepticism about the agreement's ability to correct an oversupplied market.

site_title: BP suspended from Europe's main diesel pricing platform: traders
summary: BP has been suspended from Europe's main diesel pricing platform, Platts Market on Close (MOC), due to non-performance of contract obligations regarding diesel barge deliveries. The suspension significantly reduces BP's ability to set the benchmark price of diesel fuel. The exclusion is reportedly temporary, but the duration is unclear. BP was a major participant in the MOC in January and early February, buying around 230,000 tonnes of diesel.

site_title: Goldman cuts top end of legal loss estimate by 62%
summary: Goldman Sachs lowered its estimate of potential legal losses to $2 billion, cutting the upper end of its previous estimate by 62%. The bank reported a 64% increase in non-compensation costs in the fourth quarter due to $1.95 billion set aside for litigation and regulatory issues. Goldman is involved in several judicial and regulatory proceedings, including a federal-state working group probing misconduct in the sale of mortgage-backed securities prior to the financial crisis.

site_title: Singtel to trial 5G technology with Ericsson
summary: Singtel has partnered with Ericsson to test 5G technology, specifically the Narrow Band Internet of Things (NB-IoT), to support Singapore's growing Internet of Things (IoT) segment. This technology will enable extended coverage, support less-complex devices, and prepare Singtel's 4G LTE network for IoT applications. The technology offers long-term battery life, power-saving capabilities, and will help Singapore evolve into a Smart Nation. The partnership aims to enhance Singtel's network to support the adoption of IoT, with Ericsson's head stating that IoT is an emerging market.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE Telecommunications (Singtel) has signed a partnership with Ericsson to test a new technology that will be a key component of its fifth-generation (5G) mobile network.

site_title: All eyes on Zuckerberg at Barcelona fair as security debate rages
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg is set to address security concerns at the Barcelona mobile fair, amid a US tech giants' debate on privacy and security. The controversy began when Apple refused to help the FBI break into an iPhone linked to the San Bernardino shooter. Zuckerberg's speech comes as the US government and tech companies clash over the balance between security and user data protection. The issue has sparked a global discussion on the trade-off between these two priorities.

site_title: Kuroda again comes under fire over negative rates
summary: BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda defended the central bank's negative interest rate policy before a parliamentary committee, acknowledging criticism but highlighting its benefits. The policy, introduced last week, imposes a charge on commercial banks' reserves, reducing interest rates on mortgage and other loans. Kuroda cited a 2.3% increase in bank lending and argued that the policy would have a positive effect on Japan's economy. However, critics, including opposition lawmakers, have expressed concerns about the policy's impact on consumers and businesses, with some shops urging consumers to buy safes to protect against negative rates.

images.alt_text: Mr Kuroda before an Upper House financial committee meeting of Parliament in Tokyo last week. He blames "excessive" negative sentiment among investors, rather than the BOJ's policies, for the recent falls in stock prices.

site_title: UK factory orders weaken further in February: CBI
summary: UK factory orders weakened further in February, falling to -17, its lowest level since October, according to the Confederation of British Industry. This is a sharper decline than in January and weaker than forecast. Manufacturers also expect to cut prices in the coming months. The reading marks a fresh blow to the UK economy, which shrank for the second month in a row.

site_title: Apple urges government to form commission on encryption issues
summary: Apple has urged the US government to form a commission to discuss the implications of unlocking an iPhone used by a San Bernardino shooter. The company opposes the demand, arguing it would set a dangerous precedent. Apple is willing to participate in such a discussion, but the company's passcode protections must remain intact. The Federal Bureau of Investigation is seeking to access the phone's data, but Apple has refused to comply. The proposed commission would address national security and personal freedoms concerns.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers' take on PACC Offshore Services Holdings (POSH): Analysts from Maybank Kim Eng Research view POSH as having the least balance sheet risk among oil services stocks, citing low net gearing and secured loan facilities. POSH is expected to survive the downturn and emerge stronger with a potential privatisation of its parent. In contrast, CBC Investment Research maintains a hold on Sembcorp Marine (SMM) due to limited downside risk, while IMB Research advises maintaining a hold on Singtel and selling SMM due to its exposure to the Sete Brasil rig projects.

site_title: Oil rebounds after prediction of declining US shale output
summary: Oil prices surged 7% on Monday after the International Energy Agency (IEA) predicted US shale production would decline by 600,000 barrels per day this year and another 200,000 barrels per day in 2017. This, combined with a fall in US oil rig count and global stock market gains, lifted Brent crude futures to $34.69 a barrel and US crude futures to $31.69 a barrel. However, analysts warned that market conditions remain weak due to slowing demand growth and a global oil market expected to rebalance in 2017.

site_title: US, EU open free-trade talks in Brussels
summary: US and EU top negotiators opened new talks in Brussels to discuss the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), a massive free-trade deal aiming to create the world's largest free trade zone. The talks focus on a contentious proposal to create an investment protection system, allowing companies to sue governments for harming their interests. The EU and US have been negotiating the deal since 2013, with the goal of removing tariffs and harmonizing regulations between the two blocs. The outcome of these talks could have significant implications for global trade and investment.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific Q4 net profit falls 73% to S$12.34m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings reported a 73% drop in Q4 net earnings to S$12.34 million, despite a 19% increase in revenue. Gross profit contracted 17% to S$19.90 million. The group's year-end net profit fell 12% to S$85.10 million. A final dividend of 1.297 Singapore cents was proposed, unchanged from the previous year. Net asset value per share rose to 38.34 cents, up from 33.54 cents in 2014.

site_title: US stocks rise, joining global rally
summary: US stocks rose Monday, joining a global equity rally ahead of key economic data releases. The Dow Jones Industrial Average increased 155.84 points (0.95%) to 16,547.83, while the S&P 500 rose 20.07 (1.05%) to 1,937.85. US oil prices rose over 5% after the International Energy Agency predicted a 600,000 barrel decline in US shale production in 2016. The gains come ahead of releases on consumer confidence and US economic growth for the fourth quarter of 2015.

site_title: Most in India cenbank's external panel recommended rates stay on hold
summary: The Reserve Bank of India's external panel recommended keeping interest rates on hold due to concerns about accelerating inflation. Four out of five members agreed, while one suggested an out-of-cycle cut after the government's 2016/17 budget unveiling on February 29. The panel also expressed concerns about the impact of a planned $16 billion pay hike for Indian public servants.

site_title: Speed skating-In tropical Singapore, short track slides into focus
summary: International short track speed skating returned to Singapore with the South East Asian Cup, the second such event in the city-state. The two-day event, held in western suburbs, featured 65 skaters from six countries, who competed early each day to accommodate mall shoppers. The tournament aimed to establish Singapore as a potential Winter Olympian, a goal that remains uncertain. Despite the challenges of competing in a tropical climate, the event showcased the potential for short track speed skating in Singapore.

site_title: Global Yellow Pages files defamation suit against director of Leisure Empire
summary: Global Yellow Pages Limited filed a defamation lawsuit against Goh Kok Liang, director and sole shareholder of Leisure Empire Pte Ltd, over remarks made about the company. The lawsuit was filed in the State Courts and seeks damages and an injunction to prevent further defamatory remarks. The company plans to make further announcements on the proceedings.

site_title: British PM squares up for EU referendum fight
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron will present to parliament the EU reforms secured at a Brussels summit, arguing they give Britain "special status" and are enough reason to vote to stay in the EU in a June 23 referendum. However, Conservative rival Boris Johnson has thrown his weight behind the "Brexit" campaign, sparking a challenge for Cameron. Five cabinet ministers have already declared themselves in favor of the "Leave" campaign, and reports suggest around a third of Cameron's lawmakers could back a departure.

site_title: China Environment, Enviro-Hub, Ezion, Full Apex, PSL, San Teh warn of losses
summary: A wave of profit warnings hit Singapore-listed stocks, with six companies including Enviro-Hub, San Teh, PSL, Full Apex, China Environment, and Ezion warning of losses due to various factors such as impairment provisions, weak sales, and stiff competition. These warnings, issued on Monday, followed other profit warnings from Hi-P International and Abterra on Sunday. The decline in profit expectations suggests a challenging market environment for these companies.

site_title: Amara Holdings FY15 net profit falls 59%
summary: Amara Holdings reported a 59% decline in FY15 net profit to S$14.33 million, due to a drop in fair value gain and increased operating expenses from a new hotel in Bangkok. Revenue rose 9% to S$82.43 million, driven by higher hotel investment and management segment revenue and rental income from its property segment. Earnings per share fell to 2.49 Singapore cents, and the company recommended a final dividend of one cent per share.

site_title: Ericsson, Nokia offer contrasting timelines for 5G network upgrades
summary: Ericsson and Nokia offer differing timelines for 5G network upgrades, with Ericsson predicting 150 million users on 5G networks by 2021 and Nokia anticipating a shift to "5G-ready" networks as early as 2017. The differing timelines reflect a debate over what 5G means and when equipment upgrades will be needed. Analysts also question the preparedness of operators to commit to massive capital spending on 5G, with some predicting it will take years for 5G to have a significant impact on consumers.

site_title: Siemens CEO holds high-level meetings in Iran
summary: Siemens CEO Joe Kaeser held high-level meetings in Iran, meeting with the oil minister and government representatives. Siemens, which has been engaged in Iran since 1868, aims to win projects in the country's energy sector and rail transportation. The company signed deals last month to work on Iran's railway infrastructure worth up to 1.5 billion euros. Siemens plans to speed up the delivery of compressors and turbines for gas extraction and is open to joint ventures with Iranian companies. The meetings come as Iran seeks to boost gas production and export.

site_title: FCL unit to manage Alexandra Technopark, 55 Market Street, China Square Central
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) has signed a 5-year property management agreement with Frasers Centrepoint Property Management Services to manage Alexandra Technopark, 55 Market Street, and China Square Central. The agreement, set to take effect after the expiration of an existing 10-year agreement, will see Frasers Centrepoint Property Management Services receive a 3% annual fee based on gross revenue. This move aims to maintain continuity and stability for the properties, which will benefit from the experience and expertise of Frasers Centrepoint Property Management Services.

site_title: CITIC Envirotech 9-month profit drops 21.2% on one-offs, tax, engineering decline
summary: CITIC Envirotech's 9-month net profit fell 21.2% to S$40.8 million due to a decline in engineering business, absence of one-off gains, and increased tax expenses. The company reported a 12-month net profit of S$59.3 million. Engineering revenue dropped 32.1% to S$114.6 million, while water treatment revenue rose 61.1% to S$106.5 million. Despite a challenging period, the company remains optimistic about the Chinese water treatment sector's outlook, citing positive government policies. A final dividend of 0.36 Singapore cents per share was declared.

site_title: Ericsson forms alliance with Amazon Web Services for telcos
summary: Ericsson forms an alliance with Amazon Web Services (AWS), allowing telcos to use public cloud services while maintaining control over customer data and encryption. The partnership aims to move telecom operators away from internal computer operations and towards cloud-based services. Ericsson will provide software tools and create a global team of experts in using the AWS Cloud. The first customer of the alliance is Telstra, an Australian telecommunications operator. No financial terms were disclosed as part of the agreement.

site_title: IMF chief urges Gulf states to bring in taxes
summary: IMF Chief Christine Lagarde urged Gulf states to introduce taxes, warning low crude prices will persist for an extended period. She called for strengthening fiscal frameworks, reducing reliance on oil revenues, and boosting non-hydrocarbon sources. Specifically, Lagarde recommended introducing a harmonized regional Value-Added Tax (VAT). This move aims to diversify economies and prepare for an extended period of low oil prices.

images.alt_text: The International Monetary Fund chief urged on Monday oil-exporting Gulf countries to introduce taxes, warning that low crude prices are likely to stay for an "extended period".

site_title: German private sector growth loses steam in February: PMI
summary: Germany's private sector growth slowed for the second month in February, with Markit's flash composite PMI falling to 53.8 from 54.5 in January. The reading remains above the 50 threshold, indicating growth, but suggests the economy is feeling the impact of a slowdown in emerging markets.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end up, track strong mainland market
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.9% to 19,464.09, tracking gains in mainland stocks after Beijing replaced its top securities regulator and introduced measures to support the real estate sector. The China Enterprises Index gained 1.3% to 8,221.37 points. However, Alibaba Health Information Technology Ltd's shares fell 14% after regulators suspended its drug monitoring platform. The gains were despite concerns over the US-EU trade talks and tariff threats.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks end flat; G-20 meeting awaited
summary: The South Korean won remained unchanged at 1,234.4 to the dollar as investors held back on trading ahead of a G-20 meeting. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed flat at 1,916.36, with Samsung Electronics falling 1.3% and LG Electronics rising 2.8% after unveiling new flagship devices. Foreign investors were net buyers for a third session, purchasing 35.3 billion won worth of KOSPI shares.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DBS Group reported a 20% increase in Q4 net profit to S$1 billion, while Singapore's Q4 GDP is forecast to have grown slower than initially thought. Global Yellow Pages filed a defamation lawsuit against Leisure Empire's director, and Swee Hong's CEO stepped down due to a bankruptcy order. Vard Holdings secured a 325m-krone contract in Norway. In corporate news, Raffles Medical proposed a 1-to-3 share split, and Singapore stocks rose in response to gains in HK and Dow futures, with the STI rising 3.78 points to 2,660.65.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to cut 75 global markets jobs in London, New York
summary: Deutsche Bank is cutting approximately 75 global markets jobs in London and New York, primarily in its fixed income and currencies sales and trading business. The move is part of a restructuring effort to adapt to future market demand. The job cuts, affecting less than 2% of the sales and trading workforce, come after previous restructuring programs at the German bank. The bank cited a need to "make our FIC business more suited to future market demand" in a statement.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank is to cut around 75 jobs within its global markets division in London and New York, according to one person with knowledge of the information.

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng posts 7% rise in Q4 profit
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng, a food and beverage company, reported a 7% increase in Q4 net profit to S$14.25 million, driven by higher fair value gains on investment properties. Revenue fell 4% year-on-year to S$95.61 million, while earnings per share rose to 2.47 Singapore cents. The company's full-year net profit rose 27% to S$36.83 million, driven by a 1% revenue increase to S$443.52 million.

site_title: Oil price to start slow recovery in 2017: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts that world oil prices will not rise sharply before 2017, instead experiencing a slow recovery due to massive oil stocks. The agency attributes the current low oil prices to oversupply, with demand expected to grow at a weaker pace amid financial market turmoil. Investment cuts and lower spending on oil exploration and equipment are projected to curtail supply, eventually aligning with demand. The IEA expects oil supply to drop by 17% this year and 1.2 million barrels per day over the next five years.

site_title: JTC makes open call for innovative ideas for building management
summary: JTC launches open call for innovative ideas to increase productivity and efficiency in industrial building management. The initiative aims to engage enterprises, startups, and research institutions through crowdsourcing platforms. Selected proposals will be test-bedded or piloted in JTC developments, with up to S$500,000 in funding support. Successfully developed solutions may be adopted by JTC in its future developments.

site_title: Eurozone business activity slows in February: survey
summary: The Eurozone's private sector business activity slowed sharply in February, according to a survey by Markit, with stagnation in France and slumping demand in Germany contributing to deflationary pressures. The Composite Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) fell to 52.7 points, a 13-month low, but still above the 50-point boom-or-bust line, indicating the economy continued to expand albeit at a slower pace. Economic growth is expected to slow below 0.3% in the first quarter unless a sudden uplift occurs in March.

site_title: China to close more than 1,000 coal mines in 2016: energy bureau
summary: China plans to close over 1,000 coal mines in 2016, aiming to shut 60 million tonnes of production capacity as part of its efforts to tackle a supply glut and overcapacity in the sector. This move is part of a plan to shut 500 million tonnes of surplus production capacity within three to five years. China also aims to control new thermal power builds and promote direct power sales agreements between suppliers and consumers, with the goal of reducing power prices this year.

site_title: Italy's Renzi says debt will come down this year if growth holds up
summary: Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi said that Italy's debt will fall this year if growth holds up, citing a forecast of 1.6% growth and a budget deficit of 2.4% of output. This contradicts the OECD's prediction of 1% growth. Renzi stated that a 1.4% growth rate and 2.4% deficit would lead to a decrease in debt, which would be considered positive even if lower than expected by the European fiscal compact.

site_title: Asked about Britain's EU vote, China says supports strong Europe
summary: China's Foreign Ministry has expressed support for a strong European Union, with Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying stating China has consistently supported European integration and would like to see Europe play an even greater role globally. This comes after Britain set a June date for a referendum on whether to leave the EU, a move that has raised concerns about the implications for China's free trade interests. China has long seen the EU as a vital counterbalance to the US and has benefited from Britain's support in pushing for a China-EU free trade deal.

site_title: Deutsche Bank names Jamal Al Kishi as CEO of Middle East, Africa
summary: Deutsche Bank has appointed Jamal Al Kishi as the new CEO of its Middle East and Africa operations, replacing Ashok Aram. Al Kishi will also remain as CEO of Deutsche Securities Saudi Arabia and chair the Middle East and Africa executive committee. The bank aims to reduce its workforce by 26,000 by 2018, closing operations in 10 countries and shifting trading businesses to global and regional hubs.

site_title: HSBC's Asia-Pacific hiring being investigated by SEC, bank says
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc, Europe's largest bank, is being investigated by the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) over its hiring practices in the Asia-Pacific region. The probe focuses on hiring candidates referred by or related to government officials or state-owned company employees. HSBC is cooperating with the SEC and has not predicted a timeline for the resolution of the matter. This investigation follows similar probes of global banks for hiring candidates related to powerful Asian business leaders. The bank reported a fourth-quarter loss amid lower income from lending and higher loan-impairment charges.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Monday, closing at 1,674.59 after trading 0.29 points. A total of 1.62 billion lots valued at RM1.64 billion were traded, with 468 gainers and 364 losers.

site_title: Oil prices rise on lower US rig count, but glut weighs
summary: Oil prices rose over 3% on Monday, trading at $30.59 per barrel, driven by a decline in US rig count and a fall in crude stocks. However, analysts say the market remains weak due to oversupply, with demand growth slowing. Russia and Opec's proposed production freeze at January levels would not help reduce oversupply, and Iran's return to the market will add supply to an already oversaturated market.

site_title: European shares led higher by miners, but HSBC falls
summary: European shares rose 1.3% in early trading, driven by gains in miners following a recovery in crude oil and commodity prices. Copper prices reached a two-week high, boosting shares in Rio Tinto, Glencore, and BHP Billiton. However, HSBC fell 3.8% after reporting a surprise pre-tax loss of $858 million and predicting a 'bumpier' financial environment. Despite the gains, the pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index remains down nearly 10% since the start of 2016 due to concerns over a global economic slowdown.

site_title: South Korea finance minister says no plans to directly curb household debt volume
summary: South Korea's Finance Minister Yoo Il-ho stated that the government has no plans to directly curb household debt volume, focusing instead on improving the quality of debt through measures taken last year.

site_title: Apple encryption fracas about 'victims and justice': FBI chief
summary: The US government requested a court order to force Apple to unlock an iPhone linked to the San Bernardino shooting rampage, with FBI Director James Comey stating the request is about "the victims and justice." Comey argued the request is about gaining access to the locked phone, not setting a master key, and is a narrow issue. Apple claims cooperating would undermine security for its devices, while Comey believes the case should be resolved by the American people. Both Apple CEO Tim Cook and Comey are set to testify on encryption on Capitol Hill.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise in response to gains in HK, Dow futures
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 3.78 points to 2,660.65, driven by gains in Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and US Dow futures. Turnover was 1.3 billion units worth S$1.06 billion, with 234 rises and 132 falls. DBS fell S$0.06 to S$13.62 despite releasing Q4 and full-year figures. The market reacted to a classic "buy in anticipation, sell on news" pattern, with DBS reaching an intraday high of S$13.94.

site_title: Australia to start register of foreign ownership of water rights
summary: The Australian government plans to introduce a register of foreign ownership of water rights by December 1, aiming to address concerns about foreign investment in the country's agricultural assets. The move comes after the government blocked the sale of a major landowner to foreign investors in November and lowered the reporting threshold for foreign investment in 2015. The register will provide a better understanding of foreign investment levels in water rights, potentially curbing price increases due to a water rights trading system. This is part of the government's efforts to appease voters concerned about foreign land ownership.

site_title: French business activity contracts for first time in 13 months: PMI
summary: France's private sector activity contracted for the first time in 13 months, according to a survey by Markit. The services sector, which includes hotels and cafes, fell into negative territory at 49.8, while the manufacturing sector rose to 50.3. New business orders and export orders declined, but business expectations in the services sector reached a six-month high. French companies also reduced prices, but manufacturers benefited from lower raw material costs. Despite increased staff levels, Markit's chief economist Chris Williamson warned that the drop in outstanding business orders may signal companies are cutting headcount to save money.

site_title: Singapore Q4 GDP seen revised lower, pressure for easing grows
summary: Singapore's economy is forecast to have grown at a slower pace in the fourth quarter, with a revised annualized growth rate of 1.8%, down from the initial estimate of 2%. The slowdown is attributed to weak data, including a decline in industrial production, and a gloomy outlook for the global economy. Analysts expect the Monetary Authority of Singapore to consider easing monetary policy at its April review, citing domestic headwinds and the risk of further easing. The government maintains its 2016 growth forecast of 1-3%.

site_title: Australia announces voting reforms, signalling possible early polls
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull introduced a bill on electoral reform, potentially signaling an early election to break a political deadlock. The reforms aim to limit access to parliament for smaller parties and make it harder for them to enter through vote-sharing deals. The move is seen as a response to the government's inability to pass legislation due to opposition from independent and minor party senators. A double-dissolution election, which allows for snap elections for all seats, could be held as early as June, but Turnbull plans to hold a regular election in September or October.

site_title: HSBC 2015 net profit down 1.2% at US$13.52b
summary: HSBC reported a 1.2% decrease in net profit for 2015 to US$13.52 billion, despite "seismic shifts" in the global economy. Group chairman Douglas Flint described the performance as "broadly satisfactory." The bank's pre-tax profit of US$18.9 billion fell short of analysts' forecast of US$21.8 billion.

site_title: Oil prices rebound in Asia, US crude back above US$30
summary: Oil prices rebounded in Asia, with US crude rising above US$30 a barrel, as traders considered a potential freeze by key producers. A potential agreement by Saudi Arabia and Russia to limit production if others followed suit had sparked a sharp spike last week, but crude resumed its downtrend as concerns about Iraq and Iran's output growth lingered. Despite this, analysts believe prices may have found a floor, and market expectations will focus on demand data from the US and Europe released this week.

site_title: Up to 90 million more Takata airbag inflators may face US recalls
summary: US auto safety regulators are examining the potential recall of an additional 70-90 million Takata airbag inflators due to their possible endangerment of drivers. This would nearly quadruple the existing 29 million inflators recalled, linked to nine US deaths. The inflators, which contain the volatile chemical ammonium nitrate, can rupture and spray metal shards at vehicle occupants. Takata, one of the world's largest airbag manufacturers, has acknowledged quality failures at its North American plants, contributing to the issue. The National Highway Transportation Safety Administration (NHTSA) continues to investigate the inflators, with a settlement agreed to in November to pay a $70 million penalty.

site_title: DBS says even at US$20 per barrel for 2 years, provisions won't exceed S$200m
summary: DBS Group CEO Piyush Gupta stated that even at US$20 per barrel for two years, the bank's oil and gas provisions won't exceed S$200 million. Gupta also mentioned that specific provisions may increase in China and Hong Kong. DBS does not expect additional specific provisions on its oil and gas portfolio this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on weak yen, oil rebound
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index increasing 0.90% to 16,111.05, driven by a weakening yen that lifted exporters. Oil prices rebounded, boosting sentiment. The broader Topix index rose 0.63%. The gains were a contrast to earlier losses and come as US-EU trade talks are in focus.

site_title: Update: Indian army recapture Delhi water source, caste protests continue
summary: The Indian army has regained control of the Munak canal, a key water source for Delhi, after protests by the Jat caste in neighboring Haryana state. The protests, which have killed at least 10 people, began over demands for more government jobs and education. Despite a government concession, protesters say they will continue their agitation. The situation remains volatile, with reports of inter-caste conflict and residents declaring certain areas off-limits to police and army. The water crisis in Delhi, which affects over 20 million people, appears to have been temporarily averted.

site_title: Engine trouble forces ANA Dreamliner back to Kuala Lumpur
summary: A Japan-based All Nippon Airways Boeing 787-8 Dreamliner was forced to return to Kuala Lumpur after experiencing engine trouble, with the right engine exhaust temperature rising. The plane, carrying 214 passengers and crew, took off at 8:09 am local time but landed safely back at Kuala Lumpur airport at 9:27 am. The incident marks the latest issue for the Dreamliner, which has faced setbacks since its first commercial flight in 2011. The airline is investigating the cause of the problem.

site_title: Bank of East Asia jumps most in six years as Li raises stake
summary: Bank of East Asia Ltd saw a 10% jump in shares, its largest increase in six years, after Chairman David Li increased his stake to 86.74 million shares. Li bought 110,000 shares, with the shares trading at HK$25.50. The company rejected a call from Elliott Management to consider selling itself, instead focusing on improving and executing existing strategies. The move comes after Bank of East Asia posted a profit drop, but Li's investment suggests confidence in the bank's future.

site_title: China at the heart of North Korea's illicit cash-flow funnel
summary: China is a crucial part of North Korea's illicit cash flow funnel, with approximately 70-80% of North Korea's foreign earnings coming through China. The country's geographic proximity, trade volume, and historic relationship with North Korea make it an ideal hub for evading international financial sanctions. China's banks and intermediaries have been used to channel currency in and out of North Korea, with some examples including the Chinpo Shipping Company Ltd and Complant International Transportation Co. The US and other countries have struggled to tighten sanctions on North Korea due to China's resistance and its own economic interests. To effectively block North Korea's illicit cash flow, the US and other countries must coerce China into cooperating, as sanctions can only be effective when China is coerced into cooperating.

site_title: Australia: Shares lifted as industrials rally, NZ subdued
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% to a three-week peak, driven by improving risk appetite and upbeat earnings from industrials, with logistics provider Brambles and steelmaker Bluescope Steel reporting significant gains. Meanwhile, New Zealand stocks fell 0.28% after a week of consecutive gains. Despite a 2.1% decline this year due to global growth and oil price concerns, the Australian market showed resilience, with miners and financials also benefiting from metal price increases and strong earnings.

site_title: JPMorgan may hold steady on cost target despite low interest rates
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co is expected to hold steady on its cost target, contrary to expectations that the bank would cut costs further to maintain profitability in a sluggish economy. The bank's CEO, Jamie Dimon, and top executives will discuss revenue, expenses, and shareholder returns, as well as its use of technology to improve operations. JPMorgan has already cut over 25,000 jobs since 2011 and is halfway through its $4.8 billion cost-cutting target. Analysts expect the bank to focus on striking a balance between cutting costs and spending on growth, amid low interest rates and a sluggish economy.

site_title: Update: DBS will see some rise in bad loans
summary: DBS Group Holdings expects a rise in non-performing loans (NPLs) to 1.3% in 2016, despite being well-prepared and prudent. The bank's net profit for Q4 2015 rose 20% to S$1 billion, and for FY2015, it increased 10% to S$4.5 billion. DBS's NPL ratio remains unchanged at 0.9% from 2014, with a healthy overall portfolio and good recoveries. The bank has provided for S$600 million in specific provisions in 2015 and expects minimal provisions for 2016, except for the oil and gas sector, which is expected to see losses.

site_title: ZTE unveils new value-line phones; eyes 60m-70m units in 2016
summary: China's ZTE unveils new value-priced phone models, aiming to sell 60-70 million devices in 2016, a 7-20% rise from 2015. The company introduces the Blade V7 Lite and Blade V7, with the former featuring a fingerprint scanner and the latter a retinal eye-scan feature. The Blade V7 will sell for around $277, while the Lite will be priced lower, with the exact price not yet disclosed. ZTE aims to capitalize on its successful sports marketing partnerships, including a new deal with Spanish football club Seville.

site_title: Gold falls after stocks resume gains and US inflation rises
summary: Gold prices fell 0.3% to $1,223.67 an ounce as Asian equities regained ground and US inflation rose, increasing expectations of a rate hike. The metal rose 15% this year due to global economic weakness and sliding commodity prices. The US Labor Department's report showed a 4-year high in non-food inflation, bolstering the case for a second rate increase, negatively impacting gold.

site_title: San Bernardino victims to oppose Apple on iPhone encryption
summary: Some victims of the San Bernardino attack will file a legal brief in support of the US government's attempt to force Apple to unlock the encrypted iPhone of one of the shooters, according to a lawyer representing the victims. The victims, who were targeted by terrorists, want to know why they were targeted and how the attack happened. This move gives the federal government a powerful ally in its fight against Apple, which has argued that unlocking the iPhone would set a dangerous precedent and threaten customer security.

site_title: DBS's NPLs for offshore services at 1.3%; chief to say this is 'not a Lehman moment'
summary: DBS Bank's non-performing loans (NPLs) ratio for its offshore support services segment stands at 1.3% for 2015, according to a presentation by CEO Piyush Gupta. This ratio is not considered a "Lehman moment," and Gupta stated that the figures do not indicate a recession despite slower economic growth. The bank's oil-and-gas portfolio accounts for 40% of its total portfolio, valued at S$17 billion.

site_title: Agony in rural India prompts Modi u-turn on policy he mocked
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is under pressure to address rural poverty and droughts after a devastating two-year drought left millions without income. Modi's government initially mocked the world's largest public works program, the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA), but now faces criticism for not providing enough funding. The program, which guarantees 100 days of wages per year, has been underfunded, leading to widespread discontent. Modi's government is expected to increase funding for MGNREGA in the upcoming budget, aiming to boost economic growth and alleviate rural poverty.

site_title: China's new securities regulator has a tough job ahead after market rout
summary: China's new securities regulator, Liu Shiyu, takes over amid a US$5 trillion market rout, following criticism of his predecessor, Xiao Gang, for mismanagement. Liu faces a tough job rebuilding investor morale and overseeing market reforms, including a new IPO system and expansion of trading links with Hong Kong. The new regulator will need to balance state interests with market liberalization, and restore confidence in China's second-largest stock market.

images.alt_text: Liu Shiyu is assuming oversight of the world's second-largest stock market in the wake of a US$5 trillion rout that left his predecessor criticized for mismanagement.

site_title: China industrial overcapacity damaging global economy: study
summary: China's industrial overcapacity is damaging the global economy, with steel production "completely untethered" from market demand. China produces more steel than the next four largest producers combined, and over 60% of its aluminum industry has negative cash flow. The issue has led to trade tensions and accusations of dumping in developed countries. In response, China plans to cut production by 150 million tonnes over five years, but critics argue the government's prioritization of industrial policies over consumption is part of the problem. Beijing needs to demonstrate a willingness to change itself to achieve change.

site_title: Asia: Shares edge ahead with oil, pound slips
summary: Asian shares edged higher on Monday, with the MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan rising 0.7% as investors awaited February industry surveys. Oil prices also boosted markets, with Brent crude adding 31 cents to US$33.32. Sterling slipped 1% against the dollar and euro due to concerns over the UK's potential exit from the European Union. Despite this, major currencies were relatively stable, and US consumer price inflation data showed underlying inflation accelerating, supporting the view that the Fed could raise interest rates this year.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall on selling in tech, financials
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index fell 0.2% to 8,308.40 as investors sold tech and financial shares, despite gains in transport and airline stocks. The electronics subindex dropped 0.3% and the financials subindex lost 0.2%. EVA Airways and China Airlines rose due to weak crude oil prices. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$33.247 per US dollar.

site_title: Samsung, LG unveil new devices in bid for smartphone recovery
summary: Samsung and LG unveiled new flagship devices, the Galaxy S7 and G5, respectively, in a bid to revive sales momentum and compete in a slowing smartphone market. LG's G5 features a modular design, allowing users to upgrade functions, while Samsung's Galaxy S7 offers incremental upgrades. Analysts praised LG's features, citing the potential for a sales recovery, but were lukewarm about Samsung's offerings. The smartphone market is expected to slow to 8.1% growth in 2016, with margin pressures intensifying due to Chinese manufacturers expanding overseas.

site_title: Swee Hong CEO steps down on bankruptcy order
summary: SWEE Hong Limited's CEO Ong Hock Leong has stepped down from his roles following a bankruptcy order made against him on February 18. He will cease to act as director, managing director, and group CEO effective February 18, but will remain as an adviser to the board and management team. This decision follows the company's Memorandum and Articles of Association and the Companies Act.

site_title: Otto Marine wins 3 shipbuilding contracts worth US$23m
summary: OTTO Marine secured three shipbuilding contracts worth US$23 million, including one product oil tanker and two ferries. The vessels are scheduled for delivery in 2017 and are expected to contribute positively to the company's financial performance for FY2016 and FY2017. The contracts were placed by a local Indonesian firm and an Indonesian state-owned enterprise.

site_title: Ascott ties up with Dongfu Investment to deepen presence in China
summary: CapitaLand's serviced residence business unit, The Ascott, has formed a strategic alliance with Dongfu Investment Development Corporation to deepen its presence in China. The partnership allows Ascott to manage apartments under development and future projects by Dongfu Investment, a subsidiary of China State Construction Engineering Company. The alliance aims to expand Ascott's presence in cities such as Shanghai and Jinan, with at least 10 properties slated for opening this year. The partnership is part of Ascott's target to reach 20,000 units in China by 2020.

site_title: China's yuan flat, central bank keeps firm hand ahead of G-20
summary: China's yuan remained stable against the dollar on Monday, with the People's Bank of China keeping the midpoint fixing steady ahead of the G-20 meeting in Shanghai. Traders expect the yuan's stability to last until the end of the meeting, which discusses issues including China's excess capacity, oil prices, and global growth. The G-20 meeting will take place on February 26 and 27, with a news conference by PBOC Governor Zhou Xiaochuan scheduled for February 26.

images.alt_text: China's yuan barely budged against the dollar on Monday as the central bank kept holding the line via a steady midpoint fixing. Traders expect the yuan's stability to last at least until the end of the G20 meeting in Shanghai later this week.

site_title: China tensions fuel acceleration in military spending
summary: China's military spending is accelerating due to heightened territorial tensions, propelling the Asia Pacific region to become the top military spending region by 2020, with total spending reaching $533 billion. China led growth in major arms exports from 2011-2015, with sales rising 88% and now accounting for 5.9% of global exports. Other countries in the region, such as the Philippines, Indonesia, Japan, and Vietnam, are following China's lead, with nine of the 20 fastest-growing defense budgets in 2015 located in the Asia Pacific.

images.alt_text: China's military growth combined with heightened territorial tensions is likely to propel the Asia Pacific region to the top rank of military spending by the end of the decade, according to a report by IHS Jane's.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down on stronger yen, weaker oil
summary: Tokyo stocks opened down 0.73% on Monday, weighed by a stronger yen and weaker oil prices, hurting exporters and global economic growth sentiment. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropped 115.78 points to 15,851.39.

site_title: Japan Feb flash manufacturing PMI shows growth slowing sharply as export orders shrink
summary: Japan's manufacturing activity showed growth slowing sharply in February, with the Markit/Nikkei Flash Japan Manufacturing Purchasing Managers Index falling to 50.2 from 52.3 in January. New export orders contracted at the fastest pace in three years, driven by a decline in global demand. This contraction, along with stagnant wages and depressed consumer prices, raises doubts about Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's stimulus policies aimed at re-energizing the economy.

site_title: Oil prices stay weak on ongoing overproduction, brimming crude stocks
summary: Oil prices declined in early Asian trading on Monday due to ongoing overproduction and record US crude stocks. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 4% to $29.67 per barrel, while International benchmark Brent fell 4% to $33.03 per barrel. The decline was exacerbated by a production freeze announcement last week, which pulled back gains.

site_title: Germany isn't investing the way it used to and that's a problem
summary: Germany is facing a problem with low corporate investment, despite favorable conditions such as low borrowing costs and robust domestic consumption. Capital spending as a share of output remains at a five-year low, hindering future growth. Experts attribute the lack of confidence to market turmoil, weaker global demand, and Germany's aging population. The International Monetary Fund and German authorities have called for reforms to improve conditions for private investment. Despite projections of moderate investment growth this year, recent global ructions and weakening business sentiment may further delay an investment boom.

site_title: Raffles Medical proposes 1-to-3 share split
summary: Raffles Medical Group Ltd is proposing a 1-to-3 share split, which would increase the number of issued shares from 575.25 million to 1.73 billion. The share split aims to make shares more affordable and accessible to investors, potentially broadening the shareholder base. The company's issued and paid-up share capital will remain unchanged at S$286.4 million. The proposed share split is expected to reduce the price of each board lot, making the shares more attractive to both existing and potential investors.

site_title: US dropped North Korea peace talk plan after missile test
summary: The US cancelled planned talks with North Korea to formally end the Korean War after North Korea rejected a US demand that denuclearization be a condition for negotiations. The talks were proposed by North Korea, which sought a peace treaty to replace the 1953 armistice. The US had leaned on China to play a peacemaker role, but ultimately decided not to proceed with the talks due to North Korea's refusal to address its nuclear program.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.38 points to 1671.41, following a 100-61 gain-to-loss ratio.

site_title: Japan to help build Panama metro line
summary: Japan and Panama will sign a contract in April to build the Panama City metro's Line 3, a 27km, $2 billion above-ground metro line with 14 stations, crossing the Panama Canal. The line is expected to be completed by 2022. The project aims to expand Central America's only metro system, with President Juan Carlos Varela and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe leading the signing ceremony in Tokyo.

site_title: Hong Kong mansion sells for HK$830m, less than expected
summary: Wheelock Properties Ltd sold a luxury home in Hong Kong's Peak neighborhood for HK$830 million (S$150 million), significantly below expected prices. The sale, which took just three hours, indicates a chill in the ultra-luxury segment amid a broader housing market downturn. Hong Kong's housing prices have declined 11% since September and are expected to fall another 25% this year.

site_title: South Korea won edges up, helped by exporters' sales, shares down
summary: South Korea's won edged up 0.2% to 1,232.5 against the dollar, supported by exporters' sales, but shares remained cautious ahead of a G20 meeting. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) fell 0.3% to 1,910.00 points, while foreign investors bought 4.4 billion won worth of KOSPI shares. Shares in LG Electronics rose 3.1% on hopes of increasing sales, but LG Chem fell 0.7% after announcing a battery supply deal to Fiat Chrysler Automobiles. The G20 meeting will discuss global growth and financial market volatility later this week.

site_title: Lenovo launches global wireless roaming service
summary: Lenovo launches Lenovo Connect, a global wireless roaming service allowing users to travel to 50 countries and use their devices at local prices on mobile internet, without installing new SIM cards. The service is available in China on LeMeng X3 smartphone and MIIX 700 tablet, and in Europe, Middle-East, and Africa on ThinkPad laptops starting in the first quarter. The move aims to cut roaming costs and follows the European Union's plan to abolish mobile roaming charges across the 28-country bloc by June 2017.

site_title: Uber driver arrested over deadly US shooting rampage
summary: A 45-year-old Uber driver, Jason Brian Dalton, was arrested in Michigan after a deadly shooting rampage that killed six people and seriously wounded two others. The shootings occurred at three locations, including an apartment complex, a car dealership, and a restaurant, between 6:00pm and 10:00pm on Sunday. Dalton, who passed a background check and had no prior criminal record, was apprehended two hours after the last shooting and is facing murder charges. Authorities believe he acted alone, with no evidence of multiple shooters involved.

site_title: Vard secures 325m-krone contract from Norway's largest trawler company
summary: VARD Holdings secured a 325 million Norwegian kroner (S$53.4 million) contract from Havfisk ASA, Norway's largest trawler company, to design and construct an 80-meter long stern trawler with advanced features. The vessel, to be built in Romania, will have separate cargo holds for refrigerated and frozen fish, a fish factory, and a freezing capacity of 80 tons per 24 hours. Delivery is scheduled for the first quarter of 2018.

site_title: China: Stocks rise at market open after top stock regulator removed
summary: China's major stock indexes rose 1.1-1.0% on Monday after the removal of Xiao Gang as chairman of the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) and his replacement by Liu Shiyu. The CSI300 index reached 3,083.93 points, and the Shanghai Composite Index gained 2,888.60 points. The market welcomed the change, indicating a shift in investor confidence following a period of volatility.

site_title: Malaysia's most battered stocks look like bargains to top fund
summary: Malaysia's top fund manager, Danny Wong, is betting on energy stocks, which have declined by over 30% in the past year, as crude prices are expected to rebound. Wong has been buying oil and gas companies, citing valuations that are too pessimistic. Energy shares have started to show signs of improvement, with some companies rallying 10-16% in the past month. Malaysia's economy is also showing signs of resilience, with GDP growth slowing less than expected in the fourth quarter. Wong expects energy companies to report "worst earnings" before profits improve, prompting a re-rating of the stocks.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Monday, rising 6.07 points or 0.23% to 2,662.94, driven by buying interest in several penny stocks, including QT Vascular, Spackman Entertainment Group, and China Sports International. The Straits Times Index saw 214 million shares worth S$171.3 million change hands, with gains outpacing losses 116 to 56.

site_title: Investment banks' trading revenue declined 9% in 2015
summary: Investment banks' trading revenue declined 9% in 2015, with FICC activities being the most affected. The decline was attributed to regulatory changes, retrenchment, and market volatility. This resulted in a 3% decline in overall investment banking revenue to US$160.2 billion. Banks' equity businesses and investment banking divisions saw some growth, but overall, the industry continues to struggle with restructuring and low client activity.

site_title: Fresh riots, arson in deadly north India caste crisis
summary: Fresh riots and arson broke out in north India's Haryana state on Sunday, leaving at least 12 people dead and 150 injured in a deadly caste crisis. Thousands of troops were deployed to quell the violence, which has turned violent after week-long protests by the Jat rural caste demanding quotas for government jobs and university places. Talks between Jat leaders and the Haryana government resulted in an agreement to give the community reservation through a law, but clashes continued, with mobs setting fire to homes and railway stations.

site_title: Beijing to raise threshold for issuing air pollution 'red alerts'
summary: Beijing is raising its threshold for issuing air pollution "red alerts" to 500 for a day, 300 for two days in a row, or 200 for four days. This change, taking effect in March, aims to standardize pollution alerts across Beijing and surrounding areas. The move follows a red alert issued in December due to thick smog, prompting schools to close and construction work to be suspended. The revised criteria are expected to tighten pollution controls for outlying regions, amid concerns about environmental degradation in China.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, Raffles Medical, CityDev, SingPost
summary: DBS Group reported a 20% increase in net profit for the fourth quarter to S$1 billion, while its full-year net profit rose 10% to a record S$4.5 billion. Vard Holdings secured a NOK 325 million contract for a Norwegian trawler company. Millennium & Copthorne Hotels' net profit plunged 88.6% to £5 million due to a decline in revenue. Singapore Post extended its joint venture agreement with Alibaba, with the Chinese company still fulfilling conditions.

site_title: US banks install more 'cardless' ATMs
summary: US banks are rolling out "cardless" ATMs, allowing customers to withdraw cash using their smartphones. The technology, which uses near-field communication, aims to speed up transactions and curb skimming, a growing problem that cost the global banking industry $2 billion in 2015. Dozens of US banks, including Wells Fargo, Bank of America, and Chase, are installing or updating ATMs with the new system, which is expected to be operational at 80,000 machines in North America within 18 months.

site_title: Flash: DBS Q4 net profit up 20%
summary: DBS Group Holdings reported a 20% increase in Q4 net profit, reaching S$1.34 billion. The full-year net profit rose 10% to S$5.24 billion, surpassing the S$10 billion total income mark. This growth is attributed to a strong performance in its core banking business.

site_title: AT&T to invest US$10b to bolster global enterprise services
summary: AT&T plans to invest approximately US$10 billion in its global enterprise services division, aiming to boost revenue and services such as wireless connectivity, cloud storage, and security for companies. This investment is part of the company's overall capital expenditure of US$22 billion in 2016. The business solutions unit saw a 2.7% decline in revenue in the quarter ended December 31, primarily due to lower equipment revenue and foreign exchange rate pressures.

images.alt_text: AT&T Inc will invest about US$10 billion in its global business solutions division, as it seeks to boost the unit that offers services such as wireless connectivity, cloud storage and security to companies, the wireless provider said on Sunday.

site_title: Richemont may axe up to 350 Swiss jobs
summary: Richemont, the world's second-largest luxury goods group, plans to cut up to 350 jobs in Switzerland this year due to a "difficult" watch market. The move, which involves adjusting production capacities, is part of a broader effort to adapt to the challenging market conditions.

site_title: German airlines to step up surprise medical checks for pilots
summary: German airlines will step up surprise medical checks for pilots, with the new program set to come into effect by the end of May. The move comes after a 2015 crash of Germanwings, where the co-pilot suffered from depression and deliberately crashed the plane. The new tests will ensure that pilots are not under the influence of medication or other psychoactive drugs, and will be implemented after a lower house of parliament approval. The checks will also verify that pilots are fit to fly and maintain a "safe and controlled" journey.

site_title: Egypt to float United Bank of Egypt
summary: Egypt's central bank plans to float the United Bank of Egypt, a bank in which it holds a 99% stake, in an initial public offering. The bank was formed in 2006 from the merger of three failing banks acquired by the central bank. The move aims to reduce the central bank's ownership and allow the bank to operate independently. This is the first time a state-owned company has been listed on the Cairo exchange since 2005.

site_title: Russian minister: Talks on oil output freeze should end by March
summary: Russian Energy Minister Alexander Novak said consultations on a preliminary deal to freeze oil output should be concluded by March 1. A group led by Russia and Saudi Arabia reached a common position in Doha, with the agreement expected to reduce global oil surplus by 1.3 million barrels per day. Iran welcomed the deal, but its deputy oil minister said it would increase production soon. Russia and Saudi Arabia aim to freeze January production levels, while other producers, including Mexico and Norway, are expected to take a constructive stance.

site_title: Radioactive water leak suspends plans to restart reactor in Japan
summary: A radioactive water leak at Japan's Takahama nuclear power plant has halted plans to restart the reactor, which would have been the fourth to come online after a nationwide shutdown. The leak, containing 34 litres of cooling water with radioactive substances, occurred 380km west of Tokyo. Kansai Electric Power cited safety concerns, suspending the restart plans. The incident marks a setback for Japan's efforts to increase nuclear power generation following a nationwide shutdown in 2016.

site_title: Samsung's new Galaxy phones short on innovation in a tough 2016
summary: Samsung unveiled the Galaxy S7 and S7 edge at the Mobile World Congress, but the devices' incremental upgrades may not boost sales. The new phones feature nearly identical designs to their predecessors, with some powered by Exynos processors and others by Snapdragon 820. The devices will be released globally, but the lack of significant innovation may not be enough to rejuvenate Samsung's sales, which have been declining in recent years.

site_title: China's Huawei backs Apple in fight over encryption
summary: China's Huawei has backed Apple's stance on encryption, with CEO Richard Yu stating that "privacy protection is very important" and that the company will "insist on the important things for consumers" when it comes to government demands. Huawei stopped short of saying it would take the same approach as Apple, but emphasized its commitment to security and privacy. The move comes as Huawei unveiled its new Matebook tablet, which runs Windows 10 and features an Intel Core processor. Despite this, Huawei remains confident in its growth prospects, shipping over 12 million devices in January.

site_title: India's US$16b wage bonanza may force Jaitley to cut capex
summary: India's finance minister, Arun Jaitley, is facing pressure to cut capital spending due to a proposed $16 billion wage hike for public servants and costly food and farm programs. The increase, which would boost demand, could worsen imbalances in the country's $2 trillion economy, undermining Prime Minister Narendra Modi's promise of better jobs. The hike could also lead to higher inflation and stoke inflation, potentially affecting the country's integration into the global economy.

site_title: China's debt seen rising through 2019, peaking at 283% of GDP
summary: China's debt-to-GDP ratio is expected to continue rising, peaking at 283% by 2019, according to a Bloomberg News survey of economists. This increase poses risks to policymakers as they try to prevent a slowdown without triggering a credit blowout. The country's economic growth is slowing, with exports and services struggling to pick up the slack from slowing investment and manufacturing. To address these concerns, China's central bank is boosting reserves for some banks to prevent a repeat of the 2009-2010 credit blowout.

site_title: Raffles Medical reports 2.4% rise in FY2015 net profit
summary: RAFFLES Medical Group reported a 2.4% increase in FY2015 net profit to S$69.3 million, driven by growth in healthcare services and hospital services divisions. Excluding a fair value gain, net profit rose 4.9% to S$67.8 million. Revenue increased 9.6% to S$410.5 million, with contributions from newly acquired International SOS and expanding Raffles Medical clinic network. A final dividend of 4.5 Singapore cents a share is proposed, representing a 9.1% increase from the previous year.

site_title: DBS Q4 net profit up 20%, FY2015 up 10% as total income crosses S$10b
summary: DBS Group reported a 20% increase in Q4 net profit to S$1 billion, driven by a 13% growth in total income and 11% rise in net interest income. Full-year net profit rose 10% to S$4.5 billion, marking the first time total income crossed S$10 billion. Net interest margin improved to 1.84% and non-interest income rose 19%. A final dividend of 30 cents per share has been proposed, with the full-year dividend at 60 cents per share.

site_title: Korean giants launch new smartphone in slowing market
summary: South Korean tech giants Samsung and LG unveiled new flagship smartphones, the Galaxy S7 and Galaxy S7 edge, and the LG G5, a modular smartphone, at the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona. The launches come as the global smartphone market slows, with sales increasing only 9.7% in the final quarter of last year. Analysts say the new devices may not be enough to revive sales, as they offer mostly incremental value to consumers. LG's modular design and accessories may help it compete with Samsung, but the industry faces a tough choice between focusing on low-price segments or features that differentiate their phones.

site_title: Nokia 5G pickup could begin as early as 2017: chief executive
summary: Nokia's CEO, Rajeev Suri, stated that the shift to 5G wireless networks could begin as early as 2017, ahead of the widely anticipated mass-market upgrades in 2020. The company plans to invest in 5G technology in 2016 and expects sales of 5G-ready equipment to start in 2017. Suri predicted that 5G will happen faster than expected, surprising some in the industry.

site_title: Trump supreme as White House race rolls on
summary: Donald Trump solidified his position as the frontrunner in the Republican presidential primary, winning the South Carolina primary and hammering home his message that he is the only candidate who can defeat Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton in November. Trump has 61 delegates, while Clinton has 502 and Bernie Sanders has 70. Trump predicted he could win New York state and the general election, while Rubio criticized Trump's lack of substance and Cruz questioned his conservative credentials. The Democratic primary is set to continue, with Sanders seeking to rebound from his loss in Nevada.

images.alt_text: Only five Republicans were left in the race for the White House Sunday, and frontrunner Donald Trump hammered home the idea that he is the only one who could defeat Democrat Hillary Clinton in November.

site_title: Australia to make paying tax a condition for foreign investment
summary: Australia plans to introduce new requirements on foreign investment applications, requiring multinational companies to pay tax on earnings within the country. Treasurer Scott Morrison will have powers to take action, including ordering divestment of Australian assets, if companies fail to comply. This move aims to tackle large companies using base erosion and profit-shifting methods to avoid tax. Following similar efforts by the Group of 20 nations, the move is part of Australia's efforts to close tax loopholes and increase transparency.

site_title: Wandervale EC draws over 400 e-applications
summary: Wandervale EC, Singapore's first executive condominium launched in 2016, has received over 400 e-applications, accounting for three-quarters of its 534 units. The project features 130 three-bedroom, 322 three-bedroom premium, and 82 four-bedroom units, priced at S$750-S$770 per square foot.
