images.alt_text: Football clubs received just 0.5 per cent in training compensation from the record US$4.2 billion transfer fees paid last year as agents received record payments, the international professional footballers union FIFPro claimed on Monday.

site_title: UOB's Q4 profit up 0.3% from a year ago, full-year down 1.2%
summary: UOB Group reported a 0.3% increase in Q4 net earnings to S$788 million, despite a 1.2% decline in full-year net earnings to S$3.21 billion. Strong core income and gains from the sale of investment securities drove growth, while one-off expenses and higher non-performing loan provisions weighed on results. The bank's non-performing loan ratio remained stable, and its Common Equity Tier 1 and Total Capital Adequacy Ratio stood at 13% and 15.6%, respectively.

images.alt_text: The UOB Group reported on Tuesday net earnings of S$788 million for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2015, up 0.3 per cent compared to S$786 million a year ago.

site_title: Dutch open their first 'poop bank' to treat gut diseases
summary: Dutch researchers have opened the country's first "poop bank" to treat people with chronic gut infections. The Netherlands Donor Feces Bank (NDFB) collects, stores, and distributes stool samples from healthy donors to help with transplants of faecal matter. This is particularly useful for treating Clostridium difficile (CD) infections, which can be fatal if left untreated. The bank aims to aid research into other illnesses, such as Crohn's disease, and will not pay donors, who must be in good health and have good intestinal flora.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise as bank and telecom stocks jump
summary: European shares rose 3-2.9% on Monday, driven by a rebound in banking stocks and French telecoms shares amid signs of takeover activity. The FTSEurofirst 300 index rose 2.8%, while Italian bank Monte Paschi jumped 9.2% and French telecoms shares surged 6.8%. The European Central Bank's plans to buy bad bank loans and a primary budget surplus in Greece also boosted markets. Despite a 12% decline this year, investors see a faster recovery for battered financial stocks, with some analysts predicting French market consolidation.

site_title: BOJ launches negative rates, already dubbed a failure by markets
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) implemented negative interest rates on February 15, 2016, charging banks 0.1% to park reserves, in an attempt to stimulate growth. However, the move was deemed a failure by markets, driving down the yen and Japanese share prices, but ultimately failing to boost spending and investment. Global markets were already in a tailspin due to concerns about China's slowdown, US rate hikes, and oil prices, making the BOJ's action ineffective. The policy's impact on banks' profitability was also significant, with bank shares plummeting by up to 30%.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan implements negative interest rates on Tuesday in a radical plan already deemed a failure by financial markets, highlighting Tokyo's lack of options to spur growth as global markets sputter.

site_title: 'Brexit' to put £466b of UK trade at risk: Study
summary: A study by the Centre for Economic and Business Research finds that a British departure from the European Union could put £466 billion of UK trade at risk. The UK's EU membership provides "easy" access to trade with 27 member states and 68 other nations with negotiated agreements. A referendum on EU membership is expected, with polls showing a narrowing gap between those supporting and opposing the UK's departure. Campaigners on both sides are urging businesses to consider the trade implications of a Brexit.

site_title: RBA sees low rates aiding consumer spending, house construction
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has stated that record-low interest rates are supporting consumer spending and house construction, with a lower currency improving firms' competitiveness. The bank left interest rates unchanged at 2% and will monitor growth and inflation. Governor Glenn Stevens is weighing the impact of a darkening global outlook, particularly in China, against signs of improvement in the local economy. The RBA noted that very low interest rates are supporting growth in household consumption and dwelling investment, and that the depreciation of the exchange rate is boosting demand for domestic production.

site_title: Missing Malaysia jet weeks away from keeping secrets forever
summary: Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, a Boeing 777, has been missing for nearly two years, with only a single wing flap recovered from Reunion Island. The search, led by the Australian Transport Safety Bureau, is nearing its end, with the last ships expected to finish scanning the southern Indian Ocean by June. Despite extensive efforts, no signs of the 239 people on board or any debris have been found. The investigation suggests that the plane may have been deliberately steered off course, but the exact circumstances remain unclear, and the search may fail, leaving the world's aviation industry with its biggest unsolved mystery since Amelia Earhart's disappearance in 1937.

site_title: Tokyo borrowers play negative rates game in office property boon
summary: The Bank of Japan's decision to pay negative interest on reserves and expand purchases of Reits is expected to boost Tokyo office property prices, with predictions of a 10% rise in prime office space this year. Investors are expected to pour more money into property, driven by the BOJ's efforts to stimulate the economy. Real estate investment in Tokyo is forecast to climb 10% to 4.5 trillion yen, with office rents rising 5-10% this year, according to estimates.

site_title: Technology helps keep miners afloat but prices under water
summary: Miners are using technology to stay afloat despite the worst commodity price downturn in nearly two decades. New technologies such as real-time tracking and "ventilation on demand" systems are helping companies reduce downtime, save fuel, and boost production. Despite a 20% fall in profits, Australian mining companies have shown resilience, prolonging oversupply and putting downward pressure on prices. Gold miners, in particular, have stepped up technology investment, with some companies seeing significant cost savings and improved exploration success rates.

images.alt_text: New technology is helping miners cut costs to survive the worst downturn in commodity prices in nearly two decades, which is good news for companies that might otherwise have gone to the wall, not so good for an industry drowning in overcapacity.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday; STI eases 0.35%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.35% or 9.13 points to 2,598.77 at 9am on Tuesday, following a previous day's rally. The market was influenced by a sharp fourth-quarter net loss at Chinese shipbuilder Cosco Corp. The STI saw 28 million shares worth S$51.9 million trade, with gainers outnumbering losers 47 to 46.

site_title: Indonesia turns to manufacturing to counter commodities slump
summary: Indonesia is turning to manufacturing to counter the economic slump caused by falling commodity prices. The country's President Joko Widodo has liberalized dozens of sectors to improve competitiveness and stimulate growth. Despite efforts, manufacturing growth has lagged the overall economy, and the sector has struggled with creaky infrastructure, slow progress on free-trade pacts, and high tariffs. Foreign investors are needed to be convinced of the government's commitment to reform, while domestic firms must compete internationally. The country faces daunting challenges, including a decline in exports and a shift towards protectionism, but some experts believe that shifting the debate towards competitiveness is a positive step.

site_title: Pirelli shareholders approve Marco Polo Industrial Holding merger
summary: Pirelli shareholders approved a merger with Marco Polo Industrial Holding, a Chinese company controlled by ChemChina, in a 7.4-billion-euro takeover last year. The merger is expected to be implemented by mid-2016, with seven new advisors, six of whom are Chinese, joining the group's board. The deal culminates the Chinese takeover of Pirelli, a flagship company in Milan, Italy, founded in 1872.

site_title: Black market mark-ups show true pain of US dollar pegs
summary: Developing countries face significant pressure to ease controls on their currencies due to high black market mark-ups. Some nations, such as Nigeria, Angola, and Egypt, pay up to 136% more than official exchange rates to obtain US dollars, indicating unsustainable pegs. Countries like Argentina and Kazakhstan have abandoned fixed exchange rates to boost competitiveness. The existence of thriving black markets is a sign that a country may be on the verge of changing its currency policy, with some predicting further devaluations in the coming months.

site_title: Flash: Great Eastern's Q4 net profit up 5% at S$218.8m vs S$207.8m
summary: Great Eastern Holdings posted a 5% increase in its Q4 net profit to S$218.8 million, surpassing expectations. The company maintained its dividend payout. This follows a period of economic uncertainty, with rising oil prices and concerns over US-EU tariffs. Meanwhile, other news includes NTT DC Reit's oversubscribed public offer, Creative Technology's revenue warning, and Indonesia detaining a Trafigura employee in a graft case.

site_title: French social networks atwitter over asteroid hoax
summary: French social networks were abuzz with a hoax claiming a house-sized asteroid would crash into the city of Marseille on March 5. The false reports, fueled by a real asteroid passing close to Earth, gained widespread attention on Twitter and Facebook, with nearly one million eyeballs on Twitter. French radio station France Info denied the claims, stating they were "humourless" and not based on facts. NASA confirmed that the asteroid, TX68, would pass by Earth on March 5, but with no possibility of impact. The hoax started as a prank among French video gamers.

site_title: San Miguel may woo small investors as it cuts dollar debt
summary: San Miguel Corp, the Philippines' largest company, plans to sell bonds to small investors and cut its dollar-denominated debt to tap the country's growing wealth and shield earnings from a weaker peso. The company aims to reduce its dollar debt by half over the next two to three years and has already raised 33.5 billion pesos from a similar fundraising. San Miguel plans to borrow more in pesos and sell preferred shares to fund infrastructure projects, with a goal of reducing its dollar debt exposure to shield the company from foreign-exchange volatility.

site_title: China the focus as Obama hosts South East Asian leaders
summary: US President Barack Obama hosts South East Asian leaders at a California desert retreat to increase pressure on China over land grabs in the South China Sea. The summit aims to secure a united front against China's island-building and military build-up, with leaders discussing a common response to a key UN court ruling. The White House seeks to champion its "pivot to Asia" and Asean's growing importance, while China uses diplomatic and economic muscle to weaken criticism. A collective US-Asean endorsement of the court's verdict would heap pressure on China, which refuses to recognize the court's authority.

site_title: CityLife@Tampines EC awarded TOP
summary: CityLife@Tampines EC, Singapore's first hotel-inspired executive condominium project, has been awarded a temporary occupation permit. Developed by Amara Holdings, Kay Lim Holdings, and SingHaiyi Group, the 514-unit project was fully sold out within two years of its launch in 2012. The EC features hotel-inspired amenities, including a 100m infinity pool and home concierge service, offering a luxury-hotel lifestyle in a residential setting. The project's CEO, Albert Teo, expressed confidence that residents will feel at home with the comprehensive suite of hotel-grade facilities and strategic location.

site_title: Pratt & Whitney opens first manufacturing facility in Singapore
summary: Pratt & Whitney has opened its first manufacturing facility in Singapore, producing fan blades and other key components for its PurePower Geared Turbofan (GTF) engine family. The US$110 million facility, located at Seletar Aerospace Park, will hire over 100 employees and support the Asia-Pacific region and globally. The new facility produces hybrid metallic blades made from lightweight materials, offering superior aerodynamic efficiency and a 16% reduction in fuel consumption. The investment is seen as a vote of confidence in Singapore's aerospace manufacturing capabilities, with all production lines expected to be operational by the end of 2016.

site_title: Volkswagen managers were warned about diesel probe in May 2014: sources
summary: Volkswagen managers were warned in May 2014 that US regulators might investigate car engine software related to pollution levels. A letter from a high-ranking employee raised concerns about senior management's knowledge of the potential issue. The warning came over a year before Volkswagen's public admission of manipulating emission test results through software. This raises questions about how much senior managers knew about the scandal. The revelation has sparked further investigation into the company's actions.

site_title: Airbus, Boeing count on China as orders from S-E Asia, India decline
summary: China is emerging as a bright spot for the global aerospace industry, with airlines and leasing companies announcing orders for 780 planes valued at $102 billion last year. China is expected to require around 6,330 new planes worth $950 billion in the next two decades, making it the largest market in the world. In contrast, airlines in South-east Asia and India are struggling, with many carriers mired in losses, delayed deliveries, and over-ordered aircraft. The region's aviation outlook is deteriorating, while China's is seen as the strongest in its history, with the government investing heavily in infrastructure to boost air travel.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng drops plan to spin off construction units
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation has dropped its plan to spin off its construction units, citing prevailing market conditions and other factors. The company's fourth-quarter net profit plummeted 94.2% to S$9.8 million due to reduced revenue from property developments. Raymond Chia Lee Meng, son-in-law of the company's founder, has returned as group CEO after stepping down to start his own venture in Australia and Vietnam. Lim Tiam Seng will step down as executive chairman and become honorary chairman and adviser.

site_title: Strategists still bullish about European stocks despite recent rout
summary: European stock strategists remain bullish despite recent market rout, with the average forecast predicting a 23% rally for the European benchmark by year-end. UBS Group AG and Societe Generale SA are among those projecting significant gains, with estimates ranging from 28% to 36% increases. The European Central Bank is expected to boost confidence in the banking sector, and oil prices are expected to recover. However, some analysts, such as Jasper Lawler at CMC Markets, question the effectiveness of central-bank stimulus and warn of a potential misperception of the economic recovery in Europe.

images.alt_text: Strategists are standing by their optimistic calls. After a rout spanning all assets that dragged global equities into a bear market last week, the average forecast now sees the European benchmark closing the year with a 23 per cent rally from Friday's close.

site_title: EU-Asean Open Skies could start taking shape by 2017
summary: The European Commission may receive a mandate to start formal negotiations with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) on the EU-Asean Open Skies agreement by 2017, with the goal of implementing the deal by the end of the year. The agreement aims to liberalize air transport between the EU and Asean, offering greater connectivity, choice, and cheaper fares for passengers. The deal would be the first of its kind, creating a platform for linking the two regions through direct flights and capitalizing on growing markets.

site_title: Fourth telco should not be just about cheaper call and data rates
summary: Singapore's telco CEOs, Singtel's Chua Sock Koong and MyRepublic's Malcolm Rodrigues, emphasize that a fourth mobile network operator should focus on innovation and quality over cheaper prices. They claim that a business model based solely on lower prices is unsustainable and may compromise the industry's long-term quality. Both CEOs stated that they will continue to offer competitive prices while prioritizing services and innovation, rather than just competing on price. This stance is seen as a welcome move to ensure the industry's sustainability and quality.

site_title: STI rebounds as risk appetite returns
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 2.7% on Monday, driven by signs of refreshed risk appetite and arguments that equities have been oversold. The STI rose 67.95 points to 2,607.9, following a strong rally in other major Asian markets, including Tokyo's 7.2% gain and Hong Kong's 3.3% increase. The rebound came despite Shanghai dipping after the Chinese New Year break.

site_title: S'pore business confidence recovers in Q4, but still dour compared to world: survey
summary: Singapore's business confidence recovered in Q4 2015, rising to between -55 and -60, after a four-year low in Q3. The index remains pessimistic, worse than global levels, which were between -20 and -30. The survey was conducted by ACCA and the Institute of Management Accountants.

site_title: China seen boosting defence spending as South China Sea, reforms weigh
summary: China is expected to announce a significant increase in defense spending, possibly around 30% this year, to address the military's concerns over reforms and territorial disputes in the South China Sea and Taiwan. The country's military spending has been rising rapidly, with a 10.1% increase last year, and the recent US "freedom of navigation" operations have added to public pressure. The government aims to modernize the military and boost readiness, despite concerns over job security and the impact of 300,000 planned troop cuts.

images.alt_text: China will likely announce another large rise in defence spending next month, as the ruling Communist Party seeks to assuage the military's unhappiness at sweeping reforms and as worries over the South China Sea and Taiwan weigh on Beijing.

site_title: Noble's LNG traders leaving to join Glencore: sources
summary: Noble Group Ltd is losing three LNG traders, including two co-heads, to rival trader Glencore. The departures come after Noble's shares have declined by over two-thirds in the past year due to allegations of accounting irregularities and a slump in commodity markets. Noble will continue to trade LNG, with around five people involved in the business. The move is seen as an opportunity for Glencore, which has noted the growth potential of LNG trading.

site_title: Australia plans new interbank rate-setting scheme by end-2016
summary: Australia plans to implement a new interbank rate-setting scheme by the end of 2016 to minimize the risk of manipulation in the country's credit market. The changes, outlined in a discussion paper from the Council of Financial Regulators, aim to address the manipulation of the BBSW bank bill swap rate, which affects the price of money market funds. The move comes as the corporate regulator prepares to launch its first civil action for attempted rate rigging.

site_title: Using the product return process to bolster customer loyalty
summary: During the post-holiday season, retailers face a surge in product returns due to customers' changing expectations and the rise of online shopping. To manage returns effectively, businesses should implement a strategic approach, including clear return policies, easy-to-use online platforms, and convenient return options. A lenient return policy can increase purchases, but also leads to more returns. Companies should empower customers with the right information and tools to facilitate smooth returns, improve customer loyalty, and minimize the risk of losing customers due to poor customer service.

site_title: Wheat prices expected to fall further after record supply forecast
summary: US wheat prices are expected to fall further due to a record-high global supply forecast. The US Department of Agriculture has raised its estimate for world inventories to an all-time high, with falling consumption in China and India contributing to surplus concerns. Prices have fallen globally, with benchmark Chicago futures reaching a five-year low and American farmers struggling to find buyers for their relatively expensive supplies. The USDA forecasts a shrinkage in US exports to the smallest since 1972, and some analysts predict planting reductions may help keep inventories from expanding.

site_title: Cruising calmly through rough seas
summary: BLPL, a shipping line arm under Transworld Group Singapore, has successfully navigated the challenges of the shipping industry, despite economic downturn and volatile freight rates. A five-year plan is in place until 2020, with the company aiming to become an Asia regional operator. BLPL is set to make its maiden voyage into Japan by Q1 this year, thanks to a good agency and partnerships. Managing director Mahesh Sivaswamy attributes the company's success to its agency's eagerness to do business in Japan.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages provide insights on ComfortDelGro (CDG) and Singtel. ComfortDelGro's FY2015 revenue grew 1.5% to S$4.11 billion, driven by bus, rail, and taxi segments, but offset by lower prices for diesel sales. Analysts expect the launch of Downtown Line 2 to drive revenue growth. Singtel reported resilient Q3 results, maintaining full-year guidance despite economic headwinds and losses from Trustwave. Analysts maintain a positive view on Singtel due to its consistent earnings and 5% dividend yield.

site_title: SembMarine, Cosco buffeted by S$1 billion in combined Q4 losses
summary: Sembcorp Marine and Cosco Corporation (Singapore) reported combined fourth-quarter losses of S$1 billion, their worst showings in history, due to low oil prices. The losses were partly caused by the reversal of profits, bad-debt allowances, inventory write-downs, and customer requests to defer or cancel projects. Significant impairments were made on contracts due to or payments owed by Brazilian customers. Keppel Corp, with property interests, reported a fourth-quarter profit of S$405 million, while the three local banks are expected to report quarterly results with potential losses. Analysts expect oil prices to rebound, potentially leading to further write-offs.

site_title: Jokowi gains political traction after tumultuous first year
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo, known as Jokowi, has gained significant political traction after a tumultuous first year in office, with his approval ratings rising to 67% amid improved market sentiment. Challenges remain, but Jokowi has strengthened ties with parliament and his own party, and is planning a massive increase in public spending on infrastructure. He aims to lift economic growth to 7% by 2019 and has an approval rating of 37% to vote for him in 2019, with former general Prabowo Subianto in second place.

site_title: Share drubbing reflects DBS's vulnerabilities
summary: DBS Group Holdings, Singapore's largest bank, has seen a significant decline in investor confidence following its loss to Bank Central Asia (BCA) in market capitalization. BCA, owned by Indonesia's second-richest person, now holds the region's largest market capitalization at US$24.5 billion, surpassing DBS's US$23.3 billion. Despite this, DBS shares have risen this year due to its focus on Indonesia, which has shielded the bank from slowing growth in Greater China.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Wing Tai Holdings has established a new fund management unit, WT Fund Management Pte Ltd, focusing on Asia-Pacific investments. Real estate veteran Chua Choy Soon is appointed as managing director. Meanwhile, companies Acma, Mermaid Maritime, and Regal International warned of expected net losses due to impairment provisions. SIA Engineering Company plans to invest $50 million in innovation initiatives, while Sinostar Pec Holdings injected $6.3 million into a subsidiary for working capital.

site_title: HSBC will keep headquarters in London
summary: HSBC Holdings has decided to keep its headquarters in London, rejecting a plan to shift to Hong Kong after a 10-month review. The unanimous decision gives a boost to London's status as a global financial centre, which faced challenges from tougher regulation and rising costs since the 2008-09 financial crisis.

site_title: SembMarine plunges into the red on S$801m provisions
summary: SembCorp Marine, a Singapore-based yard group, reported a fourth quarter net attributable loss of S$536.8 million in FY2015, with total losses of S$289.67 million for the year. The company attributed the losses to provisions of S$801 million on rig building contracts and share of losses in other associates. Despite securing new contracts worth S$3.2 billion, the company's shares have plummeted by over 46% due to the challenging oil and gas industry. CEO Wong Weng Sun acknowledged that FY15 was one of the toughest years in recent history, with the company looking to diversify and reduce costs.

images.alt_text: For the fourth quarter, SembMarine decided to include impairments and provisions of S$609 million for rig building contracts, including S$329 million for the Sete Brasil seven-drillship projects. A further S$192 million was provided for the negative impact from share of losses in other associates.

site_title: 2 sub-groups hold their respective first meeting
summary: Singapore's Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) held its first meetings for two of its sub-groups, focusing on "future jobs and skills" and "future city". The job skills sub-group, co-chaired by Acting Education Minister Ong Ye Kung and Singtel's CEO Bill Chang, discussed ways to prepare Singaporean workers for the future, including building entrepreneurial spirit and recognizing opportunities overseas. The future city sub-group, co-chaired by National Development Minister Lawrence Wong and PSA International's CEO Tan Chong Meng, brainstormed ideas to develop Singapore's infrastructure and enhance connectivity with the region.

images.alt_text: PSA's Mr Tan says that Singapore, with its limited space, has to be bold in transforming its future landscape.

site_title: Airlines counter criticism of profiteering from oil price drop
summary: Global airlines have countered criticism of profiteering from low oil prices, with IATA's director general Tony Tyler stating that industry profitability remains fragile despite forecasted $36 billion in airline profits for 2016. Despite lower oil prices, fuel costs still account for a significant portion of airline expenses, and the industry is only starting to develop sustainable profits due to high capital costs, regulatory constraints, and intense competition. Airlines argue that they are only starting to pass on fuel cost savings to consumers as costs come down.

site_title: Thousands of Indian students protest as government cracks down on dissent
summary: Thousands of Indian students protested nationwide on Monday, sparked by the arrest of a left-wing student leader accused of sedition. The protests, which spread to at least 18 universities, including Jawaharlal Nehru University, were sparked by the government's alleged attempts to silence dissent. The government accused the student leader of "anti-India" sentiment, while critics compared the crackdown to Indira Gandhi's 1970s state of emergency. The protests are part of a broader ideological confrontation between the nationalist government and left-wing groups, with some calling it a threat to freedom of expression.

site_title: No need to stress test mutual fund sector: BlackRock
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, says a stress test of the mutual fund industry to assess its ability to withstand widespread redemptions in a financial crisis is unnecessary. Vice-chairman Barbara Novick argues that such a test would not be meaningful and that individual fund stress testing would be more effective. Novick notes that market participants, including hedge funds and pension funds, would step in to buy securities if a particular security fell in price, highlighting the interconnectedness of the market. BlackRock manages $4.6 trillion in assets.

site_title: The Revenant is top winner with 5 awards
summary: The Revenant took top honors at the British Academy of Film and Television Arts (Bafta) awards, winning five awards including Best Film, Best Director, and Best Actor for Leonardo DiCaprio. DiCaprio used his acceptance speech to thank his mother and express his gratitude to British acting talent. The film's success boosts its status as a leading contender for Oscar glory later this month.

images.alt_text: Leonardo DiCaprio (right) was named leading actor and Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu best director, both for the movie The Revenant, which was named best film.
John Boyega won the rising star award for his role as Stormtrooper Finn in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. The rising star award is the only award voted by the public.
Kate Winslet won the award for supporting actress for her work on the film Steve Jobs.

site_title: Japan's economy contracts again
summary: Japan's economy contracted at a 1.4% real annual rate in the final quarter of 2015, marking its fifth quarterly decline since Prime Minister Shinzo Abe took office. Consumer spending and exports took a hit due to worsening domestic sentiment and the external environment, making it challenging to reach Abe's 2% annual growth target. Despite a surge in Tokyo's stock prices, the underlying economy remains weak, and analysts attribute the contraction to a decline in private consumption. Abe hinted at official intervention in the foreign exchange market to curb the yen's rise, and further fiscal and monetary stimulus may be needed to stabilize the economy.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines on track with profit target; mulls over fleet expansion
summary: Malaysia Airlines is on track to return to profitability by 2018, thanks to restructuring efforts that included job cuts, route changes, and a shift towards owned aircraft. CEO Christoph Mueller said the airline has finished laying off employees and is focusing on product improvements. The company is also reorganizing its network, scrapping European routes and partnering with Emirates for longer-haul destinations. Malaysia Airlines aims to establish Kuala Lumpur as a hub for regional travel and is shifting to smaller jets as part of the revamp.

images.alt_text: Mr Mueller said it is very important for the industry that investigators eventually find the remains of Flight 370.

site_title: Savvy newcomers treat second career in wine business seriously
summary: Wealthy individuals are taking a serious approach to their second career in the wine business, applying the same principles that made them successful in their first careers. Many are creating profitable businesses, producing 10,000 cases or fewer, and viewing winemaking as a startup. Successful newcomers, such as venture capitalist Charles J. McMinn, are taking a calculated approach, investing in quality grapes, renting a winery, and outsourcing logistics. Experts say the wine industry's strong financial play and technological advances have attracted non-wine people, and time is essential for achieving profitability, with 10 years typically required to get to profitability.

site_title: Tat Hong unit surrenders Gul Crescent lease to JTC for pre-tax gain of S$9.5 million
summary: A wholly owned unit of crane rental firm Tat Hong Holdings has surrendered its lease of 11 Gul Crescent to JTC Corporation for S$21 million, generating a pre-tax gain of S$9.5 million. The property, with a 25-year remaining lease, was previously leased by Tat Hong HeavyEquipment and had a net book value of S$11.4 million. The disposal was part of Tat Hong's plan to optimise operations in land-scarce Singapore, following failed attempts to sell the property in 2013 and 2015.

site_title: Google considers building option to traditional set-top box
summary: Google is considering building an alternative to traditional cable set-top boxes, with vice-president Milo Medin predicting Android TV will eventually allow consumers to abandon bulky boxes. The move would mark a turning point in the rapidly changing US media landscape, with Google, Apple, and Amazon potentially offering their own devices to deliver cable channels. The Federal Communications Commission's proposal to force cable companies to relinquish control over content display could also benefit Google, allowing for more competition and potentially lower cable bills.

site_title: Malaysia faces spike in risks as central bank chief retires, gas markets slump
summary: Malaysia is facing heightened risks as its central bank chief, Zeti Akhtar Aziz, retires in April and the country's liquefied natural gas (LNG) exports are expected to drop due to a slump in global oil prices. The LNG contracts are linked to oil prices but have a typical lag of three to four months, and analysts warn that the market has not fully priced in the potential fall in LNG prices. The central bank's credibility is also at risk if a replacement is not suitable, which could impact the economy and the currency.

site_title: On economic stupidity
summary: The US presidential election has largely ignored macroeconomic policy, despite significant economic risks, including a substantial amount of troubled debt and market turmoil. Financial markets are flashing warnings, with bond markets expecting many years of economic weakness. The Republican candidates' views on macroeconomic policy range from crazy to utterly crazy, with Donald Trump accusing the Fed of being in the tank for Democrats. Even seemingly sensible Republicans have extreme views, while Democratic candidates, including Bernie Sanders, talk sensibly about macroeconomic policy, but Sanders' approach has raised concerns about congressional oversight.

site_title: Philippines to auction off jewels recovered from Marcos
summary: Philippine authorities plan to auction off millions of dollars' worth of jewelry recovered from late dictator Ferdinand Marcos and his family. The Presidential Commission on Good Government aims to retrieve hundreds of art masterpieces believed to have been obtained with "ill-gotten wealth." The move comes after the commission launched a website to facilitate the recovery of stolen assets. The auction is expected to take place as soon as possible, with the goal of returning the recovered items to their rightful owners.

site_title: Amid tumble in aluminium prices, Iceland offers cheap power to its smelters
summary: Iceland's aluminium smelters continue to operate profitably despite a global market downturn, thanks to contracts linking power costs to metal prices. The island's three smelters, run by Rio Tinto, Century Aluminum, and Alcoa, contribute 38% to Iceland's economy. This unique power arrangement allows them to maintain production without cutting costs, unlike other smelters facing challenges. The industry remains a vital pillar of Iceland's economy, alongside fishing and tourism.

site_title: Indonesia's Jan exports slide by more than 20%; central bank may cut rates
summary: Indonesia posted a small trade surplus in January, defying expectations for a third monthly deficit, due to a slump in imports from weak domestic consumption. Sliding commodity prices led to a sharp drop in export earnings. The country's central bank may cut rates again this week due to deteriorating global demand.

site_title: Challenger's 2015 profit rises 23% despite 1% fall in revenue
summary: Challenger Technologies reported a 23% increase in net profit to S$18.2 million in 2015, driven by higher government grants and lower operating expenses from closing Malaysian retail operations. Revenue fell 1%. Earnings per share rose 1.01 cents. The company attributed the results to these factors, which offset the decline in revenue.

site_title: Great Scot! Highlands grows unlikely winner tea
summary: TAM O'Braan, an Irishman living in the Scottish Highlands, has successfully grown tea in the region, defying experts who said it couldn't be done. He imported tea trees from the Himalayas and adapted them to Scotland's climate, using the country's fog, rainfall, and soil to produce a unique and sweet flavor. His Dalreoch Estate tea was crowned a winner at the Salon de The awards in Paris and is now sold in luxury stores, including Mariage Freres and Fortnum & Mason.

site_title: Political revolutions, according to Bernie and the Donald
summary: US politicians Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump are leading populist movements, challenging the economic elite, and stirring anxiety on Wall Street. Sanders, a socialist, aims to transform the US into a social-democratic country with a national healthcare system, free college education, and expanded welfare state. Trump, a billionaire, promises to protect American workers with tariffs and a national healthcare system, targeting politicians seen as in the pockets of Wall Street. Their rival, Hillary Clinton, is seen as part of the establishment, while Jeb Bush is perceived as a puppet of big donors. This populist wave raises concerns over the stability of the US economy and the Fed's interest policy, fueling market turmoil.

site_title: Airspace integration needed in Asia-Pacific amid growing traffic
summary: Air traffic in the Asia-Pacific region is expected to increase significantly over the next two decades, with 34% of global traffic currently taking place in the region. To manage this growth efficiently and safely, governments must integrate airspace across borders. The International Air Transport Association (Iata) and Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan emphasized the need for better equipment, facilities, and a highly trained workforce. Collaborative decision-making in air traffic management is also being implemented between major city pairs, with Singapore, Bangkok, and Hong Kong among the initial participants.

site_title: Companies get creative as venture investment in medical devices stalls
summary: Venture capital funding for medical device companies has remained stagnant since the 2008 recession, with total funding dropping after 2008 and failing to recover. This trend contrasts with other areas of venture capital, where companies with fewer than 200 employees can secure over $100 million in funding. Experts attribute the lack of investment in medical devices to a variety of factors, including regulatory hurdles and intense competition in the market. As a result, medical device companies are becoming increasingly creative in their fundraising efforts.

site_title: US: Markets closed for holiday
summary: US markets closed on Monday, February 15, 2016, for Presidents Day.

site_title: GET.com, BT jointly launch online financial comparison tool for consumers
summary: Singapore-based GET.com and BT jointly launched GETxBT Compare, a digital platform for consumers to compare and apply for home loans, credit cards, and personal loans online. Powered by GET.com's proprietary comparison technology, the tool provides an intuitive and transparent platform for consumers to make informed decisions. The partnership aims to create a credible and transparent platform, aligning with Singapore's increasing sophistication in digital banking. The launch coincides with GET.com's first anniversary in Singapore and marks the start of several initiatives by BT to enhance personal finance tools and resources.

site_title: Designers slog on a robot voice that humans like
summary: A team of IBM linguists, engineers, and marketers designed a synthetic voice for Watson, the company's Jeopardy!-playing AI program, in 2009. The voice was not human-like but not like HAL 9000 from the movie 2001: A Space Odyssey. Since then, software designers have grappled with creating a "personality" for conversational agents, which are software programs that understand natural language and speech. While progress has been made, creating a computerized voice indistinguishable from a human one is still challenging, with designers facing the "uncanny valley" phenomenon, where voices that are almost human-sounding can be disturbing.

site_title: Q: Who's really in charge of the global economy? A: No one
summary: The global economy has no single entity in charge, according to a recent IMF speech. Central banks, such as the US Federal Reserve, Bank of England, and European Central Bank, have embarked on "quantitative easing" with differing objectives, contributing to currency fluctuations and capital flows. The IMF, despite its role in promoting international monetary cooperation and stability, is hindered by member countries' lack of coordination. National finance ministries, such as the US Treasury, also set fiscal policies independently, further fragmenting global control. The World Trade Organisation and World Bank, originally tasked with facilitating international trade and reducing poverty, have been usurped by regional trade agreements and development banks.

site_title: HSBC's choice may please nobody
summary: HSBC has decided to maintain its London headquarters, despite considering alternative locations such as Toronto and Paris, citing high costs and complexity of a move. The decision comes as London has become more bank-friendly and Hong Kong's appeal has diminished due to China's economic slowdown and uncertain financial policy. The bank's business in China will continue to expand, but its ideal location remains a recurring question, potentially leaving both cities feeling short-changed. HSBC's board unanimously agreed that the costs outweighed the benefits of a move.

site_title: Sunnylands meet should set tone for future US-Asean engagement
summary: US President Barack Obama is hosting the first-ever gathering of all 10 Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) leaders at the Sunnylands summit, marking a significant step in US-Asean engagement. The region faces challenges such as the rule of law, peaceful resolution of disputes, economic growth, and moderate Islam under assault. Obama aims to underscore the growing convergence of US-Asean security and economic interests, particularly in the face of China's growing influence. The summit will focus on issues like the Trans-Pacific Partnership, the South China Sea, and the global fight against terrorism, setting the tone for future US-Asean engagement.

images.alt_text: Sunnylands provides Mr Obama with an opportunity to showcase the TPP's benefits to other South-east Asian nations.

site_title: Justice Antonin Scalia and the 'dead' Constitution
summary: Justice Antonin Scalia significantly altered the US Supreme Court's interpretation of the Constitution and laws during his nearly 30-year tenure. He championed "originalism" and "textualism," believing judges should decide cases according to the original meaning of the Constitution. Scalia's unyielding views and outspoken personality, often described as a "court of one," led to solo dissents and strained relationships with colleagues. His legacy, however, may be revived through younger lawyers and conservative Federalist Society members who revere his judicial opinions, potentially leading to future appointments to the Supreme Court.

site_title: Yen drops on calmer global financial nerves
summary: The yen's advance halted as Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe criticized excessive currency volatility, saying "appropriate action" would be taken in the exchange rate market. The yen had risen 7% since February due to global financial market sell-offs. China's yuan gained more than 1% on its first full day of trade in a week, helping to settle global financial nerves. The euro and Australian dollar also rose, while the US dollar fell against other currencies. Market analysts expect a "risk on" sentiment, but note that China's growth data was weak and Japan's woes continue.

site_title: Chinese trade threat prompts steel-led EU industry demonstration
summary: European Union industries, led by the steel sector, held a demonstration in Brussels to protest the potential loss of jobs due to Chinese competition, seeking to persuade policymakers to retain import tariffs. The EU is considering recognizing China as a market economy, which would make it harder for manufacturers to win high duties on allegedly "dumped" shipments. The demonstration highlighted fears that Chinese exports could wipe out industries and leave hundreds of thousands of people jobless, with over 234,000 EU jobs linked to Chinese imports.

site_title: GE Aviation to invest S$110m in its repair facility
summary: GE Aviation is investing S$110 million in its Singapore repair facility over the next 10 years, focusing on projects including a Lean Lab, an Asia-Pacific centre of excellence, and an Advanced-Technologies Centre. The investment aims to enhance the facility's capabilities and support GE's customer repair needs for existing and new engines. The facility, which has been operating for 35 years, has grown from US$2 million in sales to over US$1 billion in sales last year, and employs 1,500 staff.

site_title: Meaningful quarterly reporting can improve governance and transparency
summary: BlackRock CEO supports meaningful quarterly reporting, disagreeing with the notion that long-term value creation should be prioritized over transparency. He believes companies should focus on demonstrating progress against strategic plans rather than just meeting EPS targets. Quarterly reports can provide context and help investors understand financial implications, but issuers must explain deviations from trends. The CEO argues that quarterly reporting can help mitigate short-termism and level the playing field for different investors, particularly retail shareholders in Singapore.

site_title: Boeing sees growth and orders from South-east Asia
summary: Boeing projects 3,750 new planes valued at $550 billion for South-east Asia over the next 20 years, representing 10% of global demand. Despite concerns of a slowdown in the aviation industry, Boeing sees no deferrals on plane deliveries. Senior vice-president Dinesh Keskar attributes this to airlines' increasing efficiency in ordering planes, with some opting for the sale and leaseback option. The region's 6.5% annual traffic growth rate falls behind other markets, but South-east Asia remains an important market for Boeing.

site_title: SingPost remains committed to providing quality service
summary: SingPost, Singapore's postal service, remains committed to providing quality service despite concerns about the complexity of mailing a letter. Since 1993, the company has used non-monetary indicators to label stamps, ensuring older stamps remain valid with changing postal rates. This practice aligns with international best practices and prioritizes customer convenience.

site_title: January new-home sales slow amid dearth of property launches
summary: Singapore's private home market saw a 16% drop in new-home sales in January, with 322 units sold, compared to 384 in December and 378 last year. Only 146 units were launched, the lowest since December 2014. Developers "drip-fed" unsold units into the market, and consultants expect the sluggish market to continue, citing prolonged effects of property cooling measures, economic slowdown, and market volatility. Experts warn that the current market conditions may hinder a "soft landing" for the private home market in 2016.

images.alt_text: Developers sold 322 private residential homes in January, a 16 per cent drop from the 384 sold in December, and a 14 per cent drop from a year ago.

site_title: The lure of white sand beaches, turquoise lagoons
summary: Singapore-based groups have acquired several resorts in the Maldives, shrugging off concerns about global warming and rising sea levels. JLL Hotels & Hospitality Group has launched an expression of interest (EOI) for the foreclosure sale of the Maavelavaru Island Resort, a 114-villa resort in the Noonu Atoll. The resort was developed with over $100 million investment but stalled in 2011. Singapore groups, such as Hotel Properties and CDL Hospitality Trusts, own the most number of resorts in the Maldives, with many buyers drawn to the country's investor-friendly policies and high average daily room rates.

site_title: Bad loans at China banks hit decade high as economy slows
summary: China's commercial banks have seen a 51% rise in non-performing loans to 1.27 trillion yuan in December, the highest level since June 2006. The bad-loan ratio has climbed to 1.67%, while the industry's ability to absorb losses has weakened. This slowdown in the economy has put pressure on policymakers, with GDP growth expected to slow further.

site_title: China's January trade figures continue shrinking
summary: China's trade figures for January showed a contraction, with exports falling 11.2% and imports dropping 18.8% in dollar terms. Despite a larger-than-expected trade surplus, analysts attribute the decline to weak external demand, not exchange rate changes. The country's economy continues to stall, with a 6.9% growth rate last year, and policymakers face pressure to address capital flight and economic uncertainties. The central bank may gain some leeway in managing capital outflows, but economists expect the RMB to continue to fall in the short term.

site_title: Teenagers migrate to online messaging apps to dodge parents' prying
summary: Teenagers are increasingly using online messaging apps such as Kik, Line, WhatsApp, and others to maintain private social lives, avoiding parental monitoring. These apps, often used anonymously, have become popular among teens, with 40% of users identified in a survey. This shift is seen as a way for teenagers to maintain their digital independence and evade parental controls.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. Stocks in Europe and the US declined, with banks and healthcare companies affected by market concerns. The US stock market edged down from records amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and similar operating losses for the second half of the year. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained an employee of Trafigura in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: UBS rates bankers' behaviour in performance review revamp: sources
summary: Swiss bank UBS has introduced a new performance review format, scoring employees on their behavior, with integrity and collaboration being key criteria. The behavior component now accounts for 30% of reviews and can affect year-end bonuses. This change comes after UBS has faced several scandals, including a rogue trading scandal in 2011 and billions of dollars in settlements for manipulation and tax evasion. The review format aims to promote a more ethical and team-oriented work environment.

site_title: Discretionary spending wanes in December
summary: Singapore's retail sales grew 2.9% year-on-year in December, driven by a 62.5% increase in car sales, but excluding cars, sales would have dropped 3.6%. Discretionary spending waned due to weak equity values, online shopping, and job security concerns. The telecommunications and food segments posted significant declines, with a 26.4% drop in telecommunications sales and a 10% decline in food sales, the first since 2008.

site_title: Australia finds liquid meth in bra inserts in A$1b bust
summary: Australian police have seized over A$1 billion in crystal methamphetamine, the largest liquid methamphetamine seizure in Australian history. Three Hong Kongers and a Chinese national were arrested during the operation, which also involved gel bra inserts concealing the substance. Justice Minister Michael Keenan described it as the largest seizure of liquid methamphetamine in Australian history.

images.alt_text: Australian police have seized more than A$1 billion (S$1 billion) in crystal methamphetamine, or ice, some concealed in gel bra inserts in one of the country's biggest drug busts, authorities said on Monday.

site_title: HomeAway takes on Airbnb in new advertising campaign
summary: HomeAway launches a new advertising campaign, "It's Your Vacation, Why Share It?", targeting the online home-rental service Airbnb, without directly mentioning its competitor. The campaign depicts awkward, gross, or annoying situations that can occur in shared-lodging arrangements. The ads aim to highlight the difference between HomeAway and Airbnb, positioning HomeAway as a more private and exclusive option. The campaign is part of HomeAway's efforts to elevate consumer awareness and grow its market share in the private rental segment, which is rapidly growing.

site_title: EU regulators to examine lawmakers' report on IKEA taxes
summary: EU regulators will examine a report accusing IKEA of avoiding 1 billion euros in taxes over six years through tax schemes in Luxembourg, Belgium, and the Netherlands. IKEA claims it paid an effective corporate income tax rate of 19% in 2015. The European Commission will study the report and its findings, while the Netherlands and Luxembourg have challenged the Commission's decision. Hearings are likely at the end of the year, with judges expected to rule next year.

site_title: ECB chief says bank is ready to act in March if needed
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) President Mario Draghi said the bank is ready to ease policy in March if needed to address low inflation and financial market turmoil. Draghi stated that the ECB will review its policies on March 10 and may recalibrate them if necessary. The bank's recent easing efforts have been partially reversed due to market volatility, and Draghi emphasized the need for supportive fiscal policies from governments to boost economies. Markets now expect at least two rate cuts, but analysts are more cautious.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank is ready to ease policy in March if the recent financial market turmoil or the long-term impact of low energy prices threatens to keep inflation persistently low, its president Mario Draghi said on Monday.

site_title: Cosco Corp battered by Q4 loss of S$484m
summary: Cosco Corp, a Singapore-listed Chinese shipbuilder, reported a massive S$484 million loss for its fourth quarter, driven by allowances for impairment and write-offs on offshore-related orders. The company's full-year losses reached S$570 million, with revenue falling 21% to S$725.5 million due to lower contributions from marine engineering and shipbuilding. Cosco's solvency metrics deteriorated as more debt was incurred to finance shipyard operations. The company's order book stood at US$8 billion at end-2015, but margins continue to face "severe downward pressure."

images.alt_text: Mainboard-listed Chinese shipbuilder Cosco Corporation (Singapore) unveiled a massive S$484 million loss for its fourth quarter, dragging full-year losses to S$570 million.

site_title: Google "Project Loon" balloon enters Sri Lanka for Internet tests
summary: Google's "Project Loon" balloon-powered high-speed Internet service began its first tests in Sri Lanka, with one balloon entering the country's airspace. The balloon was launched from South America and is currently over southern Sri Lanka. The joint venture, which includes a 25% stake for the Sri Lankan government, aims to deliver cheaper data rates and improve internet coverage. The project will use helium-filled balloons twice as high as commercial airliners, with a lifespan of 180 days and recyclable materials. This marks Sri Lanka's first foray into balloon-powered internet.

site_title: Asia-Pacific corporations have biggest capacity for M&A: KPMG
summary: Asia-Pacific corporations have the greatest capacity for mergers and acquisitions (M&As), according to a KPMG study. The region's ability to fund M&A growth is expected to rise by 13% over the next 12 months, driven by companies paying down debt and bolstering cash reserves. This bodes well for M&As overall, with the world's largest businesses predicted to show more interest in transactions. Asia-Pacific corporations have an M&A capacity of 19%, followed closely by the African and Middle Eastern regions, with Singapore-based companies expected to see a 15% increase in M&A funding capacity.

site_title: Toyota-led profit gains at risk as carmakers face strong yen
summary: Japanese carmakers, led by Toyota, may face a slowdown in profit gains due to a strong yen. Analysts estimate a 5.5% increase in earnings to 4.55 trillion yen (S$56 billion) for the fiscal year 2017, marking the slowest pace of growth in five years. This is attributed to the weaker yen, which has reduced profit margins for the industry.

site_title: Philippines to put up for sale seized Marcos property, jewelry
summary: The Philippine government plans to sell seized assets of former dictator Ferdinand Marcos and his family, including jewelry and real estate, to raise at least $17.7 million. The assets, valued at $10 billion, were confiscated after Marcos' ouster in 1986. The sale will include 300 pieces of jewelry, including a 25-carat pink diamond, and two real estate properties. Proceeds from the sale will go to the Bureau of Treasury and Philippine Commission on Good Government. The move comes after Imelda Marcos, the late dictator's widow, contested a previous attempt to auction the jewelry in 2005.

site_title: Thailand expects review by UN aviation body to be delayed
summary: Thailand's review by the UN's International Civil Aviation Authority (ICAO) is expected to be delayed until early 2017 due to a lack of qualified auditors. The country's new civil aviation authority, CAAT, needs more time to complete training for its auditors. This comes after the US FAA downgraded Thailand's safety ratings in December and ICAO downgraded the country in June 2015. CAAT has completed new guidelines for safety inspections, but more time is required to meet the November deadline for re-certifying 41 Thai-registered airlines.

site_title: Mobius says China's irrational stock market is creating bargains
summary: Mark Mobius, a money manager, views China's stock market as an opportunity to buy bargains amid a 49% decline in the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index. Mobius attributes the market's irrational behavior to government intervention and speculation. Despite a 4.8% rally on Monday, Mobius notes that it's too early to predict a broader market rebound, and he recommends focusing on individual companies' fundamentals. China's economic slowdown and heavy-handed state intervention have led to outflows and volatility, but fundamentals remain positive.

site_title: Acma, Mermaid Maritime, Regal International warn of FY15 net losses
summary: Three companies, Acma Ltd, Mermaid Maritime, and Regal International Group Ltd, have warned of expected net losses for FY15 due to impairment provisions. Acma expects a net loss due to an impairment provision on its Neftech investment, Mermaid Maritime due to non-cash provisions for assets and investments, and Regal International Group Ltd due to impairment of goodwill and decreased revenue from its property business. These losses are attributed to various factors including weaker market demand and decreased projects completed. The companies expect to report losses for the full year ended Dec 31, 2015.

site_title: India's exports shrink in January; RBI against devaluation
summary: India's exports declined 13.6% in January for the 14th consecutive month, mainly due to weak demand from Europe. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has resisted pressure to devalue the currency to boost exports. The central bank's Governor Raghuram Rajan stated that sustained devaluation is not a good strategy. The trade deficit narrowed to $7.64 billion in January, mainly due to soft demand for imported crude oil and falling commodity prices. India's economy is expected to grow 7.6% in the 2015/16 financial year, but exports are unlikely to improve in the near future.

site_title: Opec members increasingly keen to end oil glut: Nigeria oil minister
summary: OPEC members are increasingly inclined to address the global oil price rout, with Nigeria's oil minister Emmanuel Ibe Kachiwku stating a growing consensus on ending the oil glut. The price crash has crippled economies reliant on oil sales, and OPEC's next regular meeting is in June, with an emergency meeting not being considered feasible due to uncertainty. The International Energy Agency warns of potential oversupply of 1.5 million barrels per day, and Venezuela's oil minister has proposed a production freeze to address the issue.

site_title: HSBC hints could shift to Paris in case of Brexit
summary: HSBC's chairman Douglas Flint hinted that the lender could shift its operations to Paris if Britain votes to leave the European Union. Flint stated that HSBC has a major bank in France, allowing the company to move activity and people between London and Paris if necessary. This move would enable HSBC to maintain its European operations despite potential Brexit restrictions.

site_title: China dampens gold's rally as peak demand period wraps up
summary: China's investors sold gold, pushing prices down more than 2% on Monday, amid concerns that the rally won't last. The metal has risen nearly 14% since 2016, but Chinese consumers typically buy gold in jewelry form, not bullion, and may not support prices further. Dealers in Asia said Chinese buyers are offering gold to book profits, with prices about $60 an ounce higher than before their holiday. Demand typically slows after the Lunar New Year holiday, which saw a 22% increase in gold and silver jewelry sales.

site_title: Update: Sembcorp Marine makes S$609m impairment for rigs, sinks into the red for FY15
summary: Sembcorp Marine reported a net loss of S$290 million for FY15 due to a S$609m impairment for rigs, including S$329m for Sete Brasil drillship projects. Revenue slipped 15% to S$4.97 billion, mainly due to lower revenue recognition from rig building projects. The company has secured S$3.2 billion in new orders, and its net order book backlog stands at S$10.4 billion. The board recommended a final ordinary one-tier tax exempt dividend of 2 cents per share, down from 13 cents previously.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng drops spin-off plan
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation has dropped plans to spin off its construction subsidiaries, citing market conditions and other factors. The company made the decision after careful consideration.

site_title: SingPost raises stake in Shenzhen 4PX by 17.9% for S$35m
summary: SingPost raised its stake in Shenzhen 4PX by 17.9% for S$35 million, increasing its equity interest from 18% to 35.91%. The move is part of SingPost's strategy to strengthen its integrated ecommerce logistics solutions. 4PX, a Chinese ecommerce cross-border solutions provider, serves over 20,000 merchants globally and offers logistics, software, and consulting services. The investment aims to leverage on China's rapid ecommerce growth.

site_title: Long-awaited Charlie Chaplin museum to open in April
summary: A museum dedicated to Charlie Chaplin will open on April 17 at his former Swiss home, after over 15 years of planning. The museum, Chaplin's World, will feature a replica of a Hollywood studio, exhibits on Chaplin's life and work, and a mock-up of his London home. The project has faced numerous delays, including a lawsuit and building permit issues. The museum is being developed by French operator Grevin, which also runs waxwork museums in Paris, Montreal, Seoul, and Prague. The opening coincides with what would have been Chaplin's 127th birthday.

site_title: Cosco (S) unveils massive S$484m Q4 loss
summary: Cosco Corporation (Singapore) reported a Q4 loss of S$484 million, with full-year losses at S$570 million, due to inventory write-downs and allowances for impairment. Q4 revenue fell 21% to S$725.5 million, while full-year revenue declined 17% to S$3.5 billion.

site_title: Miyoshi plans a listing transfer to Catalist
summary: MIYOSHI Limited plans to transfer its listing from the mainboard of the Singapore Exchange to the Catalist Board due to its trading price being below the 20 cents minimum requirement. The group aims to raise its share price through corporate actions such as share consolidation and restructuring. The proposed transfer is subject to shareholder and SGX approval.

site_title: Tat Hong unit surrenders Gul Crescent lease to JTC for S$21 million
summary: Tat Hong Holdings' wholly-owned unit, Tat Hong HeavyEquipment, has surrendered the lease of 11 Gul Crescent to JTC Corporation for S$21 million. The property had a net book value of S$11.4 million, resulting in a pre-tax gain of around S$9.5 million for Tat Hong Holdings. The decision was made due to the property becoming "redundant".

site_title: SIA Engineering to invest up to S$50m in innovation, technology adoption projects
summary: SIA Engineering Company Limited (SIAEC) plans to invest up to S$50 million in innovation and technology adoption projects over the next few years, focusing on additive manufacturing, robotics, and data analytics to enhance airline customers' fleet operating efficiencies and reliability. The company aims to develop innovative solutions to improve productivity and process improvements in its business, with the support of the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB). CEO Png Kim Chiang emphasized the need to invest in emerging technologies to remain competitive in the MRO industry.

site_title: Man Utd to name Old Trafford stand after Bobby Charlton
summary: Manchester United is set to name the South Stand at Old Trafford after legendary player Bobby Charlton, who made 758 appearances for the club and scored 249 goals. Charlton, a 78-year-old United director, joined the club as an apprentice in 1953 and previously held the record for most goals scored for England, until Wayne Rooney broke it in 2015. The unveiling will take place during a Premier League game against Everton on April 2.

site_title: Asian carriers more cautious with orders: Boeing
summary: Asian carriers, including those in Southeast Asia, have become more cautious in placing orders for new aircraft due to thinner profits and a global economic downturn. Boeing's Dinesh Keskar stated that the time for big-ticket orders may be over, replaced by smaller buys with shorter replacement cycles. Despite this, Boeing's backlog is over 5,000 airplanes, and major airlines in the region are doing well, with some even requesting early deliveries. The International Air Transport Association's Tony Tyler noted that Asia-Pacific carriers are expected to generate $6.6 billion in profit this year, but face challenges from low fuel costs and competition from Gulf carriers.

site_title: Shell pursues transition plan after sealing US$53b BG deal
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has sealed a $53 billion acquisition of British rival BG Group to form the world's top liquefied natural gas company. The deal, which marks a significant shift in Shell's focus, aims to transform the company into a more specialized group. CEO Ben van Beurden stated that the merger will result in a simpler, leaner, and more competitive company, focusing on deepwater oil production and LNG. The deal's success will define van Beurden's legacy as he seeks to transform Shell during a time of slumping oil prices.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: New home sales by developers dropped 16% in January, with 322 units sold, a decline from December's 384 units and a year-ago 14% drop. Sembcorp Marine made a $609m impairment for rigs, leading to a loss for FY15. Business confidence in Singapore rebounded from a four-year low, but remains pessimistic. Retail sales rose 2.9% in December, driven by motor vehicle sales. Noble Group's LNG traders left for Glencore, and Technics Oil & Gas resumed trading after failing to sell assets.

site_title: Ringgit rises from one-week low as stocks rally boosts sentiment
summary: Malaysia's ringgit strengthened 1% to 4.1298 a dollar, ending a two-day loss, as emerging-market equities rebounded and risk appetite improved. The FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index rose 0.4% on speculation that a selloff was overdone. A stronger Chinese yuan, which gained the most since 2005, is expected to benefit exporters who export to China. However, the sustained impact of a bear market and declining Brent crude prices remains uncertain.

site_title: Wing Tai sets up fund management unit
summary: Wing Tai Holdings Limited has established a new fund management unit, WT Fund Management Pte Ltd, to explore investment opportunities in the Asia-Pacific region. The unit, led by real estate veteran Chua Choy Soon, will focus on investments for institutional investors with a medium to long-term horizon. Wing Tai will commit equity alongside institutional investors, leveraging its 50-year presence in the region for market insights and networks. This move aims to provide a credible investment partner for Asian investors.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.22 points to close at 1,649.96, with 1.54 billion lots valued at RM1.54 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 497-297. The market's upward trend followed the global trend, despite US-EU trade talks being a focus.

site_title: HSBC CEO says Asia turmoil is slowing pace of hiring in China
summary: HSBC CEO Stuart Gulliver stated that Asia turmoil, particularly China's economic slowdown, may slow the pace of hiring in China's Pearl River Delta. Despite this, HSBC plans to add 4,000 jobs in the region over the coming years, but at a "slightly slower" pace. Gulliver remains optimistic about Asia's growth outlook, citing its potential for faster GDP growth over the next 10 years, but acknowledges the uncertainty and challenges posed by the current market conditions.

images.alt_text: HSBC Holdings Plc may slow the pace of hiring in China's Pearl River Delta amid a market rout and cooling growth in the world's second-largest economy, Chief Executive Officer Stuart Gulliver said.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine posts S$535 mln quarterly loss as orders shrink
summary: Sembcorp Marine Ltd posted a quarterly loss of S$535.2 million due to inventories write-downs and provision for foreseeable losses on delayed rig-building projects. The company's net order book backlog as of Dec 31, 2015, was S$10.4 billion. This marks a significant decline in the company's financial performance, highlighting the challenges faced by the rig-building industry.

site_title: Oil extends rally on prospects Opec could act to counter low prices
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, extending a rally triggered by speculation that Opec might agree to cut production to reduce a supply glut. Brent crude futures rose 33 cents to $33.69 a barrel, while US futures rose 35 cents to $29.79 a barrel. Analysts say Opec's willingness to cooperate on an output cut, combined with Russia's desire for improved relations with Iran and Saudi Arabia, may prompt the cartel to take action. However, many remain skeptical about the likelihood of a deal, citing concerns it would only solve the problem in the short term.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares jump over 3% on global market bounce
summary: Hong Kong stocks jumped 3.3% on Monday, their best performance in five months, driven by a surge in Japanese shares and gains in US and European markets. The benchmark Hang Seng index rose to 18,918.14 points, while the China Enterprises Index rallied 4.8%. Energy and financial shares were among the biggest gainers, with HSBC surging 4.3% after deciding to keep its headquarters in Britain. The gains followed a global equity sell-off last week and unexpected light losses in mainland China stock markets after the Lunar New Year holiday.

site_title: Thai finmin says restriction on foreign bond issues not a capital control
summary: Thailand's finance minister Apisak Tantivorawong clarified that the country's restriction on foreign bond issuers taking funds out of the country is not a capital control. The restriction applies to foreign entities issuing baht bonds in Thailand, requiring them to keep proceeds in local currency for domestic use. This aims to prevent foreign issuers from profiting from low Thai interest rates and arbitraging the difference. The rule applies to four foreign entities, and analysts expect neighboring countries to be exempt from the rule due to the Thai government's encouragement.

site_title: Japan economy shrinks during Q4 in body blow for 'Abenomics'
summary: Japan's economy contracted 0.4% in Q4 2015, its second quarterly decline, as weak demand for big-ticket items and a resurgent yen threatened to dent companies' profits. The contraction, or 1.4% annualized drop, has raised concerns about Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" growth plan, which aims to boost the economy through monetary easing and fiscal stimulus. Analysts say the data shows Japan's economy remains too dependent on export-led growth, which has suffered due to China's slowdown and global economic concerns.

site_title: Japanese banks rush to cut deposit rates ahead of BOJ going negative
summary: Japanese banks are cutting deposit rates ahead of the Bank of Japan's introduction of negative interest rates, with Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp reducing its ordinary deposit rate to 0.001% per year. The move follows sharp falls in benchmark bond yields and is aimed at preserving liquidity. However, executives believe further cuts in loan interest rates are unlikely to boost loan demand, citing volatility in global markets and a surplus of funds among businesses and households.

site_title: Singapore shares close 2.7% up on Monday
summary: Singapore stocks rose 2.7% on Monday, driven by sentiments that equities have been oversold. The Straits Times Index increased 67.95 points to 2,607.9, with blue chips like Noble Group, Singtel, and Technics Oil & Gas leading the gains. Gainers outnumbered losers 234 to 136, indicating a strong market trend. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and amid global market uncertainty, with US-EU trade talks and Trump's tariff threats in focus.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares bounce on miners and takeover rally
summary: Australian shares rose 1.64% on Monday, driven by a Wall Street bounce and relief for resource companies. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 4843.50, while New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index surged 1.7% to 6034.28. The gains followed last week's heavy losses.

site_title: Philippines cuts 2016 exports, import growth target
summary: The Philippines lowered its 2016 export growth target to 5% from 6%, while cutting its import growth target to 10% from 12%. The government still expects a 7-8% GDP growth this year and 7-8% through 2019. A budget of 3.35 trillion pesos ($70.6 billion) is planned for 2017, 12% higher than this year's record high budget. The peso is expected to remain stable at 45-48 pesos to the dollar from 2016 to 2019.

site_title: China guides yuan higher after central bank comments
summary: China's central bank fixed the yuan at 6.5118 to US$1, a 0.30% increase from the previous fix, marking the biggest jump in over three months. PBOC head Zhou Xiaochuan attributed the move to foreign speculators and said there's no reason for the yuan to fall further. This move aims to guide the yuan higher and support China's economic growth, which slowed to 6.9% in 2015. Despite this, analysts predict further depreciation, with some forecasting a weakening to 6.8 to US$1 by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: China's central bank on Monday fixed the value of the yuan higher by the biggest margin for more than three months after its chief Zhou Xiaochuan said there was no reason the unit should fall further.

site_title: US dollar bounces back in face of hedge fund angst as China returns
summary: The US dollar rebounded against the yen and euro after China strengthened its yuan, easing global financial turmoil. Retail sales in the US rose more than forecast, boosting risk sentiment and reducing bets on a Federal Reserve interest rate hike. Hedge funds cut their dollar bets to the lowest since June, and the Aussie and Kiwi dollars surged. China's trade data showed a trade surplus, but investors remained skeptical about the Fed's decision, citing a 30% probability of a rate hike in 2016.

images.alt_text: The US dollar held gains after China strengthened the yuan as the nation returned from week-long holidays, helping to ease global financial turmoil that had spurred investors to bet the Federal Reserve will delay raising US interest rates.

site_title: ECB in talks with Italy over buying bundles of bad loans: Treasury
summary: The European Central Bank is in talks with Italy's government about buying bundles of bad loans as collateral in exchange for cash, as part of its asset-purchase program. This move aims to help Italian banks offload their 200 billion euros of soured credit, but may fuel concerns about the ECB taking on too much risk. The ECB may buy these securities as part of its 1.5 trillion euros program or accept them as collateral in return for cash.

site_title: Motor vehicles help December retail sales rise 2.9%
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 2.9% in December 2015, driven by a 62.5% year-on-year growth in motor vehicle sales, which lifted the sector from a 3.6% decline. Food and beverages sales declined 5.7%, while telecommunications apparatus and computers saw a 26.4% drop. On a seasonally adjusted basis, retail sales declined 2.1% from November. Total retail sales reached S$4.1 billion, up from S$4 billion in the same period last year.

site_title: Boeing sees new aircraft demand worth US$550b in SE Asia in 20 years
summary: Southeast Asia needs 3,750 new aircraft worth US$550 billion over the next 20 years, driven mainly by low-cost carriers and growing markets in Indonesia, Myanmar, and Vietnam, according to Boeing. Single-aisle aircraft like the Boeing 737 and Airbus A320 will account for 76% of the demand, led by the growth of these emerging markets.

site_title: China: Stocks end down, pare losses on stronger yuan
summary: China stocks ended lower but recovered from initial losses, bolstered by a stronger yuan and a surge in Japanese equities. Investors took advantage of the weak start to trading to hunt for bargains after a global sell-off. Disappointing Chinese trade data early in the session was partially offset by the stronger yuan, easing fears of depreciation.

site_title: Malaysia faces spike in risks as central bank chief retires, gas markets tank
summary: Malaysia faces heightened economic risks as its central bank chief, Zeti Akhtar Aziz, retires in April, coinciding with a potential slump in liquefied natural gas (LNG) exports due to a 40% drop in crude prices.
