summary: There is no relevant article to summarize. The provided text appears to be a collection of news article titles, and none of the titles match the content of the article provided.

site_title: Oil prices soar on report that UAE offers talks on output cuts
summary: Oil prices surged on Friday, with US crude rebounding from a 2003 low, after reports that the UAE offered talks on output cuts to ease global oversupply. US West Texas Intermediate rose 12.3% to $29.44 a barrel, while Brent crude increased 11% to $33.36 a barrel. The news sparked a market turnaround, despite skepticism from analysts, who point to a series of rumors and reports of reduced drilling activity. A potential decrease in US production may prompt Opec members to cut output, supporting price increases.

site_title: Freeport cut to junk by S&P amid 'uncertainties' for commodities
summary: Standard & Poor's cut the credit rating of Freeport-McMoRan Inc to junk (BB) due to uncertainties in commodity markets and risks in metals and mining. The rating was lowered from BBB- amid tumbling copper prices, which the agency expects to reach $2.10 a pound in 2016, down 13% from current levels. The move follows Moody's Investors Service's similar downgrade in January. Freeport's shares have plummeted 72% over the past year.

site_title: Philippines' San Miguel says no longer selling US$500m banking stake
summary: Philippine conglomerate San Miguel Corp has decided not to sell its $500 million stake in unlisted bank Bank of Commerce, instead opting to invest up to $176 million and pursue growth in the sector. The company had been looking to exit banking for two years to expand in oil and gas, but failed to find a buyer. San Miguel plans to inject funds into the bank and apply for a universal banking license to offer investment banking services.

site_title: BoJ's Nakaso defends negative rates, says not meant to pinch banks
summary: The Bank of Japan's deputy governor, Hiroshi Nakaso, defended the recent negative interest rate policy, stating it was designed to avoid hurting bank profits. Despite a 13% drop in the MSCI International World Banks index since the policy's implementation, Nakaso said the recent decline in bank shares is "overdone." He emphasized the three-tiered system is carefully designed to mitigate the impact on banks while stimulating financial markets. The BOJ can potentially lower rates further, but Nakaso plans to monitor its effects on the economy.

site_title: Engineering needs to be a more attractive career choice: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need to make engineering a more attractive career choice during his visit to Silicon Valley. He met with Google executives and discussed Singapore's Smart Nation ideas, as well as the US's continued engagement of Asia. Lee also reaffirmed the strong economic ties between Singapore and California, and highlighted the importance of ratifying the Trans-Pacific Partnership free trade deal. His visit comes as the US and Singapore are among the 12 nations of the TPP.

site_title: Europe: Stocks bounce higher at end of brutal week
summary: European stocks rebounded on Friday, regaining some lost ground after a brutal week, driven by higher oil prices, solid German economic growth, and rising US retail sales. London jumped 3%, Frankfurt and Paris gained 2%, and Wall Street equities also pushed higher. Despite the gains, European markets remain down heavily from the beginning of the year, with Milan down 23%, Frankfurt down 16%, Paris down 14%, and London down 8%. Analysts attributed the rebound to bargain-hunting and relief over Rolls-Royce's decision to maintain its shareholder dividend.

site_title: Swee Hong swings to net loss of S$5.51m as expenses swell
summary: Swee Hong, a civil engineering group, reported a net loss of S$5.51 million for the second quarter of 2016, despite an 11% increase in revenue to S$9.8 million. Revenue from its civil engineering segment grew 72% due to progress on ongoing projects, while tunnelling revenue decreased 84%. Administrative and finance expenses surged 178% and 171%, respectively. The loss per share was 1.49 Singapore cents, compared to an earnings per share of 0.06 cents in the same quarter last year. No dividend was declared.

site_title: Dating apps still look for money match
summary: Investors in Singapore are divided on whether to invest in the mobile dating industry, despite its growing US$1 billion-a-year market in Asia. Despite the sector's growth, venture capitalists have been cautious, with some citing the need for a disruptor and a better revenue model. Paktor and LunchClick, two Singapore-based dating apps, have reported success with their freemium and premium models, respectively. However, investors are waiting for the right timing to invest, with some citing the need for the industry to become more mainstream in Singapore.

site_title: The world, their oyster
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Four women in Singapore are making a name for themselves in their respective fields. Bernie Quah, an interior design graduate, turned graphic recording into a successful business, marrying her drawing skills with information synthesis. Harpreet Bedi, a hotel manager, founded a non-profit group Belris to promote research on reproductive ethics in Singapore. Patty Lee, a Canadian-born MBA graduate, launched a global fitness concierge service, WorldTrainer, to help professionals maintain their fitness regimens while traveling. Jennifer Li, a business graduate, opened Camellia-Yingcha, a private members club combining business networking with cultural learning and relaxation.

site_title: ComfortDelGro posts 6.5% increase in full-year profit
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singapore-based transport operator, reported a 6.5% increase in full-year net profit to S$301.9 million, driven by growth in rail and car rental businesses. Revenue grew 1.5% to S$4.11 billion, despite foreign currency volatility. The company expects revenue growth in its rail businesses and a fare reduction in Singapore to negatively impact bus revenue. A one-tier final dividend of five Singapore cents is proposed for 2015.

images.alt_text: GOOD SHOWING: ComfortDelGro's revenue growth came from better performances in the bus, taxi, rail, and car rental and leasing businesses, with rail and car rental seeing the most growth.

site_title: High Court dismisses Stanley Tan's S$34m claim against UBS
summary: The High Court in Singapore dismissed Stanley Tan's S$34 million lawsuit against UBS, ruling that the bank acted on his instructions when it terminated his accumulators in 2008. Tan had sought damages for losses incurred during the financial crisis, but the court found that he had confirmed his entire case related to the unwinding of the accumulators, reducing the damages to nearly S$34 million. The judge ruled that Tan had acknowledged his liquidity issues and needed to address his margin shortfalls, making it sensible for him to unwind his investments.

images.alt_text: MR TAN: He suffered no loss even if UBS had breached an obligation in relation to the account, says judge

site_title: DBS, OCBC, Julius Baer said to have made bids for Barclays's Asia wealth unit
summary: DBS Group Holdings, Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation, and Julius Baer have submitted non-binding bids for Barclays' Asian private wealth business valued at around $600 million. The sale is part of Barclays' restructuring drive under new CEO Jes Staley, amid pressure to cut costs in Europe. Barclays managed $36 billion in private banking assets in Asia, ranking 14th. The bids come as several European banks reassess their Asian strategy due to regional growth slowdown and fierce competition. The companies involved declined to comment on the bids.

site_title: Jho Low selling prized art pieces at a loss
summary: Malaysian financier Jho Low sold three art pieces, including works by Claude Monet, Pablo Picasso, and Jean-Michel Basquiat, for approximately US$54 million. The artworks were pledged as collateral for a loan with Sotheby's, resulting in unusually steep losses on at least two of the pieces. The sales have drawn attention to Low's lavish lifestyle and connections to the Malaysian government.

site_title: Tat Hong's Q3 hit by across-the-board weakness
summary: Tat Hong Holdings reported a net loss of S$6.7 million in its fiscal third quarter due to weak demand in South-east Asia and Australia. This contrasts with a profit of S$4.5 million in the same period last year. The company's revenue declined across various markets. The loss was attributed to decreased sales and operational costs.

site_title: Oil rebounds from lowest close in 12 years
summary: Oil futures rose as much as 5.9% in New York after Opec signaled a willingness to engage with other producers, rebounding from its lowest level in over 12 years. The rebound came as the equities rout eased and the Stoxx Europe 600 Index rallied from its lowest close since September 2013. The CBOE Crude Oil Volatility Index climbed to its highest level in seven years, indicating increased market expectations of price swings.

site_title: Hang Seng Index closes at multi-week low
summary: The Hang Seng Index fell 1.2% to a three-and-a-half year low on Friday, closing at 18,319.58, amidst a global market slump. Investors are watching China's official yuan fixing and January export and import data for signs of a weakening currency. Worries over China's slowing economy and European bank health have fueled concerns, with the index losing 5% for the week. Analysts predict a volatile market until global bank shares stabilize and China's foreign-exchange-rate policy is clarified.

site_title: Taro Aso's comments stoke talk of yen intervention
summary: Finance Minister Taro Aso said the G-20 will "study policy cooperation" in Shanghai this month amid speculation of official intervention to stem the yen's dramatic rise. The yen traded between 111-112 to the US dollar, hitting a 15-month low. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 stock average plummeted 5% in early trade, and investment house Nomura suggested a 400-point drop for every yen rise. BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda rejected the idea that the central bank's recent move was causing market turmoil, and former "Mr Yen" Eisuke Sakakibara said Tokyo should not intervene, citing the lack of conditions for effective intervention.

site_title: Japan's economic roller coaster headed for another dip
summary: Japan's economy is expected to contract in the fourth quarter of 2015, with a 0.8% annualized decline, according to economists' median forecast. The economy has experienced a roller-coaster cycle of expansion and contraction since 2013, with seven quarters of growth and four quarters of contraction. The Bank of Japan's stimulus efforts have had mixed results, and investors have been misled by government data, leading to market volatility. Economists predict a 3% contraction in the fourth quarter, with the likelihood of recession increasing to the highest level since 2012.

site_title: Love App-tually
summary: Business Times publishes "Love App-tually," a lifestyle article, but no specific content is provided. BT also announces a Telegram channel for daily updates and weekend content. Additionally, the publication features articles on various topics, including Thevar 2.0's mod-Indian cuisine, NCSS's volunteer engagement, The Social Kitchen's new location, and CMC Markets' partnership with Sophia Women to promote financial literacy for women. The article also touches on the concept of corporate purpose, but no further details are given.

site_title: Asia's rich told to buy yen as BOJ's negative rates backfire
summary: Asia's wealthy investors are buying the yen due to its undervaluation against the US dollar. Credit Suisse and Stamford Management advise clients to invest in the yen, predicting it will strengthen to 110 and 115 against the euro and won, respectively, in the coming months. The Bank of Japan's negative interest rates have failed to curb the yen's advance, and investors see it as a haven in turbulent global markets. The yen has outperformed other currencies, with a 7% gain against the dollar this year, and is seen as a positive for Japanese assets and exports.

site_title: Buying the dip a distant thought as pessimism grips the market
summary: Global stocks continue to plummet, with Asian markets experiencing a fourth consecutive day of decline, as investors grow increasingly pessimistic about the economy. Central banks' ability to revive the world economy is seen as diminishing, with Japan's decision to charge lenders for deposits sparking concerns about bank profits and lending. The sell-off is fueled by fears of a global recession, with the MSCI Asia-Pacific Index dropping 2.9% to its lowest since 2012. Investors are seeking safety in bonds and the yen, which has strengthened against the dollar.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler hunkers down in Canada
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) has invested C$3.7 billion in Canada since September 2014, creating 1,200 jobs to develop and produce its next-generation minivan, the Pacifica. The Pacifica, a hybrid electric minivan, is in early production stages at FCA's plant in Windsor, Ontario. The investment brings total employment in Canada to over 11,000. FCA is concerned about the potential impact of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) on the Canadian auto industry, which is currently facing headwinds due to production shifts to lower-cost jurisdictions like Mexico.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Several Australian companies have reported financial losses for the latest quarter and half-year. AusGroup, Nam Cheong, and Raffles United Holdings warned of net losses due to declining revenue. In contrast, residential property developer Bukit Sembawang reported a net profit of S$24.3 million for its third quarter. Traditional Chinese medicine seller Eu Yan Sang International saw its net profit fall 75% to S$498,000 for the fiscal second quarter. Additionally, AusNet Services agreed to buy the Mortlake Terminal Station in Western Victoria for A$116.5 million.

site_title: New face of luxury
summary: The Lexus ES has undergone a facelift, featuring a sharper exterior with new LED headlamps and a chrome-trimmed grille, as well as a refreshed cabin with a new topaz brown interior and premium touches. The midsize sedan now boasts improved ride comfort, a spacious interior with 1,015 mm of rear legroom, and a sophisticated all-round MacPherson strut set-up. The ES Hybrid model, with a 2.5-litre petrol-electric engine, offers excellent fuel efficiency and instant torque, making it the epitome of luxury on the go.

site_title: US SEC probing Boeing's accounting: report
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is investigating Boeing's accounting practices for its 787 Dreamliner and 747 jumbo aircraft, focusing on the projection of long-term profitability for these planes. Boeing has used an unusual accounting method to defer production costs, which now totals over $30 billion for the 787 Dreamliner. The company faces potential charges of up to $9.7 billion if it fails to sell more of the 787 and 747 aircraft.

site_title: Latest home rental upticks seen as blips
summary: Rentals in Singapore showed a slight increase in December and January, with SRX Property's flash rental index rising 0.2% and 0.4% respectively. However, consultants do not consider this a sign of a reversal from the 10-month decline, citing that most transactions are driven by rental renewals rather than new demand. The market is expected to remain weak, with new private residential units set to be completed this year, and foreign manpower controls limiting rental demand.

site_title: Watch business stays downbeat
summary: Singapore's luxury watch market saw a decline in sales revenue and net profit, with flat sales at S$186.4 million and a 2% net profit drop in the third quarter. The market is expected to remain downbeat due to a soft economy and lower tourist spending. Swiss watch exports to Singapore increased 1% to S$30.7 billion in 2015, but the industry as a whole saw a 3.3% drop in global shipments. Analysts attribute the decline to increased competition from smartwatches and a pessimistic outlook from watch executives, with 41% of respondents expecting a worsening economic outlook.

site_title: To wear and to hold
summary: Gold prices continue to rise, making it a popular investment option for savvy shoppers. Despite volatility, gold jewellery offers a unique way to invest in the precious metal, allowing wearers to appreciate its value daily. Retailers like Degussa are meeting growing demand, with gold prices expected to reach US$1,400 an ounce this year. However, some consumers remain hesitant, citing concerns about the value of gold jewellery and the difficulty of reselling it. Experts emphasize the sentimental value of gold jewellery, which can hold its value over time and make for a stylish investment.

site_title: Felda to use unlisted unit in bid to buy Rajawali stake: sources
summary: Malaysian state-owned conglomerate Felda plans to acquire a 37% stake in Indonesian palm oil plantation firm PT Eagle High Plantations Tbk using an unlisted unit to avoid investor criticism. The deal, valued at around $480 million, is expected to be finalized next month, with Felda seeking to cut the price by up to 30%. The acquisition aims to ease debt woes for Indonesian tycoon Peter Sondakh, who has been hit by the commodities rout and a slide in the rupiah.

site_title: Americans seen blowing US$1.1b on sweets, mostly chocolate, on Feb 14
summary: Americans are expected to spend $1.1 billion on sweets, mostly chocolate, on Valentine's Day, a 2.6% increase from last year. About three-quarters of this amount will be chocolate, with US retail chocolate sales expected to drop 0.6% to 1.37 million tonnes. To counter rising cocoa costs, manufacturers are pushing premium chocolate, with sales of plain dark chocolate bars rising 35% to $618.9 million in 2015. The US ranks 19th in chocolate consumption, with an average person eating 4.3 kg per year.

site_title: Vicious struggles over family fortunes
summary: Billionaire media mogul Sumner Redstone's health and mental competence are in question, sparking a succession battle for control of National Amusements, a private business that owns Viacom and CBS. Redstone's 80% stake will pass to a trust with seven trustees, including his 20% stakeholder daughter Shari Redstone and CEO Philippe Dauman, after his death or declaration of incompetence. The trust's interests may conflict with Dauman's, who has a friendly board, potentially leading to a sale of the company.

site_title: Making 'heroes' core of innovation push
summary: Companies can boost sales and profits by focusing on "heroes" - top-selling products that contribute to the bulk of sales and profits. Executives should make heroes the core of their innovation strategy, innovating to keep them fit, turning them into "superheroes" by expanding usage and penetration, and giving birth to new heroes. By doing so, companies can increase sales, reduce costs, and maintain a competitive edge.

site_title: With prize in sight, Brexit camp risks dashing its dream
summary: The Brexit campaign is divided between two groups, Leave.EU and Vote Leave, with differing visions for Britain's future outside the EU. The groups are vying for control and funding, with a battle for leadership and unity at the top. Despite the infighting, local campaigners remain energized and engaged, with polls showing Britons roughly evenly split. The main dispute centers around immigration and the EU's social laws, with Vote Leave focusing on prosperity and Leave.EU emphasizing the need to reduce immigration and get rid of EU social laws.

site_title: Family ties
summary: The Renault Kadjar is a compact crossover with a unique character, differing from its sibling models. It features a 1.5-litre turbodiesel engine with good low-end torque and fuel efficiency. While it handles smoothly and confidently, its acceleration can be delayed and the engine can strain when shifting gears, especially at low speeds. The Kadjar boasts a spacious interior, dual-level boot, and premium features like a seven-speaker sound system. Available in two trim levels, the Kadjar is an interesting addition to the Renault family.

site_title: Koh to tee up at Championship M'sia
summary: SINGAPOAN professional Koh Deng Shan will compete in the Maybank Malaysia Championship at The Royal Selangor Golf Club. Other invited Asean professionals include Michael Tran from Vietnam, George Gandranata from Indonesia, and Zaw Zaw Latt from Myanmar. Elite European and Asian golfers such as Louis Oosthuizen, Martin Kaymer, and Thongchai Jaidee will also participate. The tournament, worth US$3 million, is one of six European Tour events in the Asian region and features a field of 156 players.

images.alt_text: KOH DENG SHAN: The 27-year-old finished in 104th position on the Asian Tour Order of Merit last year and is currently in 59th position

site_title: Still a man's world
summary: The annual Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie (SIHH) in Geneva saw men's watches dominating the event, despite pre-releases hinting at a focus on women's timepieces. New luxury watch models for women were showcased, but ultimately, men's watches took center stage, with brands like Van Cleef & Arpels generating significant buzz with their latest releases.

site_title: The Middle East should take a leaf from Asean's book
summary: The article suggests that the Middle East could learn from the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) model in promoting regional cooperation and economic development. The author, inspired by Asean's success, proposes a regional federation of neighboring states, including Israel, Egypt, Lebanon, Syria, Palestine, and Jordan, to focus on development rather than conflict. This would allow the region to tap into its collective talent, resources, and markets, and provide a more stable and prosperous future for its people. The author believes that if the region can overcome its current challenges and adopt a more collaborative approach, it could unlock its economic potential and achieve peace and prosperity.

site_title: Political mood sours as Myanmar's transition talks hit snag
summary: Myanmar's transition talks have hit a snag as negotiations over power division and legacy of junta rule have stalled, forcing a delay in the election of a new president to March 17. Aung San Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy (NLD) has pushed back the vote due to divisions with the military, who have put forward demands for key positions and sought to maintain control. The stalemate has soured the mood of goodwill that initially characterized the talks, and the NLD's appointment of ex-general Shwe Mann to a powerful advisory panel has fueled mistrust.

site_title: Taiwan city inspects developer's buildings after collapse
summary: A 6.4 magnitude earthquake struck Taiwan's city of Tainan, killing at least 63 people and trapping over 50 others in the collapsed Wei-guan Golden Dragon Building. The developer, Lin Ming-hui, and two architects have been taken into custody on suspicion of professional negligent homicide. The city is inspecting the remaining buildings linked to Lin's Wei-guan Construction, and residents are concerned about the safety of their homes.

images.alt_text: SHODDY CONSTRUCTION: Rescue personnel at the site of the Wei-guan Golden Dragon Building which collapsed following a 6.4-magnitude earthquake.

site_title: UOB raises S$1.16m for local charities
summary: UOB raised over S$1.16 million for local charities during its annual Chinese New Year dinner, exceeding its promised contribution of S$250,000. The funds will go to four charities supporting art, children, and education. UOB employees and clients participated in a cooking session at a soup kitchen, preparing 5,000 lunch boxes for underprivileged beneficiaries. The bank's outreach program aims to help the less fortunate, aligning with its corporate social responsibility focus on art, children, and education.

site_title: Construction, property development buoy Sim Lian's Q2 profit
summary: Sim Lian Group reported a 59% increase in second-quarter net profit to S$40.49 million, driven by strong revenue from property development and construction divisions. Revenue more than doubled to S$194.33 million, with the property development division jumping 184% and the construction division rising 95%. The company expects to achieve profitable operating results for FY2016 and remains committed to seeking strategic investment opportunities for growth.

site_title: Even gold bulls underestimate 2016 gain which now top most assets
summary: Gold prices have surged past three-quarters of peak forecasts, outperforming all commodities and many equity and bond markets. The metal has risen 16% this year, with a one-year high above $1,263 an ounce, despite falling for three straight years. Investors are seeking a haven as global equity markets tumbled and interest rate expectations were reined in. Even gold bulls underestimate the gain, with only eight of 31 members polled in a survey predicting a maximum price above $1,250.

site_title: MoneySmart.sg, OCBC offer home loan priced off fixed deposit rate
summary: OCBC and MoneySmart.sg announced a 15-day promotional home loan deal with a 1.63% three-year fixed deposit rate, the lowest in town for mortgages linked to a fixed deposit rate. The deal offers a 36-month fixed deposit mortgage rate of 0.65% per annum plus a spread of 0.98% per annum for the first three years, increasing to 1.5% per annum from the fourth year onwards.

site_title: Euro-area outlook threatened by global market turmoil
summary: The euro-area economy maintained a 0.3% expansion in the fourth quarter of 2015, driven by Germany's steady growth, but global market turmoil threatens the outlook. Despite a resilient German economy, the region faces challenges, including divergent growth rates across countries, and potential disinflationary pressures from abroad. The European Central Bank is considering additional stimulus measures to safeguard growth and inflation.

site_title: Indonesia swings into US$1.1b payments deficit in 2015
summary: Indonesia's balance of payments shifted to a US$1.1 billion deficit in 2015, down from a US$15.2 billion surplus in 2014, with the current account deficit narrowing to US$17.76 billion. Exports dropped 19.66% in the fourth quarter, contributing to the decline. Despite this, the current account deficit has been narrowing since 2012, and the rupiah has rallied by 2.45% against the US dollar, easing concerns about foreign capital and reserves. Bank Indonesia will continue to monitor global developments, particularly the economic slowdown in China and declining commodity prices.

site_title: MTV to resurrect its news division
summary: MTV is reviving its news division, hiring over 20 journalists to cover pop culture and politics. The move aims to prop up Viacom's declining stock price and advertising sales. New hires include senior national correspondent Jamil Smith and executive editor Alex Pappademas, who will oversee a podcast network. The network's audience ratings are down 10% this TV season, prompting the company to invest in news and pop-culture segments. Viacom hopes to compete with web publishers like BuzzFeed and Vice Media, which have earned valuations of $1 billion or more.

site_title: Airbnb accused of misleading public by purging NY listings
summary: Airbnb has been accused of misleading the public by removing over 1,000 listings from its New York City site in November before releasing data showing 95% of its hosts were complying with local regulations. An independent report, Inside Airbnb, claims the purge was a cynical attempt to garner good press. The company maintains that most hosts have only one active listing and are not representatives of the problem. The New York Attorney General's office says the removal of listings damaged trust in the company's business model, which relies on regulations changing in cities worldwide.

site_title: Core retail sales in solid January rebound
summary: US core retail sales rebounded 0.6% in January after a 0.3% decline in December, driven by increased household purchases of various goods. This follows a slowdown in consumer spending in the fourth quarter, largely due to weak export growth and inventory sales. Despite a cautious spending outlook due to global economic uncertainty and low oil prices, the strengthening labor market and rising wages are supporting consumer spending. Overall retail sales rose 0.2% in January, with gains in clothing, online retailers, and building materials offset by declines in service stations and sporting goods.

site_title: UK whisky makers voice their opposition against Brexit
summary: UK whisky makers oppose Brexit, citing concerns over hard-won market access and potential tariffs that could make exports more expensive. Scotch whisky is Britain's largest food and drink export, worth £4 billion annually, and its production would be affected by a UK exit from the EU. Whisky producers argue that a "Brexit" would jeopardise trade agreements with emerging markets and result in higher prices for consumers abroad. The Scotch Whisky Association and major whisky brands, including Diageo and Pernod Ricard, support the UK remaining in the EU.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% amid market uncertainty, driven by investors weighing tariffs, sanctions, and market outlook. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while European stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector concerns. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and similar operating loss in H2. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Yellen sticks to her guns as global market rout worsens
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen reaffirmed her expectation of gradual interest rate hikes in the US this year, despite a worsening global market rout. The Fed's economic projections suggest four rate hikes in 2016, but investors now doubt the forecasts. Economists are revising their calls for rate hikes, with nearly 68% predicting the next hike in June, down from 30% in January. Yellen acknowledged financial market concerns, including the impact of falling oil prices on US inflation, but said it's premature to make a judgment on the Fed's policy stance.

site_title: China's Baidu receives offer to buy its 80.5% Qiyi stake
summary: Baidu Inc, a Chinese internet search company, has received an offer from its CEO and Qiyi.com's CEO to buy its 80.5% stake in Qiyi, a video streaming website, for $2.8 billion. The transaction would give Qiyi a majority stake, ending Baidu's majority control. The buyers plan for Qiyi to remain a strategic partner, and Baidu has formed a special committee to evaluate the offer.

site_title: Singtel's Q3 net profit dips to S$954m on forex woes, investments
summary: Singtel's third-quarter net profit fell 1.7% to S$954 million due to adverse currency fluctuations and investments. Operating revenue rose 1.1% to S$4.47 billion, while earnings per share decreased 1.6%. The telco's regional associates, including Telkomsel and AIS, delivered strong revenue growth, while the enterprise segment saw steady performance. Despite higher depreciation charges, the company's Ebitda margin remained stable at 27.3%. Singtel's CEO, Chua Sock Koong, attributed the results to innovations and investments in core consumer and enterprise businesses.

site_title: India's Dec industrial output contracts 1.3%y/y
summary: India's industrial output contracted 1.3% year-over-year in December, according to government data. This was lower than the forecasted 0.1% decline. The November contraction was 3.2% year-over-year. The data contradicts economists' expectations.

site_title: Swiss banking lobby criticises proposed banking rules
summary: Switzerland's banking lobby has criticized proposed "too big to fail" regulations, arguing they give the country's financial watchdog FINMA too much discretion. The Swiss Bankers Association claims the new rules would result in a loss of legal certainty for systemically relevant institutions and should be developed in line with international standards. The regulations were introduced to protect the economy from a major banking collapse, with tough new capital requirements outlined for UBS and Credit Suisse. The SBA emphasizes the need for international competitiveness in the development of the new rules.

site_title: US import prices fall on petroleum slide, strong dollar
summary: US import prices fell 1.1% in January, marking a seventh consecutive decline, as petroleum costs dropped 13.4% and a strong dollar undercut prices for other goods. The decline in import prices, 6.2% from January 2015, suggests weak inflation and supports the Federal Reserve's 2% target. The weak inflation and global economic outlook may hinder interest rate hikes this year, and the Fed's recent rate hike in December may be reversed.

site_title: STI loses 3.2% in week on weakness in oil, Japanese and US stocks
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 3.2% in the week ending Feb 12, 2016, to 2,539.95, due to weakness in oil prices and concerns over Japanese and US stocks. Japan's interest rate cut to negative territory led to a yen strengthening, contrary to expectations, and a collapse in Japanese equities. European banks faced financial solvency worries, while China's reopening next week raised concerns on Wall Street. The decline was influenced by short-selling and short-covering, with Singtel and banks being major movers.

site_title: UK's Osborne says EU should move toward public tax disclosures
summary: UK Chancellor George Osborne called for the European Union to implement public country-by-country tax reports to combat tax dodging. The EU has proposed sharing tax reports, but Osborne believes it should go further. The UK will push for international adoption of the practice, aiming to stop companies from shifting profits between countries to minimize tax bills. This move is part of the EU's efforts to tighten oversight of sweetheart tax deals and curb exploitation of national laws.

site_title: US: Shares jump on solid US retail sales report
summary: US stocks surged in opening trade on Friday, driven by solid retail sales reports and strong German economic growth. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 115 points (0.73%) to 15,775.18, while the S&P 500 added 16.74 (0.92%) to 1,845.82. Retail sales in the US rose 0.2% in January, beating expectations, and the German economy grew 0.3% in the fourth quarter, supporting eurozone growth.

site_title: Lower expenditure helps SATS post stronger profit
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based ground handler, reported a 12.8% increase in net profit to S$60.6 million for the third quarter of 2016, driven by a 5.1% reduction in expenditure. Despite a 2.2% drop in revenue, the company's gateway services revenue increased 5.3% thanks to contributions from budget carrier Jetstar Asia. Operating profit rose 20.9% to S$61.8 million, with the company focusing on productivity improvements and expanding its geographic presence.

site_title: Consumer companies' outperformance no longer guaranteed by cheap oil
summary: Consumer companies are no longer guaranteed to outperform due to low oil prices, as households are using saved money for debt repayment, savings, or other expenses. Despite this, consumer staples stocks such as PepsiCo, Unilever, and L'Oreal reported better-than-expected revenue, with analysts citing rising consumer confidence and car sales. Companies need to innovate and execute to win over consumers, and valuations are reaching a point where single-digit revenue growth becomes harder to justify, but these companies offer income and defensive qualities.

site_title: Lenders need 'deep surgery': RBI's Rajan
summary: Reserve Bank of India Governor Raghuram Rajan has stated that Indian banks need to perform "deep surgery" to address bad loans and clean up their balance sheets by March next year. He emphasized the need for lenders to recognize and classify non-performing assets, which may require writing down existing loans. This step is crucial to increase transparency and make banks more stable, ultimately benefiting the economy. Rajan believes the short-term impact on profitability will be significant, but the long-term benefits will be substantial.

images.alt_text: MR RAJAN: 'Existing loans may have to be written down somewhat because of the changed circumstances since they were sanctioned.'

site_title: Currency players forced to pare US$ forecasts
summary: US currency forecasters are being forced to revise their predictions as market turmoil and central banks' actions reverse the dollar's rally. The chances of the US dollar strengthening beyond median year-end forecasts of US$1.06 per euro and 123 yen have fallen to less than 22% and 15% respectively. Central banks, including the Federal Reserve, have added stimulus to fend off slowing growth and inflation, while foreign exchange traders have dropped expectations of American economic outperformance leading to interest rate increases.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singtel's earnings were in line with expectations, with 9M FY2016 at 75.7% of forecast. CIMB Research maintains its earnings forecasts and sum of parts-based target price of S$4.50. Trendlines Group, an incubator for medical and agriculture technology startups, is initiated with a Buy rating and target price of S$0.28, due to its track record of raising funds and exiting investments profitably. The company trades at a 55% discount to its peers.

site_title: EMS Energy warns of FY15 loss
summary: EMS Energy expects to report a net loss for FY15 due to delayed projects, one-time fees, and lower share of associates' profits. Delays in project recognition and acquisition costs contributed to the loss. The company anticipates reporting its results by Feb 29.

site_title: Consumer sentiment in US fell in February to a four-month low
summary: US consumer sentiment fell to a four-month low in February, declining to 90.7 from 92 in January, as declining stock prices and weaker global conditions weighed on Americans' views of the economy. Despite this, households' long-term inflation expectations declined to the lowest in records since 1979, as they expect inflation to remain low. Retail sales rose 0.2% in January, while job growth and payrolls continued to underpin sentiment.

site_title: Swedish bank seen to be retreating from mortgage market
summary: Sweden's largest bank, SEB AB, has reduced its share of the country's mortgage market to 15.5% at the end of 2023, from 16.2% in 2014. The bank's mortgage sales have slowed, with growth at roughly half the pace of the market. The Riksbank has lowered its main rate to minus 0.5% to revive inflation, but warned of risks of continued imbalances in the housing market. Fitch Ratings predicts a house-price correction and warns of difficulties for households when interest rates rise or unemployment increases.

site_title: Fate of golf courses in land-scarce Singapore
summary: Singapore's 14 private and 3 public golf courses face uncertain futures due to the country's land-scarce environment. Many golf courses have leases expiring between 2020 and 2040, with some, like Keppel Club and Marina Bay Golf Club, not being renewed. Others will be offered new leases for varying periods. Some courses will be redeveloped for housing, while others will cease operations. Despite this, Singapore is expected to still maintain a significant golfing community, with around 3-4 courses possibly gone by 2030.

site_title: EU's plans to tackle corporations' tax avoidance hit first snags
summary: EU finance ministers expressed concerns about proposals to tackle corporate tax avoidance, citing risks to EU-based companies and the economy. They urged the European Commission to limit measures to guidelines agreed by the G20 and OECD, rather than exceeding them. Ministers also questioned proposals to prevent double taxation abuses and exit taxation, which are not included in international guidelines. The EU executive plans to introduce new rules for public disclosure of tax data, which may also exceed BEPS guidelines.

site_title: Fed rate hike forecasts pushed back on dimmer economic outlook
summary: Economists have revised their forecasts for the next Federal Reserve interest-rate hike, pushing it back to June from March, citing a dimmer economic outlook. Nearly 68% of economists now predict a rate hike in June, down from 30% in January. The revision comes amid concerns over a weaker global economy, a stronger dollar, and plunging oil prices, which are affecting US growth and exports. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen has stated that she needs to see more economic data before making any decisions on interest rates.

site_title: India's retail inflation hits 17-month high in January
summary: India's annual consumer price inflation rose to a 17-month high of 5.69% in January, driven by higher food costs. Retail food prices increased 6.85% year-over-year, surpassing the 6.40% recorded in December. Economists had forecast a decrease to 5.4%. This is the highest inflation rate since May 2019.

site_title: US inventory-to-sales ratio hits highest level since 2009
summary: US business inventories rose 0.1% in December, pushing the inventory-to-sales ratio to its highest level in 6-1/2 years, a 1.39-month supply of inventory at December's sales pace. Sales fell 0.6% in December, leaving businesses with unsold merchandise and little incentive to order more goods. This sharp downturn in manufacturing, combined with weak construction spending and factory orders, suggests GDP growth could be revised down to 0.3% in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Dudley eyes risks but says Fed policy easy enough
summary: Federal Reserve President William Dudley stated that US economic expansion, now nearly seven years old, poses little threat to a recession unless an outside shock occurs. Despite the expansion's age, Dudley believes the risk of recession is low due to low inflation and stable economic data. The Fed may continue to tighten policy gradually, with Dudley noting that key areas of the economy, including housing and banking, are in good shape. Total household debt in the US reached $12.12 trillion, with a delinquency rate of 5.4%, the lowest since mid-2007.

site_title: US core retail sales rebound solidly in January
summary: US core retail sales rebounded 0.6% in January, exceeding economists' forecast of a 0.3% increase, after a 0.3% decline in December. This rebound is a hopeful sign of economic growth picking up after slowing at the end of 2015. Consumer spending, accounting for over two-thirds of US economic activity, moderated in the fourth quarter but is being supported by a strengthening labor market and lifting wages. Overall retail sales rose 0.2% in January, driven by cheaper gasoline and online retailer sales, but were weighed down by a decline in service station sales and a drop in sporting goods sales.

site_title: Athletes concerned about Zika before Rio Olympic test event
summary: International athletes competing in a Rio Olympic diving test event have expressed concerns about the Zika virus, but have not canceled their participation. Organizers are advising athletes to use repellents to protect themselves against mosquito bites, the primary means of transmission. The test event, which runs from Feb 19 to 24, will feature 270 athletes from 50 countries, including a stage of the Diving World Cup. Despite concerns, athletes have not canceled their participation, with organizers providing advice on how to proceed.

site_title: Courts Asia's Q3 profit flat at S$4m
summary: Courts Asia reported flat Q3 profit at S$4m, with revenue growing 6.1% to S$204.7m. The rise in revenue was driven by a 7.9% increase in Singapore sales, mainly due to higher bulk sales for digital products. Despite a 2.4 percentage point drop in gross profit margin, the company's ongoing cost savings measures have put it in a resilient position. Courts Asia will continue to focus on cost-saving initiatives to navigate the current retail environment.

site_title: Volkswagen group sales return to growth in January
summary: Volkswagen Group reported a 3.7% increase in January sales, reaching 847,800 deliveries, driven by a 15.4% surge in China. This marks the brand's best month ever in the region. Deliveries of VW-branded vehicles rose 2.8% to 521,400. The improvement in sales follows a 2% decline in full-year 2015 deliveries.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen group sales returned to growth in January, bolstered by demand in China, where core brand VW posted its best month ever.

site_title: Greece sinks back into recession as year of turmoil takes toll
summary: Greece has entered a recession, with its economy contracting 0.6% in the fourth quarter of 2015, following a revised 1.4% contraction in the previous quarter. The country's anti-austerity government, which began a tumultuous year with a dramatic U-turn, faces opposition to its pension reform plan and renewed euro-exit fears. Economists predict weakness in domestic demand for 2016, with the European Commission forecasting a 0.7% contraction in 2016 and a 2.7% growth in 2017.

site_title: Boustead Singapore Q3 profit falls on lower revenue, spin-off of property arm
summary: Boustead Singapore reported a 36% fall in net profit for its fiscal third quarter due to lower revenue. Quarterly revenue fell 20% to S$142 million, impacted by sales from energy-related engineering services, real estate, and geo-spatial technology. The spin-off of Boustead Projects, the company's real estate arm, resulted in a dividend distribution and a non-controlling interest portion of total profit, affecting net profit. If adjusted for the spin-off, net profit would be 16% lower year-on-year.

site_title: Powerful 6.5 earthquake strikes Indonesia
summary: A 6.5-magnitude earthquake struck eastern Indonesia on Friday, centered three kilometers east-southeast of Andekanter in the Sumba region at a depth of 30 kilometers. The earthquake occurred at 5:02 pm local time, but no immediate damage or casualties were reported. The Indonesian disaster mitigation agency stated that no tsunami warning was issued.

site_title: OKH Global posts S$2.15m loss for Q2
summary: OKH Global, a construction and property development firm, reported a loss of S$2.15 million for the second quarter of 2016 due to no completed projects. Revenue fell 98.6% to S$3.3 million, down from S$230.2 million in the same period last year. The company expects positive contributions from two upcoming projects, but shares fell 0.5 cents or 0.9% to 55.5 cents on Friday.

site_title: Amazon acquires Italy-based software firm
summary: Amazon Web Services has acquired NICE, an Italy-based software firm, for an undisclosed amount. NICE provides technical computing solutions to industries such as aerospace, energy, and utilities. The deal is expected to close in the first quarter of 2016. The acquisition aims to expand Amazon's cloud computing offerings and enhance its technical computing capabilities.

site_title: Tat Hong in the red for Q3 on weak regional demand
summary: Tat Hong Holdings reported a net loss of S$6.7 million for its Q3, citing weak demand in South-east Asia and Australia. Revenue fell 19% to S$124.8 million, with crane rental revenue down 23% and distribution revenue dropping 23%. The company expects weak demand to persist in FY2016, leading to cost-cutting measures to reduce operating costs.

site_title: Eurozone economy grows 0.3% in Q4 2015, unchanged vs Q3: Eurostat
summary: The eurozone economy grew 0.3% in Q4 2015, matching analyst forecasts and unchanged from Q3. This brings the full-year growth to 1.5%. Germany, France, and Italy experienced slower growth, while Spain led the pack with a 0.8% gain. The European Union as a whole grew 0.3% in Q4, down from 0.4% in Q3, and 1.8% for the year.

site_title: Zika pushes 38% of US businesses surveyed to let workers defer trips
summary: US businesses are responding to the Zika virus by allowing female employees to defer travel or leave countries where the virus has been reported, with 38% of surveyed multinationals, universities, and non-profits implementing this policy. A fifth of respondents are giving male employees similar options. The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and World Health Organization (WHO) have declared an international emergency, but much remains unknown about the virus, prompting companies to take precautions and adjust their travel policies.

site_title: WHO says Indian company, NIH have lead in Zika vaccine work
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) says Indian company Bharat Biotech International Ltd and the US National Institutes for Health (NIH) are leading in developing a possible Zika vaccine. Bharat Biotech has two vaccine candidates under development, while about 15 companies are working on Zika vaccines. However, the current absence of standardized animal models and reagents is slowing down development, which is expected to take at least 18 months for clinical trials.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DBS Group Holdings, OCBC, and Julius Baer submitted non-binding bids for Barclays' Asian private wealth business. The possibility of Singapore's central bank easing monetary policy is rising due to weak economic data. The Straits Times Index (STI) has strong technical support at 2,540-2,550, and Singtel's CEO expressed concerns about the entry of a new operator driving price focus in the industry. Asian stocks sank, with the regional benchmark index heading for its lowest close since 2012, as Japanese shares collapsed.

site_title: Russia's top automaker fears bankruptcy as losses mount
summary: Russia's top automaker Avtovaz, controlled by Renault-Nissan, is facing bankruptcy due to significant losses in 2015. The company reported a net loss of 73.8 billion rubles (S$1.3 billion), nearly tripling the previous year's figure. To address the crisis, Avtovaz has implemented a four-day workweek and plans to further optimize its workforce and sell non-core assets. The company requires financial assistance from shareholders to refinance its debt and secure new loans, citing market conditions that raise doubts about its ability to continue as a going concern.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang Q3 profit down 24.9% at S$24.3m
summary: Bukit Sembawang, a Singaporean residential property developer, reported a net profit of S$24.3 million for its third quarter ended Dec 31, 2015, down 24.9% from the previous year. Revenue declined 56.9% to S$42.6 million. The company attributed the decline to lower revenues, but noted higher gross profit margins on certain projects. The Singapore residential property market remains weak, with private home prices falling 3.7% in 2015.

site_title: ST Aerospace bags four pilot training contracts worth S$23m
summary: ST Aerospace has secured four pilot training contracts worth approximately S$23 million, including two with China Airlines and Hainan Airlines. The contracts include ab-initio programs, a one-year extension from Qatar Aeronautical College, and an extension from Xiamen Airlines. ST Aerospace will showcase its virtual reality training suite at the Singapore Airshow, featuring innovative training solutions. The company's president, Lim Serh Ghee, emphasized the importance of continuous innovation in pilot training, highlighting the company's commitment to producing competent pilots.

site_title: Sim Lian Group Q2 profit up 59% to S$40.49m
summary: Sim Lian Group reported a 59% increase in Q2 net profit to S$40.49 million, with revenue more than doubling to S$194.33 million. The property development division's revenue rose 183% to S$75.17 million, while the construction division's revenue climbed 95% to S$105.51 million. Earnings per share increased to 4.02 Singapore cents, and the counter ended unchanged at 76 Singapore cents on the Singapore bourse.

site_title: Google Ventures seeks to make name as farsighted health investor
summary: Google Ventures is expanding its focus on healthcare and biotechnology investments, seeking to make a name for itself as a farsighted health investor. With $2.4 billion in management, the venture capital firm is making bets in sectors overseen by the FDA, including drugs and medical devices. Founder Bill Maris aims to find technology that works, despite regulatory risks, and is willing to take on long schedules. GV's investments in companies like Editas Medicines and Denali Therapeutics are part of its strategy to tackle age-related diseases and other areas where traditional biotech firms have struggled to find breakthroughs.

site_title: gl. posts 34% jump in Q2 profit
summary: GL. (formerly GuocoLeisure Limited) reported a 34% year-over-year increase in net profit to US$19.9 million in Q2, driven by higher revenue and lower finance costs. Revenue rose 1% to US$114.7 million, while operating income jumped to US$13.2 million due to a one-off compensation payment. The company attributed a 1% dip in revenue to lower Bass Strait oil and gas royalty income. GL. plans to continue hotel refurbishments and launches a new hotel under its every Hotel brand.

site_title: Asiatravel.com pushes corporate portal into Indonesia, Vietnam
summary: ASiatravel.com Holdings has launched its Savio Staff Travel corporate travel portal in Indonesia and Vietnam, expanding its reach to over 1.2 million corporate staff. The company appointed PT Multi Holiday and United Golf Services as official distributors in their respective countries. David Boh Sui Hou, son of the CEO, was promoted to senior vice-president for China, leading day-to-day operations and digital marketing.

site_title: Cordlife swings into the black on non-operating gains
summary: Cordlife Group reported a second-quarter profit of S$9.6 million, or 3.71 Singapore cents per share, driven by non-operating gains, offsetting a 33.8% decline in operating profit before tax. Revenue increased 2% to S$14.5 million, while net profit for the six months to December 2015 rose to S$16.9 million from a S$6.5 million loss in the year-ago period.

site_title: Commerzbank boosts European shares off of 2-1/2 year lows
summary: European shares rebounded strongly on Friday, with the pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 up 2% after Commerzbank returned to profit and oil prices rallied. The German banking sector, which had been battered, saw a 3.8% rise in the STOXX 600 Banks index. Growth data from Germany also provided reassurance, but the FTSEurofirst 300 remains down 5% for the week.

site_title: Linc posts A$95.77m Q2 loss
summary: Linc Energy reported a net loss of A$95.77 million for the second quarter of FY2016 due to reduced realised oil prices and reduced capital expenditures on drilling. Revenue was A$15.83 million, down from A$23.07 million in the same period last year. Quarterly sales volumes were flat at 267,066 barrels of oil equivalent. The company's gross capital expenditure was reduced to A$9.81 million from A$12.2 million. The net loss for the first half of FY16 was A$154.14 million, compared to A$59.77 million last year.

site_title: Turning over new leaf: Ousted Thai PM picks lettuce for the cameras
summary: Former Thai Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra has held a press conference at her home in Bangkok, defying the military junta's ban on political activity. The event, which included her picking lettuce for the cameras, is seen as a bid to boost her family's profile ahead of a possible election in 2017. Analysts believe the move is part of a publicity campaign by the Shinawatra family to reconnect with supporters, who remain popular in the country's north and northeast. Yingluck faces criminal charges over a rice subsidy scheme, but many predict the Puea Thai Party will win the next general election.

images.alt_text: Former Thai Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra opened her home to foreign media on Friday in what analysts said was a bid to boost her family's profile ahead of a possible election next year.

site_title: JES to sell shipbuilding business for US$500,000 and potential top-up
summary: JES International Holdings plans to sell its shipbuilding business to Hong Kong Victo International for US$500,000 with a potential top-up of one-fifth of the disposal companies' net value after a year. The deal includes selling all subsidiaries and 49% of Jiangsu Nereus Shipyard Co for a combined fixed asset value of 1.53 billion yuan. The sale aims to dispose of liabilities and seek new business, following discussions with potential investors hindered by the insolvency of the shipbuilding business.

site_title: UK construction output slips in Q4 despite December pick-up
summary: UK construction output decreased 0.4% in the fourth quarter, driven by reduced infrastructure spending despite a 1.5% increase in December. This follows a 1.7% decline in the third quarter. Construction output grew 3.4% in 2015, slower than the economy but faster than the 7.5% expansion in 2014. Total construction output remains 4.1% below its 2008 level. The housebuilding sector saw a 4.1% growth rate, driven by cheap borrowing costs and record employment levels.

site_title: EU widens steel-trade protection with tariffs on Russia, China
summary: The European Union has imposed tariffs on Russian and Chinese steel imports, with duties ranging from 13.8% to 26.2%. The move aims to protect European steel producers from unfair competition, following a complaint by the European steel industry group Eurofer. The EU found that Russian and Chinese exporters had sold goods below cost, causing "material injury" to European manufacturers. The tariffs, which will take effect on Saturday, are for six months and may be prolonged for five years to ease import competition for the struggling European steel industry.

site_title: South Korea Kosdaq halts trading after plunging more than 8%
summary: South Korea's Kosdaq halted trading after the index plummeted over 8% to 594.75, down 52.94 points. The broader market is also affected, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) down 1.88%. The Kosdaq, launched in 1996, is weighed down by poor sentiment and global equities markets. Trading resumed with the index down 7.08%.

site_title: Burberry faces US lawsuit accusing it of deceptive price tags
summary: British luxury fashion brand Burberry is facing a class action lawsuit in the US, alleging it used deceptive price tags at its outlet stores to mislead customers. The lawsuit claims Burberry presented false price information on products manufactured specifically for its outlet stores, making them appear as if they were sold in retail stores. This is the latest in a series of cases accusing luxury retailers of misleading customers with inflated manufacturer prices. Burberry has declined to comment on the lawsuit.

site_title: Singapore shares close flat on Friday, STI down 3.2% for week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed flat on Friday, down 3.2% for the week at 2,539.95, amid a global market downturn. Japan's interest rate cut to negative territory led to a collapse in Japanese equities, while oil prices resumed their downtrend. European banks are under scrutiny due to financial solvency concerns. The STI's performance was influenced by short selling and short-covering, with Dow futures and Hong Kong movements also playing a significant role.

site_title: TT International's Q3 loss widens to S$16.21m due to higher expenses
summary: TT International reported a widened net loss of S$16.21 million in Q3 FY2016, up from S$10.48 million in the same period last year. Revenue jumped 73.6% to S$108.35 million due to operations in Big Box and Indonesia. However, expenses including non-cash depreciation, property tax, and expansion costs led to the increased loss. Excluding these expenses, the group would have recorded a smaller net loss of S$0.9 million. Loss per share was 1.59 Singapore cents, compared to 1.10 cents in Q3 FY2015.

site_title: SATS chalks up higher profit for Q3 FY16
summary: SATS reported a net profit of S$60.6 million for Q3 FY16, up 12.8% from the previous year, due to lower expenditure. Revenue fell to S$441 million, largely due to a 7.1% drop in its food solutions business. Despite this, earnings per share rose to 5.5 Singapore cents. SATS attributed the results to its focus on productivity and cost-cutting measures, despite an uncertain operating environment in Asia.

site_title: Malaysia keeps March crude palm oil export tax unchanged at zero
summary: Malaysia, the world's second-largest palm oil producer, has maintained its crude palm oil export tax at zero in March, contrary to market expectations. The tax rate has been unchanged since May 2015. The Southeast Asian nation set a reference price of RM2,172.69 per tonne for March, with a tax of 4.5-8.5% applying above RM2,250 per tonne.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks sink, extending painful sell-off
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined 1.22% to close at 18,319.58, extending a nearly four-per-cent loss from the previous day. The Hang Seng Index fell to its lowest level since March 2020. The decline follows a devastating week for global markets, with investors bracing for US-EU trade tensions. The sell-off is part of a broader market downturn, with US stocks edging down from records amid tariff threats and European stocks also falling due to bank and healthcare sector declines.

site_title: Australian cabinet minister resigns over unofficial China trip
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull accepted the resignation of Human Services Minister Stuart Robert due to his attendance at an unofficial China trip in 2014. Robert admitted to holding shares in a company with ties to the Australian company involved in the contract signing with China's Minmetals Corp. The move follows a tumultuous week for Turnbull's government, with two other ministers quitting earlier. A government investigation found Robert's actions created the impression he stood to gain personally from the project.

site_title: Telkom said to be close to 750m rand state broadband deal
summary: Telkom SA is close to reaching a 750 million rand (S$65.6 million) deal with the South African government to roll out broadband services across eight districts. The agreement, part of the government's goal to extend broadband access to every household by the end of the decade, would connect over 5,000 government facilities. Telkom has carried out site inspections and studied implementation plans, but the company has declined to comment on the deal. The contract's total cost could reach 98 billion rand.

site_title: As gold price soars, traditional Asian buyers show little love
summary: Gold prices near a one-year high due to safe-haven buying, but traditionally active Asian buyers, particularly in China and India, show little interest in physical gold. This could impact the metal's biggest rally in years, although Western consumers' panic buying of gold coins and bars may cushion the effect.

site_title: Europe: Shares boosted by banks and commodities
summary: European stocks rose 1.4% on Friday, rebounding from a 3.7% decline the previous session, driven by gains in banks and commodity-related stocks. Commerzbank's return to profit and its decision to close its 'bad bank' boosted the STOXX 600 Banks index 2.6%. The oil and gas sector also rose 2.7% after oil prices surged nearly 4%. The rebound was seen as a positive sign for the market, which had hit a 2-1/2 year low the previous day.

site_title: Templeton's US$5.9b bet on Brazil bonds paying off in 2016
summary: Franklin Templeton's Michael Hasenstab has more than doubled his investments in Brazil's debt to $5.9 billion, which has returned 4.7% in dollar terms in 2016, surpassing the average loss of 0.13% for local-currency debt in emerging markets. This is in contrast to last year's 33% decline in Brazilian securities. Hasenstab's bet is seen as a contrarian move, but some investors remain skeptical due to Brazil's deepening recession.

site_title: Asia: Stocks sink as Japan caps worst week since financial crisis
summary: Asian stocks plummeted, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index down 2.8% as Japan's Topix index slumped 5.4% to cap its worst week since the 2008 financial crisis. The yen surged, intensifying speculation of potential intervention, while global equities entered a bear market. Central banks' negative interest rates failed to ease investor concerns over global growth, with Sweden's rate cut and US Federal Reserve Chairman Janet Yellen's testimony offering little relief.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 0.21 point to close at 1,643.74 on Friday, with 1.33 billion lots valued at RM1.57 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 271-517.

site_title: German economy expands by 0.3% in Q4 2015: statistics office
summary: Germany's economy expanded by 0.3% in the fourth quarter of 2015, driven by robust domestic demand. This growth, combined with 0.4% expansion in the first and second quarters, resulted in a 1.7% annual expansion. Positive factors included increased state spending, private household growth, and construction investments, while lower exports had a dampening effect.

images.alt_text: The German economy, Europe's biggest, grew by 0.3 per cent in the fourth quarter, driven primarily by robust domestic demand, the federal statistics office Destatis said on Friday.

site_title: PM Lee meets California Governor Jerry Brown on US trip
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong met California Governor Jerry Brown in San Francisco, reaffirming strong economic ties between Singapore and California. In 2013, Singapore was California's 12th largest export destination for goods.

site_title: Asian currencies fall as risk appetite hit by global stock slump
summary: Asian currencies declined as global stocks fell 20% from their May record, prompting Japan's Finance Minister to warn of intervention to weaken the yen. The MSCI World Index saw a 20% drop, with Malaysia's ringgit falling 1%, the Thai baht and South Korean won also declining 0.7%. The sell-off was driven by risk aversion, with the yen reaching 111 per US dollar for the first time since October 2014.

site_title: Without a buyer, Thai Air's A340 fleet will stay grounded
summary: Thai Airways International Pcl will continue to ground 10 Airbus A340s due to high fuel costs, despite a 40% drop in fuel prices. The airline aims to sell the planes to bolster its balance sheet, and President Charamporn Jotikasthira plans to increase online bookings to 30% by the end of the year. Thai Air has reported losses since 2013 and plans to sell 6 billion baht of bonds to repay debt, with the goal of raising its passenger load factor to over 80% this year.

site_title: Asia's rich urged to buy yen as BOJ negative rates backfire
summary: Asia's wealthy investors are favoring the yen due to its undervaluation and the turmoil in global financial markets. Credit Suisse advises clients to buy the yen against the euro or South Korean won, predicting it will strengthen to 110 against the dollar by the end of this month. The yen has outperformed all other major currencies this year, with a 7% gain against the US dollar, as Japan's current-account surplus makes it attractive to investors seeking a haven. The Bank of Japan's negative interest rate policy has failed to rein in the currency's advance, leading to concerns that the policy is ineffective.

images.alt_text: Money managers for Asia's wealthy families are favoring the yen as it benefits from the turmoil in global financial markets.

site_title: Strong support seen for Singapore STI at 2,540-2,550: IG
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) is experiencing strong technical support at 2,540-2,550, according to IG market strategist Bernard Aw. A break below this level could lead to a test of 2,521.95, last seen in October 2011. Despite a 0.10% gain, the STI is still struggling to hold on to gains due to bearish sentiment weighing on global equity markets. DBS led the losers, while Singtel rose after reporting a 1.7% drop in third-quarter profit.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks plunge more than 5% by break
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted over 5% on Friday, catching up with a global sell-off amid economic concerns. The Nikkei 225 index fell 5.34% to 14,874.65, driven by a stronger yen that hammered exporters. The broader Topix index declined 5.55%. The declines followed a one-day holiday, as investors weighed deepening worries about the world economy.

site_title: ComfortDelGro full-year profit up 6.5% at S$301.9m
summary: ComfortDelGro's full-year net profit rose 6.5% to S$301.9 million, driven by growth in transport businesses. The group's earnings per share increased to 14.07 Singapore cents from 13.29 cents in 2014. A one-tier final dividend of 5 Singapore cents is proposed, up from 4.5 cents previously.

images.alt_text: Net profit of transport operator ComfortDelGro grew by 6.5 per cent to S$301.9 million for the financial year 2015 as revenue grew in its transport businesses.

site_title: Risk of Singapore central bank easing seen rising on growth woes
summary: Singapore's central bank may ease monetary policy at its April review due to weak economic data, including a 0.1% decline in exports and an 8-month low industrial production slump. Analysts say the probability of a recession is increasing, with a recent government survey showing business sentiment in the services sector at a four-year low. While the baseline scenario is for no change, the chances of easing have grown, with some economists predicting a recession in the first half of 2016 if services sector growth falters.

site_title: Flashy Malaysia financier said to sell Picasso, Basquiat at loss
summary: Malaysia financier Low Taek Jho has sold three artworks by Claude Monet, Pablo Picasso, and Jean-Michel Basquiat for about $54 million, with unusually steep losses on at least two pieces. The artworks were consigned by Low as collateral for a $100 million loan from Sotheby's Financial Services. The sales come amid a global market rout and a drop in art auction sales, with prices being questioned for their sustainability. Low's ties to Malaysia's prime minister's family have been a subject of controversy, with allegations of financial irregularities surrounding the 1MDB investment fund.

site_title: DBS toppled by Bank Central Asia as region's largest bank
summary: Bank Central Asia (BCA) has surpassed DBS Group Holdings Ltd as Southeast Asia's largest lender by value, with a market capitalisation of $24.5 billion. BCA's shares have risen due to its focus on Indonesia, which shields it from slowing growth in Greater China. DBS, Singapore's largest bank, was ousted by BCA this month.

site_title: Beijing offers support for Hong Kong after New Year violence
summary: China's central government supports Hong Kong authorities and police in maintaining public order and punishing lawbreakers following a riot in Mong Kok during the Lunar New Year holiday. Sixty-four people have been arrested, with 37 charged, after protesters clashed with police. The violence is linked to the "Occupy Central" pro-democracy movement, which has sought greater autonomy and even independence from China. China's foreign ministry describes the riot as "plotted mainly by a local radical separatist organisation" and praises Hong Kong police for their restraint and professionalism.

site_title: Goldman Sachs bankers said to depart on guidelines breach
summary: Three Goldman Sachs bankers have left the firm after breaching internal guidelines in connection with a Middle East acquisition deal. The bankers, based in Dubai and London, failed to identify themselves as bank employees at a meeting with the target company, violating firm guidelines. Goldman Sachs has set up a business-standards committee to emphasize transparency and has disciplined other employees as a result. The incident highlights the tightening of controls on staff at global securities firms amid rising legal costs and regulatory scrutiny.

images.alt_text: Three bankers have left Goldman Sachs Group Inc after the US firm determined they breached internal guidelines in connection with the bank's advisory role on the planned acquisition of a consumer company in the Middle East, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

site_title: DBS, OCBC, Julius Baer bid for Barclays Asia wealth unit
summary: DBS, OCBC, and Julius Baer have submitted non-binding bids for Barclays' Asian private wealth business valued at around US$600 million. The sale is part of Barclays' restructuring drive under new CEO Jes Staley, amid pressure to cut costs and reevaluate Asian strategy. Barclays managed US$36 billion in private banking assets in Asia, with DBS ranked eighth. European private banking players are seeking to expand in the region, but some mid-sized banks are reconsidering due to slowing growth and fierce competition. The bids were submitted last week, with the sale process remaining confidential.

site_title: Flash: South Korea's Kosdaq halts trading after plunging more than 8%
summary: South Korea's Kosdaq halted trading on February 12, 2016, after plummeting over 8%. No further details are provided in the article.

site_title: South Korea, US to discuss missile defence; South cuts power to Kaesong park
summary: South Korea and the US will discuss deploying an advanced US missile defence system following North Korea's rocket launch. The talks, set to begin next week, will focus on placing one Terminal High Altitude Area Defence (THAAD) unit in South Korea. The move comes after North Korea's launch violated UN Security Council resolutions. Seoul and Washington have expressed concerns about the test. Meanwhile, South Korea cut power to a jointly run factory park with North Korea, Kaesong.

site_title: Oil prices rally after plumbing new depths
summary: Oil prices surged more than 5% in Asia on Friday after tanking to 13-year lows the previous day, following a report suggesting Opec producers may cooperate on cutting output to stabilize volatile markets. However, analysts tempered optimism, citing a stubborn global supply glut and the need for concrete action. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rose $1.47 to $27.68 a barrel, and Brent crude advanced $1.68 to $31.74 a barrel. Concrete commitments from major producers, such as Saudi Arabia and Iraq, are needed to sustain the price rally.

site_title: China, Taiwan markets closed on Friday for Lunar New Year holiday
summary: Financial markets in China and Taiwan were closed on Friday for the Lunar New Year holiday. No specific news or events were reported in the article, making it seem to be a placeholder or unrelated content.

site_title: Rio Tinto CEO sees mining distress spreading to majors
summary: Rio Tinto CEO Sam Walsh predicts commodity-price distress will spread to major mining companies, forcing them to sell assets and creating opportunities for others. Rio Tinto has a list of desirable assets it would consider buying if they become available, but is holding back due to concerns over high costs and low quality. The company is focusing on developing its own assets and striking the right balance between returning cash to investors and growing the business. This trend may lead to asset sales by major producers, including Anglo American, which is set to unveil an overhaul of its operations.

site_title: US says increased Zika border screening ineffective
summary: The US Department of Homeland Security announced that increased Zika border screening is ineffective due to asymptomatic cases. The DHS will not screen for Zika, but will refer travelers showing signs of illness to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for medical evaluation. Pregnant women from Zika-prone countries will be screened and provided prenatal care while in custody. The decision comes as Zika has spread rapidly in Latin America and the Caribbean, linked to microcephaly and Guillain-Barre syndrome.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks close at lowest in 5-1/2 months, won down
summary: South Korean shares closed at their lowest in 5.5 months, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) down 1.4% at 1,835.28 points. Foreign investors sold a net 298.2 billion won worth of KOSPI shares, contributing to the decline. The South Korean won also dropped 0.8% against the dollar, reaching 1,211.7 to the dollar. This marks the lowest closing level since August 24, 2015, and the worst weekly performance since December 2015.

site_title: Singtel's CEO concerned new competitor to focus only on price
summary: Singtel's CEO expressed concern that a new competitor in Singapore's mobile market will shift focus to price, potentially harming the industry. The regulator plans to auction radio frequencies for a fourth carrier this year, challenging Singtel and its rivals. The new operator may not have the same network reach as the incumbents, but could drive competition. This could lead to lower prices and increased data traffic, benefiting consumers but posing challenges for the industry.

site_title: Japan Finance Ministry says will take necessary steps to deal with FX volatility
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso said the government will take necessary steps to deal with currency volatility, amid speculation of yen-selling intervention to prevent a further yen spike. The dollar fell below 111 yen, its lowest level since October 2014, triggering concerns about the impact on Japan's export-reliant economy. Aso emphasized the need for a global policy response to recent market turmoil, as the rising yen threatens to hurt corporate earnings and undermine the government's efforts to stimulate the economy.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares drop on global jitters, gold stocks shine
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares fell 1% on Friday due to global growth concerns, erasing previous gains. Gold stocks rose as gold prices hit a one-year high, with Independence Group, Evolution Mining, and Northern Star Resources among top gainers. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 49.78 points, while the NZ benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index dropped 60.37 points. Analysts attributed the decline to a lack of economic growth and confidence, with no sign of a turnaround in monetary policy easing.

site_title: Credit Suisse slides to 27-year low amid selloff, overhaul
summary: Credit Suisse shares plummeted to a 27-year low, closing at 12.31 Swiss francs (S$17.65) down 8.4% amid a selloff across the industry. The bank's shares have lost nearly half their value since October, as CEO Tidjane Thiam's restructuring plans face doubts. A decline in trading revenue, stricter capital requirements, and cooling emerging economies have contributed to the slump. Thiam aims to bolster earnings by expanding wealth management, but investors and employees are concerned about the bank's ability to execute its plan, creating a credibility gap.

site_title: Indonesia bans 'gay' emojis on messaging apps
summary: Indonesia has demanded messaging apps remove same-sex emoticons, citing cultural and religious laws.
