The emojis, available on LINE, WhatsApp, Facebook, and Twitter, depict same-sex couples and the rainbow flag. The Communication and Information Ministry, spokesman Ismail Cawidu, stated that such contents are not allowed in Indonesia. The move is part of a crackdown on gay rights in the Muslim-majority country. Operators must remove the emojis or face a ban in Indonesia.

images.alt_text: In the latest crackdown on gay rights in Indonesia, the government has demanded all instant messaging apps remove same-sex emoticons or face a ban in the Muslim-majority country.

site_title: AusNet Services buys Mortlake Terminal Station for A$110m
summary: AUSNet Services has agreed to purchase Mortlake Terminal Station in Western Victoria, Australia for A$110 million from Origin Energy. The terminal station connects Origin's Mortlake Power Station to Victoria's electricity market and is expected to increase AusNet Services' cash inflows by A$8.8 million in FY2018. The acquisition is closely aligned with AusNet Services' core operations and will be funded using existing corporate debt facilities. The deal also reaffirms the company's dividend guidance of 8.53 Australian cents per share for FY2016.

site_title: Shunned for years, gold stages comeback as equities melt down
summary: Gold prices surged 5% on Thursday, its largest daily gain in over seven years, amid a weaker dollar, crashing oil prices, and concerns about the global economy. The US central bank's possible interest rate cut instead of a hike has boosted gold's safe-haven status. This rally has revived gold's prospects for a sustained price increase, last seen in a 10% 10-day stretch in 2011, when it peaked at over $1,920 per ounce.

images.alt_text: Gold's prospects for a sustained price rally are better than they have been for years as a weaker dollar, crashing oil prices and concerns about the global economy have revived its safe-haven status after years as the dog of global financial markets.

site_title: Uber settles claims its 'safe rides fee' misled passengers
summary: Uber has agreed to pay $28.5 million to settle claims that its "safe rides fee" was misleading, as it failed to disclose that its background checks on drivers weren't as rigorous as advertised. The company will change the fee to a "booking fee" to resolve class-action lawsuits. This settlement comes as Uber continues to face allegations by California prosecutors that it gives the public false assurances about ride safety. The company will also make changes to its driver screening process.

site_title: Rents of condos, HDB flats in Singapore up in January
summary: Singapore's condo and HDB flat rents rose in January, with private homes increasing 0.2% and HDB flats up 0.7%. This marks a second consecutive month of growth after 10 months of decline. Private home rents are 14.6% lower than their peak in 2013 and 5.5% lower than 2015 levels. January's rental growth was driven by the city fringe and suburban areas, while Core Central Region experienced a 2.4% decline. HDB flat rental volume contracted by 5.4% in January.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall amid global rout, won down
summary: South Korean stocks fell 1.4% on Friday as the global economy's health worries continued to affect the market. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) dropped to 1,836.09 points, with medical supplies leading decliners. However, auto shares rose due to hopes that a stronger yen would ease pressure on profit margins. Defence shares performed strongly, while foreign investors sold local equities and bonds, contributing to the won's decline. Analysts predict the KOSPI may not find a bottom until it falls to around 1,800 points.

site_title: Asia: Stocks extend world rout amid rising yen while oil rallies
summary: Global stocks extended their rout, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index down 2.1% as of 10:40am Tokyo time, on track for a weekly decline of 5.4%. The yen surged 0.2% to 112.24 U.S. cents, its strongest two-week advance since 1998, amid rising anxiety over central banks' ability to revive the world economy. Oil rebounded from a 12-year low, while US index futures signaled gains after losses in the US. Regulators in Japan said they would respond to market volatility if necessary, amid concerns that a stronger yen threatens to imperil the country's economy.

site_title: S&P cuts Deutsche Bank's Tier 1 securities rating to B+ from BB-
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) cut Deutsche Bank's Tier 1 securities rating to B+ from BB-, citing uncertainty over the bank's German GAAP earnings prospects due to restructuring and volatile market conditions. Despite this, S&P expects Deutsche Bank to make steady progress toward its financial and operational targets for 2020. The bank's shares have fallen 40% this year, and it plans to buy back billions of euros worth of debt to reverse falling security values. S&P also lowered a perpetual Tier 2 instrument rating to BB- from BB.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.1% up on Friday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.1% higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index advancing to 2,540.75. The gain came after US Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen stated she wasn't ruling out negative interest rates. Trading volume was moderate, with 27 million shares changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 73 to 35, despite a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.42 points to 1648.37. The market saw 40.7 million lots traded worth RM20.64 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 128 to 61.

site_title: Yellen says no negative interest rates in store for US
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated that the Fed has no plans to implement negative interest rates, despite European central banks' recent moves into negative territory. Yellen expressed surprise at the depth of negative rates in some countries, but emphasized that the Fed is studying the issue to be prepared. The Fed had raised its federal funds rate in December, and Yellen noted that it would be premature to conclude the impact of global market fluctuations on the US economy.

site_title: Google self-driving car effort expands hiring, posts manufacturing jobs
summary: Google's self-driving car project is expanding its hiring efforts, posting dozens of manufacturing jobs, including positions in motion control, robotics, and sensors. The company is also advertising jobs in marketing, real estate, and operations. The hiring spree suggests Google may be building its own hardware to supply the software for autonomous vehicles. Despite previous denials, the jobs listing provides evidence that Google is investing heavily in the project, which is expected to partner with established carmakers.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks tumble more than 4% in early trade
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted more than 4% in early trade on Friday, following a global sell-off amid worries about the world economy. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 4.59% and the Topix index declined 4.50%, as a stronger yen hurt Japanese exporters. Experts believe the market has entered a phase where it's pricing in a US recession, despite reassurances from Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen. The dollar fell to 112.10 yen, its lowest level in several days.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Eu Yan Sang, Metro, Raffles Education
summary:
Singapore stocks to watch: 
- Singtel reported a net profit of S$954 million for the three months ended Dec 31, 2015, with revenue rising 1.1% to S$4.5 billion.
- Eu Yan Sang International's net profit fell to S$498,000 for the fiscal second quarter.
- Metro Holdings' net profit dropped 12.6% to S$55.7 million in the third quarter.
- Raffles Education Corp swung to a loss for the second quarter, with a net loss of S$5.2 million.

site_title: Taiwan city looks at developer's other buildings after quake collapse
summary: A 6.4 magnitude earthquake struck the Taiwanese city of Tainan, killing at least 63 people and trapping over 50 others in the Wei-guan Golden Dragon Building, a seven-story complex built by developer Lin Ming-hui. The building's design and construction were found to be flawed, with missing main beam joints and a poor structural system. Lin, two architects, and the company's owner have been taken into custody on suspicion of professional negligent homicide. The city is now inspecting other buildings built by Lin's company, with at least 40 structures on the list.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend losses on global economy fears
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined 1.44% on Friday, extending a near four percent drop from the previous day, amid growing concerns over the global economy. The Hang Seng Index fell to 18,278.80. This decline follows a similar trend seen in Europe, where stocks were also affected by bank and healthcare issues, as well as US-EU trade talks. The global market volatility continues to impact Asian stock markets, with investors becoming increasingly nervous about the state of the economy.

site_title: 'Grexit' fears loom without solid Greek reforms: IMF
summary: IMF warns of "Grexit" fears resurfacing if Greece doesn't implement credible reforms, particularly on pensions, to reach medium-term surplus target. Poul Thomsen, head of the IMF's European department, stated that a plan built on optimistic assumptions will revive fears of a Greek exit from the eurozone, stifling investment. The IMF has expressed concerns over the pension reform and debt relief from European partners, emphasizing the need for viable decisions to arrive at a program that adds up.

site_title: Barry Manilow rushed to hospital, cancels shows
summary: Barry Manilow, 72, was rushed to a hospital in Los Angeles after emergency oral surgery, forcing him to cancel shows on his final tour. The singer, who had just played a sold-out show in Memphis, postponed Thursday and Friday dates, with rescheduled shows to follow. The reason for the surgery was not specified, but Manilow's management stated it was due to complications.

site_title: Europe: Slump in banks and resources pushes shares to 2-1/2 year low
summary: A European share index plummeted 3.7% to its 2-1/2 year low, led by a 6.3% decline in the banking sector. The FTSEurofirst 300 is down 16.6% for the year, its biggest monthly fall since 2008. The slump is attributed to concerns over profitability in a low-growth, low-interest rate environment. The index has snapped a seven-day winning streak and is down 11.3% in February, the worst start to the month since 2008.

site_title: Singtel Q3 profit slides 1.7%, forex hurts
summary: Singtel reported a 1.7% fall in Q3 net profit to S$954 million, due to adverse currency movements and investments, despite growing mobile data usage. Underlying net profit was S$955 million, beating analyst estimates. Revenue rose 1.1% to S$4.47 billion.

site_title: Online travel shares surge on cheap-oil boost
summary: Online travel shares surged on Thursday following solid earnings announcements, driven by a boost in leisure tourism from cheap oil. Expedia's shares jumped 9.6% to $103.37, while TripAdvisor's vaulted 12.4% to $61.07. Despite higher expenses, both companies reported significant revenue gains, with Expedia's fourth-quarter revenues increasing 25.3% to $1.7 billion and TripAdvisor's 7.0% to $309 million. Expedia projects 35-45% growth in 2016 earnings.

site_title: Yen adds to gains as investors run for cover
summary: The Japanese yen surged 0.9% against the dollar and 0.6% on the euro following concerns over global market turmoil and the Federal Reserve's noncommittal stance on interest rate policy. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's dovish tone hinted at the possibility of rate cuts and negative interest rates, causing the US dollar to decline. The yen's gains follow a 1.5% increase on Wednesday, and the dollar finished at 112.39 yen, while the euro rose 0.4% to US$1.1323.

site_title: Indonesia to fortify airports countrywide after deadly attack
summary: Indonesia is upgrading airport security nationwide after a deadly attack by Islamic State militants in Jakarta. The measures include installing fences, "first-class" baggage x-ray machines, and retraining security officers. Transport Minister Ignasius Jonan emphasized the need for proactive security measures, stating that waiting for indications is not enough. The upgrades aim to increase airport security standards across the country.

images.alt_text: Indonesia is upgrading security at its 192 airports to guard against possible terrorist attacks, weeks after a deadly bombing and shooting assault by Islamic State militants in downtown Jakarta.

site_title: Eurozone chief plays down bank crisis fears
summary: Eurozone chief Jeroen Dijsselbloem played down fears of a new banking crisis, stating that eurozone banks are stronger than a few years ago. Despite concerns over a potential "bail-in" element of the EU's banking union plan, Dijsselbloem assured markets and investors that they can cope with the rules. Eurozone officials also downplayed concerns about Greece and Portugal, with Greece's bailout review expected to be completed by the end of March and Portugal agreeing to implement additional measures to meet EU budgetary rules.

site_title: HBO Now has 800,000 paid streaming subscribers
summary: HBO Now, a standalone video streaming service, has attracted 800,000 paid subscribers since its launch in April 2015. The service, which costs $15 a month, is available on various streaming devices and has been a significant contributor to HBO's total subscriber growth, adding 2.7 million subscribers in the US last year. Analysts expect the service to grow, with HBO projecting half of the 10 million US homes with web service but no traditional cable or satellite TV subscriptions will subscribe. The service will gain momentum with new programming and global expansion.

site_title: Oil slumps again; US crude at 2003 low
summary: Oil prices slid again, with US crude reaching a 13-year low of $26.21 per barrel. The decline was attributed to a persistent global crude oil glut and a lack of economic recovery. Analysts cited a report from OPEC showing a 130,000 barrel per day production increase in January, contributing to low oil prices. Experts predict that low oil prices may be sustained for an extended period due to the ongoing oversupply and conflicting interests among OPEC members.

site_title: US: Wall St traders dump Boeing, bank stocks
summary: US stocks experienced a decline on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 1.29% and the S&P 500 down 1.23%. Boeing shares plummeted 6.8% due to an investigation into accounting maneuvers that may have exaggerated its profitability outlook. The Nasdaq Composite lost 0.4%. Despite the losses, the US markets closed well off their lows. The decline was attributed to a global market selloff and ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Croesus Q2 DPU slides despite higher earnings
summary: Croesus Retail Trust reported a Q2 DPU of 1.79 Singapore cents, down from 2.08 Singapore cents in the previous year, due to an enlarged unit base after a rights issue. The trust's earnings were boosted by the acquisition of two malls in Japan. CFO noted that negative interest rates could be beneficial for borrowing costs in the future.

site_title: Storm-battered Royal Caribbean ship returns to port
summary: A Royal Caribbean cruise ship, Anthem of the Seas, returned to its New Jersey port after being battered by an Atlantic storm. The ship, carrying 4,500 passengers and 1,600 crew, was hit by high winds and 9-meter waves off Cape Hatteras, North Carolina, cutting short its 7-night cruise to the Bahamas. At least four people suffered minor injuries. The US Coast Guard plans to investigate the incident to determine "causal factors or lessons learned" to prevent future injuries or damage. The ship will undergo inspections and repairs before its next trip.

site_title: Malaysian industrial output up in December
summary: Malaysia's industrial production index (IPI) rose 2.7% in December from a year ago, driven by positive growth in manufacturing and electricity indices. However, the manufacturing sector's sales value dipped 1.2% due to declines in 42 of 138 industries surveyed. Economists see a slowing trend, citing a weak global economic recovery and tepid export growth, which fell 1.4% year-on-year in December. The decline in exports and internal demand is expected to impact the manufacturing sector, potentially leading to job losses.

site_title: Dim prospects, ABSD set to cut foreigner home buying again this year
summary: Foreigner home buying in Singapore decreased 22% in 2015, with 895 units sold, down from 1,148 units in 2014. This decline is attributed to higher purchase taxes and dim prospects for gains. Industry insiders expect no reduction in the additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) rates, further reducing foreigner interest. With no improvement in prospects, the market remains glum for 2016.

site_title: Twitter resumes skid on disappointing quarterly report
summary: Twitter shares plummeted 4.47% to an all-time low of $14.31 after its quarterly report failed to ease concerns over stagnant growth. The company's base of monthly active users remained unchanged at 320 million, and organic revenue growth decelerated. Analysts, including RBC Capital Markets and Topeka Capital Markets, expressed caution, citing a need for more user growth and innovation. Co-founder Jack Dorsey reassured analysts that his priorities include improving user experience, live-streaming, and safety features, but no specific timeline for changes was provided.

site_title: A toast to all-season wines
summary: A wine expert compares three red wines from Rioja and Bordeaux regions in Spain and France, evaluating their taste, freshness, and price. The Rioja wine from Priorato, Gran Clos, outperformed the Bordeaux wine, Le Plus de la Fleur de Bouard, in terms of freshness and value. The expert praises Priorato's Garnacha varietal, highlighting its ability to pair well with Asian cuisine. The article concludes that wine enthusiasts should venture beyond Bordeaux and Burgundy, exploring other regions and varietals, such as Spain's Priorato and Rhone Valley.

site_title: Cisco shares up 7.5% amid forecast that Q3 sales could grow 4%
summary: Cisco Systems Inc. has forecasted Q3 sales growth of up to 4%, contradicting concerns about a weakening global economy and slowing corporate demand. The company's shares rose 7.5% to $24.19 in extended trading, beating some analyst estimates. This positive prediction suggests that corporate spending remains robust, despite fears of an economic downturn.

site_title: Rotary Engg's bid to stay lawsuit to be heard on Feb 19
summary: Rotary Engineering's lawsuit appeal will be heard in the High Court of Singapore on February 19. The company is challenging a Bahrain-based lawsuit alleging breaches of contract in Saudi Arabia. Rotary insists the case should be heard in Saudi Arabia due to its close connection, despite the Bahrain parties seeking a Singapore hearing.

site_title: French wine and spirits exports hit all-time high
summary: French wine and spirits exports reached an all-time high in 2015, reaching 11.7 billion euros, driven by a weak euro, strong demand for champagne and cognac, and a recovery in the Chinese market. The US market also saw a significant increase, accounting for 22% of exports. However, producers warned that wine shipments fell 3.6% by volume, and the sector's market share has been cut by nearly half by volume over the past 15 years.

site_title: Wong's debut album features a musical menagerie
summary: Dawn Wong's debut album, Marco Lopo, features a diverse range of musical styles, including jazz, soul, pop, and swing. The album, which includes 10 original tracks, tells stories of human-like animals navigating life's challenges. Wong, a former bank executive, drew inspiration from her own experiences and reality TV show Project Superstar. The album will be launched with Wong's new band, The Ark Royal, at a show in Singapore next week, with handmade copies and merchandise available for purchase. Wong aims to make the album accessible and appealing to a wide audience, departing from the typical conservative Chinese music scene.

site_title: Asians to invest more in properties beyond the region than in it
summary: Asian investors are shifting their focus to real estate markets outside of their region, with a 26.8% increase in outbound capital flow last year, reaching $39.7 billion. This trend is driven by weaker economic growth and waning rents in Asia, with investors favoring Europe and North America, where they invested $14.3 billion within the region. Sovereign wealth funds in Singapore and Hong Kong are also rebalancing their portfolios, with Singapore-based investors purchasing a record $26.3 billion in overseas real estate in 2015.

site_title: Chow's Mermaid makes box-office waves
summary: Stephen Chow's fantasy-comedy film "The Mermaid" sets a new record for the opening day of a domestic film in China, raking in US$42 million. The film, which blends Chow's signature "mou lei tau" comedy with an ecological message, stars mainland actor Deng Chao as a wealthy businessman who falls for a mermaid. The film's success showcases Chow's enduring influence on Chinese cinema, despite his reduced acting role. With its stellar performance and absurd gags, "The Mermaid" has become a box-office hit, earning a rating of B+.

images.alt_text: Comedian Stephen Chow goes behind the camera in The Mermaid and shows he has the directorial chops to pull off a box-office winner. His fantasy-comedy starring Deng Chao (right) pulled in US$42 million, setting a new record for the opening day of a domestic film in China.

site_title: UK property sales surge as investors try to beat tax hike
summary: UK property sales surged in February as investors attempted to beat a 3% transaction tax hike on rental investments set to take effect in April. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors reported the largest increase in sales since 2014, with 74% of participants expecting buy-to-let investors to boost demand before the tax rise. Despite a slowdown in economic growth forecasts, demand for housing remains buoyant due to tight supply, record employment, and cheap mortgage rates.

site_title: Why employment regulations sometimes have unintended effects on workers
summary: Tech giants such as Yahoo and Deutsche Bank have announced significant workforce cuts, with Yahoo shedding 15% of its staff and Deutsche Bank eliminating 25% of its workforce. This practice, known as retrenchment, is common in industries with uncertain demand, such as tech. Employment protection laws can have unintended effects, leading to changes in hiring and relocation practices, potentially harming workers.

site_title: China's struggling middle class deserves better
summary: China's struggling middle class faces limited investment options due to unstable domestic markets, hindering their ability to build wealth. Unlike Western households, Chinese investors are restricted from investing globally, making them vulnerable to market fluctuations. The Chinese stock market's immaturity and lack of policy clarity exacerbate this issue, leading investors to seek alternative markets, such as the US. China's middle-class wealth-building path is becoming increasingly global and treacherous, unlike the US, where institutional stability and functioning markets have historically supported financial stability.

site_title: China bank losses could overshadow that of sub-prime crisis
summary: China's banking system may face losses of over four times those suffered by US banks during the sub-prime crisis, according to hedge fund manager Kyle Bass. If China's banks lose 10% of their assets due to non-performing loans, approximately $3.5 trillion in equity would vanish. This estimate is based on Bass's analysis of China's banking system and its exposure to non-performing loans. The potential losses could be significant, potentially overshadowing those experienced during the 2008 sub-prime crisis.

site_title: Metro's Q3 profit falls 12.6% on flat retail sales, lower associate contributions
summary: Metro Holdings' net profit fell 12.6% to S$55.9 million in Q3 2015 due to flat retail sales and lower associate contributions. Revenue was mostly flat, with retail revenue rising 0.47%. The retail division narrowed its operating loss to S$0.3 million, while the property division's operating loss widened to S$4.6 million. Metro expects currency volatility and challenging competition in the year ahead. The company announced a £1 million (S$2.003 million) investment in a UK office development site.

site_title: Lippo Group invests in fintech start-up
summary: Lippo Group, a Singapore-based conglomerate led by the Riady family, has invested an undisclosed amount in fintech start-up Call Levels, its first foray into the financial technology space. Call Levels offers a mobile app providing real-time price alerts across 10,000 assets to users, distinct from brokerage services that provide trade execution alerts. The start-up has seen significant user growth, tripling in three months to 60,000 users, and has been recognized as a top fintech app. The investment was made by Call Levels itself, not as a formal strategy by Lippo.

site_title: Gold jumps to highest level in eight months
summary: Gold prices surged to an 8-month high of over $1,200 an ounce, driven by investors seeking a safe-haven asset amid global market turmoil. The metal's value rose 3.26% in a single day, with central bank purchases contributing to its growth. Despite a strong start to the year, analysts expect gold to drop this month due to slowing Chinese consumer purchases. Global gold demand in 2015 was virtually flat, with a 4% increase in central bank purchases, while mine production fell 3% in the fourth quarter.

site_title: MAS, CAD investigating Koyo International MD
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) are investigating Koyo International's managing director Foo Chek Heng for "possible offences" under the Securities and Futures Act. Foo told the company he disputes the allegations and will cooperate fully in the investigation. The company's shares fell 7.4% on Thursday, adding to their losses, after the MAS and CAD interviewed Foo and he handed over his documents. This comes after a 84% crash in the stock on January 18 due to a "trade with caution" warning by the Singapore Exchange (SGX).

site_title: China turns glut of oil into flood of diesel swamping Asia
summary: China is flooding Asia with diesel due to a glut of oil, cutting profit margins for fuel producers in India and South Korea. China's total net exports of oil products are expected to rise 31% this year to 25 million tonnes, with diesel exports jumping 75% last year. This surge in refined products threatens to disrupt the energy market, affecting the profit margins of fuel producers in the region.

site_title: Some disturbing parallels to the collapse of globalisation
summary: The international financial system is at risk of a significant collapse, similar to the 1930s Great Depression, due to emerging parallels between the two periods. Globalisation's rapid retreat in the 1930s was fueled by resentment over immigration, trade, and capital flows. Recent developments, including the contraction of global foreign exchange reserves, net capital outflows from emerging markets, and the rise of protectionism, echo these earlier grievances. Capital controls, tariffs, and currency devaluations are hindering trade and exacerbating economic instability, threatening the global economy's current fragile state.

images.alt_text: Like Germany in the 1920s, China's banking system has become bogged down with bad debts and industrial excess capacity is rife.

site_title: An IPO elsewhere is not always a big loss for SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) may not have lost much by allowing 8I Holdings to list on the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX) instead of itself, as the firm's stock has performed well despite the decision. 8I Holdings, a Singaporean investment and financial education firm, has seen its stock value increase five-fold since its 2014 listing. However, the firm's business model lacks sharpness, and its sustainability is doubtful due to its mixed investment and education activities. The SGX still needs to focus on attracting quality firms with strong growth prospects to boost its IPO activity and market capitalization.

site_title: Zooming in on the exposed flank of 1970s rock 'n' roll
summary: HBO's Vinyl series, executive produced by Mick Jagger, premieres on Feb 15 at 10am on HBO, offering an expose of the 1970s music industry through the eyes of a desperate record company president. The show mixes facts with fiction, featuring iconic bands like Led Zeppelin and The New York Dolls, with direction by Martin Scorsese and a slick production value. Vinyl aims to live up to the hype of classic rock music, with a two-hour pilot episode and new episodes simulcast with the US every Monday morning.

site_title: Negative rates to stay as long as needed: IMF official
summary: IMF official Jose Vinals stated that central banks will continue to push interest rates below zero if it benefits the economy. Central banks in Europe and Japan have signaled readiness to provide additional stimulus, but investor concerns over slowing global growth persist. Vinals emphasized that negative rates are a tool to support the economy, not a penalty for banks. He noted that the alternative scenario, where no stimulus was provided, would have been worse for the economy and banking sector.

site_title: Valentine options
summary: A free French drive-in movie event, "P.S. I Love You," will be held on Feb 13 from 5:30pm to 11pm in Singapore, featuring a food fair, games, and activities, as well as a screening of the French movie "Priceless." The event is organized to celebrate 10 years of partnership between Citroen and Cycle & Carriage, and admission is free.

site_title: Tesla shares surge after CEO Musk promises positive cash flow in 2016
summary: Tesla shares surged 10% in after-hours trading following CEO Elon Musk's promise of positive cash flow in 2016, with the company forecasting a 60-80% increase in vehicle sales this year and plans to turn a profit on an adjusted basis by the fourth quarter. Despite a wider fourth-quarter net loss of $2.44 per share, Musk assured investors that Tesla will cut costs, hit production targets, and generate positive cash flow in March. The company also announced plans to invest $1.5 billion to add capacity and produce its first net profit by the end of the year.

site_title: Twitter struggles to expand user base with new plans
summary: Twitter reported no new users in the fourth quarter, with monthly active users remaining at 320 million, the same number as the previous quarter. Revenue forecast was also disappointing, with analysts predicting $627.6 million in revenue, but Twitter only projected $595-610 million. CEO Jack Dorsey's efforts to revamp the product, including live streaming video and user-friendly features, were not enough to boost user growth or ad revenue, which has been declining. The company's shares have dropped 68% in the past year, and analysts warn that Twitter's future is uncertain, particularly if a recession hits.

site_title: Former dance director opens up on leaving Paris Opera Ballet
summary: Former Paris Opera Ballet director Benjamin Millepied has announced his departure, citing that he is not the right man for the job. Millepied, 38, had brought a glamorous profile and international attention to the company, but critics argue that he abandoned too quickly and neglected the French repertory. His departure has sparked debate about the company's traditions and culture, with some dancers and critics praising his efforts to increase diversity and others criticizing his blunt approach. Millepied will be succeeded by Aurelie Dupont, a former Paris Opera Ballet etoile, on July 15.

images.alt_text: Outgoing choreographer Benjamin Millepied (right), director of the Paris Opera Stephane Lissner (left) and former French ballet dancer Aurelie Dupont at a photocall in Paris on Feb 4. Mr Lissner said former principal ballerina Dupont, who announced her retirement last spring, would replace Mr Millepied.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Saizen Reit cuts its interim distribution per unit by 8.7% due to a weaker Japanese yen and higher issued units, resulting in a 19.2% drop in total return attributable to unitholders in the second fiscal quarter. Health Management International's net profit stayed flat in the second fiscal quarter, despite revenue growth and improved gross profit margin, but administrative costs and tax expenses offset the gains.

site_title: HSBC drops plan for global 2016 wage freeze in speedy backpedal
summary: HSBC chief executive Stuart Gulliver has reversed his plan for a global wage freeze in 2016 after employee backlash, instead proceeding with pay rises as originally proposed. The pay freeze, which was part of HSBC's efforts to cut $5 billion in costs by 2017, was met with employee complaints. The hiring freeze remains in place, with Gulliver citing macroeconomic pressures such as falling oil prices and slowing Chinese growth as reasons for the decision.

images.alt_text: Mr Gulliver last month imposed a freeze on hiring and compensation as part of a drive to cut costs.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singtel is set to release its Q3 FY2016 results on Feb 12, with analysts expecting revenue of S$4.4 billion and underlying net profit of S$945 million. Meanwhile, Optus is seen as a potential bright spot in the coming year due to its business efficiency improvements.

site_title: Climate change will slow westbound transatlantic flights: study
summary: Climate change is expected to slow westbound transatlantic flights due to strengthened headwinds, increasing fuel costs and CO2 emissions. A study by researchers at the University of Reading found that the jet stream will speed up, making flights between North America and Europe longer. Eastbound flights will benefit from stronger tailwinds, but the net result is a significant increase in journey times. The study estimates an additional 2,000 flight hours per year, burning 7.2 million gallons of fuel and emitting 70 million kilos of CO2.

site_title: Building productivity grants 'temporary': minister
summary: Singapore's National Development Minister Lawrence Wong says construction productivity grants are a temporary measure to kick-start the industry, as they will eventually become economically viable without government support. The grants, part of the Building & Construction Authority's Productivity Innovation Project, have helped OUE Ltd cover part of the costs of using Prefabricated Pre-finished Volumetric Construction (PPVC) technology in its Crowne Plaza Changi Airport extension project. Wong believes that as the industry adopts PPVC technology more widely, cost differentials will decrease, making it economically viable without grants.

images.alt_text: Crowne Plaza Changi Airport's new 10-storey extension is being built using the more productive PPVC technology.

site_title: Bondholders protest Trikomsel's move to recognise claim
summary: Bondholders of Trikomsel, a financially troubled Indonesian telecommunications company, are protesting the administrators' decision to recognize an intercompany claim but reject claims related to direct guarantees on two outstanding Singapore dollar notes. This move has sparked concerns among investors. The administrators' low-profile decision has raised questions about their priorities and the impact on bondholders' interests.

site_title: Norway's wealth fund gets political pushback in asset bid
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund, valued at $810 billion, faces opposition from the country's Labor Party over its proposed entry into the $20 trillion infrastructure market. The fund's management has been criticized for rising strategy implementation costs, and lawmakers are concerned about the impact on the domestic economy. The Labor Party's Torstein Tvedt Solberg calls for a reevaluation of the fund's mandate, citing uncertainties in the market and the need for deeper structural changes. A parliamentary vote could come as soon as this year, with the minority government relying on Labor Party support.

site_title: City buzz
summary:
Here's a summary of the article content in 100 words or less:

In Singapore, Ah Hoi's Kitchen at Hotel Jen Tanglin Singapore offers a 12 at 12 lunch menu, featuring 12 dishes for S$12 nett per person, with a free meal for the 12th person. Lolla & Lollapalooza also introduced new lunch menus with affordable prices. Meanwhile, artist Keng Lye's "Alive Without Breath II: Creature Comforts" exhibition is on at K+ Curatorial Space, and The Projector is celebrating its one-ish birthday with a screening of "What We Do In The Shadows." Jazz singer Diana Krall will perform two intimate concerts in Singapore as part of her "The Wallflower World Tour 2016."

site_title: Making sense of the soaring yen amid financial market turmoil
summary: The Japanese yen has surged by over 7% against the US dollar in the first 11 days of February, defying initial expectations of a weakening currency after the Bank of Japan introduced a negative interest rate policy. The yen's rise is attributed to the unwinding of the "carry trade," where investors borrowed heavily in yen to invest in higher-yielding assets, and sentiment shifting towards the yen as a "safe" asset during financial market turmoil. The yen's strengthening has negatively impacted Japan's stock market and economy, exacerbating deflation and inflationary expectations, and may continue to affect the country's macroeconomy until financial market stability returns.

site_title: Indonesia allows greater foreign stakes from roads to cinemas
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo has announced plans to allow full foreign ownership in various industries, including toll roads, cinemas, and restaurants, to attract investment and create jobs. The government will also raise foreign ownership limits in golf courses, health support services, and airport support to 67%. This move aims to offset weaker export performance and provide more jobs to drive annual economic growth, which has been stagnant at a six-year low. The government plans to simplify overseas investment limits to three levels and close 19 industries to foreign stakes.

site_title: Artists without borders
summary: Three Singapore artists, Heman Chong, Jeremy Tiang, and Chua Yun Chun, are breaking geographical boundaries to achieve success globally. Chong's visual art has garnered international recognition, with solo exhibitions in Shanghai and Seoul. Tiang, a writer-playwright-translator, has published works in New York and London, while also maintaining a connection to Singapore. Chua, a dancer, left Singapore for New York in 2014 to pursue better artistic growth opportunities, facing challenges as an Asian dancer in the American market. Despite these challenges, they attribute their success to the can-do spirit of the city and their willingness to take risks and improvise.

site_title: Yen continues climb as safe-haven appeal strengthens
summary: The yen reached a 15-month high of 112.50 to the US dollar, driven by a safe-haven appeal amid international financial turbulence. Analysts attribute the yen's climb to factors such as dollar selling, Japanese investors' heavy investment in foreign stocks and bonds, and the unwinding of "carry trade" positions. JP Morgan's Tohru Sasaki forecasts the yen to reach 110 by the end of 2016, with the potential for further appreciation if the yen continues to spike. The Japanese authorities may intervene to smooth out movements, but analysts believe their efforts would be negated by the underlying factors.

site_title: Keppel Fels said to have been shortlisted for Hess semisub
summary: Keppel Fels, in a joint bid with McDermott, has been shortlisted for a massive floating production contract for the Equus gas field development off western Australia. The contract, expected to be worth hundreds of millions of dollars, is part of a $7 billion development budget. The company is competing with other shortlisted bidders, including Samsung Heavy Industries and SBM Offshore, to design and build a semi-submersible production unit. The project's outcome is uncertain due to market conditions, with Hess facing an uphill challenge in selling the produced LNG at competitive prices.

images.alt_text: KEPPEL Fels, in a joint bid with McDermott of the US, is said to have made the shortlist for one of the largest floating production contracts on offer in the international bid circuit this year.

site_title: Marvel antihero is dead in the water
summary: Deadpool, the Marvel antihero, has made his cinematic debut in a film that showcases his characterization and plot. Ryan Reynolds stars as the "clown prince of the superhero genre," who breaks the fourth wall and addresses the audience with witty one-liners. The film follows Deadpool's origin story, from his transformation into the mutant mercenary after being horribly disfigured and losing his sense of humor. Despite its edginess and moral ambiguity, the film concludes that Deadpool is "dead shallow" due to its lack of heft in its storyline.

site_title: 0.6% rise in SRX resale condo price index draws divided views
summary: A 0.6% month-on-month rise in Singapore's resale condo price index in January has sparked divided views on the market's outlook. Some, like Savills Singapore, believe it may mark an inflection point, while ERA Realty sees the overall trend as still downwards due to economic headwinds and a mismatch between supply and demand. The index still shows a 1.7% year-on-year drop and a 7.2% decline from 2014's peak.

site_title: Is share consolidation the way to go to achieve MTP?
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is implementing a minimum trading price (MTP) of 20 cents, aiming to reduce volatility and increase liquidity. However, the strategy of share consolidation has raised concerns among small retail investors, who may be disproportionately affected. Companies are now racing to reduce their share capital, with some opting for a 500-to-1 ratio. The SGX should reconsider its approach to ensure the interests of small shareholders are protected.

site_title: Worst CNY start for HK stocks since 1994
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 3.9% on their first working day of the Chinese New Year, their worst start since 1994, amid a global equity rout and concerns over the world economy. The Hang Seng Index tumbled 12% for the year, with energy companies leading declines due to a 11% drop in crude prices. Rioting in Mong Kok's shopping district threatens to deter mainland visitors and worsen retail sales. Analysts predict a 12% drop in the Hang Seng Index's earnings per share over the next 12 months, citing capital outflows, a slumping property market, and China's economic slowdown.

site_title: Societe Generale Q4 profit misses estimates as investment-bank earnings slump
summary: Societe Generale, France's second-largest bank, reported Q4 profit that missed estimates as investment-bank earnings slumped and the bank set aside provisions for potential legal costs. Net income rose to 656 million euros, but fell short of the 944 million euro average estimate. The bank's investment-banking bonus pool for 2015 declined due to weak market conditions and adaptation costs. Despite this, Societe Generale maintained its target for a 10% return on equity and announced cost-cutting measures to adapt to increasing regulation and clients' migration to mobile banking.

site_title: Berlitz Marine looks to opportunistic acquisitions
summary: Berlitz Marine has completed the purchase of two anchor handling tug supply vessels (AHTSs) from Pacific Richfield Marine for loans from DBS, its "valued banker". The vessels, Pacific 38 and 68, were acquired to fulfill contractual commitments in the UAE and to bid competitively for contracts under challenging economic conditions. The acquisition is part of Berlitz Marine's strategy to selectively buy offshore support vessels to replace charter-in units on its operating fleet, with the goal of maintaining high fleet utilization rates despite market downturn.

site_title: Lagarde looks set for 2nd IMF term as no challengers emerge
summary: Christine Lagarde is set to win a second term as managing director of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) after no candidates emerged to challenge her. Her five-year term expires on July 5. Lagarde, 60, has been nominated by the fund's executive board, which represents 188 member nations. Her re-election comes despite ongoing legal troubles in France, where she faces trial for "negligence" related to a settlement during her time as finance minister. US Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew has expressed support for her re-election, citing her exceptional job performance and broad support among IMF membership.

site_title: Husky-CNOOC to award 2016's first leased floating production job
summary: Husky-CNOOC's joint venture, HCML, has awarded its first leased floating production contract to a Singaporean operator, marking a shift in Indonesia's local-content rules. The contract is tied to the MDA-MBH gas-and-condensate project in Indonesia's Madura Strait. The move is seen as a boon for Singapore's offshore and marine (O&M) players, who are now in the running for subcontracting work under the revised rules. This award comes as Indonesia's energy sector continues to evolve, with a focus on local content and cooperation between international players and local operators.

site_title: HK celebrities in gritty stage drama
summary: Hong Kong's Dionysus Contemporary Theatre is presenting its second Western classic, French playwright Yasmin Reza's Tony Award-winning God of Carnage. The play, which explores marriage, family, and societal issues, was adapted for Chinese audiences with some French references removed. The production, which features a cast of local actors, including Anthony Wong and Louisa So, aims to improve the local theatre scene by working on original Hong Kong plays. The play will be performed on February 20 and 21 at The Esplanade Theatre, with tickets available for booking.

site_title: FCL's Aussie unit buys 135ha site in Queensland
summary: Frasers Property Australia has acquired a 135-hectare site in south-east Queensland for an "end value of S$270 million". The site, halfway between Brisbane and the Gold Coast, will feature 1,350 detached housing lots. The project is scheduled for a public launch in spring 2016 with planning approval and infrastructure in place.

site_title: Asahi offers to buy beer brands Peroni and Grolsch for 2.5b euros
summary: Asahi Group Holdings of Japan has made a binding offer to buy beer brands Peroni and Grolsch, along with certain European operations of SABMiller, for 2.55 billion euros. The deal aims to ease regulatory concerns for Anheuser-Busch InBev's nearly US$103 billion merger with SABMiller. The sale includes brands and operations such as Royal Dutch Grolsch, Birra Peroni, and Miller Brands UK, but excludes US rights to Peroni and Grolsch.

images.alt_text: ASAHI Group Holdings of Japan has made a binding offer to buy the beer brands Peroni and Grolsch, as well as certain European operations of SABMiller, for 2.55 billion euros (S$3.93 billion).

site_title: India's manufacturing surge to fizzle out as oil bounty fades
summary: India's manufacturing sector showed a 12.6% surge in the last three months of 2015, but this growth was largely driven by lower input costs rather than higher volumes. This discrepancy has raised concerns about the accuracy of India's growth data and the country's ability to meet its full-year GDP growth estimate of 7.6%. Economists predict a wobbly economic recovery ahead, with some forecasting growth rates of 7.4% this year and 7.6% next year. The government's reliance on household consumption and investment to drive growth may also be challenged, with some experts warning of an "unrealistic" 12% increase in consumption in January-March.

site_title: Yields on Deutsche Bank CoCos rise to more than 13%
summary: Yields on Deutsche Bank's Contingent Convertible Bonds (CoCos) have surged to over 13%, causing investors to feel the pain as shares plummet 40% in the same period. The CoCos, designed to absorb losses and protect European taxpayers, are facing their first test as weak bank earnings and a global market rout raise concerns about banks' stability. Investors are learning that the risk is not just of default, but also of skipping coupon payments without defaulting, with prices pricing in an average of three years of skipped coupons.

site_title: Lower costs, higher aircraft utilisation lift Jet Airways' profit
summary: Jet Airways reported profits of US$71 million for the third quarter ended Dec 31, 2015, its third consecutive profitable quarter. Lower costs and higher aircraft utilization boosted performance, with total cost per available-seat-kilometre falling 15% and passenger revenues reaching US$733.7 million. The airline attributed its success to its turnaround efforts, despite structural challenges in India's aviation industry. Outgoing CEO Cramer Ball will join Alitalia in March, citing progress in the turnaround plan and plans to cut costs and leverage synergies with Etihad Airways, which holds a 24% stake in Jet Airways.

images.alt_text: INDIA'S Jet Airways reported profits of US$71 million for the third quarter ended Dec 31, 2015 - its third consecutive profitable quarter - up from US$0.5 million a year ago, as it continues on its turnaround efforts.

site_title: 'Brexit' bandwagon gathers pace as EU fears copycat demands
summary: The European Union is concerned as populist and anti-EU forces surge across the region, inspired by the UK's Brexit strategy. EU leaders see David Cameron's approach as a template for pushing their own causes, with some nations seeking to overhaul EU terms or roll back EU oversight. The bloc's economic foundations are fragile, and any attempts to copy Cameron's strategy could have a destabilizing effect, potentially leading to a Europe a la carte approach with diverse demands. The EU faces a difficult few years as it navigates these challenges.

site_title: Small businesses still hugely exposed to FX swings: report
summary: Only 20-25% of small and medium-sized British and French companies hedge their exposure to fluctuations in currency rates, according to a report by East & Partners. In contrast, 80-90% of large businesses use options or forward contracts to cover foreign exchange risks. The report found that UK companies with revenues under 20 million pounds are less likely to hedge, while French peers are less likely than their UK counterparts. Despite rising trends, small businesses remain heavily exposed to currency swings.

site_title: Sovereign funds' selling could hit US$700b of European stocks
summary: Sovereign funds in European countries may sell up to $700 billion in stocks, including major banks, due to the oil slump and squeezed public finances. Recent market sell-offs could be exacerbated by these funds selling equity portfolios. This could lead to significant losses for European stocks.

site_title: Leading shipping lines offer to settle EU pricing probe: sources
summary: Leading shipping container groups Maersk, MSC, and 13 other firms have offered to change their pricing practices to settle an EU antitrust probe, potentially avoiding fines. The companies will adjust their methods to announce future price hikes, providing regulatory guidance for sectors like supermarkets and chemical firms. This move comes after the EU launched an investigation into the shipping industry's pricing practices in 2016. The agreement is seen as a significant development, offering clarity and guidance for industries that use similar methods to announce price hikes.

site_title: Yen hits strongest level in 15 months against US$
summary: The yen reached its strongest level in 15 months against the US dollar, rising 2% to 111.37 yen, driven by global capital flows seeking safety amid chaotic stock market fluctuations. The euro and Swiss franc also gained value against the US dollar. Japanese policymakers are considering official intervention to cool the currency's rise, but it's uncertain whether the IMF and G-20 would support such action. The US Federal Reserve's Janet Yellen's testimony to Congress reinforced expectations of gradual policy tightening, fueling the yen's buying momentum.

site_title: Yellen's warning over global economy sparks another stock rout
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's warning on the global economy sparked a stock market rout, with world stocks slumping and oil falling to 12-year lows. The Dow continued its overnight fall, and Asian markets followed suit, with Hong Kong stocks tumbling 4% and European markets experiencing significant declines. Oil prices dropped close to $27 per barrel due to oversupply, while commodity stocks like Rio Tinto plummeted 4.14% after posting an annual net loss.

images.alt_text: World stocks slumped on Thursday, gripped by another fierce selloff after a warning by Federal Reserve boss Janet Yellen over the global economy, while oil fell close to 12-year lows.

site_title: Lagarde set for new IMF term after nomination deadline passes
summary: Christine Lagarde is set to win a second term as managing director of the International Monetary Fund after no candidates emerged to challenge her. The nomination deadline passed on Wednesday, with Lagarde being the only candidate. The fund's executive board plans to complete the selection process as soon as possible. Lagarde's term expires July 5, 2016.

site_title: 'Creative destruction' the next step for companies to survive and thrive
summary: Singapore businesses are being urged to adopt "creative destruction" to survive and thrive in an increasingly tech-driven economy. Companies must create forces that disrupt their existing business to stay competitive, as multinational corporations are laying off staff and focusing on innovation. The government-formed Committee on the Future Economy is supporting firms and industry clusters to use technology and new business models to create value. Corporations are recognizing the importance of innovation, with many MNCs and local enterprises engaging with startups to acquire new skills and explore partnerships.

site_title: SEC probes Boeing's accounting of Dreamliner, 747
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is investigating Boeing Co over its accounting of the costs and expected sales of the 787 Dreamliner and 747 jumbo aircraft. The investigation focuses on Boeing's projection of long-term profitability for these jets. As a result, Boeing's shares dropped nearly 8% to $107.10.

site_title: The crash of 2016?
summary: The global economy is facing a crisis, with emerging-market countries, particularly China, experiencing rapid decline. China's annual growth has slowed to 6% or lower, leading to a collapse in commodity prices and a ripple effect on other countries. Commodity-producing nations like Brazil and South Africa are struggling, and banks in emerging markets are tightening credit. The US economy, already sluggish, is also feeling the impact, with consumers and businesses acting cautiously. The International Monetary Fund warns that a thin margin for error exists between continued recovery and recession, and the global economy is at risk of a downturn.

site_title: Deepening EU-Asean ties in aviation is a win-win situation
summary: The European Union and Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) are strengthening their aviation ties, aiming for a single aviation area. This move is expected to boost air traffic between the two regions, creating jobs and economic opportunities. The EU and Asean will negotiate a bloc-to-bloc aviation agreement, improving market access, investment opportunities, and regulatory cooperation. This partnership is seen as a win-win situation, as it will enhance direct flights and reduce emissions from aviation, which is forecast to grow by 63% by 2020.

site_title: Singtel leads ST Index's 1.7% fall
summary: Singtel led the Straits Times Index's 1.7% decline, with a S$0.12 drop to S$3.54, as weak oil prices, a plunge in Hong Kong's market, and Dow futures' 270-point loss weighed on Singapore stocks. The index fell to 2,538.28, with 119 gains and 264 losses in turnover of S$1.05 billion. Analysts attributed the selling to falling oil prices, China's slowing economy, and concerns over central banks' efforts.

site_title: East and West clash in Huang Ying's Macbeth
summary: Beijing-based director Huang Ying presents a contemporary interpretation of Shakespeare's Macbeth, blending Asian and Western cultures. The 13-year-old staging incorporates the Japanese Suzuki method, emphasizing the actor's body and animal energy. The production features "Autumn pants" and workers' clothes, setting the scene for a modern, Chinese society. Huang aims to redefine Macbeth as an anti-hero story, exploring themes of insomnia and self-destruction in contemporary China. The play, staged in Mandarin with English surtitles, will be performed in Singapore from February 16-18.

site_title: Total CEO says sector must stay the course on cutting capacity
summary: Total CEO Patrick Pouyanne warns the oil refining sector to remain vigilant despite current high margins, citing an overcapacity of refining globally, particularly in diesel. He reiterates his plan to reduce Total's capacity by 20% by 2016, a year ahead of schedule, to avoid complacency. Pouyanne expects strong oil demand growth this year, despite expectations of lower demand, and urges peers to rationalize capacity.

site_title: Consumer comfort in US holds close to a three-month high
summary: US consumer comfort remains near a three-month high, holding at 44.5 in the Bloomberg Consumer Comfort Index for the week ending February 7. This is attributed to falling gasoline prices and increased job security, leading to improved attitudes about the buying climate. However, Americans' views on the economy have dimmed due to market volatility. Confidence among full-time workers reached its highest level since mid-April, with the most significant increase seen among those earning $40,000-$50,000.

site_title: US: Wall St tumbles at open on global growth worries
summary: US stocks tumbled at the open on Thursday as investors fled to safe haven assets due to global growth concerns. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 139.16 points, or 0.87%, to 15,775.58, while the S&P 500 dropped 15.76 points, or 0.85%, to 1,836.1. The Nasdaq Composite index fell 63.35 points, or 1.48%, to 4,220.24. The decline follows previous record highs and amid US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Scorsese and Jagger's 18-year labour of love
summary: Martin Scorsese and Mick Jagger's 18-year labor of love, the HBO series Vinyl, premieres on February 14 and 15. Set in the 1970s, the show is a hard-rocking drama about the excesses of the music industry, centered around Richie Finestra, a cocaine-fueled record company owner played by Bobby Cannavale. The series, which Scorsese co-created with Terence Winter, explores the intersection of rock 'n' roll, gangsters, and big money, featuring cameos from real-life musicians like Elvis Presley and David Bowie.

site_title: Sealing the changing perception of US engagement in Asean
summary: US President Barack Obama is set to host a special summit with Asean leaders on Feb 15-16, 2016, at Sunnylands, California, marking a significant shift in US engagement with the Asean region. This summit comes after the US and Asean elevated their relationship to a strategic level in 2015. The meeting will be the first to be held on US soil, reflecting the Obama administration's commitment to the Asean Community. The summit is seen as a final seal to a series of efforts initiated during Obama's presidency to change perceptions about US engagement in the region.

site_title: Daimler to invest 2.6b euros for next generation diesel engine
summary: Daimler plans to invest 2.6 billion euros by 2019 to develop next-generation diesel engines, meeting new pollution standards. The investment will focus on engine development and production capacities. Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) technology will be introduced on smaller Mercedes-Benz cars by 2019, replacing current nitrous oxide trap exhaust systems. This marks a significant shift, as SCR systems are currently only used on large Mercedes-Benz cars.

site_title: Internet is growing market for illegal drugs, says EU watchdog
summary: The European Union's watchdog agency reported that the internet has become a growing marketplace for trading illegal drugs in Europe. According to the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction, nearly a quarter of the EU's adult population, over 80 million people, have used illicit drugs. The report found that the online drug supply is expanding, with 10% of internet users globally buying drugs online in 2015. The EMCDDA warned that digital literacy and advancements in technology are diversifying the range of available drugs, posing a worrying development for law enforcement.

site_title: US venture capitalist Andreessen apologises for India comment
summary: US venture capitalist Marc Andreessen apologized for a tweet stating that anti-colonialism has been an economic disaster for India. The comment was made after India's telecom regulator blocked Facebook's Free Basics service, which offered free mobile internet. Andreessen's tweet sparked controversy, and he later apologized for his remarks, which were perceived as insensitive and dismissive of India's complex historical context. The incident highlighted the challenges of navigating cultural and economic differences in international business.

images.alt_text: STAR Silicon Valley venture capitalist Marc Andreessen apologised on Wednesday for a tweet contending that anti-colonialism has been an economic disaster for India.

site_title: Morgan Stanley to pay US$3.2b to settle financial crisis-era charges
summary: Morgan Stanley agreed to pay US$3.2 billion to settle charges it misled investors in residential mortgage-backed securities that soured during the 2007-2009 financial crisis. The case stems from an investigation by the Residential Mortgage-Backed Securities Group, a joint federal and state task force launched in 2012. The settlement resolves allegations of misconduct by Morgan Stanley. The payment is part of a larger settlement with the US government and state authorities.

site_title: ST Aerospace opens new aircraft interiors centre to serve region
summary: ST Aerospace has opened a new aircraft interiors centre in Singapore, its second worldwide, to cater to the growing demand for private jets in the Asia-Pacific. The centre, valued at S$1.7 million, will design and install cabin interiors and offer maintenance services for narrow-body private jets. The facility is expected to create 70 new jobs and invest S$8 million over three years, with a focus on serving clients in the Asia-Pacific and Middle East.

site_title: PepsiCo's quarterly revenue beats estimates
summary: PepsiCo Inc reported better-than-expected quarterly net revenue of US$18.59 billion, driven by higher sales of snacks and beverages in North America. Net income rose to US$1.72 billion, or $1.17 per share, from US$1.31 billion, or 87 cents per share, a year earlier. The 7% decline in net revenue beat analysts' expectations of US$18.51 billion, as a strong dollar reduced the impact on sales.

site_title: France's Hollande to announce government shake-up
summary: France's President Francois Hollande is set to announce a government reshuffle, aiming to boost his popularity ahead of a 2017 re-election bid. Hollande will name a new foreign minister, potentially Jean-Marc Ayrault, who has experience in dealing with European issues. The president is also considering Segolene Royal for the position, despite criticism from some in his own party. Hollande's government has faced opposition and criticism over its handling of economic issues and security measures, with an opinion poll showing 75% of French people opposed to his re-election.

site_title: Sweden cuts rates deeper into negative territory, steps up currency war
summary: Sweden's central bank, the Riksbank, cut its main interest rate to -0.50% from -0.35% to weaken the currency, but this move may not be enough to push up inflation, which has undershot the 2% target for over five years. Analysts warn that the Riksbank is running out of ammunition and may not be able to compete with the European Central Bank's possible further easing in March. The move has sparked a currency war, with the Swedish crown weakening sharply against the euro.

site_title: Coca-Cola stops making drinks at three Indian plants
summary: Coca-Cola has temporarily suspended manufacturing at three Indian plants due to lower sales, amid challenges from activists over alleged groundwater depletion. The plants in Andhra Pradesh, Meghalaya, and Rajasthan produce drinks for the US giant, with nearly 300 employees affected. The company has faced resistance in the past, including in Kaladera, Rajasthan, where local groups claim it diverted scarce water meant for farmers. Coca-Cola denies wrongdoing and plans to invest $5 billion in India by 2020.

site_title: France's Hollande reshuffles his government before 2017 elections
summary: French President Francois Hollande reshuffled his government on Thursday, ahead of the 2017 presidential elections. Former Prime Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault became foreign minister, replacing Laurent Fabius, while the Greens party's Emmanuelle Cosse joined as Housing Minister. Manuel Valls remained as prime minister, and Emmanuel Macron kept his position as economy minister. The moves are seen as an effort by Hollande to reach out to beyond his Socialist party in preparation for the election.

site_title: Thai Q4 GDP growth seen cooling slightly as exports slump
summary: Thailand's economic growth is expected to slow slightly in Q4, with a forecasted 0.9% seasonally adjusted GDP growth, down from 1.0% in the previous quarter. Exports are expected to continue contracting, and high household debt levels are restraining domestic consumption. The military's stimulus measures and infrastructure projects are the key growth drivers, but the recovery remains fragile. Full-year 2015 growth is expected at 2.8%, up from a three-year low in 2014, with growth forecast to quicken to 3.2% in 2016.

site_title: EU thrashes out changes to 'Brexit' deal
summary: European Union negotiators finalized changes to the 'Brexit' deal in Brussels, aiming to address British Prime Minister David Cameron's reform demands ahead of a February 18-19 summit. The deal will be presented to leaders before a possible June referendum. EU President Donald Tusk had proposed the changes last week to meet Cameron's demands, which include reforms to EU laws and institutions. The agreement is expected to secure Britain's place in the EU.

site_title: Nestle ends IAAF partnership after alleged doping scandal
summary: Nestle SA, the world's largest food company, ended its sponsorship of the IAAF's Kids Athletics program after allegations of corruption and doping within the sport. The decision was made due to negative publicity caused by the allegations, which could harm Nestle's reputation and image. The IAAF's Kids Athletics program was sponsored by Nestle since 2012. The World Anti-Doping Agency will investigate over a decade of track-and-field drug tests following a leak of 12,000 blood tests of 5,000 athletes from 2001 to 2012.

site_title: Harrison Ford's broken leg on Star Wars set lands firm in court
summary: A production company, Foodles Productions (UK) Ltd, will face four charges under Britain's health and safety laws for failing to protect Harrison Ford, who broke his leg on the set of "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" in 2014. Ford was struck by a heavy hydraulic metal door while filming at Pinewood Studios. The incident occurred on June 12, 2014, and the actor was airlifted to a hospital and underwent surgery on his left leg. Foodles Productions will appear at High Wycombe Magistrates Court on May 12.

images.alt_text: A production company that was involved in making "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" will face criminal charges over an incident during filming in which Harrison Ford broke his leg, Britain's Health and Safety Executive said on Thursday.

site_title: Sterling falls as unnerved investors flock to safe havens
summary: Sterling falls to a 13-month low against the euro and yen due to global growth concerns and investor fear of a 'Brexit' from Europe. The pound has lost around 10% against the euro in the past two months, with investors seeking safe havens. Sterling's decline is attributed to Britain's current account deficit and reliance on foreign capital, making it a riskier asset compared to countries with surpluses. The euro has risen against sterling, and investors are awaiting the outcome of a Brussels summit where British Prime Minister David Cameron will try to agree on EU reform.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% due to market uncertainty and global events. US stocks declined, with records at risk amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potentially lower H2 revenue and similar operating losses. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Health Management International posts flat profit of RM5.4m for Q2
summary: Health Management International (HMI) posted a flat profit of RM5.4 million in its second fiscal quarter, despite a 13% increase in revenue to RM96.6 million. Higher administrative costs and income tax expenses offset the revenue growth. Gross profit margin improved to 31.7%, while administrative expenses grew 34% and tax expense increased 64%. The company is upgrading and expanding its hospitals in Malaysia, with a 10-storey medical block expected to begin construction this year. Directors are cautiously optimistic about the group's performance in the current fiscal year.

site_title: Asia markets suffer fresh rout as Hong Kong, dollar dive
summary: Asian markets experienced a fresh rout, with Hong Kong leading the decline, after Federal Reserve Chairman Janet Yellen raised concerns about the global economy. The dollar hit 15-month lows against the yen, and oil prices sank below $27 a barrel due to a supply glut and production surge. Analysts attributed the losses to a possible global recession and the ongoing impact of commodity price declines, with Rio Tinto reporting a net loss of $866 million.

site_title: US jobless claims fall more than expected, near cycle lows
summary: US jobless claims fell 16,000 to 269,000 in the week ending Feb 6, exceeding expectations and reaching near post-recession lows. The drop suggests the labor market remains solid despite economic slowdown and stock market turmoil. This is the 49th consecutive week of claims below the 300,000 threshold, indicating strong labor market conditions. The four-week moving average also fell to 281,250, and the unemployment rate fell below 5% for the first time in eight years.

site_title: Jokowi seeks China funds, rate cuts to meet Indonesia GDP target
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo aims to reach a 7% GDP growth target by 2019 through increased infrastructure spending and lower borrowing costs. He seeks funding from China's Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank and wants to cut interest rates to match inflation. The government plans to implement business-friendly reforms and increase spending on railways and ports. Despite struggling to enact his agenda, Jokowi is confident he can achieve his target, citing progress in infrastructure development and a growing economy.

site_title: Metro Q3 profit falls 12.6% on flat retail sales, lower associate contributions
summary: Metro Holdings' net profit fell 12.6% in Q3 to S$55.9 million due to flat retail sales and lower associate contributions. Revenue declined 1.3% to S$41 million, with retail revenue rising 0.47%. The company expects currency volatility to impact results in the year ahead. Metro's retail division faces challenging competition and high operating costs.

site_title: GM's Opel to build next generation electric car in 2017
summary: General Motors' European division Opel plans to build the Ampera-e, an affordable five-seater electric car, in 2017. The car shares the same underpinnings as the Chevrolet Bolt EV and promises to transform the electric vehicle market in Europe with its long-range capabilities and affordable price. Production is set to start in 2017, with further details on range and price to be announced later.

site_title: Eurozone chief says banks in 'much better place' than few years ago
summary: Eurozone chief Jeroen Dijsselbloem stated that the eurozone and its banks are stronger than a few years ago, playing down concerns that have affected global markets. He emphasized the importance of the banking union, which aims to strengthen European banks, and expressed confidence that markets will adjust to this change. This statement follows recent volatility in European bank stocks, but also comes after reports of a potential bond buyback by Deutsche Bank to alleviate concerns about its financial strength.

images.alt_text: Eurogroup chief Jeroen Dijsselbloem said Thursday that the EU's single currency area and its banks were stronger than a few years ago, playing down concerns that have spooked global markets.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed at 1,643.950, down 0.460 points. 1.23 billion lots valued at RM1.41 billion were traded, with 272 gainers and 437 losers.

site_title: BoE's Cunliffe does not expect UK to join EU banking union
summary: Bank of England Deputy Governor Jon Cunliffe stated that Britain is unlikely to join the European Union's banking union, citing that the UK's participation in the wider EU single market makes it unnecessary. The banking union, which supervises eurozone lenders, is necessary for shared currency and lender of last resort. Cunliffe's comments came during a UK parliament committee meeting, where he emphasized the UK's existing single market membership as a reason for not joining the banking union.

images.alt_text: Britain is unlikely to join the European Union's banking union, which is centred on the eurozone, as it is not needed for being part of the wider EU single market, Bank of England Deputy Governor Jon Cunliffe said on Thursday.

site_title: Raffles Education posts S$5.2m loss for Q2 on unrealised exchange loss
summary: Raffles Education Corporation reported a net loss of S$5.2 million for Q2 FY2016, primarily due to an unrealised exchange loss of S$1.8 million. Revenue declined 2.2% year-over-year to S$29.5 million, while depreciation and amortisation expenses increased 77.3% to S$2.9 million. The group attributed its financial performance to macroeconomic challenges, including currency volatility, interest rate movements, and increased competition.

site_title: Saizen Reit trims DPU by 8.7% to 2.83 Singapore cents
summary: Saizen Reit has reduced its interim distribution per unit by 8.7% to 2.83 Singapore cents due to a weaker Japanese yen and increased issued units. Total return attributable to unitholders fell 19.2% to 369.4 million yen in Q2, and 35.8% to 573.5 million yen in H1, mainly due to a 0.5% decline in net property income.

site_title: HSBC cancels 2016 pay freeze: memo from CEO Gulliver
summary: HSBC cancels 2016 pay freeze, reversing a plan to freeze both pay and hiring. CEO Stuart Gulliver announced the change after receiving feedback on the freeze, citing that pay rises will be funded from the 2016 variable bonus pool, originally meant for 2017 bonuses. Bonuses for 2015 will not be affected. Gulliver stated that not all staff will receive a pay rise, consistent with prior years.

site_title: Civmec Q2 profit falls 34.6% on weaker Australian dollar
summary: Australian engineering company Civmec reported a 34.6% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$4.8 million for the Q2 period, due to a weakening Australian dollar. Revenue dropped 27.6% to S$91.5 million. For the six months, net profit fell 26.8% and revenue declined 20.6%. Civmec shares slipped 1.3% to close at 38.0 Singapore cents.

site_title: Indonesia unveils 'big bang' for foreign investment, boldest move in 10 yrs
summary: Indonesia unveiled a 'big bang' liberalization of its economy, opening dozens of sectors to foreign investors. The move, aimed at stimulating the economy, loosened foreign investment restrictions on sectors such as restaurants, agriculture, and movie theaters. 29 sectors were removed from the 'negative investment list', while 19 were added. The reforms are seen as a step in the right direction, but implementation and addressing local concerns about ownership are crucial.

site_title: SE Asia economies set for squeeze as big firms line up spending cuts
summary: Southeast Asian economies are expected to face a spending cut by major firms, including a 10% reduction in capital expenditure over the next 12 months, according to a Reuters survey. This will impact economic growth in the region, which has been a development hotspot, and could lead to fewer jobs and less domestic investment. The cuts come as profits sag and debt mounts, with a 38% decline in profits in the latest quarter and a seven-year high in debt. The impact will be felt across the region, with Singapore, Thailand, and Indonesia expected to see significant spending cuts.

site_title: Dozens face riot charges over Hong Kong Lunar New Year violence
summary: Dozens of people in Hong Kong were charged with rioting on Thursday after violence broke out on the first day of the Lunar New Year holiday. 64 people were arrested, with 37 charged, following clashes between protesters and police in Mong Kok. Over 130 people were wounded, and rioting carries a maximum sentence of 10 years in prison. The violence is linked to an ongoing pro-democracy movement that began in 2014, with some of those charged belonging to groups calling for greater autonomy and independence from China.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore Stocks: MAS and CAD investigating Koyo International's managing director Foo Chek Heng; condo resale prices rose 0.6% in January; FCL's Australian arm bought a site worth S$270m; ST Aerospace launched a new VIP aircraft interiors centre. SE Asia economies face squeeze as firms cut spending; China's banking system may see losses of more than four times those suffered by US banks during the subprime crisis. Singapore shares closed weaker, following Hong Kong and Dow futures' drops.
