summary: Millennials can improve their financial footing by aligning their spending with their values. Experts suggest doing a "values check" to identify meaningful expenses, cutting back on non-essential spending, and using budgeting apps like Level Money. Additionally, automating savings through payroll deductions and challenging oneself to save 1% more each month can put savings on autopilot. By prioritizing time and making conscious financial decisions, young adults can set themselves up for long-term financial success.

site_title: Treasuries extend best start to year since the financial crisis
summary: US Treasuries extended their best start to a year since the financial crisis, advancing for a fourth week in five, as slowing growth and tumbling commodity prices led traders to doubt a Federal Reserve rate hike this year. Yields rose after a Labour Department report showed wages increased more than forecast in January, but the 10-year break-even rate still fell to its lowest since 2009. Treasuries have gained 2.8% this year, the most since 2008, as investors seek the safety of government debt amid global uncertainty.

site_title: China central bank does 110b yuan reverse repos, injects net 440b yuan for week
summary: China's central bank injected 440 billion yuan into the money markets through 14-day reverse bond repurchase agreements, bringing the total net injections for the week to 110 billion yuan. This is the second-largest weekly injection on record, following a 690 billion yuan injection last week. The People's Bank of China conducted the injection during a special session on Saturday, ahead of the Chinese Lunar New Year, which closes the financial markets next week.

site_title: Wevr raises US$25m, will launch new virtual reality platform
summary: Wevr, a virtual reality company, raised $25 million from investors including HTC Corp and Samsung Ventures to launch Wevr Transport, a platform for VR creators to distribute content. The platform is available in a limited test phase and features free content from Wevr and other studios, with paid experiences potentially added later this year. Wevr's CEO, Neville Spiteri, expects consumers to pay for valuable content, with future revenue models including advertising and other models. The launch comes as Facebook's Oculus unit, Sony, and others plan to introduce modern VR headsets this year.

site_title: Taiwan's TSMC says some wafers damaged in quake, some customers may be affected
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) reported that some wafers made in Tainan were damaged following Saturday's earthquake. The company plans to increase production activity to make up for delayed shipments. As a result, some customers may be affected by the disruptions. TSMC is taking steps to mitigate the impact and ensure timely delivery of products.

site_title: North Korea fires rocket weeks after nuclear test
summary: North Korea launched a long-range rocket on February 7, 2016, just weeks after conducting its fourth nuclear test. The launch was condemned by Japan and the US, with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe calling it "unacceptable" and violating international law. The UN Security Council will hold an emergency meeting on the launch. The move has raised concerns about North Korea's capabilities in developing nuclear warheads and ballistic missiles, with some experts warning that the country's next technological step could be to prove its space launch vehicles can carry re-entry vehicles capable of re-entering the atmosphere.

site_title: China's forex reserves decline to US$3.23t
summary: China's foreign-exchange reserves declined to $3.23 trillion in January, a decrease of $99.5 billion, marking the smallest level since 2012. The yuan's retreat to a five-year low exacerbated depreciation pressure, prompting the central bank to sell dollars. The reserves have fallen by over half a trillion dollars in 2015, the first-ever annual decline. Experts warn that the rapid pace of depletion is unsustainable, with capital outflows reaching $158.7 billion in December and $1 trillion last year, as speculators bet against the currency.

site_title: Investors cheer Argentina's swift offer to holdouts
summary: Argentina's new President Mauricio Macri offered a $6.5 billion payment to settle defaulted bonds, accepting a 25% discount, and two holdouts have already accepted the terms. Investors praise the swift offer, seeing it as a step towards resolving disputes and restoring foreign investors' confidence. However, obstacles remain, including approval from Congress, which Macri lacks a majority in, and potential demands from remaining holdouts for better terms. A deal is expected to boost Argentina's economy and improve its debt market prospects.

site_title: Twitter users cool toward mellow Coldplay ahead of Super Bowl
summary: Twitter users are mocking British rock band Coldplay ahead of the Super Bowl halftime show, criticizing the band's mellow ballads for not fitting the show's typical peppy atmosphere. The jokes were sparked by a push for the hashtag #BetterHalftimeShows, with some users suggesting alternative ideas, such as having players perform a skit. Despite this, some users are actually looking forward to the performance, including a Paralympic athlete. Twitter users have generated more than 182,000 tweets about Beyonce, who was confirmed as a performer earlier, compared to around 132,000 about Coldplay.

site_title: BlackBerry cuts jobs in Florida, Ontario in push to profit
summary: BlackBerry Ltd is cutting 75 jobs at its Florida office and a small number in Waterloo, Ontario, as part of its efforts to trim costs and become profitable. The company is shifting its focus to software and cutting costs after smartphone sales continue to decline. BlackBerry's stock fell 3% to $7.18, down 20% for the year. The company has pivoted to using Google's Android operating system instead of its own BB10.

site_title: New year, new travel: more Chinese choose tourism over tradition
summary: More Chinese are opting for tourism over traditional Lunar New Year celebrations, with over 30% of those planning a break citing a desire to "get far away from relatives" or find the holiday "boring". This trend is driven by rising individualism and financial independence, with many young Chinese choosing to spend the holiday abroad. The Chinese government estimates 2.91 billion trips will be taken during the holiday season, with 40% booked for tourist travel, up from 20% two years ago.

site_title: Crew of hijacked Singapore-registered vessel, Safmarine Kuramo released
summary: The crew of the Singapore-registered container vessel Safmarine Kuramo, hijacked off the Nigerian Coast earlier this week, were released unharmed on Saturday following efforts by Nigerian authorities. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) reported the incident on Friday night, and the crew was later released. The exact circumstances surrounding the hijacking are not specified.

site_title: Qatar Airways seeks high-potential deals
summary: Qatar Airways is open to taking stakes in airlines requiring investment to reach full potential, according to chief commercial officer Hugh Dunleavy. The airline views ultra-profitable airlines like British Airways as candidates for partnerships, but also considers smaller operators. Meridiana SpA, an Italian airline, has held discussions with ministers about industrial partnerships, prompting comparisons with Etihad Airways. If a deal is made, it would be Qatar's first investment in a smaller airline.

site_title: Top cybercrime ring disrupted as authorities raid Moscow offices: sources
summary: Russian authorities raided offices associated with a Moscow film distribution and production company, 25th Floor, in November as part of a crackdown on a notorious financial hacking operation, believed to be responsible for tens of millions of dollars in losses at financial institutions. The password-stealing software program, Dyre, has not been deployed since the raid, and experts say the case represents Russia's biggest effort to date to crack down on cybercrime. A number of people were questioned by authorities, but details remain unclear, with no official confirmation of arrests or criminal charges.

site_title: Speculators cut net US dollar longs to lowest since week of Oct 20: CFTC
summary: Speculators cut US dollar longs to their lowest level since October 20, with net longs dropping to $18.20 billion, down from $23.85 billion in the previous week. This marks the first time in 15 weeks that net dollar longs fell below $20 billion. The move is attributed to concerns over external market stress, including a slowdown in China and decline in oil prices, which could slow the Federal Reserve's tightening policy.

site_title: Quake fells Taiwan apartment tower, two reported killed so far
summary: A powerful 6.4-magnitude earthquake struck southern Taiwan, toppling a 17-story apartment building where over 100 people are feared trapped. Two people, including an infant girl, have been killed, and at least 26 are injured. Rescuers are working to reach survivors, using dogs, acoustic equipment, and hydraulic ladders to navigate the rubble. The quake, centered 27 miles southeast of Tainan, was followed by several aftershocks, and several other buildings have been damaged in the city of 2 million people.

site_title: Technology shares plunge in US as patience for valuations ebbs
summary: US technology shares plummeted on Friday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index falling to its lowest since October 2014, as investors lost patience with high price-earnings ratios. The Nasdaq 100 Index dropped 3.4%, while the S&P 500 Index fell 1.9%, led by declines in data analytics firms and tech giants like Facebook and Salesforce. The sell-off was triggered by mixed economic data, including a report showing job growth settled into a more sustainable pace, but also a drop in the unemployment rate.

site_title: Update: Five dead after powerful Taiwan quake fells buildings
summary: A 6.4-magnitude earthquake struck Taiwan, killing at least five people and trapping over 30 in the rubble of a 16-storey apartment complex in Tainan. The complex, which housed over 100 families, collapsed during Lunar New Year celebrations, with reports of widespread destruction and gas leaks. Rescue efforts are ongoing, with over 200 people freed and 40 hospitalized. Officials fear more people may be trapped, as many families had planned to return for the upcoming holiday.

images.alt_text: A powerful earthquake in Taiwan felled a 16-storey apartment complex full of families who had gathered for Lunar New Year celebrations in the early hours of Saturday, with at least five dead and more than 30 feared trapped.

site_title: Oil falls in volatile trade ahead of key oil producer meeting
summary: Oil prices ended the week lower, snapping two weeks of gains, as speculation about a possible deal between top oil producers clashed with concerns about a growing supply glut. A key meeting between Venezuelan and Saudi oil ministers on Sunday is seen as "make or break" for a possible OPEC deal. Despite a brief rally, prices fell 40 US cents to $34.06 a barrel, with US crude futures closing 83 US cents lower at $30.89 a barrel. Concerns about a global supply glut and oversupply have returned, with only 100,000 barrels per day of oil production shut in globally.

site_title: Twitter shuts down 125,000 accounts for promoting terrorism
summary: Twitter has suspended over 125,000 accounts for promoting or threatening terrorism since the middle of last year, following meetings with government officials to address the spread of Islamic State influence on the platform. The company has increased its review teams and cooperated with law enforcement, condemning the use of Twitter for promoting terrorism. This proactive stance marks a shift for Twitter, which typically removes content after it's flagged by users. The administration welcomed the move as a constructive step in combating terrorism.

images.alt_text: [SAN FRANCISCO] Twitter Inc said it suspended more than 125,000 accounts since the middle of last year for promoting or threatening terrorism, marking its progress after several meetings with high-level government officials about the spread of influence from the Islamic State.

site_title: WikiLeaks' Assange detained arbitrarily, says UN panel
summary: A UN panel ruled that WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange should be released from the Ecuadorian embassy in London, where he has been detained for over three years, and awarded compensation for his arbitrary detention. The panel found that Assange's rights were infringed upon, despite Ecuador and Britain denying that he was being deprived of freedom. The decision is not binding, but the UN Working Group on Arbitrary Detention said his physical integrity and freedom of movement should be respected and he should receive compensation.

site_title: Bridgewater's top leaders call for votes on each other: WSJ
summary: Ray Dalio, founder of Bridgewater Associates, is reportedly spitting with co-CEO Greg Jensen over behavior and has asked employees to vote on Jensen's integrity. Dalio claims Jensen said things about him in meetings without discussing it first, but Jensen disputes this, calling the dispute "healthy." The issue arises as Bridgewater is halfway through a 10-year succession plan, with Dalio and Jensen sharing CEO roles. The dispute has sparked a vote among management and stakeholder committees on Jensen's integrity, a move that reflects Dalio's efforts to promote a culture of honesty.

site_title: Beware festive indulgences
summary: A Chinese New Year article advises individuals, especially those with diabetes, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia, to limit their consumption of traditional festive foods to avoid negative health effects. These foods can cause blood sugar surges, insulin resistance, and weight gain. The article also warns of the impact on patients with depression, reflux, and heartburn, and encourages readers to prioritize healthy lifestyle choices and seek professional help if needed.

site_title: US, India in talks to settle solar power trade dispute
summary: The US and India are in talks to settle a long-running solar power trade dispute, delaying the World Trade Organization's (WTO) announcement of a ruling. The US had filed a WTO challenge in 2013, claiming India's national solar program discriminated against imported solar panels. Talks aim to reach an out-of-court resolution before the WTO's public announcement, which was initially scheduled for next Wednesday. The US and India have been in discussions, following a confidential WTO dispute settlement panel's ruling that would likely favor the US.

site_title: Economists, RBI devise models to better track India's GDP
summary: Economists and the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) are developing alternative models to track India's GDP, citing concerns over the accuracy of official data. Despite official projections of 7.3% growth for the October-December quarter, many experts believe the economy is experiencing a slowdown, with weak sales, slow bank lending, and investment. Hybrid models combining old and new GDP methods are being used to get a better understanding of the economy's underlying health, with some estimates suggesting annualized growth of 5-6%.

site_title: Xtra Efficient
summary: Jaguar has introduced the XE 2.0D, a highly economical two-litre turbodiesel-powered sedan. The engine produces 180 hp and 430 Newton-metres of torque, while consuming 4.2 litres per 100 kilometres and 109 gram per km of carbon dioxide. The XE 2.0D boasts a refined and quiet turbodiesel unit, a sophisticated suspension system, and a well-balanced handling. However, it experiences slight turbo lag and has a slightly soft suspension, which can be mitigated with the Dynamic driving mode or paddle shifts.

site_title: Indonesian economy gains speed in Q4 with 5.04% growth
summary: Indonesia's economy grew 5.04% in the fourth quarter, exceeding expectations, driven by higher public spending and infrastructure investment. This marks the fastest growth in a year and suggests the worst may be over. The government's stimulus measures, including tax breaks and increased capital spending, are expected to boost momentum. Analysts predict steady growth improvement this year after a five-year slowdown.

site_title: UE jumps 10% on subsidiary sale
summary: United Engineers (UE) shares surged 10% after the company agreed to sell its indirectly-owned subsidiary MultiFineline Electronix (MFlex) for US$23.95 per share, yielding S$505m in net proceeds. The disposal will be done through a merger with Suzhou Dongshan Precision Manufacturing, and is expected to close in Q3 2016. UE expects to realise an attributable net disposal gain of about S$115.2 million. The transaction is part of UE's plan to streamline its businesses and exit non-strategic operations.

site_title: Noble's bank debt prices show investors think worst isn't over
summary: Noble Group's bank debt prices have dropped to 75 US cents on the dollar, indicating investors' concern that the company's financial issues may not be fully resolved. The decline in debt prices is attributed to the company's rating cut to junk by Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's, as well as concerns over its ability to refinance its debt and improve its liquidity. The company's credit lines are trading at high yields, and investors are signaling that the worst may not be over for the commodities trader.

site_title: Karhoo taxi-booking app registers with LTA
summary: Karhoo, a New York-based ride-booking app, has successfully registered with Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) to operate a third-party taxi-booking service. The app will launch in Singapore, New York, and London, and will only work with licensed taxi and limousine firms. Karhoo has partnered with taxi firm Prime to add its fleet to the platform, and will offer on-demand rides with accredited drivers. The registration comes under a new regulatory framework to safeguard commuters using such services, with Uber and other apps also being assessed by the LTA.

site_title: Salted but not sated
summary: Irvin Gunawan, a 30-year-old Indonesian-born entrepreneur, has created a successful business with his Salted Egg Potato Chips (and fish skin) in Singapore. The snack, which he developed with a blank canvas and stumbled upon, has become a viral sensation, with sales multiplying by five or six times since its launch. Despite the success, Gunawan remains vigilant about maintaining the quality of his products, which are still made in-house. He plans to expand production but promises to prioritize quality, aiming to be like Apple by focusing on one product at a time.

site_title: RBA forecasts faster growth, lower jobless
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) maintained its forecast of accelerating growth in Australia, driven by low interest rates and petrol prices, despite concerns about China's economic slowdown. The RBA trimmed its inflation forecast and kept interest rates unchanged at 2% for the ninth month, citing a depreciating local dollar that increases the competitiveness of local industries. The central bank expressed uncertainty about China's growth, citing risks of sharp slowing in economic activity or increase in financial stresses that could spill over to other economies in the region.

site_title: McDonald's edging out KFC, Pizza Hut in China revival battle
summary: McDonald's is outpacing rival KFC and Pizza Hut in China's revival battle, with same-store sales rising 4% in the fourth quarter, a second straight quarter of growth. Yum Brands, the parent company of KFC and Pizza Hut, is struggling to recover from a series of food safety scandals in 2012, which left annual China sales falling for the first time. McDonald's advantage lies in China's lingering sensitivity towards chicken products, which has contributed to its faster recovery, with sales now above 95% of pre-scandal levels, while Yum's sales are below 80%.

site_title: Airline battle brews in Persian Gulf as Iran eyes regional hub role
summary: Iran is investing $27 billion in an airline fleet, positioning Teheran as a potential long-term transit point between East and West, rivaling regional hubs like Dubai. The move is seen as a signal to regional rivals that Iran aims to compete for transit passengers. Iran's order of dozens of long-distance European jets comes after the lifting of sanctions, and analysts predict an economic battle for dominance in the skies over the Persian Gulf.

site_title: Song wins S'pore Open
summary: Song Young Han won the US$1 million SMBC Singapore Open golf tournament with a 12-under-par 272, defeating Jordan Spieth who finished second. Spieth, making his first appearance in Singapore, had a birdie putt on the 18th on Sunday but was unable to overcome Song's consistent play. Song's victory earned him his first professional tour title and a world ranking rise from 204th to 113th.

site_title: The plunging oil price - why and what it means
summary: The global oil price has plummeted due to a surge in supply relative to demand, encouraging fuel efficiencies and new oil sources. This is similar to past responses to sharp oil price rises in the 1970s. The current decline may be nearing its bottom, with prices potentially falling to US$20/barrel, but could also push down further to US$20. The negative impact on producers is likely to predominate, but a lower oil price will eventually boost economic growth in developed countries and benefit energy-importing nations in Asia.

site_title: Grey hair's the in thing now
summary: Millennial men are embracing grey hair as a fashion statement, dyeing their hair silver or platinum to adopt a youthful, edgy look. Inspired by celebrities like Zayn Malik and Gus Kenworthy, who have publicly shown off their grey hair, the trend is gaining traction, with a three-fold increase in searches for grey hair dye on Amazon. Stylists estimate the process can cost up to $600 and requires regular maintenance. The trend is seen as a bold way to express oneself and stand out from the crowd, but its sustainability is uncertain, with some predicting it's just a fad.

site_title: Optimum package
summary: The new Kia Optima boasts a stronger bodyshell, more premium materials, and a more spacious cabin. The car's exterior design is subtle, with a sleeker front end and wrap-around headlamps, while its interior features a cleaner and more upscale design. The Optima's ride comfort is improved, with better bump absorption and vehicle stability, thanks to its new platform and chassis. The car's performance is adequate, but lacks low-end oomph, with a 2.0L naturally aspirated engine and a 6-speed automatic transmission. With its attractive pricing, the Optima is a good combination of quality, features, and price.

site_title: China Minzhong's Q2 profit falls 60% to 29m yuan
summary: China Minzhong Food Corp reported a 60% decline in Q2 net profit to 29.1 million yuan, due to foreign exchange losses and an impairment in receivables. Revenue dipped 2% to 523.5 million yuan, mainly affected by a drop in sales from its vegetable and mushroom spores cultivation unit and beverage business. The company attributed the decline to a timing difference in mushroom spores trading and an economic slowdown in the beverage business. The main blow to its bottom line came from increased other expenses and foreign exchange losses.

site_title: Deutsche Bank leads new worry about lenders' credit risk
summary: Deutsche Bank is facing growing concerns about its ability to repay debt due to falling energy prices, which could lead to substantial losses. Analysts predict a 1.14 billion euros increase in loan loss provisions, surpassing the average forecast of 19%. The bank's junior subordinated debt has plummeted, and credit-default swaps are also experiencing a significant decline. This trend is not limited to Deutsche Bank, with other major banks such as HSBC and Standard Chartered also facing similar concerns, particularly due to their exposure to Chinese corporate loans.

images.alt_text: TOUGH TIMES: Deutsche Bank, which may have significant energy exposure that's not well secured, is struggling in the face of falling debt-trading profits and an unclear strategy for increasing income.

site_title: Travellers hit the road on CNY long weekend
summary: Singaporeans are taking advantage of the long Chinese New Year (CNY) weekend to embark on extended vacations, with travel demand flying high. Airlines have added more services, and travel agents report a 10-20% increase in bookings. Top destinations include Japan, Europe, Australia, and China, as well as regional cruises. To capitalize on the long weekend, some travelers are taking 7-11 day trips, while others are opting for cruises and travel packages that incorporate CNY festivities.

site_title: Cameron boosted in bid to avert 'Brexit' as Poles are satisfied
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron secured support from Poland's ruling party leader Jaroslaw Kaczynski, paving the way for a potential deal on Britain's EU membership. Kaczynski expressed satisfaction with a plan allowing Britain to cut welfare benefits for new migrants, while securing guarantees for Poles living in the UK. The agreement is crucial for Cameron's bid to hold a UK referendum on EU membership by June 23, with a recent poll showing a nine percentage-point lead for those seeking "Brexit".

site_title: SGH campus to get makeover under 20-year masterplan
summary: Singapore General Hospital (SGH) will undergo a 20-year redevelopment, tripling patient care space and integrating medical care, research, and education. The hospital will relocate to the Outram Road and Eu Tong Sen Street area, nearer the Outram Park MRT station, to provide more convenient access. The new campus will feature a Research Park, a National Cancer Centre, and an Elective Care Centre, increasing capacity in targeted areas like cancer and diabetes. The redevelopment aims to provide patient-centric care and strengthen capabilities through collaboration with industry partners.

site_title: New golf goodies on the market
summary: New golf products have been released in the market, including FootJoy's FreeStyle golf shoes, Titleist's Pro V1 and Pro V1x golf balls, and Titleist's Vokey Design SM6 wedges. The new FootJoy shoes offer superior traction and comfort, while the Titleist balls provide more short game control and long-lasting durability. The Titleist wedges feature a groundbreaking Progressive Center of Gravity design for precise distance and trajectory control. Meanwhile, TaylorMade Golf's M2 Collection includes drivers, fairways, rescue clubs, and irons with a focus on forgiveness and ball speed protection.

site_title: Tiger Airways to delist as SIA raises stake over 90%
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) has acquired over 93% of Tiger Airways, enabling it to successfully delist the budget carrier. SIA initially offered 41 cents per share, but raised it to 45 cents after minority shareholders expressed dissatisfaction. The offer closes on Feb 19, and if accepted, shares will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange, leaving shareholders with unlisted stock. SIA believes integrating Tiger will improve the carrier's future growth prospects in a challenging operating environment.

site_title: Outdoor spreads
summary: Several restaurants in Singapore are offering picnic baskets for outdoor spreads. Options include Sunrise Bistro & Bar's seafood basket ($140), Prive's charcuterie and pastry basket ($40), Casa Verde's simple picnic basket ($30), and Heaven's Bloom & Baskets' customizable baskets ($238-$268). Balzac Brasserie offers artisanal bread with cold cuts or cheeses ($98), while Hotel Fort Canning's weekend package includes a picnic basket with Asian-inspired snacks ($760).

site_title: Singtel rally helps trim STI's loss to 6 pts for week
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) experienced a volatile week, with a 2.5% gain on Friday to close at 2,623.21, reducing its weekly loss to six points. Singtel's 6.3% surge contributed to the index's gain. Despite the strong bounce, dealers reported "very quiet" activity, and heightened short-selling and short-covering added to market swings. The US Federal Reserve's uncertainty on interest rate hikes and China's manufacturing contraction also weighed on the market.

site_title: Picture perfect picnics
summary: A new service, Picneeds, offers bespoke picnic planning, setting up the trimmings, and cleanup, starting at S$150 for a basic package. The company, founded by 29-year-old Khairul Amri, aims to cater to busy couples and families who want a hassle-free picnic experience. Meanwhile, indoor picnic service ANDSOFORTH offers secret supper events with air-conditioning, a theatrical set, and food prepared by chef Jason Ang. Other services, such as Extreme Picnic and Bar Canary, also offer unique picnic experiences, including vegan options and gourmet meals.

site_title: US added 151,000 jobs in January
summary: US employers added 151,000 jobs in January, easing concerns of a recession, despite a slowdown from the previous year's surge. The unemployment rate fell to 4.9% from 5% in December, suggesting modest strength in the economy. The US has gained nearly 14 million jobs since 2010, with steady hiring in sectors like professional services and construction. The Federal Reserve's decision to raise short-term interest rates in December appears to have had a positive impact, but markets remain cautious due to global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Jho Low's private banker earned S$27 million in last 4 years
summary: A senior private banker at Swiss bank BSI, Yak Yew Chee, earned S$27 million in the last four years, with S$6.4 million in salary and bonuses last year alone. Chee's accounts were frozen by Singapore's Commercial Affairs Department in September due to ongoing investigations into his client, Malaysian tycoon Jho Low, linked to the 1MDB scandal. Chee's lawyer withdrew a motion to unfreeze his accounts after the public prosecutor confirmed he could remit S$1.76 million to settle tax and legal matters.

site_title: Obama seeks to impose new fee on oil companies
summary: President Barack Obama's budget request to Congress includes a new fee of US$10 per barrel on oil companies to generate up to US$32 billion in annual revenue. The funds will be spent on transportation and infrastructure projects, including bridges, highways, high-speed rail, and research on advanced vehicles.

site_title: Forever festive
summary: A Chinese New Year fashion guide advises against buying festive, yet impractical, outfits that only get worn once. Instead, strike a balance between traditional and modern elements to create a timeless look. Designers recommend mixing traditional motifs like peonies and bright red with non-traditional elements, such as modern Asian-inspired accessories, to achieve a stylish and auspicious look that can be worn every day. Affordable options include accessories like jade jewelry and oriental-inspired clothing from local brands and high-fashion labels like Dries Van Noten and Comme de Garcon.

site_title: House-proud Koreans embrace decor as IKEA, rivals tap singles
summary: IKEA's largest South Korean store opened in 2014, tapping into the country's growing demand for home furnishings. Local market leader Hanssem saw a 31% increase in revenue and a doubling of its share price in 2015, while Shinsegae's Jaju chain expanded its stores. The success of these home furnishing chains is seen as a bright spot in South Korea's sluggish economy, driven by the rising number of people living alone and spending on home decor.

site_title: Luxury retailers face a new reality in HK
summary: Hong Kong's luxury retail sector is facing a double-digit decline in sales due to Chinese shoppers diverting their holidays and discretionary spend elsewhere. After a decade of unprecedented growth, the number of mainland Chinese visitors to Hong Kong has declined, with sales plummeting to an extent last seen during the SARS crisis in 2002. Factors contributing to this decline include the Chinese government's anti-corruption campaign, mounting cultural tension, and changes in travel patterns and consumer sophistication. Luxury goods companies are responding by rationalizing store networks and negotiating lower rents with landlords, but the decline in tourism and retail sales is seen as structural.

site_title: Yusheng and CNY dinners still popular
summary: Demand for yusheng, a traditional Chinese New Year dish made with shredded vegetables and raw fish, remains high in Singapore despite concerns over raw fish due to a Group B Streptococcus (GBS) bacteria outbreak. Restaurants report a 5-15% increase in yusheng sales, with some offering substitutes like abalones, lobsters, or clams. Many restaurants are also selling saltwater fish like salmon, which is considered safer. Despite a sluggish economy, reunion dinners remain popular, with many restaurants fully booked on CNY eve and a significant increase in takeout orders.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CapitaLand's serviced residences arm, The Ascott Holdings, sold its 154-unit Somerset ZhongGuanCun Beijing to Hong Kong Qianhai Zhongjin Group for S$125 million. Roxy-Pacific Holdings acquired the leasehold interests in the Kudafunafaru island in the Maldives for US$31 million. These sales are part of CapitaLand's strategy to enhance capital productivity and pursue other projects.

site_title: Spruce up your abode
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Three Singaporean retailers offer unique home decor items: Lovera Collections, founded by self-confessed crockery hoarder Vera Ong, sells colorful, food-safe plates; Studio Asobi creates handmade ceramic pieces, including sake sets and vases, after Lee Huiwen and Kenneth Lau trained in Japan; and Make History allows users to create their own history using physical items, such as TimeCapsules and Treasure Tins; and DesignerBox delivers unique, design-focused home accessories created by international designers. Each retailer aims to bring personality and style to customers' homes, with a focus on quality and aesthetics.

site_title: Fallen angels incoming as US$23b of China bonds near junk
summary: China's economic slowdown prompts rating agencies to downgrade more investment-grade issuers to junk, with US$22.6 billion of offshore bonds now rated one step above junk. The downgrade trend is expected to continue, with some 40% of 2015 downgrades on China credits happening in the fourth quarter. This has significant implications for investors, with funds with high-grade mandates forced to reduce junk holdings and investors needing to do more fundamental work on those names. China's central bank steps up support for the property market with a new mortgage downpayment policy, but experts warn of deteriorating credit quality for Chinese companies.

site_title: Apsil to acquire Century 21 (AsPac)
summary: Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments Ltd (Apsil) has acquired Century 21 (AsPac) Pte Ltd, strengthening its agent strength in real estate. The merger will bring the total headcount under the C21 brand to 1,100 agents in Singapore, with a goal of reaching 2,000 agents by the end of the year. The combined sales force of GAP and Century 21 franchisee offices will make Apsil the seventh largest agency in Singapore by headcount. The acquisition is part of Apsil's new core business in real estate, exiting its loss-making bereavement care services business.

site_title: New lease of life
summary: Steven Chai and Christine Loh, a couple from Singapore, have renovated their 3-bedroom apartment to celebrate Chinese New Year. The renovated space features a mix of eclectic and industrial design, with a focus on natural elements like florals, bamboo, and artificial turf. The couple has also incorporated symbolic items, such as a monkey plush toy and figurines with auspicious messages. With the help of designer Mike Tan, they have created a warm and inviting space that reflects their personal style.

The dining table is placed right by these windows; decorative items placed around the home for Chinese New Year include chocolate in the shape of gold ingots, a monkey plush toy and figurines carrying banners that say Gong Xi Fa Cai.
This year, the couple have included table arrangements such as azaleas (above), and bamboo plants and artificial fronds.

site_title: Cortina's Q3 profit down 1.2% at S$2.8m
summary: Cortina Holdings, a Singaporean luxury watch retailer, reported a 1.2% decline in Q3 net profit to S$2.76 million, driven by a slowdown in the Chinese economy. Revenue remained flat at S$97.7 million, while overall expenses rose marginally. For the nine-month period, net profit fell 17.8% to S$7 million due to lower tourist arrivals and reduced spending. The company expects to remain profitable despite the challenging business environment, citing a shrinking demand for luxury brands as the Chinese economy slows.

site_title: SIA jumps to 6-month high of S$11.24 as profit tops analyst estimates
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a 36% increase in quarterly net income to S$274.9 million, beating analyst estimates, as lower fuel prices attracted more passengers with cheaper fares. The airline's stock rose 3.9% to S$11.24, its highest close since July 29. SIA boosted seat occupancy to 80% from 78% a year earlier, despite losing S$72 million in fuel hedges and S$77 million from a weakening currency. Fuel prices have fallen 39% in the past 12 months, contributing to the improved earnings.

site_title: Hong Kong approves leveraged ETFs while warning of risks
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission has authorized leveraged and inverse exchange-traded funds (ETFs), while warning investors of potential risks. The regulator introduced conditions for firms offering these products to "protect the interests of Hong Kong's investing public." Leveraged ETFs use derivatives to amplify gains or losses, while inverse ETFs allow traders to profit from falling markets. Margin financing for these ETFs will be allowed, but exchange participants are advised not to provide it to investors. The move comes amid criticism from regulators in the US, where BlackRock and the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority have warned of their dangers.

site_title: Super Bowl home rental prices not meeting high hopes
summary: San Francisco Bay Area residents renting out their homes for Super Bowl 50 are facing disappointment, with some listings going unsold despite high prices. Vacation rental companies like Airbnb and HomeAway report brisk business, but most expensive listings remain empty. The average Airbnb host is expected to make around $1,000 for the entire event, far from the $10,000-per-night price some homeowners had hoped for. As the game approaches, prices are being reduced, with some listings dropping to $1,500-$2,500 per night.

site_title: Bank of England cuts inflation forecast in 'unforgiving' environment
summary: The Bank of England has cut its inflation forecast to 0.8% for 2016, citing a turbulent global economy. The Monetary Policy Committee voted 9-0 to keep interest rates on hold, with a sole dissenter, Ian McCafferty, reversing his call for higher borrowing costs. Governor Mark Carney said the UK's economy is "unforgiving" and that officials will wait for inflation to return to the 2% target before increasing interest rates. The forecast suggests inflation will only reach 2% in 2018, and the bank is unlikely to raise interest rates until the third quarter of 2018.

site_title: SGX conducts review after finding big role by group in Zhongmin's buy volume
summary: SGX is reviewing trading in Zhongmin Baihui Retail Group after discovering a small group of individuals accounted for over 90% of buy volume in the stock since October 2015. Despite broader market declines, Zhongmin Baihui's shares have remained stable, rarely closing lower than S$1.76. The exchange urges investors to exercise caution, citing a possible connection among the individuals involved. SGX will review the trades and take necessary actions.

site_title: Singtel surges more than 6% in active trade
summary: Singtel shares surged more than 6% in active trade on February 5, 2016, with the telco closing at S$3.70 after buying airwaves in Australia's 1800 MHz spectrum band for A$196 million. The move helped the Straits Times Index trade higher, bucking regional trends. Analysts speculate that the jump could be due to positioning ahead of Singtel's earnings release or a flurry of interest in defensive plays, as rival telcos also rose sharply in the past few days.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% amid market uncertainty, with investors weighing tariffs, sanctions, and market outlook. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while Europe's stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector concerns. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and similar operating loss in H2. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Sharp shows Japan Inc may be more open to foreign interest
summary: Sharp Corp has opted for Taiwan's Foxconn as its preferred suitor, paving the way for the biggest foreign takeover of a Japanese tech company at around $5.6 billion. This move is seen as a shift in Japan's insular technology sector, driven by a shift in political thinking and a drive for improved corporate governance. The decision is also seen as a step towards boosting foreign direct investment in Japan, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe aiming to double inbound foreign investment to $300 billion by 2020.

site_title: Buses lift SBS Transit's 2015 earnings
summary: SBS Transit reported a 17% increase in net earnings to S$16.7 million for the year ended Dec 31, 2015, driven by a 78.2% surge in bus operating profits to S$22 million. Revenue rose 7.7% to S$1.02 billion, with bus revenue increasing 7.5% to S$810.5 million. Rail operating profits slumped 61.9% to S$3.2 million due to higher staff costs and premises costs. The company attributed the bus profit increase to higher revenue and lower fuel costs.

site_title: GE to phase out compact fluorescent light bulbs
summary: General Electric (GE) plans to stop making and selling compact fluorescent light bulbs (CFLs) in the US by the end of the year, citing the rise of LED technology and customer preference. CFLs were once popular due to their energy efficiency, but their harsh light quality and mercury content led to consumer complaints. LED prices have dropped significantly, making them a more attractive option, with 15% of bulb shipments now being LEDs, up from 5% in 2014. Retailers are also moving away from CFLs due to upcoming Energy Star regulations.

site_title: China's 'teapots' eat into crude glut - but build Asian fuel surplus
summary: China's independent oil refiners, known as "teapots," are buying hundreds of thousands of barrels a day of crude oil at discounted prices, adding to China's fuel exports and swelling the global surplus. With quotas approved for over 1 million barrels per day, the teapots are expected to increase purchases further this year, locking in margins until oil prices rise above $40 a barrel. This is supported by Beijing's freeze on domestic pump prices, and the refiners are preparing to export fuel to April, with weak domestic demand potentially forcing them to export more.

site_title: Airbus in talks to delay some A320neo deliveries: sources
summary: Airbus is renegotiating delivery schedules for its A320neo jet, with some airlines told the aircraft will be delayed by around two months due to issues with Pratt & Whitney engines and Geared Turbofan engine deliveries. The European planemaker missed its 2015 target for delivering the first A320neo aircraft. Airbus and Pratt & Whitney are in talks with airlines over deliveries, but declined further comment.

site_title: Transamerica sees strong growth for universal life plans in Asia
summary: Transamerica Life (Bermuda) has seen strong growth in its universal life plans in Asia, with sales tripling over the past three years. The insurer attributes the growth to the region's robust wealth and high net worth individuals, who are seeking legacy planning and wealth preservation. Transamerica expects a 20% annual growth rate in the coming years, driven by the need for high net worth individuals to maintain and pass on their wealth. The company has strengthened its team and capabilities, positioning itself as a leader in jumbo deals and service.

site_title: Concern grows over China's chip ambition
summary: China is investing billions in domestic microchip production, potentially bolstering its military capabilities and technology industry. US officials blocked a $2.9 billion Philips deal due to concerns over Chinese acquisition of advanced semiconductor material gallium nitride, which has military and space applications. The material is key to creating powerful microchips, including those used in radar systems for anti-ballistic missiles. The US government views China's efforts as a national security risk, citing concerns over the theft of trade secrets and recruitment of engineers knowledgeable about the material.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as US employment gains drop
summary: US stocks opened lower after data showed employment gains slowed in January, contradicting a previous boost from warm weather. The Dow Jones fell 3.9 points, the S&P 500 lost 3.89 points, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 18.34 points. The decline follows a recent record high, amid ongoing US-EU trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia's Dec export growth below forecast
summary: Malaysia's exports grew 1.4% in December, below the forecast of 5% and the November growth of 6.3%. The slowdown in demand for commodities, particularly in China, Malaysia's largest trade partner, is largely to blame. Shipments of liquefied natural gas fell 36.7% and electronics and electrical products grew 6.4%. Despite a marginal increase in exports in 2015, the country's economy is expected to moderate this year, and the central bank may provide more policy support to counter weak exports.

site_title: LeapFrog to be bought by VTech in shake-up for toy industry
summary: LeapFrog Enterprises Inc, a maker of children's electronics, will be acquired by Hong Kong's VTech Holdings Ltd for approximately $72 million. The acquisition is a 75% premium over LeapFrog's last closing price. LeapFrog, which struggled to compete in the educational electronics market, will help VTech tighten its grip on the category. The deal is seen as part of a larger consolidation in the toy industry, following speculation of a potential merger between Mattel Inc and Hasbro Inc.

site_title: Los Angeles shows the way on chic menswear
summary: Los Angeles is gaining recognition as a hub for chic menswear, driven by the city's garment industry, celebrity influence, and creative talent. Designers such as CWST, Chapter, John Elliott, and Stampd are redefining surfwear and streetwear with a "made in Los Angeles" vibe, characterized by ease, drapiness, and a casual touch. The city's mild climate and laid-back lifestyle are also influencing the trend, which prioritizes elegance with comfort and a touch of California cool. This shift is seen as a response to the traditional suit and tie uniform, and is being driven by the city's lower living costs and abundance of creative talent.

site_title: More profit warnings on Friday
summary: Several Singapore-listed firms issued profit warnings on Friday, citing factors such as a slowdown in Chinese projects, increased labor costs, and lower revenue. Far East Group, HG Metal Manufacturing, and SBI Offshore warned of a net loss for the financial year ended December 31, 2015, citing specific reasons including deferred or cancelled orders, asset impairment, and unrealized foreign exchange losses. The warnings are part of a trend of more profit warnings from Singapore-listed firms.

site_title: Bond rally defies bear pack as record low yields keep on coming
summary: Investor demand for bonds remains strong, defying economists' predictions of rising yields. Record low yields were recorded in Germany, Japan, and the US, with 10-year yields touching 0.035% in Japan and 1.84% in the US. The rally is attributed to uneven US economic growth and concerns over a smaller-than-expected employment number. Economists project the US 10-year yield to rise to 2.24% by March 31, but the odds of a further rate increase in 2016 are less than 50%.

site_title: Loss-making oil fields unlikely to be shut willingly: Wood Mackenzie
summary: Industry research group Wood Mackenzie finds that only 100,000 barrels of oil (0.1%) out of 96.1 million barrels globally have been shut since price plunge, with most closures in Canada's oil sands, conventional US projects, and ageing fields in Britain's North Sea. Despite being "cash negative" at current prices, many producers will continue to operate, as restarting production is costly and they hope for a rebound in prices.

site_title: VW postpones 2015 results, AGM as scandal effects unclear
summary: Volkswagen has postponed publication of its 2015 results and annual shareholders' meeting due to the ongoing effects of the emissions test-rigging scandal. The carmaker will set new dates for its annual press conference and shareholders' meeting, with new dates to be announced. VW expects an operating group result before special items to be at the level of the prior year, within the expected range for fiscal 2015. The company is still grappling with the aftermath of the scandal, which has led to widespread criticism and regulatory scrutiny.

site_title: SIA raises stake in Tiger Airways to over 93%
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) has raised its stake in Tiger Airways to over 93% through a series of share purchases, allowing it to delist the budget carrier from the Singapore Exchange. SIA initially offered 41 Singapore cents per share, increasing it to 45 cents after long-term minority shareholders complained. Tiger Airways' initial public offering took place at S$1.50 per share. The move will enable SIA to acquire full control of the low-cost carrier.

site_title: China M&A flurry drives cross-border activity to 11-year high
summary: China has driven a surge in cross-border mergers and acquisitions, with worldwide activity reaching US$132.7 billion in 2016, a 31% increase from the previous year. Chinese acquisitions now account for 47% of overall cross-border deals. The largest-ever foreign purchase by a Chinese firm is ChemChina's US$43 billion acquisition of Swiss seeds and pesticides group Syngenta. This marks the strongest year-to-date period for cross-border M&A since 2006, driven by Chinese acquisitions and sluggish start to M&A activity globally.

site_title: SingPost appoints Drew & Napier as joint special auditor with PwC
summary: SingPost appoints Drew & Napier as joint special auditor with PwC to conduct a corporate governance probe amid public pressure. The law firm will lead the investigation alongside PwC, with Senior Counsel Hri Kumar at the helm. The decision aims to address concerns raised by shareholders and the public. SingPost shares rose after the announcement. The scope of work and terms of reference for the joint audit will be the same as those of PwC.

site_title: TNT to sell airlines to meet EU rules after FedEx acquisition
summary: TNT Express plans to sell its airline operations, TNT Airways and Pan Air Lineas Aereas, to ASL Aviation Group to comply with EU rules. The sale follows FedEx's 4.4 billion euro acquisition of TNT Express. EU rules prohibit foreign investors from owning more than 49% of a European airline and require control to remain in EU hands. ASL Aviation Group will continue to operate flights for TNT following the acquisition, with a fleet growth from 90 to 130 aircraft. The deal strengthens FedEx's position as the world's No.3 player in delivery services.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific to acquire resort property in the Maldives for US$31m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings has agreed to acquire the leasehold interests of the Kudafunafaru island in the Maldives for US$31 million. The acquisition will be financed by internal funds and bank borrowings, pending government approval. The deal involves Roxy Hotels and Resorts obtaining head leasehold interest in the property, along with its assets and economic interests. The acquisition is subject to regulatory approval from the government of Maldives.

site_title: Showdown in Europe over privacy has US firms ducking for cover
summary: US companies are re-evaluating their data transfer practices with the European Union's "Privacy Shield" agreement facing uncertainty due to a belated deal between EU and US officials. The agreement aims to provide legal cover for cross-border data transfers but regulators in Europe are gearing up to enforce tough privacy laws, and activists predict further challenges. Companies, including Google and Facebook, are racing to find alternatives, such as stricter data-handling policies or leasing data centers in Europe. The agreement's approval process is expected to be lengthy, and its long-term viability is uncertain.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported Q3 results, guiding for continued "pressure on loads and yields" due to low fuel prices and investment bank retrenchments. However, SIA's average fuel cost hedges are falling, and cost savings are gaining the upper hand. Citi Research downgraded SIA to "Sell" with a target price of S$10.15, citing a target ex-cash price to earnings ratio of 13.4 times. In contrast, CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) maintained a "Buy" call with a target price of S$1.69, citing its attractive valuations and financial flexibility.

site_title: CapitaLand unit to divest a Beijing serviced apartment
summary: CapitaLand's wholly-owned unit, The Ascott Holdings, has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to dispose of its Beijing serviced apartment property for S$125 million. The buyer is Hong Kong Qianhai Zhongjin Group Co. The sale is part of CapitaLand's strategy to enhance capital productivity and strengthen its capability to pursue other projects. The transaction is expected to enhance returns for its shareholders.

site_title: FSL Trust divests vessels to pare debt
summary: FSL Trust, a ship leasing company, has divested two containerships, generating US$10.8 million in proceeds. The majority of the proceeds will be used to pare down its outstanding debt, reducing quarterly loan repayments by US$320,000. The company will incur a US$4.2 million loss due to the vessel disposal, following a US$1 million writedown in Q4 2015. The decision was made to protect unitholder value in a challenging container market.

site_title: Trade gap in US widens as exports fall to four-year low
summary: The US trade deficit widened 2.7% to $43.4 billion in December, its largest since 2012. Weaker foreign sales and stable US domestic demand drove the increase. For 2015, the trade gap expanded 4.6% to $531.5 billion, surpassing the previous record in 2012. Imports rose 0.3% while exports declined 0.3% to $181.5 billion, the weakest since January 2012. The US now imports more from China than any other country, with combined exports and imports valued at $598.1 billion in 2015.

site_title: China Minzhong's Q2 profit drops 60%
summary: China Minzhong Food Corporation reported a 60% drop in Q2 profit to 29.1 million yuan, attributed to a foreign exchange loss and impairment of receivables. Revenue declined 2% to 523.5 million yuan, mainly due to decreased sales in its cultivation and branded businesses. The company expects challenges in its cultivation and processed business segments due to labor shortages and rising costs, but noted government support for agriculture and technology to boost food security.

site_title: SGX alleges dominance of connected individuals in recent buying of Zhongmin Baihui shares
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is reviewing trading in Zhongmin Baihui Retail Group due to concerns that a small group of connected individuals accounted for almost all the buy volume in the stock since October 2015. This group of individuals, responsible for over 90% of the on-market buy volume, appear to be connected to each other. SGX urges investors to exercise caution when dealing in the stock, which has remained relatively stable despite broader market declines.

site_title: TEHO International unit appoints Hotel Okura Co to operate hotel in Cambodia
summary: TEHO International Inc has appointed Hotel Okura Co to operate its hotel, The Okura Prestige Phnom Penh, in Cambodia. The hotel is part of TEHO's integrated development project, The Bay, which also includes upscale residential condominiums and retail space. Hotel Okura will provide technical services and assist with managing and operating the hotel.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.69 points to close at 1,662.46 on Friday, driven by gains of 388 stocks. However, 412 stocks declined in value. The trading volume reached 1.49 billion lots worth RM1.68 billion.

site_title: 6.3% jump in Singtel helps push STI up 2.5%
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 2.5% on Friday, driven by a 6.3% surge in Singtel, adding 20 points to the index. The index closed at 2,623.21, reducing its weekly loss to 6 points. Despite the bounce, dealers reported quiet activity, citing heightened short-selling and short-covering. This was attributed to concerns over a global slowdown and US interest rate hikes.

site_title: Cortina Holdings Q3 profit falls 1.2% with flat revenue growth
summary: Cortina Holdings reported a 1.2% decline in net profit for Q3 2015, to S$2.76 million, despite flat revenue growth of S$97.7 million. The retailer attributed the decline to a challenging global economy, particularly in Asia's luxury market, where demand is expected to shrink due to China's slowing economy. Despite this, Cortina Holdings expects to remain profitable for the current fiscal year.

site_title: Stamford Land reports lower profit for Q3
summary: Stamford Land Corp reported a 13.1% year-on-year drop in net profit to S$11.1 million for Q3FY16, due to lower revenue contributions across its businesses. Revenue declined 22.5% to S$52.52 million. The decline was attributed to the Australian dollar and New Zealand dollar. Despite this, the group expects hotel operations and development segments to perform in line with the comparable period last year. Capital expenditure plans include room refurbishment and enhancement of future revenue.

site_title: SBS Transit net earnings jump 17% to S$16.7m in FY15
summary: SBS Transit reported a 17% increase in net earnings to S$16.7 million for FY15, driven by a surge in bus operating profits. Revenue rose 7.7% to S$1.02 billion, with bus revenue increasing 7.5% to S$810.5 million. Rail operating profits plummeted 61.9% to S$3.2 million due to higher staff costs and other expenses. The company proposed a final dividend of 1.05 cents per share, unchanged from 2014.

site_title: Hot stock: United Engineers jumps 10% after news of subsidiary disposal
summary: United Engineers (UE) jumped 10% to S$1.94 after its trading halt was lifted, with 1.5 million shares traded. The surge was despite the halt not being lifted until after noontime, with trading volume three times higher than on Thursday.

site_title: APSIL to acquire Century 21 (AsPac) and merge it with unit Global Alliance Property
summary: APSIL, a Malaysian real estate firm, is acquiring Century 21 (AsPac) Pte Ltd and merging it with its unit Global Alliance Property (GAP) Pte Ltd. The acquisition, announced in a non-binding MOU, aims to strengthen APSIL's agent strength. The combined sales force of GAP and Century 21 will be 1,091 agents across 21 offices, making it the seventh-largest agency in Singapore. This follows APSIL's earlier acquisition of Century 21 Hong Kong and its divestment of its bereavement care services business.

site_title: China-backed development bank appoints five foreign vice presidents
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) appointed five foreign vice presidents, including Danny Alexander from Britain and Joachim von Amsberg from Germany, to strengthen its international presence and counter concerns over China's influence. The appointments follow vows by AIIB President Jin Liqun that the bank would be an international institution, not used to boost Beijing's influence. The move is seen as a diplomatic triumph for China, which opposes a global financial order dominated by the US. The AIIB aims to lend up to $15 billion annually, with an internal compliance department to ensure transparency.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries divests stake in China-based water facility operator
summary: Sembcorp Industries is selling its 49% stake in Yancheng China Water Co for 260 million yuan (S$55 million). The sale is part of a conditional agreement and is expected to result in a net gain of approximately S$35 million. Yancheng China Water operates a municipal water facility in Jiangsu, China, and the transaction will be completed upon completion of the agreement.

site_title: BlackRock finds value in battered state-owned Indian banks
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest money manager, has turned bullish on India's state-owned lenders, citing their undervalued state due to concerns over bad loans. The company's chief investment officer, S Naganath, believes that with a three-year view, the public sector banks will be very bullish. Indian state-owned lenders have seen their valuations hit a record low, with a gauge of 12 state-owned lenders trading at 0.52 times its book value, due to rising bad loans and a slower economic revival.

site_title: Mercedes January sales rise 20% on 52% China sales jump
summary: Mercedes-Benz reported a 20% increase in January sales to 150,814 vehicles, driven by a 52% rise in deliveries in China and a 63% increase in sports utility vehicle sales. This marks the 35th consecutive month of increased sales, with growth of 15.2% in Europe, 37.1% in Asia-Pacific, and flat growth in the US. The company's China sales jump is attributed to a strong demand for luxury vehicles in the region.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei falls for 4th day as strong yen hits; US jobs in focus
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average fell for a fourth day, dropping 1.3% to 16,819.59 points, amid concerns a stronger yen may squeeze exporters' earnings. Investors await US jobs data for clues on the Federal Reserve's policy outlook. Sharp Corp rose on buyout hopes, while the broader Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also declined.

site_title: Hot stock update: Singtel surges more than 6% in active trade
summary: Singtel shares surged more than 6% in active trade, fueling the Straits Times Index to trade higher. The telco closed 6.3% or 22 cents higher at S$3.70 after opening at S$3.51. In active trade, 47.7 million shares changed hands, contributing to the STI's 64.72-point or 2.53% increase to 2,623.21.

site_title: Just Eat boosts global presence with four online takeaway deals
summary: Just Eat, the UK's largest online takeaway marketplace, agreed to buy four online-takeaway food businesses from Rocket Internet for a total of 94.7 million pounds (S$193 million). The deals expand Just Eat's global presence in Spain, Italy, Brazil, and Mexico, where it already operates. The acquisitions are expected to increase earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization by 5 million pounds in 2017 and 10 million pounds in 2018, with aggregate orders growing by 83% in 2015.

site_title: China not going back to 'old road' of capital controls: forex regulator
summary: China will maintain its current approach to foreign exchange regulation, cracking down on illegal activities but avoiding a return to capital controls. According to SAFE head Pan Gongsheng, China's economic growth is stable, and the yuan is stable against a basket of currencies. The international balance of payments is also stable, with cross-border capital flow risks under control. This approach aims to balance economic growth with financial stability.

site_title: Asia-Europe container freight rates fall 8.1%: source
summary: Asia-Europe container freight rates fell 8.1% to $431 per 20-foot container in the week ended February 5, marking the fifth consecutive week of decline. This rate is considered loss-making for shipping companies. Rates also dropped 7.0% to Mediterranean ports, 4.8% to US West Coast, and 5.1% to US East Coast. Maersk Line's recent 61% drop in net profit for the third quarter highlights the impact of falling freight rates on the company.

site_title: Europe: BNP Paribas helps European shares rise before US jobs data
summary: European shares rose 0.3% to 1,297.69 points before a key US jobs report, driven by gains from BNP Paribas, which rose 4% after cutting investment banking costs and quitting some activities to boost profitability. However, ArcelorMittal fell 6% after raising $3 billion in fresh capital to reduce debt. The US jobs report is expected to provide clues on the Federal Reserve's monetary policy outlook.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares climb on oil rally, US gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.55% to close at 19,288.17, driven by a rally in energy firms following a pick-up in oil prices. In contrast, Shanghai and Shenzhen indices fell 0.63% and 1.15%, respectively. US stocks also gained, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite expectations of another interest rate hike. The gains were attributed to a decline in US interest rate expectations and a focus on US-EU trade talks.

site_title: CAD seized private banker's 12 bank accounts with nearly S$10m in 1MDB probe
summary: The Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) in Singapore seized 12 bank accounts belonging to senior private banker Yak Yew Chee, holding nearly S$10m, in connection with the 1MDB probe. Yak, 58, is linked to Malaysian tycoon Jho Low and entities linked to 1Malaysia Development Berhad. He was on paid leave from BSI Singapore and previously worked at RBS Coutts. CAD officer Wan Abdul Rahman Abdul Latiff confirmed the investigation into possible breaches of laws, and a judge granted Yak's request to withdraw his motion to lift the freeze on his accounts.

site_title: WikiLeaks' Assange to demand freedom as wins backing from UN panel
summary: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange will demand his freedom from the Ecuadorian embassy in London after a UN panel ruled that his detention was arbitrary. Assange has been holed up in the embassy since 2012 to avoid a rape investigation. The panel, composed of five independent experts, ruled in Assange's favor, stating that his rights had been infringed by being unable to take up asylum in Ecuador. The decision sets the stage for Assange to leave the embassy, potentially resolving the long-standing standoff.

site_title: China: Stocks close lower ahead of Lunar New Year
summary: China's stocks fell 0.7% on Friday, closing at 2,963.79, ahead of the Lunar New Year holiday. The decline was attributed to market views that government measures to raise investment ceilings for overseas investors would not lead to an immediate surge in foreign buying of Chinese equities. Trading was thin as many traders left for the holiday, and mainland markets will be closed next week.

site_title: How much global oil output halted due to low prices? Just 0.1%
summary: Global oil production has only decreased by 0.1% due to low prices since the beginning of 2015, according to a report by Wood Mackenzie Ltd. Despite low oil prices, major oil companies such as BP and Occidental Petroleum Corp. are not curbing production, with the US shale industry and slumping currencies in oil-rich countries contributing to the resilience. The report estimates that 100,000 barrels a day of production have been impacted by low prices, and another 3.4 million barrels a day are losing money at current prices.

site_title: Australia: Shares recoup losses as miners rally
summary: Australian shares recovered from two-week lows, ending almost unchanged at 4,976.2 points. A late rally in mining stocks offset losses in heavyweight banks and consumer stocks. New Zealand's benchmark index edged up 0.26% to 6,153.80. The benchmark fell 0.08% on Friday.

site_title: Flash: Motion filed by banker to 1MDB, Jho Low to lift the freeze on his bank accounts withdrawn in Singapore court
summary: A Singaporean court has allowed the unfreezing of nearly S$10 million in bank accounts belonging to private banker Tan Seang Kiang, who was linked to 1MDB, a Malaysian state development fund. The motion was filed by Tan, who was accused of laundering money for 1MDB. The court's decision comes after a motion was filed by Jho Low, the alleged mastermind behind the 1MDB scandal, to lift the freeze on Tan's bank accounts. The move is seen as a significant development in the ongoing 1MDB probe.

site_title: Toyota raises forecast for profit on surging SUV, Lexus sales
summary: Toyota Motor Corp raised its profit forecast, citing surging SUV and Lexus sales. The company now expects net income of 2.27 trillion yen, exceeding analyst predictions of 2.25 trillion yen. This puts Toyota on track to become the first Japanese company to surpass 3 trillion yen in annual operating profit. Third-quarter operating profit was 722.3 billion yen, missing analyst estimates. The company also announced plans to buy back up to 0.74% of its shares.

images.alt_text: Toyota Motor Corp raised its profit forecast after surging sales of RAV4 sport utility vehicles and Lexus luxury models, putting it on track to become the first Japanese company to top 3 trillion yen (S$36 billion) in annual operating profit.

site_title: Terror attacks loom as Indonesian trio vie for IS glory
summary: Indonesian police warn that a power struggle among three Islamic State militants in Syria could lead to violent attacks in Southeast Asia, similar to the January Jakarta assault. The trio, Bahrumsyah, Abu Jandal, and Bahrun Naim, have been plotting attacks throughout 2015 and are competing to impress IS central command. A crackdown has uncovered a complex web of small militant cells, with police arresting about 20 suspected militants and exposing a tangled web of splinter cells and competing allegiances. The police chief warns that more terrorist attacks are likely as local IS leaders compete to establish their supremacy.

site_title: French trade deficit narrows in December to 3.9b euros
summary: France's trade deficit narrowed to 3.9 billion euros in December, exceeding forecasts, and was the smallest since September. Imports of aeronautics materials and chemical products fell, while exports of aerospace and space goods held steady. The year-end trade deficit of 45.67 billion euros is the lowest since 2009. The current account balance showed a 700 million euro deficit in December, down from 1.5 billion in November.

site_title: Continental recalls 5m cars on air-bag control units
summary: Continental Automotive Systems Inc. has recalled 5 million vehicles due to a defect in their air-bag control units, which may corrode and interrupt electrical connections, causing the devices to deploy inadvertently or fail to activate. The affected vehicles include models from Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, Honda, Volkswagen, Mazda, Kia, Volvo, and Daimler. The recalls follow another air-bag crisis sparked by Takata-made devices that explode with too much force, leading to injuries and accidents. Continental has known about the defect since 2008, and Honda has expanded its recall to fix potentially lethal safety devices in 2.2 million vehicles.

site_title: Toshiba dives to 35-year low as Tokyo shares turn lower
summary: Toshiba's shares plummeted to a 35-year low of 171 yen, a 14% drop, after the company widened its annual loss forecast to $6.0 billion. The firm cited a global economic slowdown and a profit-padding scandal for the shortfall. Toshiba blamed charges related to the scandal and weak sales for the disappointing results.

site_title: South Korea central bank: Uncertainty high over China, Japan, North Korea
summary: South Korea's central bank has increased its vigilance in monitoring global markets due to heightened uncertainty, citing factors such as China's economic risks, Japan's negative interest rates, weak oil prices, and North Korea's planned rocket launch. The Bank of Korea will review developments during the Lunar New Year festival holiday and hold a meeting on February 10. South Korean markets will close from February 8 and resume trading on February 11. The bank's decision comes amid growing global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia's Dec export growth below forecast as commodities drag
summary: Malaysia's exports grew 1.4% in December, below the 6.3% forecast, due to weak global demand for the country's commodities, particularly liquefied natural gas. Shipments of electronics and electrical products increased 6.4%. The country's economy, Southeast Asia's third-largest, has been hit hard by the slowdown in demand. Despite a 1.9% increase in exports for 2015, economists expect more policy support to counter weak exports and moderate growth in 2016. The ringgit currency fell to a session low before returning to pre-breach levels.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) seized 12 bank accounts worth S$9.7 million of senior private banker Yak Yew Chee in connection with the 1MDB probe. Meanwhile, Vietnam expressed surprise over the US's tariff announcement on July 11, 2025, and sought a lower rate. The Asian garment industry braced for higher US tariffs. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Citigroup to hire ex-Goldman MD as Japan investment banking head
summary: Citigroup Inc plans to hire Yusuke Asai, a former managing director at Goldman Sachs Group Inc, as its head of investment banking in Japan. Asai, who worked at Goldman Sachs from 2000 to 2013, will also become deputy president at Citigroup Global Markets Japan Inc in April. This is Citigroup's most senior hire in Japan since selling its local retail banking and card businesses late last year. Asai previously served as CEO at Reinsurance Group of America Inc.'s Japan unit since 2013.

site_title: Asia: Stocks subdued, dollar wobbles before US jobs data
summary: Asian stocks were subdued on Friday ahead of the US jobs report, with Shanghai shares rising 0.1%, South Korea's KOSPI shedding 0.1%, and Australian shares losing 0.7%. Japan's Nikkei dropped 1.2%, its fourth straight day of losses. The dollar wobbled as investors awaited the US jobs report, which could influence the Federal Reserve's monetary policy outlook.

site_title: Singapore Air jumps to 6-month high as profit tops estimates
summary: Singapore Airlines' quarterly profit jumped 36% to S$274.9 million, beating analyst estimates, as lower fuel prices and cheaper fares attracted more passengers. The airline's stock rose 3.9% to a six-month high, and occupancy rates increased to 80% from 78% a year earlier. Despite losing S$72 million in fuel hedges and S$77 million from a weaker currency, the airline achieved the profit with lower fares.

site_title: China graft watchdog raps financial regulators
summary: China's main anti-graft watchdog criticized four financial regulators, citing problems including using public funds for holidays and lack of corruption risk controls. The regulators, including the People's Bank of China and China Securities Regulatory Commission, vowed to follow party rules on fighting corruption. The Central Commission for Discipline listed a series of problems at each regulator, including the use of public funds for personal expenses and inadequate internal controls. The regulators acknowledged the issues and promised to take action to address them.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher after Wall St gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.54% on Friday, tracking gains in New York and Europe, as the likelihood of further US interest rates this year faded. The Hang Seng Index climbed to 19,287.36, while Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indexes remained flat and rose 0.15%, respectively.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won close up ahead of US payrolls
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.1% on Friday ahead of US jobs data, which may influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions. The won closed up 0.4% at 1,197.4 against the dollar. Foreign investors turned net buyers, purchasing 8 billion won worth of shares. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rose 0.1% to 1,917.79 points for the week, despite subdued trading.

site_title: Doubting India's 'fastest-growing' GDP stats, economists devise their own
summary: Economists in India are questioning the accuracy of the country's GDP growth statistics, citing concerns over the methodology used to calculate the numbers. They argue that the official figures, which show India as the world's fastest-growing big economy, are overstated and do not accurately reflect the country's economic reality. This has led some economists to devise their own alternative measures, such as tracking rural motorbike sales and rail freight, which suggest a weaker growth rate than the official data.

site_title: China foreign reserves head for record drop on yuan defense
summary: China's foreign-exchange reserves are expected to post a second consecutive record monthly drop, falling to $3.2 trillion in January, with a possible decline of $118 billion, according to economists' estimates. This is due to policy makers intervening to support the yuan amid flagging growth and capital outflows. The yuan has weakened to a five-year low, and China's economy is facing a significant capital outflow problem, which may accelerate the depletion of its reserves.

site_title: Indonesian growth beats estimates as Widodo seeks economic boost
summary: Indonesia's economic growth exceeded analyst estimates in the final quarter of 2015, with a 5.04% increase in gross domestic product. President Joko Widodo has been implementing reforms to boost foreign investment and infrastructure spending, aiming to revitalize the economy. Despite progress, the economy remains vulnerable to global trends, such as the slowdown in China and weak exports. The country's 2015 growth rate of 4.79% was lower than the previous year's pace of 5.02%.

site_title: Crude oil prices steady in thin Asian trading ahead of Lunar New Year
summary: Crude oil futures remained steady in thin Asian trading ahead of the Lunar New Year holiday. International benchmark Brent crude futures were trading at US$34.52 per barrel, up 6 cents from their last settlement. US crude futures were up 5 cents at US$31.77 a barrel due to low liquidity. The Lunar New Year holiday will last for most of next week, affecting trading activity in the region.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
