summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.29 points to 1654.6. The market saw 25.5 million lots traded worth RM10.6 million, with 69 gainers and 64 losers.

site_title: Indonesia Q4 GDP growth picks up speed, 2015 growth still weak
summary: Indonesia's Q4 GDP growth accelerated to 5.04% in 2015, surpassing market expectations, driven by government spending. The economy expanded 4.79% for the year, slightly better than forecasted. This marks the fifth consecutive year of slowing growth, but slightly better than expected. On a quarterly basis, the economy contracted 1.83%.

site_title: Mattel, Hasbro would face rising antitrust worry over mega deals
summary: A potential merger between toy giants Hasbro and Mattel would require antitrust approval from US officials, who are increasingly scrutinizing large deals in concentrated industries. The combined company would control about 20% of the US $24 billion toy market, but regulators may view this as insufficient to raise concerns. The FTC would likely focus on the broader market impact, considering the deal's potential to reduce competition and increase negotiating power with retailers. The outcome depends on how officials define the market and weigh the benefits against the risks.

site_title: SGH campus to get 20-year makeover under redevelopment masterplan
summary: Singapore General Hospital (SGH) campus will undergo a 20-year redevelopment, focusing on patient care, research, and education. The 43-hectare campus will expand current capacity by intensifying land use, with 60% dedicated to healthcare facilities and 40% for research and education. The redevelopment will be in two phases, with phase 1 focusing on relocating or developing key healthcare institutions and phase 2 on the main SGH Complex. A new research park will also be established to facilitate biomedical research and collaborations. The plan aims to meet growing healthcare needs and ensure patient safety and accessibility.

images.alt_text: Singapore's largest healthcare hub, the Singapore General Hospital (SGH) campus, will undergo major redevelopment spanning 20 years, to meet the growing needs of the population.

site_title: Australia: Shares hauled down by banks, retail, NZ flat
summary: Australian shares fell 0.7% mid-session on Friday, led by big banks and consumer stocks, due to disappointing retail sales in December and positioning ahead of China's foreign exchange reserves report. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 38.5 points to 4,941.9. Resources stocks, however, limited losses, with BHP Billiton, Newcrest Mining, and Alumina Ltd gaining. New Zealand shares remained steady, with Air New Zealand and Ryman Healthcare among the top gainers.

site_title: Lawyers earning 1,100 pounds an hour put UK justice at risk
summary: The cost of hiring top London lawyers has skyrocketed to over £1,100 per hour, making it inaccessible to smaller businesses and limiting access to justice for the poorest. The average hourly fee rose from 674 pounds in 2005 to a record 1,100 pounds in 2015, with the biggest firms not publishing their rates. This has led to concerns about the cost of hiring a law firm, with a 2013 lawsuit resulting in a £36 million bill for the loser.

site_title: McDonald's edging out KFC, Pizza Hut in China revival battle
summary: McDonald's is edging out KFC and Pizza Hut in China's revival battle, with same-store sales data showing McDonald's recovering faster from food safety scandals in 2012. McDonald's fourth-quarter sales in China rose 4%, while Yum's same-store sales growth was slower, leading to a 0.4% sales drop in 2015. The reasons behind McDonald's success are unclear, but a weaker economy and local rival strengths may be contributing factors. Yum is preparing to spin off its China operations, which has complicated its strategy.

site_title: Japanese airlines to alter routes to avoid North Korea missile
summary: Japan's two largest airlines, All Nippon Airways and Japan Airlines, will alter routes for some flights from February 8-25 due to North Korea's planned satellite-bearing rocket launch. The affected flights will divert over the Philippines, where missile parts and debris are expected to fall. This change affects three ANA flights: Tokyo to Manila, Manila to Tokyo, and Jakarta to Narita International Airport. The move aims to minimize risks to passengers and crew.

images.alt_text: Japan's two biggest airlines said on Friday they are changing routes for some flights as North Korea plans to launch what it says will be a satellite-bearing rocket later this month.

site_title: Sumitomo warns on commodity prices as writedowns mount
summary: Sumitomo Corp, a Japanese trading house, warns that commodity prices won't recover in the next two years due to mounting impairments. The company cut its full-year profit target by over half, estimating a net loss of 100 billion yen, and expects full-year impairments to rise to 170 billion yen. This follows a writedown on its Madagascan nickel project and a 93% cut in its partner Sumitomo Metal Mining Co's full-year net income forecast. The move is attributed to faltering Chinese demand, sliding raw materials prices, and the global oil glut.

site_title: Noble's bank debt prices signal concern that worst isn't over
summary: Noble Group's bank debt prices have fallen to 75 US cents on the dollar, signaling concerns that the company's financial struggles may not be over. Moody's and Standard & Poor's have cut its credit rating to junk, and investors are worried about its ability to refinance this year, leading to debt restructuring and a potential haircut. The company's shares and bonds have slumped over the past year due to declining commodity prices and allegations of accounting irregularities.

site_title: Banker in 1MDB-linked Singapore case withdraws request to unfreeze accounts
summary: A banker at BSI's Singapore unit, Yak Yew Chee, withdrew his court application to unfreeze his accounts as part of a probe into possible money laundering linked to 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB). The withdrawal came after his lawyer requested permission to transfer S$1.76 million to pay tax and legal fees without seizure. Singapore's Commercial Affairs Department had previously seized S$9.7 million from Yak's accounts. The case is part of a broader investigation into 1MDB, which is being probed by authorities in Malaysia, Switzerland, and the US.

site_title: Hot stock: Singapore Air jumps most in two months as profit beats estimates
summary: Singapore Airlines rose 3.4% to S$11.24 after beating analyst estimates with a 36% increase in quarterly net income to S$274.9 million. Lower fuel prices helped the carrier attract more passengers with cheaper fares, boosting occupancy to 80% from 78% last year. Despite losing S$72 million in fuel hedges and S$77 million from currency fluctuations, the airline's profit was bolstered by plunging jet fuel prices, which fell 39% in the past 12 months.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Loyz Energy, ARA, Wing Tai, SingPost, Perennial
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Singaporean stocks saw mixed results, with Singtel's Optus acquiring 1800 MHz spectrum licenses, ARA Asset Management reporting a 41% net profit rise, and Perennial Real Estate Holdings posting a 93% net profit increase. In contrast, Loyz Energy reported a net loss of US$631,000 due to a 58% decline in revenue, while Wing Tai Holdings' net profit slumped 85% year-on-year. SingPost will take a break from acquisitions to digest recent deals, and its Q3 net profit rose 0.6%.

site_title: Seoul: Won firmer on broadly weaker dollar; shares steady
summary: The South Korean won rose to a near two-week high, reaching 1,193.8 per dollar, driven by a broadly weaker dollar and expected support for commodity prices. However, investors remained cautious ahead of US jobs data. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) remained steady, with shares in Kakao Corp gaining 1.2% despite a lower-than-expected fourth-quarter net profit. Foreign investors sold KOSPI shares, weighing on the index.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open sharply lower on stronger yen
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted 1.49% on Friday, led by a stronger yen that hurts exporters' profitability. The yen rose to 116.83 from 116.74, down from a week-high of 121.45. European and US shares mostly rose despite oil price drops and US data showing a drop in productivity. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell to 16,790.53, while the Topix index dropped to 1,368.61. A stronger yen tends to knock demand for shares, and the Bank of Japan's negative interest rate policy has contributed to the yen's rise.

site_title: Hot stock: Singtel surges more than 3% in active volume
summary: Singtel shares surged more than 3% in active trading, driving the Straits Times Index (STI) higher despite regional market weakness. The telco's Australian subsidiary, Optus, bought airwaves in the 1800 MHz spectrum band for A$196 million, expanding its 4G network. A local broker expressed surprise at the stock's move, attributing it to unknown factors. The STI rose 1.53% to 2,597.70, with 17 million shares changing hands.

site_title: UE to sell MFlex unit to Suzhou Dongshan at US$23.95 per share
summary: United Engineers (UE) plans to sell its indirectly-owned subsidiary, MultiFineline Electronix (MFlex), to Suzhou Dongshan Precision Manufacturing for US$23.95 per share. The merger will result in MFlex becoming the surviving corporation, wholly owned by Suzhou Dongshan. The disposal is part of UE's plan to streamline its businesses and exit non-strategic operations. The deal is subject to shareholder approval and has been supported by UE, with all shares to be voted in favor of the merger. Net proceeds will be used to repay external borrowings and working capital.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.6% on Friday, opening at 2,573.91, driven by gains in telco Singtel (1.1%) and palm oil producer First Resources (1.6%). Asian markets were mixed, with Tokyo stocks falling 1.49% due to a stronger yen. On Wall Street, stocks finished modestly higher, with the Dow Jones gaining 0.49% and the S&P 500 adding 0.15%. The US jobs report for January is expected to be released on Friday.

site_title: Ivy League grads take on lenders charging 139% rates in Mexico
summary: Ivy League graduates Allan Apoj and David Poritz have founded online lender Credijusto, which aims to provide cheaper loans to small businesses in Mexico. The company charges interest rates between 26% to 32%, significantly lower than payday lenders and microlenders that charge 139%. Credijusto plans to lend $2 billion over five years, targeting businesses with average annual revenue of $48,000. The startup is backed by Victory Park Capital, a Chicago-based firm that supports non-traditional lending.

site_title: World Bank says wars, cheap oil hurting Middle East growth
summary: The World Bank reports that the Middle East and North Africa experienced 2.6% economic growth in 2015, below its forecast of 2.8%, due to war, terrorism, and cheap oil. The five-year Syrian war has cost the region $35 billion in lost output, equivalent to Syria's GDP in 2007. The plunge in oil prices has led to sharp government revenue declines and growing budget deficits, particularly in oil-exporting countries like Saudi Arabia, where public debt is expected to reach 20% of GDP by 2017.

site_title: Chinese shoppers in South Korea shun luxury for local brands
summary: Chinese tourists visiting South Korea are increasingly opting for local brands over luxury global brands, driven by a desire for authentic and affordable shopping experiences. This shift is attributed to the growing influence of the "Korean Wave" and younger, more price-conscious Chinese travelers. As a result, local brands such as Stylenanda and Sulwhasoo cosmetics have become top sellers in duty-free shops, surpassing luxury brands like Louis Vuitton and Chanel. This trend is expected to continue, with the South Korean government anticipating a record 8 million Chinese visitors in 2016.

site_title: Singtel's Optus to boost regional mobile coverage with 1800 MHz spectrum
summary: Optus, a telco unit of Singtel in Australia, has acquired new regional licences in the 1800 MHz spectrum band for A$196 million (S$197 million). This acquisition will help expand its 4G network coverage to more places around Australia, reaching 98.5% of the population.

site_title: LinkedIn shares plummet after sales outlook trails estimates
summary: LinkedIn's shares plummeted 30% in extended trading after the company forecast slower revenue growth in 2016, missing analyst estimates. Revenue is expected to be $820 million in the first quarter and $3.6-3.65 billion for the year, down from a previous estimate of $867.1 million and $3.9 billion. The company attributed the miss to weakness in sales of advertising and marketing tools, as well as slower economic growth in Europe and Asia. LinkedIn's shares have declined 15% this year, with co-founder Reid Hoffman's net worth potentially falling to around $3 billion.

site_title: Wall Street pulls back from mortgage market that Fed made boring
summary: The US Federal Reserve's quantitative easing program has led to a significant decline in mortgage bond trading volume, with average daily trading volume plummeting by over 40%. Banks such as Barclays, Deutsche Bank, and Societe Generale are scaling back their mortgage bond businesses, with some, like Deutsche Bank, planning to exit the safest mortgage bond market. The Fed's large holdings of mortgage-backed securities are also limiting the market's growth potential. As a result, banks are re-evaluating their fixed-income trading businesses and becoming more selective in their asset choices.

site_title: Trafigura scores metals deal with Nyrstar as Noble contract ends
summary: Trafigura Group has secured a deal with Nyrstar NV, Europe's largest zinc smelter, to supply up to 125 million euros of zinc concentrates over three years. The deal, worth US$150 million, will be repaid with physical zinc deliveries and replaces a similar agreement with Noble Group Ltd, which will expire at the end of 2016. Trafigura, a top shareholder of Nyrstar, has also agreed to underwrite the company's rights offering and has appointed two nominees to its board, further solidifying its control over the company.

site_title: IMF chief: China can avoid 'hard landing' but spillovers seen
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde says China can avoid a "hard landing" by pursuing reforms and sticking to a market-driven exchange rate policy. However, spillovers from China's transition to a slower growth rate will pressure oil and commodity exporters globally, increasing demands for international financing help. The IMF plans to improve financing tools to address emerging market difficulties. Lagarde also suggests advanced economies support growth with accommodative monetary policy and infrastructure spending, while emerging markets can boost non-commodity revenues and flexible exchange rates to ease fiscal pressures.

site_title: IMF chief sees risks in emerging-markets slowdown
summary: International Monetary Fund (IMF) chief Christine Lagarde warned that the slowdown in emerging-market economies could lead to rising global inequalities. China's cooling economy and falling commodity prices have caused growth to falter in countries like Brazil and Russia, with the IMF now projecting that income levels of emerging economies will converge to advanced economy levels at less than two-thirds the pace predicted a decade ago. Lagarde attributed the risks to rising inequality, protectionism, and populism, recommending that emerging economies improve their spending policies and increase non-commodity revenues to boost growth.

site_title: Julius Baer to pay US$547m for helping clients avoid taxes
summary: Julius Baer agreed to pay US$547 million to avoid prosecution in the US after admitting it helped American clients hide billions of dollars in assets from the Internal Revenue Service. The bank made detailed admissions of wrongdoing, and prosecutors dropped a conspiracy charge in three years if the bank abides by the terms of the deal. This follows guilty pleas from two client advisers, who admitted helping US clients avoid taxes, and comes after larger Swiss rivals UBS and Credit Suisse also resolved US tax probes with significant penalties.

site_title: Obama floats US$10-a-barrel oil tax
summary: US President Barack Obama proposed a $10-a-barrel tax on oil firms to fund infrastructure improvements, to be phased in over five years. The tax would be levied on companies but could be passed on to consumers. The plan aims to support innovative transportation investments and reduce dependence on fossil fuels. However, its passage in a Republican-controlled Congress is highly unlikely.

site_title: Philippine inflation slows in January on declining commodity prices
summary: The Philippine economy experienced a slowdown in inflation for the first time in five months in January, with the consumer price index rising 1.3% from the previous year. Core inflation slowed to 1.8% and the monthly rise in consumer prices remained unchanged at 0.2%. The central bank's target for the year is 2-4%. This marks a positive turn for the economy, which had seen steady inflation increases in the previous months.

images.alt_text: Philippine annual inflation slowed for the first time in five months in January due to declining commodity costs and slower price increases in clothing and transport, the statistics agency said on Friday.

site_title: Funk legend Maurice White of Earth, Wind & Fire dead at 74
summary: Maurice White, the 74-year-old founder of Earth, Wind & Fire, has died. White was a key figure in breaking racial barriers and selling over 100 million albums in the 1970s with hits like "September" and "Shining Star." His unique blend of jazz, pop, R&B, rock, and funk defined the band's sound, making them one of the most successful acts of the decade. White's death is the latest in a string of prominent musicians to pass away since 2016.

site_title: Home box office
summary: Singapore films are off to a strong start in 2016 with three new releases: Long Long Time Ago, In the Room, and Let's Eat. Director Jack Neo's nostalgic family drama Long Long Time Ago is set against the backdrop of modern Singapore's birth and explores kampung living. Eric Khoo's erotic anthology In the Room has been given a commercial release with an R21 rating after censorship-related setbacks. Meanwhile, Hong Kong actor Chapman To makes his directorial debut with the festive comedy Let's Eat, which is co-produced with Malaysia.

site_title: Airbnb hands over 1.2m euros to Paris city coffers
summary: Airbnb has paid the city of Paris 1.169 million euros, or 1.4 million overnight stays, in tourist tax for the last quarter of 2015. The company, which charges users a 83-cent per night tax, reached an agreement with Paris authorities last year. This is part of a larger effort by Airbnb to collect and remit taxes in various cities, including Amsterdam, Washington, and Chicago.

site_title: Unpaid and angry, some Chinese workers ditch LNY holidays to protest
summary: Chinese workers at a construction project in Hebei province are protesting by camping in offices, demanding unpaid wages of up to a year. The workers, who are mostly migrant laborers, were promised 20,000 to 50,000 yuan in paychecks but have yet to receive payment. The issue is part of a larger trend of labor unrest in China, with 774 labor strikes reported in December and January, mostly over wage arrears. The government has arrested labor activists and issued a notice calling for authorities to investigate wage arrears, but the situation remains a concern for Beijing as it seeks to avoid social unrest.

site_title: UK starting salaries rise in January at slowest pace since 2013
summary: UK starting salaries rose in January, but at the slowest pace since 2013. The Recruitment and Employment Confederation reported a slight increase in permanent job placements, but noted ongoing skill shortages in construction and manufacturing. The survey also warned that the government's plan to cut pay for temporary nursing staff may compromise patient safety. Meanwhile, consumer spending rose 3.8% year-on-year in January, but 30% of Britons expect the economy to deteriorate in the next three months.

images.alt_text: British starting salaries for new permanent and temporary jobs rose last month at the slowest pace since October 2013, according to a survey on Friday which will do little to quell the Bank of England's unease about a slowdown in wage growth.

site_title: China confirms three missing Hong Kong booksellers under probe
summary: China has confirmed that three missing Hong Kong booksellers, Lui Por, Cheung Chi Ping, and Lam Wing Kee, are under investigation for "illegal activities" by Chinese police. The investigation is related to publisher Gui Minhai, who is in custody over a decade-old traffic accident. The disappearance of the five men in October raised concerns about China's encroachment on Hong Kong's autonomy. Hong Kong police have requested a meeting with Lee Bo, another missing bookseller, but he declined, citing Chinese police actions.

site_title: Oil market heads lower
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate declining 56 cents to $31.72 a barrel, and Brent North Sea oil shedding 58 cents to $34.46 a barrel. The decline was attributed to concerns over a resurgent supply glut and traders' skepticism about a near-term deal by major producers to cut output. US commercial oil inventories remain at record levels, and a potential meeting of Opec and Russia producers has provided intermittent support to oil prices, but doubts over Saudi Arabia's participation and Russia's willingness to cooperate continue to undermine hopes for a production cut.

site_title: Goldman Sachs says iron ore prices face extra pressure from China steel cuts
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts iron ore prices face additional pressure due to China's plan to reduce steel capacity by 100-150 million tonnes, potentially resulting in a 55-95 million ton drop in actual steel output. This would translate to 90-150 million tons of lost iron ore, or 15% of the seaborne market, according to the bank's report.

site_title: Frozen bank accounts sow doubts on Malaysia transparency efforts
summary: Malaysia's efforts to boost transparency are being undermined by the freezing of bank accounts linked to the troubled 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) fund. Investigations across multiple countries, including the US, Switzerland, and Singapore, have raised questions about the country's ability to govern itself. The probes, potentially running for years, may damage Malaysia's reputation as a transparent investment destination, with investors and analysts expressing concerns about the country's economic and commercial prospects. The government's handling of 1MDB has also sparked internal turmoil, with some officials warning of a "scary downhill course" for the country.

site_title: Europe: Shares end down in choppy trade, led by Credit Suisse
summary: European shares fell 0.15% on Thursday, led by a 10.9% drop in Credit Suisse due to its first full-year loss since 2008. Weaker-than-expected US data on productivity and jobless claims also weighed on the market. However, a rally in commodities lifted miners and oil sector stocks, with Royal Dutch Shell rising 6% and ING jumping 8.9%. Export-oriented auto stocks fell 2.7%, while AstraZeneca slumped 6% due to the arrival of cheap generic rivals to its top-selling cholesterol drug.

site_title: Joe Alaskey, voice of Daffy Duck, Bugs Bunny, dies
summary: Joe Alaskey, the voice behind iconic cartoon characters like Daffy Duck, Bugs Bunny, and Tweety Bird, has died at 63. Alaskey, a successor to Mel Blanc, won an Emmy in 2004 for his performance in Cartoon Network's Duck Dodgers. He also lent his voice to notable roles, including Richard Nixon in Forrest Gump and Jackie Gleason in King Of The World. Alaskey's versatility and ability to adapt to various characters were praised by colleagues, with one describing him as a master of impersonation, saying he could "become someone else" to overcome shyness.

site_title: US: Stocks gain ahead of jobs report
summary: US stocks rose modestly ahead of the January jobs report, with the Dow gaining 79.92 points (0.49%) and the S&P 500 adding 2.92 (0.15%). Despite a drop in oil prices and mixed economic news, industrial stocks and media companies like Caterpillar, Alcoa, and CBS surged. The Nasdaq Composite Index climbed 5.32 (0.12%). The jobs report is expected to show 188,000 jobs added, down from December's surge.

site_title: Fed's Mester says US economy to overcome 'soft patch'
summary: US economy remains sound despite recent market turbulence, according to Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester. She expects the economy to overcome its "soft patch" and continue with moderate growth, with solid jobs and income growth indicating strong fundamentals. Inflation is expected to rise, but at a slightly slower pace than initially anticipated. Mester's comments suggest the Federal Reserve can continue tightening monetary policy as planned.

images.alt_text: Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester said that while the global selloff in stocks and oil poses risks, she is not about to cut her expectations of continued US economic growth and labour market improvement.

site_title: Negative interest rates not meant to help yen exchange rate: Kuroda
summary: BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda defended the central bank's decision to introduce negative interest rates, stating it's necessary for stimulating consumption and investment. Despite concerns of a "currency war," Kuroda denied the BOJ targets exchange rates, and the yen's recent appreciation. The negative rates are expected to push down real interest rates, but Kuroda acknowledged the possibility of deposit rates turning negative for individuals, which could impact small depositors. The move aims to boost the economy and achieve the 2% annual inflation target.

site_title: EU leaders not happy with 'Brexit' offer: sources
summary: EU leaders are dissatisfied with proposals for a deal to keep Britain in the EU, which Prime Minister David Cameron hopes to secure at a summit this month. European leaders are unhappy with a four-year "emergency brake" limiting welfare payments to migrants and a "red card" system for national parliaments to overrule draft EU laws. The lack of satisfaction suggests that a deal may be difficult to reach, with Cameron set to engage in a whirlwind diplomatic effort to win over his sceptical EU counterparts.

site_title: Eurozone factory growth slows in January
summary: Eurozone factory growth slowed in January, with incoming orders failing to increase, despite companies cutting prices at the deepest rate for a year. This disappointing reading may lead the European Central Bank to reconsider its policy stance, as it hinted at potential easing within months.

site_title: Ditching choreography in the name of dance
summary: TheatreWorks co-produces RE/PLAY Dance Edit, a dance piece that challenges traditional choreography by allowing six dancers to create and repeat their own movements without interruption. The artistic director, Junnoka Tada, aims to explore the diversity of dancers and their self-expression through this unique format. The piece, set to run from Feb 17-20, features dancers from different countries and backgrounds, and a Cambodian version is planned for 2017. This experiment seeks to rethink the concept of dance and its relationship with the body, space, and audience.

site_title: Parable looks at anti-foreigner sentiments
summary: Nine Years Theatre, a Mandarin theatre company, stages Noda Hideki's Red Demon, a play tackling anti-foreigner sentiments in Singapore. The production, marking a departure from Western classics, explores xenophobia and the irony of Singaporean Chinese displaying hatred towards new immigrants. The play's allegorical tale of a stranger's persecution parallels current issues, including the Syrian refugee crisis. Red Demon will be performed in Mandarin with English surtitles at the Drama Centre Black Box from March 3 to 13.

images.alt_text: Red Demon by Nine Years Theatre explores xenophobia through a mythical tale set in a timeless place.

site_title: HDB resale prices down 0.5% in January: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore dropped 0.5% in January, marking the first decline in seven months, according to SRX Property. This indicates a potential shift towards price stability this year.

site_title: No 'draconian measures' for Greece: IMF's Lagarde
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde stated that Greece will not face "draconian measures" despite a general strike over pension reforms. The IMF wants Greece to make progress on pension reform and ease its debt burden. Lagarde emphasized that the current pension system is unsustainable and needs a profound overhaul. The IMF is calling for reforms and debt relief to accompany the process. The Greek government and its creditors have contested certain reform measures, leading to the general strike.

site_title: Cisco to pay US$1.4b for IoT firm Jasper Tech
summary: Cisco Systems Inc is acquiring IoT firm Jasper Technologies Inc for $1.4 billion in cash and equity awards, its largest deal since 2013. The acquisition aims to leverage Jasper's IoT service platform to expand Cisco's offerings in the emerging field of Internet of Things (IoT). Jasper's software platform connects devices to the internet and provides monitoring services, aligning with Cisco's strategy to shift towards high-end networking equipment and data analytics software. The deal is seen as a strategic move to tap into the growing IoT market and enhance Cisco's growth prospects.

site_title: It's still the economy, stupid!
summary: The US economy is showing signs of a slowdown or recession, with recent indicators pointing to a decrease in personal spending and a weak manufacturing sector. The stock market is also volatile, adding to concerns. However, many economists, including those at Standard & Poor's, do not forecast a recession, citing the current expansion's longevity and the potential for growth. The Federal Reserve has not raised interest rates to combat inflation, and the labor market is near full employment, with the unemployment rate at 5%. If a recession does occur, it could change the complexion of the 2016 presidential campaign, with Republicans potentially blaming President Obama's policies for the economic downturn.

site_title: Toxic loans in China weigh on global economic growth
summary: China's toxic loans pose a significant threat to global economic growth, with estimated bad debts exceeding $5 trillion. The country's stagnant lending has slowed its economy, and similar issues are affecting other countries, including the US and Europe. Delaying the clean-up of bad loans can lead to further economic disruption, as seen in Japan's experience after its 1980s credit boom. Policymakers are grappling with the challenge of recognizing losses and raising fresh capital to revive economic growth, but the high cost of similar interventions in the past suggests a daunting task ahead.

site_title: China banks pilot jet lessors in chase of US$228b market
summary: China's banks are targeting the global aviation market, with affiliates specializing in jet leasing, aiming to create global champions. BOC Aviation, the largest Chinese lessor, is set to go public with an estimated $3 billion listing, while four Chinese lessors are among the world's top 15 by fleet value. The sector, worth $228 billion, is dominated by Western firms but China's banks are seeking predictable dollar-denominated revenue streams. Chinese lessors face challenges in securing specialist expertise, but successful players like BOC Aviation have won lucrative deals, providing a model for growth.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: M1's share price is expected to rebound after a 43% drop due to concerns of a new player entering the market, according to Citi Research. The broker raises its target price to S$2.82 and upgrades the stock to "buy" from "neutral." UOB Kay Hian Research also upgrades DBS and OCBC to "buy" with lower earnings forecasts due to exposure to the oil and gas sector. Valuetronics Holdings is maintained as "buy" with a target price of S$0.52.

site_title: How the oil industry plans to please investors
summary: Major oil companies, including BP, ExxonMobil, and Royal Dutch Shell, plan to borrow more money to weather the current low crude prices, which are the lowest since 2003. Despite reporting record annual losses, they aim to maintain investor dividends by taking on billions in debt. This move has raised concerns about their credit ratings, with Shell's rating cut to the lowest ever by Standard & Poor's. Analysts predict that the companies will become increasingly leveraged, with BP's gearing expected to reach 30% by 2017.

site_title: No magic bullet to reducing childhood obesity
summary: A proposed sugar tax to reduce childhood obesity is deemed ineffective by experts, citing uncertainty about its impact and potential regressive effects on low-income households. The World Health Organisation's Commission on Ending Childhood Obesity report highlights the need for a whole-of-government and whole-of-society approach to address the issue. Food industry associations argue that a solution requires input from multiple stakeholders and evidence-based science, rather than relying on a single intervention like taxation. A holistic approach focusing on product reformulation, public education, and promotion of healthy lifestyles is considered more effective in combating obesity.

site_title: What's love got to do with it?
summary: A new play, "The Effect," by Pangdemonium explores the impact of medication on emotions and love. The play, directed by Tracie Pang, follows two actors taking an experimental antidepressant that alters their feelings towards each other. The story raises questions about the nature of love and whether it can be manipulated through science. The play is relevant to Singapore's growing reliance on medication, and it aims to promote basic human contact and love as a key to humanity.

site_title: December factory orders post biggest fall in a year
summary: US factory orders dropped 2.9% in December, the largest decline in a year, due to a strong US dollar and weak overseas demand. Manufacturing, which accounts for 12% of the economy, is pressured by inventory overhang and cuts in capital spending. Despite a possible bottoming out, dollar strength and weak demand remain a challenge. Productivity fell 3% in the fourth quarter, the largest drop in over a year, leading to a jump in labour-related costs.

site_title: Economists are calm, even if equities are not
summary: Equity markets have been turbulent at the start of 2016, but economists remain calm, citing a loose relationship between equities and economies. Listed companies account for only 15% of US economic activity, and the service sector, which is driving economic growth, is not a dominant part of the equity market. Profits are near record highs, and bank lending is on the rise, offsetting the movement in equity prices. Consumer confidence data and Google Trends show no significant concern about a recession, indicating that economists are indifferent to the equity market volatility.

site_title: IIF blames market malaise on central bank liquidity drought
summary: The Washington-based Institute of International Finance (IIF) warns that a contraction in central bank liquidity is the primary driver of the global slump in financial assets, rather than China's slowdown. The IIF attributes this to a crisis of risk appetite caused by swings in monetary policy, which has boosted appetite for risk assets but also led to inflated values that may correct and drive markets further down. The report suggests that further monetary easing will have limited impact and could lead to increased market volatility and flash crashes.

site_title: Billions in aid pledged for Syria at London conference
summary: World leaders pledged billions of dollars at a London conference to aid conflict-hit Syrians, but the package's effectiveness is hindered by the suspension of peace talks in Geneva. The European Union, Germany, Britain, and the US pledged over $10 billion, including food aid, education, and work permits for displaced Syrians. However, the situation on the ground remains dire, with nearly 40,000 civilians fleeing Aleppo and millions of Syrians struggling to cope with the influx of refugees.

site_title: GSK dismisses near-term split as new drugs offset falling Advair
summary: GSK dismissed speculation about a near-term split of its consumer health business, citing rising sales of new medicines as a reason. The company's strategy is delivering, with strong growth in HIV and respiratory drugs offsetting declining sales of Advair. GSK's CEO, Andrew Witty, believes the shift will create a sustainable business, but some investors think an early break-up could unlock value. The company stuck to its 2016 forecast, predicting double-digit core EPS growth, and reiterated its dividend will remain steady.

site_title: Shell ready for more cost cuts as earnings fall 87%
summary: Royal Dutch Shell reported its lowest annual income in over a decade, falling 87% to $1.94 billion in 2015, due to weak oil prices. The company plans to cut costs further, reducing investment, cutting 10,000 jobs, and selling assets. CEO Ben van Beurden believes oil prices have reached their bottom and are expecting growing demand. Shell scrapped multi-billion-pound projects and approved only four new projects in 2015, which may impact its reserve replacement ratio. The company maintains its annual dividend payment and will take further impactful decisions if conditions warrant.

site_title: Amid the gloom, room for optimism for CCT
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) may be better prepared than most office landlords to face strong headwinds from the completion of office space in 2016-2017. Despite rising office completions, demand is expected to be flat to negative, and office rents are forecast to slide. CCT has taken steps to minimize lease expiries and has a 40% stake in CapitaGreen, which is expected to contribute to its distributable income. The trust also has a low gearing ratio, allowing it to fund potential acquisitions without divesting assets. Analysts have differing views on CCT's prospects, with some predicting a "sell" recommendation and others a "buy" due to the trust's earnings certainty from CapitaGreen.

site_title: Up or down at Dropbox? It's hard to say
summary: Dropbox, a cloud storage company, is facing skepticism from large investors about its future, with its valuation having dropped significantly from $10 billion to $2 billion. Despite this, the company's executives claim that it is thriving, with over 400 million users and 150,000 business customers. Dropbox is focused on growing its business and expanding into new products and services, and its executives believe that it will eventually regain its valuation. The company is competing with Box, a rival that has had to spend heavily to build out a sales team, but Dropbox argues that its broad brand recognition makes the sales process more efficient.

site_title: Denmark may reverse bank rules to protect mortgage system
summary: Denmark is considering revising its bank rules to protect its $400 billion mortgage bond market, amid concerns about over-regulation. Business Minister Troels Lund Poulsen said the country may amend rules adopted from the European Union to give non-eurozone nations more flexibility. Denmark has pushed back on EU regulations, including a plan to downgrade mortgage-backed covered bonds. A report is being prepared to investigate areas where Denmark may have shown too much zeal in implementing EU rules, aiming to strike a balance between regulation and flexibility.

site_title: Wing Tai reports 85% drop in Q2 profit
summary: Wing Tai Holdings reported a 85% drop in Q2 profit to S$1.08 million, primarily due to higher income tax expenses. Revenue declined 5% to S$120.61 million, while operating profit increased 5% to S$12.98 million. The property group's net profit for the half year ended Dec 31 plummeted 90% to S$3.11 million. The company attributed the decline to cooling measures in the Singapore property market and economic climate in Malaysia.

site_title: Three top rubber producers to cut exports from March to lift prices
summary: Asia's top rubber producers, Thailand, Indonesia, and Malaysia, agree to cut exports by 615,000 tonnes for six months from March to boost prices. The cuts, accounting for 6% of global output, aim to address a chronic glut and low prices that have affected smallholder farmers. Benchmark rubber futures in Singapore and Japan rallied 2-3% on the news, but farmers say the cuts are too small to have a lasting impact.

site_title: Europe may yet emerge as economic model for Asia
summary: The eurozone crisis has not broken up, and the European Union has emerged as a model for economic recovery, with countries like Italy, Spain, and Greece experiencing strong growth and bringing budget deficits below 3% of GDP. The European Stability Mechanism (ESM) has disbursed €255 billion to crisis countries, tied to budget consolidation and structural reform. This approach has been effective, with eurozone countries regaining access to private capital markets quickly. The EU's experience may serve as a model for Asian economies, demonstrating that economic recovery can be achieved through a combination of fiscal and structural reforms, rather than relying solely on monetary stimulus.

site_title: Levelling out of Swedish property prices may not be a bad thing
summary: Swedish property prices appear to be levelling out, which may benefit the country's mortgage industry, according to Swedbank CEO Michael Wolf. The slowdown in prices will help the bank manage regulatory requirements and pay generous dividends. Despite global regulators considering minimum capital requirements for credit risk, including mortgages, Swedbank has a capital buffer to meet future requirements. The bank plans to expand lending for housing construction and may make acquisitions, but prioritizes risk management over price competition.

site_title: Acra tells PwC to ensure independence on SingPost
summary: Acra instructs PwC to ensure independence as special auditor for Singapore Post, amid concerns over PwC's long relationship with the company. Acra's Securities Investors Association (SIAS) president David Gerald stated that any necessary safeguards must be applied to maintain PwC's independence in its capacity as special auditor. If PwC fails to comply with Acra's Code of Professional Conduct and Ethics, regulatory action will be taken. The move comes after SingPost picked PwC as special auditor in January, raising questions about the lack of a request for proposal and PwC's close relationship with the company.

images.alt_text: Mr Gerald says SIAS expects PwC will address all serious concerns of the stakeholders surrounding its appointment as special auditor

site_title: ARA's Q4 profit up on higher management fees, lower expenses
summary: ARA Asset Management reported a 41% increase in Q4 net profit to S$25.6 million, driven by higher management fees and finance income, as well as lower expenses. Total revenue rose 7% to S$46.1 million, with recurrent management fees increasing 6%. The company attributed a 11% fall in full-year net profit to lower revenue overall. Shares closed at S$1.04, up 1.5 cents.

site_title: NEA to use drones for dengue control
summary: The National Environment Agency (NEA) plans to use drones to improve its dengue control program by surveying mosquito breeding grounds and depositing larvicide into roof gutters. The initiative is part of the inter-agency UAS Committee's efforts to develop over 25 potential uses of drones for government agencies. The committee balances drone use with aviation safety, public safety, security, and privacy concerns. This move is part of Singapore's broader use of drones for various purposes, including oil spill monitoring and search and rescue operations.

site_title: Amid restructuring, Credit Suisse keeps faith in Asia-Pacific
summary: Credit Suisse reported its first full-year loss since 2008, with a net loss of 2.94 billion Swiss francs, despite its Asia-Pacific division performing well. The Asia-Pacific division saw a 21% increase in income to 148 million Swiss francs, driven by higher revenues from fixed income and equities sales and trading. The bank plans to hire more bankers in the region and has brought in 70 new relationship managers, aiming to reach 800 by 2018. Despite a 4,000 job cut globally, Credit Suisse remains committed to growing its presence in Asia-Pacific.

images.alt_text: The bank is taking more market share in the trading and sales of equities and bonds, says Mr Sitohang

site_title: S'pore LNG index can be Asia benchmark in a year or two: SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) expects the Singapore LNG price index to become the Asian benchmark within the next one to two years. The index, known as Sling, has already seen the launch of futures and swaps contracts and is expected to be indexed to spot cargoes from new LNG projects. The development of the Sling index is seen as a response to the growing demand for a pricing product in the Asia-Pacific LNG market, which accounts for 75% of global LNG trade. The SGX aims to create a pricing product that can compete with Tokyo's Japan OTC Exchange.

site_title: Minimalism for the masses
summary: Composer Steve Reich will perform a one-night-only concert in Singapore on March 17 with the London Sinfonietta, marking their first collaboration in the city. Reich, a pioneer of minimalism, prefers the term "Music" to describe his compositions, rather than the label itself. The concert is part of a larger musical event, but no further details are provided.

site_title: Maybank to extend RM2b lifeline to TH Heavy Engineering
summary: Malaysian oilfield services provider TH Heavy Engineering (THHE) is set to receive up to RM2 billion in cash injection from Maybank as part of an operational and financial restructuring. The move comes after THHE's financial health was threatened by sizeable liabilities of its anchor shareholder, Lembaga Tabung Haji (LTH), a Malaysian pilgrim fund. Petronas's Malaysia Petroleum Management (MPM) unit has also intervened in the restructuring of THHE's FPSO contract with JX Nippon, which is valued at US$372 million.

site_title: Cheaper jet fuel lifts SIA's Q3FY16 bottom line
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a 35.7% year-over-year increase in its Q3FY16 bottom line to nearly S$275 million, driven by lower jet fuel costs. Revenue fell 3.9% to S$3.94 billion due to weaker yields, while operating profit nearly doubled to S$288 million. The airline attributed the better performance to reduced expenses, which offset the decline in revenue. SIA Cargo's operating profit declined 88.2% due to overcapacity and weak demand growth.

site_title: HK property sales fall 12% in 2015, underscores fears of slowdown
summary: Hong Kong property sales fell 12% in 2015, with total consideration dropping 3.9% to $417 billion, according to government data. This decline underscores fears of an economic slowdown, despite stable mortgage rates. Analysts attribute the slowdown to cooling activity in China and a growing drag on the city's economy. Property prices remain high, with a further decline expected this year, and companies are cutting expenses, including salaries and hiring freezes, as the middle class reduces spending.

site_title: Commodity bull cycle seen rising from ashes and oil bottoming
summary: Schroders, a UK-based asset manager, predicts a rebound in oil prices, potentially reaching $50 a barrel, due to reduced production following a 12-year low. This could encourage retail investors to return to raw materials, sparking a new bull cycle in commodities. Hedge funds have increased bullish bets on oil, and analysts predict a 50% rise in prices by year-end.

site_title: DBS stitching together vessel deals for Pacific Richfield Marine
summary: DBS, a major bank creditor to Pacific Richfield Marine Pte Ltd (PRM), has successfully identified buyers or charterers for five of the 40 offshore support vessels (OSVs) in PRM's fleet, helping the company to meet its target of January 31 for definitive sale and purchase agreements. DBS brokered deals with listed O&M groups Ezra Holdings and Swiber Holdings, and private-owned Berlitz Marine Group, securing loans to repay PRM's outstanding loans. This marks a significant asset divestment in the O&M sector, which is struggling due to low oil prices and overcapacity.

site_title: Brutal yet beautiful Inarritu revenge thriller
summary: Alejandro G. Inarritu's "The Revenant" is a brutal yet beautiful revenge thriller based on a real-life story of a frontiersman's near-death experience. The film, set in the 1820s, follows Hugh Glass, played by Leonardo DiCaprio, as he seeks revenge against those who betrayed and left him for dead after a brutal bear attack. The film, featuring stunning natural landscapes and intense performances, explores themes of survival, revenge, and the human condition, ultimately leaving viewers emotionally drained and visually dazzled.

site_title: Mozilla to kill Firefox smartphone operating system
summary: Mozilla to discontinue Firefox smartphone operating system, citing failure to gain traction in the market. The operating system, launched in 2013, was an open-source alternative to dominant platforms powered by Apple and Google. Despite initial partnerships and low-cost devices, Firefox OS failed to gain commercial success, leading Mozilla to shift focus to developing open-source software for the Internet of Things. Support for Firefox OS for smartphones will end in May, with staff involvement ceasing after the 2.6 release.

site_title: Amazon bookstores? Yes, e-tailers are hitting the mall now
summary: Amazon plans to open 400 brick-and-mortar bookstores, but it's not a new trend. E-tailers like Warby Parker and Bonobos have already opened stores, with malls seeking new tenants and online merchants discovering physical locations help brand discovery. Traditional retailers are also buying or partnering with online merchants to open boutiques in their stores, creating a new retail landscape. This shift is driven by the need for malls to attract new customers and online merchants to increase brand visibility.

site_title: Wines for the festive season
summary: A recent survey on the relationship between wine and heart disease reveals that moderate wine consumption, particularly red wine, can exert a protective effect against coronary heart disease. The active component in grapes, Resveratrol, is believed to be responsible for this effect. For Chinese New Year, the author recommends two generic classes of wines: lightly sweet, low-alcohol German Rieslings and Spanish/Italian red wines, such as Vega Sicilia and Rosso di Montalcino. The author suggests opting for wines with lower sugar content, such as Kabinett or Estate Kabinetts, to minimize the negative effects of alcohol on health.

site_title: As central bank powers weaken, governments need to step up
summary: Traders' loss of faith in central banks' ability to boost the global economy has led to market correction. Despite seven years of near-zero interest rates, global economic growth has stagnated, and hopes for future growth are built into stock prices. Economists warn that cheap money can lead to deflationary investments and asset bubbles. Governments, not central banks, are needed to implement structural policies to stimulate economic growth. The US, China, and Japan must address their respective economic challenges through reforms and tax cuts to prevent future crises.

site_title: Emotions run high in the best shots
summary: Former National Geographic photographer Steve McCurry emphasized the importance of storytelling and emotional content in photography, stating that camera quality is secondary. His solo exhibition at Sundaram Tagore Gallery features 53 of his iconic photographs, taken mostly in India, which he has visited over 80 times. McCurry's approach is to capture life's moments spontaneously, often incorporating nostalgia and historical value in his work. He believes that the content of a photograph should trump its technical aspects, with color and composition serving only to enhance the emotional narrative.

site_title: US$ falls again as rate rise expectations collapse
summary: The US dollar fell 0.5% against a basket of currencies, its largest daily drop in over two months, due to a collapse in interest rate expectations. The euro rose to a 3.5-month high of $1.1161, while sterling bounced 0.25% to $1.4631 amid UK-EU Brexit talks. Expectations for US interest rate hikes have collapsed, with a quarter-point rise now only priced in for 2018. The dollar's decline is attributed to weak US sentiment data and warnings from the New York Fed and European Central Bank about a weakening global economy.

site_title: Developers in China lure buyers with discounts and facilities
summary: Chinese developers are focusing on clearing unsold homes by offering discounts and improving living conditions. To attract buyers, developers are working with local governments to provide better infrastructure, such as public transportation, schools, and shopping malls. In response to changing consumer preferences, developers are also integrating their products with tourism, retirement facilities, or education. Local governments are considering policies to support rural residents and migrant workers in buying homes, with some provinces proposing loan programs and loosening restrictions on home purchases.

images.alt_text: Developers in some cities have integrated their products with tourism, retirement facilities or education to cater to targeted consumer groups and revive the sluggish market.

site_title: GLP's Q3 earnings soar despite China, investor uncertainty
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) reported a 63.8% increase in net profit to US$184.2 million in Q3, driven by higher earnings in China, development gains in Japan, and entry into the US market. Revenue rose 11.1% to US$198.9 million. The company also started US$826 million of new developments and completed US$516 million of developments with a value creation margin of around 27%. Despite concerns over China's growth and depreciating yuan, GLP's solid fundamentals and stable lease ratio of 88% in China support its appeal as a potential buyout target.

site_title: SingPost takes a break from acquisitions
summary: SingPost, a Singaporean postal and e-commerce group, reported a 0.6% increase in Q3 net profit to S$43.50 million, despite a 32% rise in revenue. Total expenses grew 37.9% to S$273.26 million, outpacing revenue growth. The company will not pursue further strategic acquisitions and is focusing on integrating existing businesses. A proposed Alibaba stake raise is also delayed, with the long-stop date extended to an unspecified date. SingPost shares rose S$0.015 to S$1.345 following the results announcement.

site_title: City buzz
summary: A festive jazz special, "Gong Xi!" by Jeremy Monteiro, is set to take place. Thevar 2.0 showcases mod-Indian cuisine, while The Social Kitchen has opened at Bank of Singapore. A zero-waste future is being pursued, and CMC Markets has partnered with Sophia Women to promote financial literacy for women. NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, and Helen Wong is retiring as OCBC CEO with Tan Teck Long as her successor.

site_title: With TPP signed, 2-year ratification process is up next
summary: The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) has been signed by 12 Pacific Rim nations, including the US, Japan, and Singapore, after five years of negotiations. The deal aims to slash trade and investment barriers, but the ratification process could take up to two years. At least six countries, including the US and Japan, must approve the final text before it becomes legally binding. The business community in Singapore welcomes the signing, but opposition from US Democrats and some Republicans could delay ratification, potentially pushing the deadline to 2017.

site_title: Stronger yuan boosts CRCT's Q4 performance in SGD terms
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) reported a 4.4% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.59 Singapore cents for Q4 2015, driven by a stronger yuan against the Singapore dollar. Gross revenue rose 6.7% to S$56.2 million, while net property income (NPI) increased 5.2% to S$35.3 million. The trust's performance was stronger in SGD terms due to the currency exchange. Full-year DPU was 10.6 cents, a 7.9% increase over FY2014.

site_title: Neo's winning box-office formula
summary: Filmmaker Jack Neo's latest movie, Long Long Time Ago, has been released despite criticism for its blatant product placements and compromised dramatic impact. Set against the backdrop of Singapore's birth, the film features a mix of nostalgia, laughs, and historical events, but its flaws may detract from its appeal. Despite this, the movie is expected to still sell out cinema halls during the festive season due to its strong heartland themes, familiar faces, and nostalgic value. Neo's ability to balance storytelling and sponsorship earns him the title of local box-office champ.

site_title: Dow futures' late selloff trims STI's gains
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 7.75 points to 2,558.49, driven by a 100-point rise in Dow futures and marginally firmer oil prices. However, the gains were partly offset by a 21-point decline from its intraday high. Offshore and marine stocks were slightly firmer, while banks were mixed. Analysts attributed the sector's underperformance to concerns over China and commodities exposure. The market is also wary of a US recession, with some predicting a corporate earnings recession in Emerging Markets and Asia.

site_title: KKR invests in Mumbai builder's plush projects
summary: KKR & Co has invested 1.5 billion rupees (S$31 million) in Sunteck Realty Ltd's luxury condominium projects in Mumbai, marking the private equity firm's interest in India's real estate market. The investment will support the developer's growth and acquisition opportunities as the market faces a funding squeeze. Home sales in Mumbai declined 17% in the September quarter, with a record 47 months needed to sell all unsold homes. The investment is part of the increasing interest by private equity firms in India's real estate market, which saw US$5 billion pumped in last year.

site_title: Protecting investors from controlling shareholders
summary: The article discusses the need to rethink the election of independent non-executive directors (INEDs) to provide a robust challenge to management in the boardroom. INEDs are crucial in monitoring executives and representing the interests of both the company and shareholders. However, the current system allows controlling shareholders to vote on INED elections, creating a structural flaw. The article proposes a two-tier voting structure, where a second vote is required for INEDs to pass, and those who fail to meet the "independent vote" requirement are restricted from providing opinions on certain transactions. This system aims to protect INEDs from being controlled by dominant management and ensure their independence.

site_title: Poland scraps US$3b Airbus helicopter deal, launches Lockheed talks: report
summary: Poland has cancelled a $3 billion deal for 50 Airbus utility helicopters, opting instead to purchase only a few aircraft from the European company. The move, made months before a NATO summit in Warsaw, may strain Poland's ties with France and delay a military program accelerated by the Ukraine crisis. The decision could also impact Poland's efforts to increase NATO presence on its territory.

site_title: Next change for House of Tan Yeok Nee: TCM Centre
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings has received in-principle approval to convert the House of Tan Yeok Nee, a national monument in Singapore, into an upmarket TCM Centre. The property will be jointly owned and operated with a partner in the TCM industry. The change of use is expected to be completed in the second quarter of 2016.

site_title: US December factory orders post biggest drop in a year
summary: US factory orders fell 2.9% in December, the largest drop in a year, due to a strong dollar and weak overseas demand. Manufacturing accounts for 12% of the economy and is pressured by inventory overhang and cuts in capital spending by oil firms. The downturn may be nearing its bottom, but dollar strength and weak demand remain a challenge. Orders for transportation equipment fell 12.6% and durable goods dropped 5.0%, while shipments of core capital goods rose 0.2%. Inventories rose for the first time in five months, but the inventories-to-shipments ratio remains high.

site_title: How long can a good economy trump bad politics?
summary: Malaysia's economy is robust, with a 4-4.5% forecast GDP growth for this year, thanks to abundant natural resources and an open economy. However, Prime Minister Najib Razak's regime is at risk if the current climate of scandal-fueled political instability persists. Despite multiple external and domestic challenges, Moody's Investors Service describes the economy as "very high." If the currency hits 5.00 per US dollar, a "palace coup against Najib" is predicted, with Umno warlords and Malaysian business tycoons joining in. A resilient economy may ensure Najib's longevity until 2018.

site_title: Banks press EU to drop 'arbitrary' derivatives-collateral rule
summary: European banks and clearinghouses are lobbying the EU to drop a proposed rule requiring intra-day collateral during trading days, citing operational complexities and inconsistency with US rules. The requirement, proposed by the European Securities and Markets Authority, aims to monitor and collect collateral hourly, but industry groups argue it's unnecessary. The EU and US have been negotiating policy changes to ensure equivalence in supervision and capital requirements, with a deal expected soon.

site_title: Ex-Julius Baer bankers to plead guilty in US in Swiss tax case
summary: Two former Julius Baer private bankers, Daniela Casadei and Fabio Frazzetto, are expected to plead guilty to charges of helping wealthy American clients evade taxes. The Swiss bank has agreed to a US$547.25 million settlement with US prosecutors. The bankers were indicted in 2011 for conspiring to help US taxpayers hide over $600 million in offshore accounts. Their pleas come after a US crackdown on offshore tax evasion by Americans through Swiss banks.

site_title: HSBC to incorporate Singapore subsidiary in May
summary: HSBC will locally incorporate its retail operations in Singapore on May 9, fulfilling the Monetary Authority of Singapore's objective to protect customer deposits. The subsidiary, HSBC Bank (Singapore) Ltd, will hold a full bank license and ringfence customer deposits from group operations. This move follows HSBC's designation as a systemically important bank, requiring local incorporation of retail operations. The subsidiary will manage the bank's 11 branches, 10 ATMs, and 2 multi-functional machines, while other lines of business will remain under the existing HSBC Singapore Branch.

site_title: Kicking off his namesake
summary: Former Japanese footballer Hidetoshi Nakata has launched his own sake, named "N", after traveling to 47 prefectures to learn about Japanese culture. He aims to educate people about sake, which he believes is often overlooked compared to wine and other liquors. Nakata partnered with brewery Takagi Shuzo to create a premium sake with a unique glass design. The sake is available in 10 countries worldwide, with a limited annual batch of 1,000 bottles, and is priced between S$2,000 and S$3,500. Nakata plans to use his platform to promote Japanese sake makers and crafts, with plans for a bazaar and app development.

images.alt_text: Says Nakata: "We didn't just have conversations about making sake, but also about the problems. I learnt that the demand for sake is decreasing in Japan, and although it's increasing in the rest of world, it isn't an easy life for sake makers."

Says Nakata: "We didn't just have conversations about making sake, but also about the problems. I learnt that the demand for sake is decreasing in Japan, and although it's increasing in the rest of world, it isn't an easy life for sake makers."

Says Nakata: "We didn't just have conversations about making sake, but also about the problems. I learnt that the demand for sake is decreasing in Japan, and although it's increasing in the rest of world, it isn't an easy life for sake makers."

site_title: ECB's Mersch says productivity drive in euro zone has cost jobs
summary: Yves Mersch, a European Central Bank policy setter, stated that the eurozone's drive for productivity growth has primarily come through labor shedding rather than strong value-added growth. This has led to job displacement, potentially increasing structural unemployment if displaced workers lack the necessary skills to find new employment.

images.alt_text: The drive for more productivity in the eurozone has come through cutting the workforce, a European Central Bank policy setter said on Thursday, warning that such job-shedding could become entrenched.

site_title: HSBC's Asia bet pays off in fee windfall from ChemChina deal
summary: HSBC has secured a significant fee of up to $95 million from its role as lead adviser to China National Chemical Corp on its $43 billion acquisition of Swiss pesticide and seeds maker Syngenta AG. This deal is the largest-ever acquisition by a Chinese firm and marks HSBC's biggest advisory mandate. The acquisition is a result of HSBC's strategic focus on Asia, where the bank has a strong presence and is ranked ninth in the Asia-Pacific for merger advisory.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Oil prices rose over 2% amid market uncertainty. Stocks in Europe and the US declined due to bank and healthcare sector concerns, with US-EU tariffs in focus. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. In other news, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case, and US stocks opened lower amid Trump's tariff threats on Canada.

site_title: New York's Equity Residential expects flat growth on rents
summary: Equity Residential expects flat growth in rents on newly signed apartment leases on Manhattan's West Side, due to increased competition from new supply, including over 6,700 luxury units. The company's chief operating officer notes that the disruption will be "short-term" and does not foresee a significant decline in the market. New lease rates are expected to be flat or slightly positive until the majority of new units are absorbed.

site_title: India's rule changes are raising investment uncertainty: carmakers
summary: Indian carmakers, including Honda and Ford, are concerned about investment uncertainty due to the government's recent rule changes, including a ban on diesel vehicles with two-litre engines or larger and stricter emission rules. These measures aim to address the country's hazardous smog, but have raised uncertainty among investors.

site_title: HSBC to transfer Singapore retail, wealth arm to local subsidiary
summary: HSBC plans to transfer its Singapore retail and wealth management business to a locally incorporated subsidiary on May 9, as required by Singapore's central bank. This move comes after HSBC was identified as one of seven foreign banks with a significant retail presence in the city-state. Regulators globally aim to ring-fence retail operations to protect domestic customers, and this transfer is part of that effort. The new subsidiary will be locally incorporated, but no further details have been provided.

site_title: Consumer comfort in US little changed near three-month high
summary: US consumer confidence cooled in the final week of January, easing to 44.2, a three-month high. The Bloomberg Consumer Comfort Index dropped due to dimmer views of personal finances and a decline in stock prices, but improved buying climate. 64% of respondents had negative views of the economy, with confidence among those 45-54 rising to its highest since September 2007. The gauge of sentiment in the South improved, while the Midwest saw the largest decline. Sustained employment growth may provide reassurance, but current views are cautious.

site_title: Raffles Education Corp to acquire additional stake in Malaysia-based Raffles College of Higher Education
summary: Raffles Education Corp has agreed to acquire up to 50% in Raffles College of Higher Education (RKL) through two agreements. The company currently holds a 20% stake and plans to increase its stake to 70% with the acquisition. The deals involve purchasing shares from Doris Chung Gim Lian for RM8.38 million and RM6.07 million, conditional on Malaysian Ministry of Education approval. The acquisition is in line with the company's business plan to access the growing educational industry in Malaysia.

site_title: Star choreographer Millepied quits Paris Opera Ballet
summary: Star choreographer Benjamin Millepied is quitting Paris Opera Ballet after less than a year in charge, citing resistance to his plans to reform the institution. Millepied, married to actress Natalie Portman, stated he wants to focus 100% on creating rather than administration. He cited the difficulty in implementing his vision as the reason for his departure, which comes after a tumultuous tenure marked by stiff resistance to his radical reforms.

site_title: Controversy in Germany over plans to cap cash transactions
summary: Germany's Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble proposes a 5,000-euro limit on cash transactions to combat money laundering and terrorism financing. The plan, which would need to be implemented at a European-wide level, has sparked controversy as the country prefers cash payments, with 79% of transactions made in cash. Critics argue it would infringe on citizens' personal economic liberty, and experts warn of negative effects on skilled trades and second-hand car sales. The proposal has been met with opposition from the Bundesbank and conservative parties, with some labeling it a "war on cash."

site_title: Transcorp CEO steps down
summary: Transcorp Holdings CEO Jong Khee Beng Ainsley has stepped down, citing plans to pursue other career opportunities and devote more time to commitments. Several other directors, including lead independent director Seah Chee Wei and executive directors Neo Yim Pui and Swee Kay Seng, are also stepping down. The company is in the process of interviewing suitable candidates for the board.

site_title: Vicom net profit up 4.2%; revenue falls 1.3%
summary: Vicom, a unit of ComfortDelGro, reported a 4.2% increase in net profit to S$31.4 million for the year ended Dec 31, 2015, despite a 1.3% fall in revenue to S$106.7 million. The company proposed a tax-exempt one-tier final dividend of 9.50 cents per ordinary share and a special dividend of 10.25 cents. Vicom's earnings per share rose to 35.45 cents from 34.02 cents last year, while net asset value per share climbed to 165.03 cents.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower after weak economic data
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday due to weak economic data, with the Dow Jones falling 0.12% to 16,317.04, the S&P 500 losing 0.16% to 1,909.49, and the Nasdaq Composite index dropping 0.26% to 4,492.55. The decline was attributed to heightened fears of an economic slowdown.

site_title: US jobless claims rise more than expected
summary: US jobless claims rose more than expected, increasing 8,000 to 285,000 for the week ended Jan 30, suggesting a slowdown in the labor market amid economic and stock market downturns. This marks the 48th consecutive week of claims below 300,000, the longest run since the 1970s. Despite the increase, economists forecast nonfarm payrolls to rise 190,000 in January, with the unemployment rate expected to remain at a 7-1/2-year low of 5%. The data has no bearing on the upcoming January employment report.

site_title: Bank of England cuts growth outlook, policymaker drops rate hike call
summary: The Bank of England cut its economic growth forecasts due to a darker global outlook, citing sharp falls in oil prices and shares, and significant risks in emerging economies. The central bank kept interest rates on hold at 0.5% and expects a gradual rise over the next three years. Policymaker Ian McCafferty dropped his call for a rate hike, citing muted wage growth expectations. The central bank forecasts 2.2% growth this year and 2.3% in 2017, with consumer price inflation expected to stay below 1% in 2016.

site_title: China to slash steel production capacity
summary: China plans to cut steel production capacity by up to 150 million tonnes over five years, closing outdated plants and refusing to license new projects. This move aims to address industrial overcapacity weighing on growth. Steel production declined 2.3% in 2015, with China accounting for half the world's crude steel production. Experts say China is sitting on an overproduction of 340 million tonnes. The move is part of Beijing's efforts to correct overcapacity issues in various industries, including cement, aluminum, and shipbuilding, with Premier Li Keqiang calling for a "cutback on overcapacity".

site_title: Some banks going the extra mile to help offshore sector - for now
summary: Banks are proactively helping offshore and marine (O&M) industry clients manage financial stress caused by low oil prices, with some offering debt restructuring and asset sales to alleviate stress. However, creditors may adopt a less accommodating stance if industry conditions worsen, and O&M players should not expect "free lunches" with any financial assistance. Excess capacity in the industry, particularly in rig and offshore support vessels, poses a structural challenge, and banks are working to stop further build-ups in capacity. A rebound in the oil market is seen as a potential silver lining for the industry, with many predicting oil prices could rebound to US$40-60 a barrel later this year.

site_title: Crises spoil Chinese, Russian appetite for luxury London property
summary: Foreign buyers, particularly from China, Russia, and the Middle East, are pulling back from luxury London property due to economic crises at home and turmoil on global markets. The decline in transactions, asking prices, and buyer interest is attributed to the fall in oil prices, currency fluctuations, and tax rises in London. According to data, Chinese and Russian buyers accounted for 4% and 3% of prime London property buyers in the first half of 2015, respectively, down from 10% and 6% in 2014.

site_title: US oil, gas industry sheds 100,000 jobs in slump: Kemp
summary: The US oil and gas industry has shed around 100,000 jobs since October 2014, with a total reduction of 16% in employment at its peak. The number of people on the payroll of oil and gas extraction firms and support services fell by almost 87,000 between October 2014 and November 2015.

site_title: Lower prices boosted air travel in 2015: IATA
summary: Global air passenger traffic jumped 6.5% in 2015, driven by lower air fares, according to IATA. This marked the strongest rise in traffic since the 2010 post-financial crisis rebound, exceeding the 10-year average annual growth rate of 5.5%. IATA attributed the strong performance to "very strong demand for aviation connectivity" despite a weaker economic backdrop.

site_title: US productivity falls sharply in fourth quarter
summary: US nonfarm productivity fell at a 3.0% annual rate in the fourth quarter, the largest drop since 2014, due to a sharp slowdown in GDP growth and an acceleration in hiring. This decline reflects a lack of investment, leading to an unprecedented decline in capital intensity. As a result, unit labour costs rose at a 4.5% pace, the fastest rate in a year, and compensation per hour increased at a 1.3% rate. Economists blame weak productivity for stagnant wages and a lowered economy's speed limit.

site_title: ARA Asset Management Q4 profit up 41% on management fees, lower expenses
summary: ARA Asset Management reported a 41% increase in net profit for the fourth quarter to S$25.6 million, driven by higher management fees and lower expenses. Total revenue rose 7% to S$46.1 million, while total expenses declined to S$16.5 million. The company's lower net foreign exchange loss and higher interest expenses contributed to the profit increase.

site_title: China's corruption watchdog finds no major problems with financial agencies
summary: China's Central Commission for Discipline Inspection found no major problems with 21 financial agencies, including the People's Bank of China and the State Administration of Foreign Exchange. Minor issues were identified, but the inspections were closely watched by investors due to the power wielded by these agencies. The central bank stated it will maintain a prudent monetary policy and fend off financial risks.

site_title: Jumbo Q1 net profit increases to S$2.08m
summary: Jumbo Restaurant group reported a net profit of S$2.08 million for the first quarter of 2016, up 24.5% from the same period last year. Revenue increased 7.6% to S$30.93 million, driven by the launch of its second Jumbo Seafood restaurant in Shanghai. Earnings per share remained flat at 0.3 Singapore cents. The increase in revenue is attributed to contributions from the Shanghai restaurant and overall growth from the rest of its restaurants.

site_title: Goldman Sachs and Pimco warn bond gains will turn into losses
summary: Goldman Sachs and Pimco have warned that bond gains are likely to turn into losses due to rising interest rates. Goldman Sachs' chief economist Jan Hatzius predicts a 3% benchmark yield by year-end, up from 1.91% currently. Pimco also expects higher yields, citing strong fundamentals in the US economy, despite some downside risks. The two firms' views align with Bloomberg's survey of economists, which projects yields will rise throughout 2016.

site_title: Technics Oil & Gas' Q1 net loss widens to S$1.21m
summary: Technics Oil & Gas reported a widened net loss of S$1.21 million in Q1 2016, down from S$593,000 in the same period last year, due to weak market demand. Revenue fell 18% to S$15.17 million. The group had previously issued a profit warning, expecting an operating net loss for the quarter. Loss per share stood at 0.53 cents, compared to 0.25 cents in the previous year. No dividend was declared.

site_title: Lower fuel costs boost bottom line for SIA in Q3
