summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a net profit of nearly S$275 million for the third quarter of 2015, driven by lower fuel costs. Revenue declined 3.9% to S$3.94 billion, mainly due to weaker yields from passenger and cargo operations. Operating profit rose to S$288 million, nearly doubling from the previous year, despite higher taxes. SIA attributed the challenging operating environment to volatile travel demand and increased competition from low-cost carriers in South-east Asia.

site_title: Credit Suisse Asia-Pacific sees no cuts in jobs, bonuses: top executive
summary: Credit Suisse Asia-Pacific will not cut jobs or bonuses, with a focus on hiring private bankers in the region. The bank has hired 70 new relationship managers and remains committed to hiring more talent. In contrast, the bank will reduce costs through "rightsizing" its London presence.

site_title: ECB should separate monetary and supervisory decision makers: Bundesbank
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) should separate its decision-making bodies for monetary policy and banking supervision to avoid conflicts of interest, according to Claudia Buch, deputy president of Germany's Bundesbank. The current setup could lead to overlapping responsibilities and decisions, and simplifying the rules governing the participation of the European Commission and the Council in the Single Resolution Mechanism for winding up failed banks would also be desirable. This separation could improve the effectiveness and credibility of the ECB's decisions.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank should have separate decision-making bodies for monetary policy and banking supervision as the current set-up could lead to conflicts of interest, the deputy president of Germany's Bundesbank said on Thursday.

site_title: ASL posts 19.8% increase in Q2 profit
summary: ASL Marine reported a 19.8% increase in Q2 attributable profit to S$1.82 million, up from S$1.52 million last year. Total revenue for Q2 FY15 was S$99.68 million, a significant turnaround from a negative turnover of S$21.09 million in Q2 FY14. The company's first half attributable profit was S$7.07 million, a 55.8% increase from last year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's central bank, MAS, is expected to ease monetary policy in April via a downward recentring of the Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate band. The Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal was signed by 12 member nations, but negotiations will still require years to complete. Short-selling in Noble Group Ltd surged to a record after the company's rally. Meanwhile, Maybank Singapore is in talks with MAS over incorporation, and HDB resale prices dropped 0.5% in January. The Straits Times Index closed 7.75 points higher, with Singapore shares ending the day higher despite intraday highs.

site_title: Beng Kuang, SMJ International, TSH Corp issue profit warnings
summary: Three Singapore companies issued profit warnings, citing significant declines in profits. Beng Kuang Marine will record a loss for its fourth quarter and 2015 financial year due to a main engine breakdown. TSH Corporation expects a net loss for 2015 due to fair value loss and lower revenue. SMJ International Holdings reported significantly lower net profit compared to 2014. The companies' warnings come amid market uncertainty, with investors weighing market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions.

site_title: Boustead Projects awarded contracts worth S$70m
summary: Boustead Projects has secured contracts worth S$70 million in the past three months, including a design-and-build contract for an industrial facility in Malaysia and two construction contracts for a petrochemical complex. The new deals have raised the company's order book backlog to S$305 million. These contracts are not expected to significantly impact the company's profitability or earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: China says foreign exchange reserves remain abundant despite recent falls
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves remain abundant despite a record US$512.66 billion drop to US$3.33 trillion in 2015, according to the State Administration of Foreign Exchange. The reserves are still far below the 100% international safety line, and risks from cross-border capital movements are under control. China is expected to post a surplus in its current account and a deficit in the capital and financial account in 2016, with a current account surplus of US$293.2 billion and a capital and financial account deficit of US$161.1 billion.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate's net profit up 93% to S$41.1m for quarter ended Dec 31
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings reported a 93% increase in net profit to S$41.11 million for the quarter ended Dec 31, 2015, driven by higher fair value gains and improved contributions from Singapore and China operations. Revenue rose 90% to S$28.40 million, excluding the impact of a one-off transaction in the year-ago period. The company will issue a dividend of 0.4 cents per share and its shares ended one cent higher at 86 cents.

site_title: UK house price growth surges again in January: Halifax
summary: UK house prices rose 1.7% in January, outpacing forecasts of a 0.3% increase, driven by a shortage of new homes on the market. This marks a slower pace than December's 2.0% growth. Year-over-year, prices increased 9.7%, up from 9.5% in December.

site_title: Pteris unit wins HK$238m contract
summary: A subsidiary of Pteris Global Limited, Shenzhen CIMC-Tianda Airport Support Co Ltd, has won a contract worth HK$238.5 million from the Airport Authority Hong Kong to supply and replace 75 aircraft loading bridges at Hong Kong International Airport's Terminal 1. The contract is expected to be completed by 2018 and is expected to positively contribute to Pteris Global's earnings per share and net tangible assets.

site_title: Goldman Sachs with Pimco warn bond gains will turn into losses
summary: Goldman Sachs and Pimco predict bond gains will turn into losses due to expected interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. The benchmark yield is forecast to rise to 3% by year-end, surpassing traders' expectations. Global economic growth is expected to subdue deflation fears, leading to increased monetary normalization. The companies have a "small underweight" position in global bonds, indicating a potential shift in market sentiment. This warning comes as the bond market is "underestimating the amount of monetary normalization that we're likely to see," according to Goldman Sachs' chief economist.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng Q4 profit drops 94.2% to S$9.8 million
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corp's fourth-quarter net profit plummeted 94.2% to S$9.8 million, largely due to decreased revenue from property developments and construction. The company reported a 58.3% decline in property development revenue and a 74.2% decline in sales from its Alexandra Central retail project. Chip Eng Seng guided for challenging conditions in the property development and construction sectors but expects an improvement in its hospitality business. The company also announced a 4.0 Singapore cent per share dividend for the year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 23.47 points to close at 1,656.77, driven by gains of 512 stocks. The index saw 2.05 billion lots valued at RM2.08 billion traded.

site_title: Acra tells PwC to ensure independence in SingPost special audit: SIAS
summary: The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) has instructed PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) to ensure its independence as the special auditor of Singapore Post. Acra warned that it will take regulatory action if PwC fails to comply with the Acra Code. PwC, which has been SingPost's external auditor since 2003, has been named as the special auditor for the company. SIAS (Securities Investors Association Singapore) has called on all parties to allow PwC to conduct the special audit while maintaining its independence.

site_title: China forex regulator eases capital rules for foreign investors
summary: China's foreign exchange regulator has eased capital rules for foreign investors, aiming to further open the domestic capital market. The Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor scheme (QFII) will see an upward investment limit raised and quota approval procedures simplified. Rules restricting QFIIs from moving capital in and out of China will also be relaxed. The move is expected to increase foreign investment in China's capital market, providing a boost to the country's economic growth.

site_title: India's IT exports seen growing 10-12% in fiscal 2017: industry body
summary: India's IT exports are expected to grow 10-12% in fiscal 2017, reaching US$121 billion, driven by high-margin digital services. The National Association of Software and Services Companies (Nasscom) attributes this growth to new business wins in digital services, shifting focus away from routine technology services contracts. This growth is expected to continue in fiscal 2016, with exports reaching US$108 billion, a 12.3% increase.

site_title: Wing Tai Q2 net profit sinks 85% to S$1.08m
summary: Wing Tai Holdings reported a 85% year-on-year decline in Q2 net profit to S$1.08 million, with revenue dipping 5% to S$120.61 million. For the half year, net profit dropped 90% to S$3.11 million, despite a 1% increase in revenue to S$298.87 million. Earnings per share fell to 0.14 Singapore cents, lower than the 0.93 cents recorded last year. No dividend was declared.

site_title: British police to arrest Wikileaks founder Assange if he leaves the Ecuadorian embassy
summary: British police have stated they will arrest WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange if he leaves the Ecuadorian embassy in London. Assange has been in the embassy since 2012 to avoid extradition to Sweden, where he faces questioning over alleged rape in 2010. A UN panel's ruling is expected to determine his fate. If Assange leaves the embassy, police will make an effort to arrest him, citing a still-active warrant.

site_title: Taiwan exports suffer double-digit fall in Jan, but better than Dec
summary: Taiwan's exports in January fell by double-digits, but the decline was less severe than the 13.9% drop in December. Finance Minister Chang Sheng-Ford attributed the decline to a high base last year. January exports are expected to continue declining due to this high base.

site_title: UBS cuts year-end target for European shares by 8%
summary: Swiss bank UBS reduced its year-end target for the pan-European STOXX 600 index by 8% to 400 points, citing slightly weaker economic growth and lower earnings growth. The bank cut its forecast for eurozone GDP to 1.6% for 2016 and 1.7% for 2017, also due to low oil prices and tighter credit market conditions. UBS lowered its 2016 EPS growth forecast to 8% from 13%, still above consensus.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rebound at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rebounded at the start of trading on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 jumping 1.5% to 5,925.6 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 rising 0.9%, and Paris's CAC 40 winning 1.2%. The rebound comes after heavy falls the previous session, amid a run of volatility in world equities. The rebound is attributed to gains in mining and healthcare stocks.

images.alt_text: Europe's main stock markets rallied at the start of trading on Thursday, rebounding from heavy falls the previous session as world equities extend a run of volatility.

site_title: Julian Assange will leave Ecuador embassy, accept arrest if loses UN case
summary: Wikileaks founder Julian Assange will leave the Ecuadorian embassy in London on Friday, accepting arrest if a UN panel rules against him. Assange took refuge in the embassy in 2012 to avoid extradition to Sweden on allegations of sexual assault and rape, which he denies.

site_title: Eurozone GDP to grow at moderate rate in 2016, 2017: Commission
summary: The European Commission estimates that the Eurozone's GDP will grow at a moderate rate of 1.7% in 2016 and 1.9% in 2017. External factors, including slower growth in emerging markets and geopolitical tensions, pose risks to the economy. Despite this, low oil prices, cheap credit, and the weak euro are expected to boost growth. All Eurozone countries, except Greece, are forecasted to grow this year, with Greece's economy expected to return to growth in 2017.

images.alt_text: Eurozone economic growth will slightly accelerate this year and next, the European Commission estimated on Thursday, but the pace will be slower in 2016 than previously forecast because of increased global risks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end up on energy stocks, weaker US dollar
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.0% to 19,183.09, driven by a 4.6% surge in energy shares, fueled by oil price rebounds and a weaker US dollar, which fell to its lowest level in three months.

site_title: Roadside recovery firm AA starts insurance underwriting business
summary: AA, a roadside recovery firm, has started underwriting insurance, expanding its existing insurance broking business. The company aims to underwrite 250,000 policies over the next few years, focusing on car insurance for AA members. Trading is on track, and the move is seen as a response to rising car insurance premiums. AA sold its first policy in January to a schoolteacher in Sheffield, marking the start of its new insurance underwriting venture.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher, but well off intraday highs
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index ended 7.75 points firmer at 2,558.49, despite a late-day decline. The market rose due to a 100-point increase in Dow futures and marginally firmer oil prices, but fell short of its intraday high of 2,579. Offshore and marine stocks rose, but banks were mixed. The gains were modest, with Keppel Corp and SembCorp Marine rising only slightly.

site_title: Toyota studies bringing Daihatsu to India in threat to Suzuki
summary: Toyota is studying the Indian market for its Daihatsu brand, which could pose a threat to Suzuki Motor Co.'s market leader position through Maruti Suzuki India Ltd. Toyota plans to introduce all-new models and smaller cars at competitive prices if it decides to bring Daihatsu to India. The move comes as India is expected to become the world's third-largest car buyer by 2019, surpassing Germany and Japan. Toyota aims to make Daihatsu a wholly owned subsidiary using $3.2 billion in stock.

site_title: Fingerprint Cards sales soar on biometric demand from China
summary: Fingerprint Cards AB, a Swedish biometric technology maker, reported a 12-fold surge in fourth-quarter sales to 1.35 billion kronor (US$160 million), driven by demand from mobile-phone makers in China. The company raised its revenue outlook for this year to 7-8.5 billion kronor and proposed a 5-to-1 stock split. Its stock jumped 6.1% to 471.40 kronor, giving the company a market value of 28 billion kronor. The company's technology is being adopted for secure mobile payments in China, where it has established a market-leading position.

site_title: China firms keen on US$1b Hong Kong insurance asset auction: sources
summary: Chinese companies, including Country Garden Holdings and China Life, have shown strong interest in bidding for Hong Kong's US$1 billion insurance asset of Dah Sing Financial Holdings, amid a slowing mainland economy and weakening yuan. Over 20 Chinese companies have expressed interest, with global insurers also participating. The sale process is confidential, but the Chinese interest highlights the broader issue of capital outflows, which have reached about US$700 billion last year. This surge in outbound purchases undermines Beijing's efforts to tackle capital outflows and could lead to overpaying for assets.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down as stronger yen hits exporters
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.85% as a stronger yen negatively impacted exporters. The Nikkei 225 index dropped to 17,044.99, while the Topix index fell 1.24% to 1,388.81. Panasonic and Hitachi plummeted due to concerns over a China slowdown affecting their financial results.

site_title: Nestle to buy out food maker Osem for about 3.3b shekels
summary: Nestle SA agreed to buy out Osem Investments Ltd, Israel's largest publicly-traded foodmaker, for approximately 3.3 billion shekels (S$1.19 billion). The deal, valued at 82.50 shekels per share, represents a 26% increase from the previous closing price. This acquisition marks Nestle's largest food deal since 2012, as the company shifts focus to consolidating its international operations. The purchase is expected to be completed by an extraordinary meeting on March 17, with JP Morgan Chase & Co serving as the sole adviser.

site_title: Hackers attack 20m accounts on Alibaba's Taobao shopping site
summary: Hackers attempted to access over 20 million active accounts on Alibaba's Taobao e-commerce website using the company's cloud computing service. The attack, detected in November, involved hackers inputting 99 million usernames and passwords into Taobao, with 20.59 million matching existing accounts. The hackers used compromised accounts to fake orders and sell accounts for fraud. Alibaba's systems blocked most log-in attempts and the hackers were caught. The incident led to a 3.7% decline in Alibaba's US-listed shares.

site_title: Stocks rise as weak dollar, US rate outlook keep oil strong
summary: Stocks rose globally on Thursday, driven by energy companies as the US dollar weakened due to speculation that interest rates may not rise this year. The dollar fell 0.2% against a basket of peers, its largest one-day percentage drop since 1998-2009. Oil prices remained strong, partly due to the weak dollar. The US currency reached its 14-week low against the euro and its weakest level against the Japanese yen. The rise in energy stocks and weak dollar lifted global stocks, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records.

site_title: Hong Kong property sales fall 12% in 2015, underscore economy fears
summary: Hong Kong property sales plummeted 12% in 2015, with a 12.3% decline in domestic sale and purchase agreements and a 3.9% drop in total consideration to $417 billion. The slowdown is attributed to economic fears, cooling activity in China, and a growing drag on the Asia financial center. Property-related businesses account for nearly a fifth of the city's economic output, and analysts expect a further decline in property prices this year.

site_title: ECB's Draghi says failing to act early on inflation is risky
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi warned that acting too late on ultra-low inflation poses a greater risk than acting too early, as a wait-and-see stance could lead to a lasting loss of confidence and persistently weaker inflation. Draghi stated that if expectations are de-anchored, a more accommodative monetary policy would be needed to reverse it, making the risks of acting too late outweigh the risks of acting too early.

site_title: South Korea slams North rocket launch, vows to destroy any threat
summary: South Korean President Park Geun Hye has vowed to destroy any North Korean threat, calling the planned rocket launch "a threat to peace on the Korean peninsula and to the world." The launch, set for February 8-25, would violate UN sanctions and Security Council resolutions. South Korea's defence ministry has issued orders to destroy any missile that might stray over its territory, and Japan has also issued a similar "destroy" order. The planned launch poses a dilemma for the international community, which is struggling to find a united response to North Korea's recent nuclear test.

site_title: KSH Q3 profit up 21.3% despite lower revenue
summary: KSH Holdings reported a 21.3% increase in net profit to S$13.8 million in Q3, despite a 9.5% decline in revenue to S$54.1 million. Lower construction costs and associate results contributed to the earnings growth. The company's earnings per share rose to 3.07 cents from 2.75 cents a year ago.

site_title: Singapore's MAS likely to ease monetary policy in April: BMI
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is likely to ease monetary policy in April, according to BMI Research, citing consistently negative CPI readings, poor export growth, and middling economic growth. The forecasted depreciation of the Singapore dollar and a CPI average of 0.3% is driven by lower oil prices, which may keep consumer prices sub-zero for a second year. The MAS will focus on core inflation, stripping out accommodation and private transport costs, in its decision-making process.

images.alt_text: Market research firm BMI Research expects Singapore's central bank to ease monetary policy in April, via a downward recentring of the Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate (S$NEER) band.

site_title: Mitsui lowers profit forecast amid rout in commodity market
summary: Mitsui & Co, Japan's second-largest trading house, lowered its full-year profit forecast by 21% due to a collapse in commodity prices. The company now expects a profit of 190 billion yen, down from 240 billion yen. The decline is attributed to the drop in iron ore, oil, and natural gas prices, which are expected to continue until 2020. This revision follows a wave of writedowns forecast for Japan's trading houses, with Mitsubishi Corp also reviewing its assets due to low prices.

site_title: HDB resale prices drop for first time in seven months: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices dropped 0.5% in January 2016, marking the first decline in seven months. Year-over-year, prices fell 1.3% from January 2015, and 11.1% since the peak in April 2013. Resale volume decreased 8.6% to 1,286 units, a 64.8% drop from its peak in May 2010.

site_title: Gold clings near 3-month peak as US rate hike views ease
summary: Gold prices remain near a three-month high after rising 1.2% in its best day in two weeks, boosted by expectations of a delayed US interest rate hike due to global economic uncertainty. The Federal Reserve's president, William Dudley, stated that tightening financial conditions and a weakening global outlook could have significant consequences for the US economy. This has led to market expectations that the Fed will postpone rate hikes until the second half of 2016.

site_title: Noble Group short selling surges to record after rally
summary: Noble Group Ltd's short selling surged to a record after the company's shares rallied 15% on Jan 29, the most in three months. The commodity trader is raising $750 million in cash from selling its remaining stake in its agricultural unit to bolster liquidity. This comes after Noble Group lost about two-thirds of its market value last year amid accounting criticism. The short selling increase may indicate market skepticism about the company's ability to recover.

site_title: Credit Suisse posts loss on impairment, trading downturn
summary: Credit Suisse Group AG posted a loss in the fourth quarter due to a 5.83 billion Swiss franc (S$8.2 billion) impairment and provisions for litigation and trading downturns. The bank's global markets division booked a pretax loss of 3.47 billion francs. CEO Tidjane Thiam announced plans to cut 4,000 jobs and save 500 million francs a year, accelerating cost-savings efforts. The bank proposed a dividend of 70 centimes per share, with an option for shareholders to receive stock instead.

site_title: Shell reports profits plunge on oil price slump
summary: Royal Dutch Shell reported a 87% plunge in annual net profits to $1.94 billion in 2015 due to slumping oil prices. The company had previously forecast $1.6-2.0 billion in profit. Shell is slashing 10,000 jobs, selling assets, and exiting projects as oil prices tumble. The company is nearing a $68 billion takeover of BG Group, which will strengthen its position in the liquefied natural gas market. Oil prices have fallen 75% in 18 months, prompting sector-wide cost-cutting measures.

images.alt_text: Royal Dutch Shell on Thursday announced an 87-per cent plunge in annual net profits on slumping oil prices.

site_title: China charges former senior police chief with murder, graft
summary: Chinese prosecutors have charged former police chief Zhao Liping with murder, bribery, and possession of firearms and explosives in connection with the 2015 murder of his mistress, whom he allegedly killed after she threatened to expose his corrupt behavior. Zhao, who served as police chief in Inner Mongolia from 2005 to 2010, was also accused of abusing his position to gain benefits and taking bribes. The charges reflect President Xi Jinping's efforts to root out corruption in the Communist Party, with Inner Mongolia being a strategically located and politically sensitive region.

site_title: First Reit, Lippo Malls Trust buy integrated development in Yogyakarta
summary: First Reit has entered into a joint venture with Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) to jointly buy an integrated development in Yogyakarta, Indonesia. The property, comprising Siloam Hospitals Yogyakarta and a retail mall, was acquired at a discount of 9.69% to its higher valuation. The joint acquisition boosts First Reit's portfolio to 18 properties and strengthens its asset base by 3.15%. First Reit will finance the hospital portion using debt facilities, while LMIRT will finance the retail mall using debt financing.

site_title: Oil prices extend rebound in Asia
summary: Oil prices rebounded in Asia, rising 1.12% to $32.64 for US West Texas Intermediate and 0.83% to $35.33 for Brent crude. The surge was driven by a weaker dollar and speculation of a possible Opec output cut. Despite bearish data showing a rise in US commercial crude inventories, analysts attributed the rebound to bargain buying. However, concerns over the global glut remain, and any price rise is expected to be short-lived unless backed by concrete movements from influential producers.

site_title: 150 years on, exhibit probes the dark world of 'Crime and Punishment'
summary: A new 150-year-old exhibition in Saint Petersburg, Russia, delves into the dark world of Fyodor Dostoyevsky's 'Crime and Punishment', exploring its themes of morality, freedom, and human life. The exhibit, located in Dostoyevsky's former apartment, immerses visitors in the novel's world with its vast collection of paintings, sketches, documents, and antiques. The exhibit showcases three dimensions: the pre-revolutionary city, the era of the novel's setting, and the philosophical and religious themes. Visitors can see recreated scenes, rare objects, and artworks that shed new light on the classic novel, which has been translated into multiple languages and adapted for the screen.

site_title: Toshiba sees bigger loss as restructuring costs mount
summary: Toshiba Corp expects a bigger loss of 710 billion yen (S$8.51 billion) due to mounting restructuring costs, following a US$1.3 billion accounting scandal. The company had previously forecast a loss of 550 billion yen. Toshiba is also slashing 6,800 consumer electronics jobs, taking total cuts to over 10,000. The scandal involved overstating profits from 2009.

site_title: China's West Air to start its thrice-weekly service to Singapore
summary: China's West Air, a Chongqing-based airline, will launch its thrice-weekly service between Singapore and Chongqing, marking the carrier's first international service. The new service, on an Airbus A320-200, starts with an inaugural flight expected to arrive in Singapore on Thursday. The move is part of a bilateral pledge to enhance air connectivity between Singapore and Chongqing, following a six-party Memorandum of Strategic Cooperation signed in January 2016. The service aims to boost transfer traffic and cultivate the aviation market between Singapore and Western China under China's "One Belt, One Road" plan.

site_title: BOJ not engaging in currency war with negative rates: Kuroda
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the central bank's adoption of negative interest rates is not part of a currency war, but rather aimed at stimulating consumption and investment by pushing down real interest rates. Kuroda emphasized that the BOJ does not target exchange rates in guiding monetary policy, similar to other major central banks.

site_title: Asia: Most markets rally, oil extends gains as dollar eases
summary: Asian markets rallied, with oil extending gains, as the US dollar eased. Energy firms led the gains amid hopes for Opec-Russia talks on output cuts. The rally follows a volatile start to 2016, with traders concerned over the global economy and oil prices. The US dollar fell despite US interest rate hike expectations being lowered.

site_title: Top US airlines offer to re-assign crew from Zika-hit routes
summary: Top US airlines United and Delta have offered to re-assign flight crew from Zika-hit routes to avoid contracting the Zika virus. United and Delta have internal memos allowing expectant flight attendants and pilots to switch routes without repercussions. The airlines have also offered refunds for flights to impacted areas and are providing options for crew members to drop their re-assigned trips without pay. The move comes amid concerns about the virus, which has been linked to thousands of birth defects in Brazil, and is prompting travel agents to report a decline in bookings for "babymooners".

site_title: Apple Pay locations reach 2m, with Chick-fil-A to come
summary: Apple Pay has expanded to over 2 million retail locations, including merchants like Chick-fil-A, Crate & Barrel, and Au Bon Pain. The service has also seen in-app purchase volume more than double in the last six months. Despite its growth, most US consumers remain reluctant to use Apple Pay, and in-store terminals are still largely unaccepting. The company aims to compete with rivals like Google's Android Pay and mobile wallets from major banks and retailers, with CEO Richard Crone predicting every large bank and retailer will have its own mobile wallet.

site_title: RBS scraps sale process for US$2.8b Indian banking business
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland Group Plc has scrapped its sale process for its US$2.8 billion Indian banking business, citing it's not feasible to sell the business in its entirety. The bank will consider winding down or selling individual parts of the business, resulting in job losses for most of its 600 employees in India by the end of the year. The decision follows a failed auction process, with bidders disagreeing on employee pension liabilities and guarantees for clients.

site_title: China growth to remain weak, deflationary pressure increasing: PBOC researcher
summary: China's economic growth is expected to remain weak, with increasing deflationary pressure, according to a senior researcher at the People's Bank of China. Lu Lei, head of research, warned that the government should take measures to prevent excessive volatility in money, currency, and stock markets. This comes as China's GDP growth is set to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks rally at open
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rose at the opening on February 4, 2016, due to lower expectations of US interest rate hikes and a surge in oil prices. The Hang Seng Index climbed 1.52% to 19,279.35, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.44% to 2,751.43. Energy firms were boosted, and other indices also saw gains.

site_title: Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal signed, but years of negotiations still to come
summary: The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal was signed by 12 member nations, including the US and Japan, in New Zealand on February 4, 2016. However, the agreement still requires years of negotiations and ratification, with a two-year process needed for approval by at least six countries. The deal aims to set common standards on issues like workers' rights and intellectual property protection in 12 Pacific nations, but faces opposition from US Democrats and some Republicans, and widespread grassroots opposition in many countries.

site_title: Sharp board said to be divided on making bailout decision today
summary: Sharp Corp's directors are divided over a bailout decision, with some supporting a government-backed plan and others favoring a deal with Foxconn Technology Group. Foxconn is offering about 660 billion yen, while the government-backed Innovation Network Corp of Japan is proposing 300 billion yen. A deal with INCJ would allow Sharp to keep its technology within Japan, while a deal with Foxconn could provide more financial support. Sharp's board meeting may be delayed as the directors debate the options.

site_title: Australia: Shares enjoy relief rally as oil jumps, NZ stocks flat
summary: Australian shares rose 1.4% on Thursday, driven by a surge in oil prices, which boosted resource companies like BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 70 points to 4,946.8. Gains also extended to major banks, while investment bank Macquarie shed 6% after a profit warning. New Zealand's benchmark index remained relatively unchanged.

site_title: Thailand grows old waiting for democracy as junta looks for love
summary: Thailand waits for a new constitution and the restoration of democracy, with the military junta drafting the nation's 20th constitution. Despite a 98.6% approval rating for Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha, the economy has struggled, with foreign direct investment slumping 78% and exports falling for three consecutive years. The junta claims it's taking time to unify the country's polarized factions, but critics say it's just delaying the inevitable. An election is set for mid-2017, but the draft charter could be rejected, and public protests could reignite.

site_title: Ascott signs seven new management contracts in Southeast Asia
summary: Ascott, a serviced residence business unit of CapitaLand, has signed seven new management contracts in Southeast Asia, adding over 1,500 apartment units to its portfolio. The new contracts are in Bangkok, Thailand; Hanoi, Vietnam; Petaling Jaya, Malaysia; Bandung, Indonesia; Penang, Malaysia; and Nha Trang, Vietnam. The new properties are expected to open by the end of 2016 and 2017, with the goal of doubling the portfolio to 80,000 units globally by 2020, according to Ascott CEO Lee Chee Koon.

site_title: US dollar suffers worst day in 7 years on signs of slowing economy, down 1% against Singdollar
summary: The US dollar experienced its worst day in 7 years, plummeting 1.7% against 9 major peers due to signs of a slowing US economy. The currency also fell to its lowest point since the start of the year to the Singapore dollar, trading at 1.4153 to the Singdollar. The decline was attributed to concerns about cooling US growth, which may impact global central banks' diverging policies.

site_title: Taiwan: Stock market closed Feb 4-12 for Lunar New Year
summary: Taiwan's stock market will be closed from February 4-12 for the Lunar New Year holiday, with the currency and money markets remaining open until the end of session on Friday. Markets will reopen on February 15.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 6.87 points to 1638.09. The index saw 46.9 million lots traded worth RM21.62 million, with 155 gainers and 54 losers.

site_title: Pacific rim nations sign US-led trade deal amid protests
summary: The US-led Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) was signed in New Zealand on February 4, 2016, by 12 member nations, including Pacific rim countries, amid loud protests. The pact aims to reduce trade barriers and investment barriers between countries comprising 40% of the global economy. The ceremony was led by New Zealand Prime Minister John Key and US Trade Representative Mike Froman, despite roadblocks outside the convention center where the signing took place. The agreement has significant implications for global trade and investment.

site_title: Yum posts unexpected fall in revenue as KFC, Pizza Hut struggle
summary: Yum Brands Inc reported a 2.5% drop in fourth-quarter revenue to US$3.95 billion, missing analysts' expectations. The decline was attributed to struggles from KFC and Pizza Hut restaurants, which faced challenges from a strong dollar, food scandals, and competition in the US. The company's China business, which accounts for about half its sales, saw a 2% increase in sales at established restaurants, but KFC system sales fell 5% and Pizza Hut system sales declined 2%. Yum Brands is on track to complete the spinoff of its China business by the end of the year.

site_title: Trump accuses Cruz of fraud in Iowa, demands re-vote
summary: Donald Trump accused Republican rival Ted Cruz of committing fraud in Iowa's caucuses, demanding a re-vote or his win nullified. Trump claimed Cruz stole the victory, citing incorrect polls and lied to voters about his policies. Cruz won 27.7% of the vote, finishing ahead of Trump's 24%. The accusations came despite Trump's gracious concession speech, raising questions about his winning strategy.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.59% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index increasing 15.02 points to 2,565.76. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Globally, the Dow and S&P 500 rose, while the Nasdaq Composite Index fell. The Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped 1.13% to 16,336.66, while the S&P 500 rose 0.50% to 1,912.53.

site_title: Bank of England to head back to the sidelines as global growth slows
summary: The Bank of England is expected to maintain interest rates on hold as it waits for signs of a turnaround in the slowing global economy and fading British wage growth. Governor Mark Carney will publish the bank's latest economic forecasts, which are expected to show near-zero inflation and a cautious outlook. The decision comes as investors await news on the UK's potential referendum on EU membership, which could unsettle markets and keep interest rates low for another two years. Economists expect the bank to raise interest rates in November this year.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England (BoE) is expected to show on Thursday that interest rates are back on hold while it waits for signs of turnarounds in the slowing global economy and fading British wage growth.

site_title: Cisco buying IoT platform Jasper for US$1.4b
summary: Cisco has acquired IoT platform Jasper Technologies for $1.4 billion. The deal aims to accelerate the recognition of the Internet of Things (IoT) value by enabling service providers, enterprises, and the ecosystem to connect, automate, manage, and analyze billions of connected devices. Jasper's platform allows businesses to connect any device over cellular networks and manage connectivity services in the cloud. The acquisition is expected to close early this year, with Cisco planning to build upon the Jasper IoT platform to create new revenue streams and opportunities.

site_title: Honda adds 2.2 million vehicles to Takata air bag recall
summary: Honda is expanding its recall of North American vehicles equipped with potentially defective Takata air bags, adding 2.23 million vehicles to the existing recall. The affected models include Acura and Honda vehicles from 2005-2016. No PSDI-5 ruptures have been reported in Honda's vehicles, but defective inflators have been linked to nine US deaths. Honda will replace the inflators with parts from another supplier starting this summer. The recall is part of a broader effort by US regulators to address the issue, which affects an estimated 24 million vehicles.

images.alt_text: Honda Motor Co Ltd is expanding its recall in North America of late-model vehicles equipped with potentially defective Takata air bags, adding 2.23 million vehicles, the automaker said Wednesday.

site_title: Apple ordered to pay US$625m in patent dispute with VirnetX
summary: A federal jury in Texas ordered Apple to pay VirnetX Holding Corp $625 million for using its Internet security technology without permission in FaceTime and iMessage features. The award was more than the $532 million VirnetX had requested and marked the second time the companies battled in court. A previous trial resulted in a $368 million award, but a US appeals court ruled the award was incorrectly calculated and ordered a new trial. Apple has filed for a mistrial, claiming VirnetX's attorneys misled the jury during closing arguments.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 rise with oil; Nasdaq falls
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumping 183.12 points (1.13%) to 16,336.66, and the S&P 500 rising 9.50 (0.50%) to 1,912.53. Energy and industrial names surged, driven by rising oil prices, while technology names like Google parent Alphabet and Amazon fell. The Nasdaq Composite Index fell 12.71 (0.28%) to 4,504.24.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down 0.7 per cent over higher yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened down 0.7% on Thursday following the dollar's sharp decline against the yen, amid concerns over rising economic risks. The Nikkei 225 index lost 120.14 points to 17,071.11, and the Topix index fell 0.98% to 1,392.43. The decline was attributed to the comments of a top Federal Reserve official, which sparked concerns about the US economy.

site_title: Mall operator CEO clarifies comments on Amazon bookstores
summary: Mall operator General Growth Properties CEO Sandeep Mathrani clarified comments on Amazon's plans for physical bookstores. Mathrani initially stated Amazon planned to open 300 to 400 bookstores, which drove down shares of Barnes & Noble. However, Mathrani did not confirm or deny Amazon's plans for bookstores in his follow-up statement, leaving the matter unclear.

site_title: GoPro shares dive as company logs losing quarter
summary: GoPro shares plummeted after the company reported a quarterly loss of $34.5 million, with revenue sinking 31% to $436.6 million. Despite a 16% year-over-year revenue growth, profit declined 71.8% to $36.13 million. The company forecast a revenue range of $160-180 million for the current quarter. GoPro also announced a 7% workforce cut to realign resources with key growth initiatives, citing a need to develop software solutions to make content easier to manage.

site_title: GLP posts 64% increase to net profit in Q3
summary: GLP reported a 63.8% increase in net profit to US$184.2 million in Q3, driven by higher earnings in China (50% increase) and Japan (34% increase). Revenue rose 11.1% to US$198.9 million, fueled by development gains in Japan and the company's entry into the US market.

site_title: Google search chief Singhal to quit, to be replaced by AI head
summary: Google's search chief Amit Singhal is retiring and will be replaced by John Giannandrea, the company's head of artificial intelligence. Giannandrea will oversee Google's efforts in machine learning, aiming to make its search engine more sophisticated. The move signals Google's desire to incorporate AI-powered features, such as its personal assistant, into its search engine. Analysts see this shift as a key part of Google's future, with Singhal's departure contributing to a decline in the company's stock price.

images.alt_text: As one of Google's earliest search pioneers steps down and the company's leader in artificial intelligence takes his place, analysts say the move signals the company's desire to make its search engine more sophisticated.

site_title: Stocks to watch: GLP, CRCT, Religare Health Trust, Frasers Centrepoint, F&N
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) reported a 63.8% increase in net profit to US$184.2 million, driven by higher earnings in China and development gains in Japan. CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) posted a 4.4% increase in distribution per unit to 2.59 Singapore cents, while Religare Health Trust (RHT) reported a 5.7% rise in total distributable income to S$15.3 million. In contrast, Frasers Centrepoint Ltd (FCL) and Fraser and Neave (F&N) posted significant declines in net profit due to revenue and profit drops.

site_title: Boeing mulls model for midsize jetliner market next decade
summary: Boeing is considering a new midsize jetliner to fill the market gap left by the discontinued 757, with the goal of balancing prices with development costs. The company is studying options with customers and exploring single- and twin-aisle models, with a potential new model entering the market after the 777X's 2020 debut. Boeing faces increased competition from Airbus, which has seen success with the A321neo. If approved, the new model would seat around 220-240 passengers and enter the market in 2018 or 2020.

site_title: Yahoo strategy falls flat on Wall Street
summary: Yahoo shares dropped 4.75% on Wednesday after the company announced plans to cut 15% of its workforce and explore "strategic alternatives" for its future. The move comes after a big quarterly loss and years of struggling. Analysts believe the plan may signal the company's openness to a sale or merger, with Verizon and Microsoft considered likely suitors. Yahoo's CEO Marissa Mayer said the plan would be a "transitional year" with declining earnings, amid pressure from a key investor calling for changes in top management.

site_title: CRCT's DPU up 4.4% in Q4
summary: Capitaland Retail China Trust (CRCT) reported a 4.4% increase in DPU to 2.59 Singapore cents in Q4 2015, driven by rental growth from CapitaMall Qibao and CapitaMall Saihan. Gross revenue rose 6.7% to S$56.2 million, while net property income increased 5.2% to S$35.3 million. The trust's performance was stronger in SGD terms due to a weaker yuan.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slump on rising oil stocks
summary: European stocks slumped on Wednesday, with London, Frankfurt, and Paris losing 1.5-2.8% due to weak oil prices, which reached a 500 million barrel mark, their highest level since the 1930s. Despite this, Wall Street edged up 0.51% at the opening, with oil prices rebounding after falling below $30 a barrel. The US Department of Energy reported record commercial oil reserves, suppressing risk appetite and dragging down the banking sector.

site_title: Going for global growth
summary: Malaysian companies GSIB Sdn Bhd and Corporate Excelsior (M) Sdn Bhd won top awards at the One Asia Awards 2015, with GSIB focusing on green technology and safety in its construction projects. GSIB's portfolio includes green and developed buildings for corporate facilities, retail, and hospitality. The company's success is attributed to its emphasis on green technology, which contributed to its rapid growth.

site_title: US$104m UBS informant urges Swiss to back whistleblower law
summary: US$104 million informant Bradley Birkenfeld urges Swiss lawmakers to pass a whistleblower law, calling for changes in the environment that are hostile to exposing corruption. The law would provide protection for whistleblowers, but critics say it would still be "timid" compared to international standards. The proposed legislation would require employees to notify their employer before reporting wrongdoing to a government agency. Birkenfeld, who was awarded the US$104 million for revealing UBS's tax-evasion schemes, says Switzerland needs to "stop living in the past" and adopt stronger protections for whistleblowers.

images.alt_text: Bradley Birkenfeld, the banker awarded US$104 million by the US for revealing how he helped UBS Group AG hide assets for rich Americans, has a message for Swiss lawmakers wrangling over the draft of the nation's first whistleblowing law: "stop living in the past."

site_title: Hollande says opposed to 'new negotiations' over Britain's EU deal
summary: French President Francois Hollande stated that there should be no further changes to the proposed EU reforms to keep Britain in the EU when discussed at a Brussels summit in two weeks. He emphasized that the compromise would allow for solutions to previously difficult problems, but no new negotiations or adjustments were acceptable. The proposed deal includes an "emergency brake" to limit welfare payments for migrants and a mechanism for non-eurozone countries to raise concerns about eurozone decisions.

site_title: Oil prices surge on fresh talk of Opec meeting on glut
summary: Oil prices surged on Wednesday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate increasing 8.0% to $32.28 a barrel and Brent North Sea crude rising 7.1% to $35.04 a barrel. Speculation about a potential Opec meeting to cut production, fueled by comments from Ecuador, drove the rally. Despite a rise in US crude inventories, analysts believe prices may stabilize around the $30 level, with some speculating that the market has moved on to hope for production cuts. The dollar's weakness also contributed to the price surge.

images.alt_text: Oil prices surged Wednesday on renewed speculation about a potential cut in global production that overshadowed another rise in US crude inventories.

site_title: Yen shows limit of negative rates by wiping out BOJ drop in days
summary: The Bank of Japan's attempt to weaken the yen through negative interest rates has been met with limited success, as the currency has already reversed a 1.9% drop. Traders are warning the central bank that monetary policy may not be effective in managing currency fluctuations. The yen's demand as a safe-haven currency, driven by its current-account surplus, is also limiting the effectiveness of the policy. This trend is echoed in other economies, such as Vietnam and the UK, where currencies are also being driven by fundamental drivers rather than monetary policy.

site_title: Looking after the well-being of others
summary: Alternate Wellness Holdings P/L, founded by CEO ARICH Tan, is a winner of the One Asia Awards in the Emerging category. The company's flagship outlet, Natural Healings, aims to inspire people to manage their health without medication or surgery. Since its opening, the clinic has gained trust and improved the lives of many individuals, with success stories and expansion to five outlets within 30 months. Tan's business vision focuses on wellness, beauty, spa, nutrition, and product lines, with subsidiaries including chiropractic and physiotherapy services.

site_title: IMF: Oil crash a 'formidable shock' to African exporters
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has stated that the 70% decline in oil prices over the past 18 months will force significant fiscal adjustments on Africa's oil exporters, such as Nigeria and Angola. The IMF is working with affected countries to adjust economic policies, with fiscal adjustment needed in most cases. Nigeria has already approached the World Bank and African Development Bank for assistance, while the IMF remains ready to assist if needed. The IMF's Managing Director, Christine Lagarde, has expressed confidence in Nigeria's ability to manage its finances without an IMF loan program.

site_title: US dollar sinks on US economic outlook concerns
summary: The US dollar fell sharply on Wednesday due to concerns over the US economic outlook. The dollar lost nearly two cents on the euro and more than two yen after a disappointing report on US services sector growth and comments from Federal Reserve official William Dudley, who expressed concern over rising economic risks. The eurozone economy showed some strength, but the dollar's decline was driven by Dudley's caution and the ISM's US services sector purchasing managers index, which dropped more than expected, indicating sluggish growth.

site_title: Fake champagne makers busted in Italy
summary: Italian police seized 9,200 bottles of fake prosecco worth hundreds of thousands of euros in a workshop near Padua. Eight people face charges for producing and distributing counterfeit Moet & Chandon champagne. No one has been taken into custody. Authorities found a machine used to make metallic bottle wrappers, which are a key component of authentic champagne packaging.

site_title: Use of 'dictator law' rises in Thailand as junta's reforms falter
summary: Thailand's junta chief Prayuth Chan-ocha is increasingly relying on "dictator law" (Article 44) to push through unpopular policies and reforms, sparking concerns about further opposition to military rule. Since seizing power in 2014, Prayuth has used Article 44 over 50 times, often bypassing activists and public objections. Critics warn that this move gives him too much power and lacks checks and balances. The government's reforms have stalled, with the economy stuttering and many institutions unreformed, leaving the junta under pressure to show results.

site_title: Flight control: China banks pilot jet leasing firms in chase for US$228b market
summary: China's banks are expanding into the global aviation market, with four Chinese lessors, including Bank of China's BOC Aviation, among the world's top 15 by fleet value in a $228 billion industry. BOC Aviation is set to go public with an estimated $3 billion listing, and the company is seen as a model of success, with a focus on profitability and a fleet valued at over $10 billion. The move aims to create Chinese global champions and tap into predictable dollar-denominated revenue streams, as China's banks seek to grow abroad.

site_title: More central bank rate cuts coming before any hike
summary: Global interest rates are likely to decrease before rising due to financial market volatility and deflation concerns. Policymakers and economists believe central banks will ease monetary policy, with expectations of US rate hikes evaporating. Central banks in Europe, Canada, Australia, and others are preparing for further easing. Market turmoil, Chinese currency devaluation, and economic slowdowns in China and Vietnam are driving these expectations. Experts predict a global equity index target of 1,150 for mid-2026, with potential implications for economies and markets worldwide.

site_title: Firms should resist short-termism, create long-term value
summary: BlackRock urges CEOs to resist short-termism and create long-term value for their companies. The firm believes that companies should develop a strategic framework for long-term value creation and have their boards review these plans. This would help shift the focus from quarterly earnings to long-term growth, allowing companies to better navigate changing environments. BlackRock also emphasizes the importance of environmental and social (ESG) factors in generating sustainable returns. The firm encourages investors, the media, and public officials to join in changing the culture of short-term results.

site_title: Time to set up US-China forex swap agreement
summary: The US and China are set to negotiate a Federal Reserve-People's Bank of China (Fed-PBOC) swap agreement to facilitate dollar and renminbi liquidity on international financial markets. The deal, which would have a symbolic effect of shoring up the Chinese authorities' exchange commitment, aims to calm financial markets and strengthen the US Treasury's bid in international financial diplomacy. A contingent credit accord between the two central banks would expose the Fed to renminbi exchange rate risk, but Fed and Treasury officials argue it would be similar to existing arrangements.

site_title: Half in US think 'some' Muslims are anti-American: poll
summary: A US survey by the Pew Research Centre found that 49% of Americans believe at least some Muslims in the US have anti-American sentiments. 11% think most or almost all Muslims are anti-American, while 42% believe few or no Muslims harbor such feelings. The survey also showed a partisan divide, with Democrats more likely to think a few Muslims are anti-American and Republicans believing more widespread anti-Americanism. There is greater consensus on the issue of violence and religion, with 68% citing violent people using religion to justify actions.

site_title: A thirst for overseas expansion
summary: Two companies, Premium Water Co Ltd and Shenzhen Carku Technology Co Ltd, have expanded their businesses internationally, seeking overseas markets to increase sales. Premium Water Co Ltd, a Japan-based company, won the STAR Award at the One Asia Awards 2015, while Shenzhen Carku Technology Co Ltd achieved rapid growth in the last three years. The companies attribute their success to innovation, quality, and effective sales promotions. Both entrepreneurs emphasize the importance of being humble, decent, and grateful for circumstances to achieve business success.

site_title: Clinton steels for fight against Sanders in New Hampshire
summary: Hillary Clinton is gearing up for a tough fight against Bernie Sanders in New Hampshire's primary, despite a narrow victory in the Iowa caucuses. Clinton's campaign is shifting focus to New Hampshire, where polls show Sanders with a double-digit lead, and plans to court young voters and liberals. Sanders is planning a significant advertising campaign and has drawn $3 million in donations, giving him $28 million compared to Clinton's $38 million. The New Hampshire primary holds emotional significance for Clinton, who has a history of success in the state, and will use televised forums and debates to contrast with Sanders and win over voters.

site_title: BOJ chief defies reactions towards negative interest rate
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda defied reactions to the recent negative interest rate decision, stating that the BOJ will impose additional monetary easing tools if necessary to achieve its goals. Kuroda emphasized that there is "no limit" to these measures, indicating a willingness to explore new tools if existing ones are insufficient. He expressed confidence in the BOJ's ability to implement more aggressive lending measures to stimulate the economy.

site_title: Rouhani invites US firms to invest in changing Iranian economy
summary: Iran's President Hassan Rouhani invited US companies to invest in the country's economy, aiming to shift its reliance from oil exports and create a manufacturing sector. He said foreign investment would turn Iran into an exporter of goods, despite concerns about a hardline vetting body's exclusion of moderate allies from elections. Rouhani also acknowledged the need for reforms to achieve his economic transformation goals, which include 8% economic growth to combat inflation and unemployment.

site_title: Big Four continue to sweep top law rankings
summary: The Big Four law firms in Singapore, Allen & Gledhill, Rajah & Tann, WongPartnership, and Drew & Napier, continue to dominate the top rankings in the country, with Allen & Gledhill holding the most Band 1 rankings. WongPartnership achieved a Band 1 ranking in Banking & Finance for the first time, and Drew & Napier led in Technology, Media, Telecoms (TMT): Domestic and Dispute Resolution: Litigation categories for the sixth consecutive year. The rankings are based on factors such as technical legal ability, professional conduct, and client service.

site_title: CPFIS: Time to relook stapled, business trusts
summary: The CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) has been debating the inclusion of stapled trusts and business trusts, which are excluded due to perceived higher risks. However, experts argue that these trusts can be defined as property funds under the Code on Collective Investment Schemes and offer comparable yields to Reits. Stapled trusts and business trusts have low development activities and adhere to operational limits, making them comparable to other listed shares. The CPF Board's rules do not explicitly exclude stapled trusts, and foreign-incorporated companies are also excluded based on jurisdiction concerns, rather than necessarily being riskier.

site_title: Super Bowl stumbles into San Francisco's haves vs have-nots divide
summary: San Francisco's preparations for Super Bowl 50 have sparked controversy, with activists viewing the event as a symbol of the city's shift towards wealth inequality. The city's demographics have changed dramatically since the 1960s, with the influx of affluent newcomers, leaving some to worry that San Francisco is losing its left-wing politics and bohemian culture. Activists see the Super Bowl as a representation of the city's elite, while others are excited to celebrate the event.

site_title: Making sense of the stock rout puzzle
summary: The stock market's recent rout remains puzzling, with explanations ranging from a slowdown in China to low oil prices. However, evidence for these factors is limited, and alternative explanations, such as delayed reactions to a slowdown in the world economy, are more plausible. Herding behavior, driven by uncertainty and fear, is also a likely factor. If the stock market slump persists, it could lead to lower consumption, lower demand, and potentially a recession.

site_title: Beerless F&N less stout in Q1, but dairy finds whey to grow
summary: F&N's Q1 net profit dropped 26.9% to S$25.7 million due to the sale of its Myanmar brewery. However, continuing operations saw a 33.9% jump in earnings. The company's dairy business contributed to the growth, offsetting the decline. Despite the drop in net profit, F&N's shares closed at S$1.96.

site_title: No Chinese New Year joy yet for market
summary: The Singapore stock market continued its losing streak for the third consecutive session, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 28.49 points to 2,550.74. The broad market weakened, with losers outnumbering gainers 249 to 118. Concerns over the oil slump and China's economic slowdown led to a decline in blue chip stocks, including Global Logistic Properties and Hongkong Land. Market experts attribute the downturn to underlying market fears, including a US manufacturing contraction and China's economic slowdown, warning that the corporate earnings recession may be more pronounced in emerging markets.

site_title: Coffee prices may rebound as dry weather hits crops
summary: Dry weather in top coffee-producing regions of Brazil and Colombia is diminishing the outlook for this year's crop, forcing investors to trim bets that prices will fall. Following below-average rain, coffee prices have rebounded almost 5% from a two-year low, with arabica coffee adding 0.3% to $1.1635 a pound. The US Department of Agriculture forecasts a record world demand this season, while global production is expected to trail demand by 3.4 million bags, leading to a tightening supply situation and higher prices.

site_title: JLL warns of further correction in property prices
summary: JLL warns of a potential 4-6% quarterly decline in Singapore residential property prices, citing past correlation with the stock market. Recent stock market declines may signal a further correction, particularly if the market loses footing, potentially leading to a recessionary correction. The firm notes that China's economic conditions will be a key factor in determining the impact on Singapore's property market, with downside risks including higher unemployment, a weaker Singapore dollar, and rising domestic interest rates.

images.alt_text: Blocks of private residential condominiums (L) and executive condominiums in Singapore. Recent declines in the domestic stock market could signal a further correction in the city-state's property prices in the months ahead.

site_title: Successful women entrepreneurs
summary: Three successful women entrepreneurs, Lynn Chow, Emma Li Yuan Yuan, and Chanel Choo Foong Yee, share their experiences in setting up and growing their businesses. They emphasize the importance of skills, industrial experience, and perseverance in overcoming challenges. Winning the One Asia Award has helped them gain recognition and expand their networks. For budding entrepreneurs, they offer advice to be resilient, resourceful, and result-oriented, and to never give up on their goals despite difficulties. They also stress the need for creativity, strategic alliances, and a strong foundation to achieve success.

site_title: Big car COE premium drops 23%
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums for big cars plummeted 23% in the February-April 2016 quota, with Cat B premiums dropping to S$38,610. This unexpected drop was attributed to a combination of factors, including the end of the Chinese New Year rush and the recent stock market downturn. The increased supply of COEs, with 16.4% more available than the previous period, also contributed to the decline. Despite this, dealers reported a "steady stream" of Cat B orders and attributed the drop to low stock levels rather than decreased demand.

site_title: LVMH posts 16% rise in profit, beating expectations
summary: LVMH, the world's largest luxury group by sales, reported a 16% rise in full-year profit to 6.6 billion euros, exceeding analyst expectations. Total sales grew 6% to 35.7 billion euros, outpacing the global luxury market's estimated 2-3% growth. Despite weakness in China, the company attributed strong sales in the US, Europe, and Japan. CEO Bernard Arnault praised the results, stating LVMH's capacity to progress and gain market share despite economic uncertainty.

site_title: Yahoo open to offers for its core assets
summary: Yahoo is open to offers for its core assets, potentially leading to the end of the company as an independent entity. The company plans to lay off 15% of its 11,000 employees, reducing its workforce by 42% from 2012 levels. CEO Marissa Mayer aims to revitalize the company, shedding assets and focusing on growing areas. Despite its marginally profitable status, Yahoo is struggling to grow, with revenue down from 2014. The company's stock has declined in after-hours trading following the announcement. Activist investors, including Starboard Value, have expressed concerns over the company's direction.

site_title: Religare Health Trust posts lower net profit but higher DPU for Q3
summary: Religare Health Trust (RHT) reported a 3% drop in net profit to S$11.2 million for Q3 2015, but a 5.7% increase in total distributable income to S$15.3 million. The DPU rose 4.9% to 1.91 Singapore cents.

site_title: Mahathir's son ousted as Malaysia premier tightens grip
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak tightened his grip on power as the son of former leader Mahathir was ousted as Kedah's chief minister. Mukhriz Mahathir resigned, citing lack of support, and was replaced by Ahmad Bashah Mohd Hanipah, a deputy chair of Najib's party. This move comes after a months-long funding scandal, and analysts see it as Najib's effort to consolidate power.

site_title: GP Industries' Q3 profit falls in absence of large one-off gain
summary: GP Industries, a Singapore-based battery manufacturer, reported a 9.4% drop in net profit for the third quarter of 2015, primarily due to currency effects and the absence of a large one-off gain. Revenue rose 6.3% to S$272 million, with sales boosted by stronger Sing-dollar sales in Asia and the Americas. The company's nine-month net profit rose 12.9% to S$27 million, driven by stronger revenue and a larger forex gain. The firm also announced the appointment of Victor Lo as CEO, effective February 3.

site_title: Steely determination to succeed
summary: Hock Seng Hoe Metal Company Pte Ltd, a Singapore-based structural steel provider, has overcome numerous obstacles to establish itself as a reputable company. Founded in 2009, it offers quality steel materials for construction, shipyards, and other industries. The company's core business includes hot-dipped galvanising, cutting, and fabrications. Managing director Sam Chee Keong attributes his success to a business philosophy of "transforming the impossible to possible," emphasizing the importance of problem-solving and perseverance.

images.alt_text: "Winning awards helps to raise the profile of our business... but a key benefit for us has been the positive impact on team morale. We all work very hard and believe in what we do. To get recognition for that gives us an extra lift. It provides validation that you're doing a great job, which makes you feel good." - Sam Chee Keong, managing director, Hock Seng Hoe Metal Co

site_title: Wireless networks used to deliver in-flight pitches
summary: Airlines are introducing in-flight retail pitches via Wi-Fi, seeking a new revenue stream, but some travelers find it annoying. The onboard retail market is growing at a 13% year-over-year rate, with airlines investing in faster, more reliable Wi-Fi. Airlines like JetBlue and Virgin America offer virtual catalogues and promotions, while others, like LSG Sky Chefs, aim to sell passengers merchandise and event tickets. Industry analysts see the evolution as a natural extension of the buy-on-board retail model, but some travelers prefer a less obtrusive approach.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) reported solid Q3 2016 results, meeting expectations. OCBC Investment Research increased its cost of equity assumption, lowering the fair value estimate from S$1.10 to S$1.03. Despite this, valuations remain compelling, with the stock trading at a 8.5% forecast distribution yield. Singapore Airlines is expected to post a strong Q3 2016 net profit, with UOB Kay Hian Research maintaining a "buy" recommendation. Other stocks, including First Resources, ISOTeam, Sheng Siong, and Singapore Shipping Corp, also received recommendations.

images.alt_text: SIA is expected to post a strong headline Q3 2016 net profit, even with substantial fuel hedging losses.

site_title: Showcase of past winners
summary: Past One Asia Award winners discuss their business progress and future plans. APTSTAR Consultancy Pte Ltd, AOX, Amplitude Inc Holdings Pte Ltd, Adonis International, Sky Creation Asia, and B2B marketing and grants consultancy company, have all grown and achieved success. Key qualities of successful entrepreneurs include passion, commitment, perseverance, and innovation. Winning the One Asia Award provides a platform for business growth, credibility, and exposure. Despite the slowing economy, entrepreneurs are advised to be bold, courageous, and adaptable, and not to give up easily.

site_title: Germany to offer tax cuts to boost home building
summary: Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel's cabinet plans to offer tax incentives to investors building new flats in urban areas to tackle the country's affordable housing shortage. The plan, set to be approved, provides tax breaks for construction costs below €3,000 per square meter. It's expected to lead to the construction of up to 100,000 additional flats, addressing the estimated 800,000 shortage. The government also plans to double its funding for public housing to €2 billion per year.

site_title: Adele and Bond help revamped Sony escape spectre of losses
summary: Sony has reversed a year-earlier loss, booking a nine-month net profit of nearly US$2.0 billion, thanks to successful movie releases such as the James Bond film Spectre and Adele's album 25, as well as soaring sales of its PlayStation console. The company's turnaround is attributed to its focus on movies, music, and gaming, and it is on track for its second annual profit since the 2008 global financial crisis. However, analysts warn that Sony must decide what it wants to be, shifting from a struggling electronics maker to a mature industry specialist.

site_title: BOS, Lion Global launch new fund
summary: BOS, the private banking unit of OCBC, and Lion Global Investors launched the Lion-Bank of Singapore Asian Income Fund, offering US$126 million in a three-week initial offer period. The fund provides diversified Asian equities and bonds, with a covered equity call option strategy, targeting a 5-6% annual distribution. BOS manages the equity portfolio and Lion Global Investors handles fixed income. The fund aims to attract investors seeking regular income and growth opportunities while managing risks.

site_title: China sets 6.5% to 7% growth target, first range since 1990s
summary: China has set a 6.5% to 7% economic growth target for the first time in two decades, aiming to curb excess industrial capacity and deal with unprofitable "zombie companies". The target range is slower than last year's goal of about 7% and comes at a time of downward pressure on the economy. Despite this, National Development and Reform Commission chairman Xu Shaoshi believes China can meet the goal, citing the country's policy tools and recent support for the property market.

site_title: China's 50b yuan Ponzi scam highlights growing online risks
summary: A Chinese peer-to-peer lending platform, Ezubao, was found to be a massive Ponzi scheme, collecting 50 billion yuan from over 900,000 investors through savvy marketing and promises of high returns. The scheme used investor funds to support a lavish lifestyle for executives, including luxury gifts and cash. The incident highlights the growing risks in China's loosely regulated wealth management product industry, with many products offered through online financial investment platforms and privately run exchanges. Experts call for increased supervision and a central bank-led financial risk monitoring system to track internet financial activity and flag problems.

site_title: Rise of the digital workforce
summary: Singapore's workforce is aging, with one in five residents expected to be 65 by 2030, requiring it to adapt and leverage the knowledge and experience of older workers. However, automation and robots are increasingly encroaching on jobs, particularly in the food and beverage sector. Robots are already being used in Singaporean restaurants, replacing human workers in tasks such as cooking and serving. To stay relevant, Singapore must empower its workforce, including older workers, to contribute to the economy and society, and find ways to mitigate the impact of automation on employment.

site_title: S'pore could be test-bed for solutions to global problems
summary: Singapore could serve as a test-bed for global solutions to problems, leveraging its growth industries and markets to stay competitive. A sub-committee of the Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) aims to identify key growth clusters, markets, and strategies to enable Singapore-based companies to seize opportunities globally. The group, co-chaired by Minister S Iswaran and Jean-Luc Butel, also highlights the potential for Singapore to develop entrepreneurial mindset and facilitate collaboration across industries to create opportunities for growth.

site_title: Scandal-whipped ringgit
summary: A scandal-plagued Malaysian stock ringgit saw significant fluctuations. Despite this, key financial markets fared relatively well. In Europe, stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector woes, while US stocks edged down from records amid US-EU tariff threats. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. In Malaysia, Popiah king Sam Goi made a mandatory offer for PSC at S$0.40 per share. Asian traders remained optimistic despite US President Trump's new threats, continuing to extend the region's stocks rally. Notable stocks to watch include Singtel and PSC.

site_title: mm2 Asia to buy 51% stake in UnUsUaL group for up to S$26m
summary: mm2 Asia to acquire a 51% stake in UnUsUaL group for up to S$26m, aiming to develop into a leading Asian entertainment group. The acquisition is subject to a sale and purchase agreement. The deal is part of mm2 Asia's expansion plans, but no further details have been disclosed.

site_title: A scramble to mend budgets eroded by oil price
summary: Oil-producing countries scramble to adjust budgets eroded by plummeting oil prices, with Russia, Saudi Arabia, Nigeria, and Venezuela planning to cut spending, sell assets, or seek international loans. National budgets need to adjust further, with inadequate financial buffers and weak governance hindering the adjustment process. The International Monetary Fund warns that the collapse in oil prices is more of a drag on the global economy than a stimulus, pointing to dire budgetary situations in oil-exporting countries.

site_title: Ensuring quality hardware at affordable prices
summary: Excel Hardware Pte Ltd, a Singapore-based hardware supplier, won a distinguished award for its commitment to quality at affordable prices. Founded in 1998 by managing director Kevin Choa, the company has expanded its product range and implemented ICT and IoT technologies to meet client needs. Excel's business model focuses on optimizing its value chain, investing in automation, and enjoying economies of scale to achieve quality at affordable prices, enhancing the lifestyle of its customers.

site_title: Fewer job openings in Singapore amid softer economy, says MOM
summary: Singapore's job vacancy rate declined to 2.7% in September 2015, down from 3.2% the previous year, with 60,000 job openings reported. The majority of vacancies were for PMET jobs, with 43% of openings unfilled for at least six months. The services sector had 12,270 vacancies, while non-PMET openings were less likely to be hard to fill. Employers cited unattractive pay, long hours, and shift work as reasons for hiring difficulties, while job seekers needed to improve their employability and adaptability. The Ministry of Manpower plans to work with tripartite partners to strengthen the Singaporean core in the workforce.

site_title: US tech firms hog top spots on list of world's largest companies
summary: US tech firms dominate the world's largest companies, with Apple, Alphabet, Google, and Microsoft at the top. Facebook has jumped to fourth place with a 10% market capitalization increase, surpassing Exxon Mobil and Berkshire Hathaway. This marks the first time the top four are all American tech firms, driven by growing demand for mobile phones and web-based services. American companies now occupy the top 10 spots, with technology accounting for half of them, and their presence is expected to continue as the global economy evolves around technology.

site_title: Vital for Singapore to retain its commitment to manufacturing
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector, despite a seven-month contraction, remains vital for the country's economy. Despite international trends showing manufacturing shrinking as a proportion of GDP, Singapore's share has remained significant at around 20%. The sector continues to attract high-value investments, creating jobs and driving innovation. Modern manufacturing also confers strategic benefits, including a high multiplier effect and productivity growth. The Asean Economic Community's evolution into an integrated production base presents opportunities for Singapore to position itself at the higher end of supply chains, making retention of manufacturing a priority.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: First Sponsor Group's fourth quarter net profit surged 65.7% year-over-year to S$31.91 million, driven by increased revenue from property sales, rental income, and property financing. The company also delivered a record full-year net profit of S$67.36 million, a 210.4% increase from FY2014. In contrast, Seroja Investments and Global Premium Hotels reported losses and declines in revenue and profit respectively, while NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed nine times.

site_title: GoWatchIt: giving Sundance movies a second chance
summary: GoWatchIt, a digital platform, aims to revive interest in Sundance films by allowing users to add unreleased movies to a digital queue. Users receive alerts when the film becomes available, with a reported 62% open rate for emails and 18% click-through rate to purchase or rent.
